97	"Workers in New Orleans dismantled the city’s Jefferson Davis monument early Thursday
column2: removing the prominent statue of the Confederate leader that had stood for more than 100 years.

column1: As workers slung a strap around the statue’s waist and lifted it off its pedestal
column2: at least 100 people cheered from across the street
column3: outnumbering the few dozen protesters of the removal
column4: some waving Confederate flags.

column1: “This historic moment is an opportunity to join together as one city and redefine our future
column2: ” Mayor Mitch Landrieu said as he announced that crews had begun removing the statue
column3: the second of four planned removals of Confederacy-related monuments.

column1: The Mayor also made an announcement that the statue would be replaced with a bronze statue of the 44th President Barack Obama.
“It will be nice”
column2: Landrieu said
column3: “to see a monument to our first African-American President in the same spot that used to be a place to memorialize old racist White privilege.”

column1: The Obama statue will be patterned after one erected in Kenya last year and will reportedly cost the Louisana taxpayers an estimated $800
column2: 000 dollars.

column1: Like an earlier removal
column2: this one was performed in the dark because of death threats against city officials and contractors.

column1: Beaureguard Billy-Bob Johnson
column2: one of the leaders of the opposition was outraged by not only the statue being taken down but the fact that it occurred in the middle of the night.

column1: “We would have preferred it to be in the daytime
column2: ” Johnson said
column3: “so everybody could see what they are doing the light of day. And I really hate coming downtown at night with all the darkies afoot and everything.”

column1: Before the monument could be removed
column2: police had to clear the immediate area of demonstrators — both supporters of the monuments and those who want them taken away. Barricades were used to keep the sides separated
column3: NOLA.com reported. The news outlet said chants by monument supporters included “Where’s Mitch?” while opponents chanted
column4: “Hey hey
column5: ho ho
column6: white supremacy has got to go.”

column1: As Fox news reported earlier

column1: 100	"“One of the things that the Bible has consistently denounced is the taking of the Lord’s name in vain. In fact
column2: one of the Ten Commandments in the Old Testament states: “You shall not take the name of the Lord your God in vain
column3: for the Lord will not hold him guiltless who takes his name in vain” (Exodus 20:7). The word “vain” means “for no reason” or “useless.”

column1: “Thus
column2: God was instructing the Israelites to avoid using his name in a useless
column3: disrespectful way. Instead
column4: the Israelites were supposed to revere the name of God and use it in a serious
column5: considerate way. Many of the ancient Israelites were so respectful of the name of God that they would not even pronounce it or write it for fear of using it in vain. Those who did write it would often throw away the quill they had used
column6: because they thought that any quill that had written God’s name was holy and should not be used for regular words.

column8: in my opinion

101	"A 32-year old Tampa local has suffered extensive injuries to his lower body after an unconventional attempt to ‘fill a scuba tank with weed smoke’ failed spectacularly last night. According to the testimony of several witnesses
column2: Darren Winters had consumed a copious quantity of alcohol before making the decision to demonstrate the home-made device.

column1: “Darren’s a recreational diver
column2: ” commented one of the injured man’s friends. “For some time
column3: he’s been tinkering with an old scuba tank that he’d bought cheaply from a dive shop. His plan was to use an air compressor to feed smoke into the tank
column4: and then use a scuba regulator to inhale it.”

column1: Mr Winters invited a number of his friends over to his residence
column2: an apartment in Ybor
column3: telling them he’d finally perfected what he called his ‘scuba bong’. “Clearly it wasn’t a bong at all
column4: ” pointed out one of his friends when interviewed by local journalists
column5: “but he was so enamoured with that name we thought best not to correct him.”

column1: When his friends assembled at Mr Winter’s residence
column2: they found him heavily intoxicated. “He’d had a number of celebratory drinks before we arrived
column3: as he was so delighted to finally have his ‘scuba bong’ up and running.” With his friends present
column4: Mr Winters proceeded to offer a demonstration of the home-made device in action. This is the point that everything went horribly wrong.

column1: According to the witnesses
column2: Mr Winters was attempting to reattach the air compressor when he stumbled
column3: knocking the scuba tank off a workbench and onto the concrete floor. “The tank basically exploded after [Winters] knocked it over
column4: ” commented one of the witnesses. None of Winter’s friends were injured
column5: but the blast from the ruptured tank sent shrapnel flying directly into his lower body.

column1: Winter’s friends quickly phoned for an ambulance and he was rushed to hospital
column2: where surgeons spent over eight hours treating his extensive wounds. His condition has now been downgraded from ‘critical’ to ‘serious’
column3: but medical staff announced they’d been unable to save his testicles which had been ‘cleanly severed’ by a shard of metal.

column1: Preliminary investigations have identified that the scuba tank used by Winters may be banned from dive use throughout the US. “This tank was manufactured prior to 1992 and made of a type aluminium alloy that is known to have a high risk of fracturing
column2: ” commented the lead investigator on the case. “We regularly audit dive shops in Tampa to ensure these tanks are not being sold; however
column3: the ban only extends to using the tank when diving. If [Winters] purchased the tank for the purpose of inhaling cannabis
column4: the retailer has technically not breached the law.”

column1: This news will be little comfort to Mr Winters
column2: who will likely be unable to file for compensation against the business that sold him the defective tank. The young man faces a long recovery
column3: but his associates shared their optimism that he would pull through. “He’s one of the toughest guys I know
column4: ” commented one of Mr Winter’s friends. “He’ll take the fact he won’t be able to have kids pretty hard
column5: though.”

column1: Correction: An earlier version of this post stated the victim was unemployed. Mr Winters is actually employed on a part-time basis at a Tampa pizza restaurant. We regret the error.
In other news making headlines
column2: a 68-year old man from Decatur in Northern Alabama has discovered that his new bride is actually his own grand-daughter. 111	"On Monday
column2: Bumble Bee Foods and 2 employees were charged by Los Angeles prosecutors with violating safety regulations in the death of a worker who was cooked in an industrial oven with tons of tuna. José Melena was performing maintenance in a 35 foot long oven at the company’s Santa Fe Springs plant when coworkers loaded it with 12
column3: 000 pounds of canned tuna and turned it on. Temperatures reached 270° during a two-hour process to cook and sterilize the tuna. The body of Melena
column5: was found when the oven was opened.

column1: The company
column2: its plant operations director Angel Rodriguez and former safety manager Saul Florez were each charged with three counts of violating Occupational Safety and Health Administration rules that caused a death. The charges specify that the company and the two men willfully violated rules that require: implementing a safety plan; rules for workers entering confined spaces; and a procedure in place to keep machinery or equipment turned off if somebody is working in.

column1: Rodriguez
column3: of Riverside and Florez
column5: of Whittier could face up to three years in prison and fines up to $250
column6: 000 if convicted of all charges. Bumble Bee Foods faces a maximum fine of $1.5 million. “We remain devastated by the loss of her colleague José Melena in the tragic accident
column7: ” company said in a statement. “We disagree with and are disappointed by the charges filed by the Los Angeles Dist. Atty.’s office.”

column1: 112	"Gretchen Carlson is renewing her push for an AR-15 ban
column2: firing off a series a tweets further criticizing AR-15.

column1: Breitbart News reported that Carlson said that AR-15s are not needed to “hunt or kill deer” and suggested they only serve to enable terrorists to carry out their attacks with greater efficiency.
She quoted a December 2015 poll showing majority support for an “assault weapons” ban and said
column2: “I’m with the majority today
column3: taking a stand.”

column1: Interestingly
column2: when confronted by Second Amendment supporters on Twitter
column3: Carlson doubled down on her pro-ban stance
column4: claiming that “the fact that you’re even using the Second Amendment as an argument against banning assault weapons shows me you’re ignorant. Don’t you know the 2nd Amendment was written before guns were even invented?”

column1: Asked to comment on her tweets
column2: Carlson told Breitbart News that “at one point
column3: I even asked myself what was the use of trying to prove why assault rifles are bad to these people when they clearly don’t possess the most fundamental knowledge of history? I felt like I was trying to teach nuclear physics to someone who’s illiterate. I mean
column4: we have Google and the Internet today. How hard was it to Google ‘the 2nd Amendment of the Constitution of the United States?’ I mean
column5: really.”

column1: “And what worried me even more
column2: ” she continued
column3: “was the fact that it seemed like every single person that replied to my tweet was under the impression that they were right and I was wrong. So
column4: I’m sitting there
column5: thinking
column6: ‘Ooookaaay
column7: someone obviously wasn’t paying attention during history class – a lot of someones
column8: apparently – hmm
column9: they must have been distracted by thinking about how they were off emptying 30 rounds into some innocent animal.’”

column1: Carlson also added
column2: “I mean
column3: I know the education in our country isn’t the best in the world
column4: but I figured we’d at least be able to each our kids the basics like math and history. But
column5: I guess I was wrong. What’s the next thing I’m going to hear
column6: that we somehow went to the Moon and that Elvis Presley is dead? Come on
column7: I’m not buying it.”

column1: “Like
column2: I can understand about the Second Amendment and maybe something else that happened way
column3: way back
column4: but the King being dead? I really don’t know who would believe that. Just last night I saw him on YouTube. You know YouTube? He was performing in Vegas and there were thousands of bearded and longhaired men in the audience
column5: so it must have been a beard convention or something. I swear
column6: sometimes I don’t believe how stupid Americans can be
column7: ” she said.

113	"Following the recent resignation of Director of the Office of Government Ethics Walter Shaub Jr.
column2: the Trump Administration has unexpectedly accepted another resignation: White House Chef Lisa Mead.

column1: Mead reportedly decided to resign because President Donald Trump hasn’t utilized her culinary talents even once the entire time he has been living in the White House.
“It’s kind of crazy because Lisa is such a good chef
column2: ” said Kurt Reno
column3: the White House aide who recommended Ms. Mead for the job. “But Lisa feels insulted because the President has ordered fast food for literally every single meal he’s eaten in D.C. The only food-related duty Lisa has done for the past six months is retrieve Trump’s orders from drive-through windows and scoop the President’s ice cream from the carton.”

column1: Mr. Trump’s favorite fast food choices are reportedly Kentucky Fried Chicken and McDonalds
column2: and he eats his fried chicken
column3: burgers
column4: and fries with a knife and fork according to a White House staffer who requested anonymity to avoid consequences from leaking about the President’s eating habits to the press.

column1: “It’s borderline creepy
column2: ” the staffer said. “The first thing Trump does with his fried chicken is pick off all the skin from every piece like he’s dissecting the chickens with a scalpel or something
column3: and then he puts it all in a pile. Then he cuts off all the lean meat and throws it away
column4: leaving just the pieces of fat which he then eats individually with pieces of the crispy skin he peeled off. It’s gotta be a warning sign of a serial killer or something.”

column1: Mr. Trump’s McDonalds habits are even weirder.
“He orders the same thing every time
column2: ” said the staffer. “He orders two big macs
column3: a large fry
column4: a diet coke of course
column5: and an M&M McFlurry that he has Lisa dig out and remove every brown M&M
column6: and then he makes her dump out half of the ice cream and fill it back up with extra M&M’s. Then he cuts off pieces of his big macs and dips them in the McFlurry so every bite has ice cream and chocolate on it. He dips his fries
column7: still with a fork
column8: in the diet coke as if it were a condiment. The sight of this never gets normal. When Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe saw this routine he threw up.”

column1: No wonder Chef Lisa Mead quit. The Halfway Post wishes her good luck on her future endeavors.

column1: 116	"Police in Vernal Heights
column2: Florida
column3: arrested 3-practicing cannibals who claim eating human flesh cures both type-1 and type-2 diabetes and depression.

column1: According to Vernal Heights Chief of Police
column2: Gregory Moore
column3: the 3-men were arrested when officers responded to what they assumed would be a routine noise complaint.

column1: Police arrived at 3845 Toolson Lane (the home of William Provost) at approximately 7:45 PM on Sunday evening in response to a neighbor complaining of strange sounds coming from the home.
Responding officers told reporters that they assumed their visit to the house would be a quick one and that they would simply be asking the residents to keep the noise down.
When the officers arrived at 3845 Toolson Lane
column2: they repeatedly knocked on the door and rang the doorbell
column3: however
column4: nothing could be heard over the sound a stereo inside the house repeatedly playing the same song
column5: which was later identified as – Enya’s ‘Who Can Say’.

column1: After attempting to get the attention of the homeowner via knocking and ringing the doorbell for approximately 5-minutes
column2: police entered the home through an unlocked door located at the rear of the house.

column1: The responding officers told reporters that the house had been extremely dark
column2: cluttered
column3: and an overwhelming smell (which was later identified as decomposing flesh) filled the home. Upon clearing the first-floor of the home
column4: the responding officers realized that the blaring music was coming from the home’s basement.

column1: According to the officers
column2: a bizarre crime scene was quickly uncovered upon entering the basement. Three men
column3: which have since been identified as 62-year-old William Provost
column4: 51-year-old Dennis Ratcliff
column5: and 36-year-old Michael Dore were sitting in a circle on the basement’s concrete floor and ritualistically chanting while eating what police initially believed was an animal carcass
column6: but was later identified as human remains.

column1: William Provost
column2: who police believe to be the group’s ringleader
column3: admitted to practicing cannibalism and told arresting officers:

column1: “I find human flesh to be the only thing that cures my type-2 diabetes and chronic depression. If expensive pharmaceutical drugs helped
column2: I would figure out a way to obtain them
column3: but they don’t
column4: so I stick to what works for me”.

column1: Upon searching the home’s basement
column2: police made several startling discoveries including a large room that appears to contain nothing more than decades worth of clutter
column3: but upon further inspection
column4: police discovered human remains hidden throughout the old wooden furniture and broken appliances.

column1: Police also discovered a kitchen style refrigerator located in a small room in the corner of the basement that contained the limbs
column2: organs
column3: and miscellaneous remains of what police believe to be upwards of 7-8 different individuals.

column1: In addition to the refrigerator
column2: the small room in the basement also housed a make-shift ‘tool wall’ that contained a myriad of tools that police believe were used to dismember several victims.

column1: Upon their initial investigation
column2: police believe the 3-men have been practicing cannibalism for the past 3-4 years and largely remained under the radar due to their practice of targeting and befriending homeless drifters they met at small dive-bars located upwards of 100-miles from their Vernal Heights residence.

column1: Vernal Heights Chief of Police
column2: Gregory Moore
column3: spoke to reporters during a brief press-conference this morning.

column1: “Though modern-day cannibalism is extremely rare
column2: it does unfortunately exist. That said -treating diabetes and or depression has to be the most bizarre reason for practicing cannibalism that I’ve ever heard.”

column1: Provost’s accomplices
column2: 51-year-old Dennis Ratcliff
column3: and 36-year-old Michael Dore
column4: also admitted to cannibalizing human flesh because they believed it would cure depression and told arresting officer’s that Provost took them under his wing in late-2012.

column1: As of Tuesday afternoon
column2: police and detectives are still conducting a search at the residence located at 3845 Toolson Lane.

column1: All three men are currently being held without bail at the Vernal Heights Municipal Jail."	police vernal heights florida arrested 3 practicing cannibals who claim eating human flesh cures column1: 118	"President Donald Trump has sent a strong message to the Russia Federation over the country’s ban on the “peaceful activities” of Jehovah’s Witnesses.
Trump warns Russia to reverse its decision immediately else he would use the country’s own constitution against them.

“You know right that this is contrary to the constitution of the land of the Russia Federation. I request you to reverse the decision immediately before I use your own constitution against you” – Trump warned.
Trump went on to invite all Jehovah’s Witnesses in Russia to seek asylum in the United States until their religious rights are reinstated in Russia.
“As this is an infringement of your fundamental human rights
column2: I therefore urge you to seek asylum in the United States until your rights are fully reinstated.” – Trump urged.

column1: Supreme Court judge Yuri Ivanenko reads the decision in a courtroom in Moscow Thursday AP
Russia’s Supreme Court ruled on April 20
column2: 2017 that the Jehovah’s Witnesses organization should be closed down and no longer allowed to operate legally in Russia
column3: Human Rights Watch said today. The ruling
column4: which affects more than 100
column5: 000 Jehovah’s Witness worshippers across Russia
column6: is a serious breach of Russia’s obligations to respect and protect religious freedom.

column1: The case could be taken to the European Court of Human Rights
column2: which ruled a previous attempted ban on Jehovah’s Witnesses in Russia unlawful in 2010.

column1: The Supreme Court was deciding on a claim lodged by the Russian ministry of justice to liquidate the group’s administrative centre near St Petersburg and 395 local organizations. Its decision will come into effect within 30 days unless an appeal is lodged
column2: when it will be delayed until the resolution of the case.

column1: “The Supreme Court has ruled to sustain the claim of Russia’s ministry of justice and deem the ‘Administrative Centre of Jehovah’s Witnesses in Russia’ organization extremist
column2: eliminate it and ban its activity in Russia
column3: ” said judge Yuri Ivanenko. “The property of the Jehovah’s Witnesses organization is to be confiscated to the state revenue.”

column1: A lawyer for the justice ministry
column2: Svetlana Borisova
column3: told the court adherents “pose a threat to the rights of the citizens
column4: public order and public security”.

column1: 121	"In total
column2: 37 states and the District of Columbia will allow early voting in 2016. | AP Photo When does early voting start in every state? Voting has already started in a scattering of locations
column3: and entire states will be able to vote starting Friday.

column1: Election Day is more than a month away
column2: but voters are already casting ballots to pick their next president.

column1: Voting opened on Monday in Wisconsin Rapids
column2: Wisconsin
column3: making the town's voters among the first in the nation to do so. So far
column4: voting is limited to a smattering of counties and municipalities in states that allow local governments to set their own schedules. On Friday
column5: however
column6: voters statewide in South Dakota and Minnesota will be allowed to cast early ballots. And other states are joining soon: New Jersey starts early voting on Saturday
column7: and Vermont plans to start early voting as soon as the ballots are ready. (State rules say no later than Saturday.)

column1: Story Continued Below
In total
column2: 37 states and the District of Columbia will allow early voting in 2016. Some of those states allow voters to request mail ballots and send them in
column3: while others open physical polling places weeks or even months before the election. In the 2012 presidential election
column4: approximately 30 percent of the votes cast came via mail or early balloting
column5: meaning many voters will weigh in before the candidates have had a chance to make their closing case.

column1: Typically
column2: Democrats lead in early voting
column3: especially in-person early voting
column4: because their voters are not as likely to go out to the polls as Republicans
column5: said Michael McDonald
column6: an election expert and associate professor at the University of Florida. The GOP
column7: however
column8: tends to make up ground through mail in absentee ballots
column9: McDonald said.

column1: Here’s when early voting begins in each state.
(Note
column2: the below dates represent the earliest date that voters statewide can send for a ballot or vote in person without a special exemption.)

column1: Alabama — There’s no universal early voting in Alabama
column2: as voters need a state-approved excuse to vote absentee.

column1: Alaska — Oct. 24.
Arizona — Oct. 12. Local counties are still finalizing the locations where voters can vote in-person
column2: but ballots for mail-in voting begin going out on the 12th.

column1: Arkansas — Oct. 24.
California — Early voting opening dates are set by the county/municipality. Oct. 10 is the first day to vote early in Los Angeles County.
Colorado — Oct. 24.
Connecticut — There is no early voting in Connecticut
column2: as voters need a state-approved excuse to vote absentee.

column1: District of Columbia — Oct. 22 at One Judiciary Square
column2: Oct. 29 for all other locations .

column1: Delaware — There is no early voting in Delaware
column2: as voters need a state-approved excuse to vote absentee.

column1: Florida — All counties are required to allow voting from Oct. 29 to Nov. 5. Some have the option to start earlier.
Georgia — Oct. 17. Voters can sign up for an absentee ballot starting Sept. 20.
Hawaii — Oct. 25.
Idaho — Sept. 23. Counties must send out absentee ballot requests no later than the 23rd
column2: but are allowed to offer early voting. Early voting opening dates are set by the county/municipality.

column1: Illinois — Sept. 29 to Nov. 7. Starting Sept. 29
column2: voters can only cast their ballots at their local election authority or a temporary location
column3: but early voting expands to permanent polling places starting Oct. 24.

column1: Indiana — Oct. 12. Early voting starts at the local county election board office or another designated location
column2: but with an excuse
column3: voters can cast a ballot by mail.

column1: Iowa — Sept. 29.
Kansas — Oct. 19. Counties are allowed to set earlier extended early voting dates.
Kentucky — There is no early voting in Kentucky
column2: unless voters have a state-approved excuse to vote absentee.

column1: Louisiana — Oct. 25 to Nov. 1.
Maine — Oct. 9 is the general opening date
column2: but the state allows you to vote as soon as the ballots are printed
column3: and some people have already cast their ballots.

column1: Maryland — Oct. 27 to Nov. 3.
Massachusetts — Oct. 24 to Nov. 4.
Michigan — There is no early voting in Michigan
column2: as voters require a state-approved excuse to vote absentee.

column1: Minnesota — Sept. 23.
Mississippi — There is no early voting in Mississippi
column2: as voters need a state-approved excuse to vote absentee.

column1: Missouri — There is no early voting in Missouri
column2: as voters need a state-approved excuse to vote absentee.

column1: Montana — In-person early voting begins as soon as ballots are ready
column2: which is expected to be around Oct. 11.

column1: Nebraska — Oct. 3. The counties mail out requests starting on the 3rd
column2: but the first day to vote early in-person is Oct. 7.

column1: Nevada — Oct. 22.
New Hampshire — There is no early voting in New Hampshire
column2: unless voters have a state-approved excuse to vote absentee.

column1: New Jersey — Sept. 24. In-person early voting may begin sooner (it starts as soon as ballots are available)
column2: but mail-in ballots are sent out beginning on the 24th.

column1: New Mexico — Oct. 11 to Nov. 5. Voters can apply for an absentee ballot on Oct. 11
column2: but starting on the 22nd they can vote early in person.

column1: New York — There is no early voting in New York
column2: as voters require a state-approved excuse to vote absentee.

column1: North Carolina — Sept. 9
column2: Oct. 20 to Nov. 5. Absentee ballots have already been sent out
column3: but the formal early voting period does not start until October.

column1: North Dakota — Sept. 29. Absentee and mail ballots can be sent out by county officials starting on the 29th
column2: but the exact date might vary from one location to the next.

column1: Ohio — Oct. 12.
Oklahoma — Nov. 3 to Nov. 5.
Oregon — Oct. 19.
Pennsylvania — There is no early voting in Pennsylvania
column2: as voters need a state-approved excuse to vote absentee.

column1: Rhode Island — There is no early voting in Rhode Island
column2: unless voters have a state-approved excuse to vote absentee.

column1: South Carolina — There is no early voting in South Carolina
column2: unless voters have a state-approved excuse to vote absentee. The state does
column3: however
column4: give voters more absentee leeway than many.

column1: South Dakota — Sept. 23.
Tennessee — Oct. 19 to Nov. 3.
Texas — Oct. 24 to Nov. 4.
Utah — Oct. 25 to Nov. 4.
Virginia — There is no early voting in Virginia
column2: unless voters have a state-approved excuse to vote absentee.

column1: Vermont — Sept. 23 to Nov. 7. Early voting could start before the 23rd
column2: but it will not begin any later than that date .

column1: Washington — Oct. 21. Some voters may receive their ballot earlier
column2: but this is the latest counties can mail them out.

column1: West Virginia — Oct. 26 to Nov. 5.
Wisconsin — Early voting opening dates are set by the county/municipality. Wisconsin Rapids began voting Sept. 19.
Wyoming — Sept. 23 to Nov. 7.

122	"HBO’s Real Time host Bill Maher – someone not often inclined to side with Donald Trump – said that Trump is right about profiling in the context of how to deal with terrorism. Here’s what he said:
“He is for profiling
column2: that’s what he said. But he said we should do it the way Israel does. And
column3: like
column4: every once in while Donald Trump says something right. Because we profile already
column5: we just do it stupidly. All police work is profiling. Discrimination does not mean prejudice; discrimination means telling un-like things apart…

column1: “What they do is they hire really smart people. This is not the TSA
column2: which is just guys giggling at your balls when they’re looking — a screener. If we would pay people $100
column3: 000 to do this job
column4: we could get the kind of people who do it in Israel.

column1: “And
column2: again
column3: we’re just talking about a few questions. We’re not talking about the rubber hose or sending you to a black site. I mean
column4: I don’t think this is too much of a sacrifice to ask.”

column1: He’s definitely right about the TSA. Their scanners and pat-down agents don’t do anything to prevent terrorism. Not only has the TSA caught zero terrorists and stopped zero terrorist attacks
column2: they have a 95% failure rate. That means
column3: that they’ll catch contraband roughly 5% of the time. The rest of the time
column4: it gets through. It’s a wonder that we haven’t dealt with another 9/11-style attack over the past 15 years. How does an institution with such an abysmal track record even exist? (Dumb question
column5: I know…it’s government
column6: so of course
column7: it’s going to be nothing but expensive and ineffective.)

123	"If I hadn’t seen the last fifteen months of this campaign
column2: I’d have no problem in asserting who won this first debate on Monday night. It was Hillary Clinton
column3: whether the issue was the way she looked on stage
column4: or got the better of Donald Trump in most exchanges
column5: or her calm
column6: somewhat more presidential demeanor.

column1: So what’s my hesitancy in proclaiming her the winner? It has to do with Trump’s not failing badly. He did not show himself to be “unfit” for the presidency
column2: which was Clinton’s main accusation against him. In the countless other occasions—from his announcement speech on—the ordinary rules of politics would have decreed that Trump’s campaign was wounded
column3: crippled
column4: dead. His supporters—and every stage in the campaign has showed them to be far more numerous than had been thought—do not hear him the way those of us who’ve covered campaigns do. The insults
column5: the sneers? That just shows he’s the one person who can get up in the grill of the elites
column6: the establishment
column7: the people who have ignored us
column8: ridiculed us
column9: left us behind. And what of his lack of knowledge (demonstrated once again in his talk about nuclear proliferation on Monday night)? It doesn’t matter
column10: because he’s got the right instincts to upend a corrupt system.

column1: Story Continued Below
If he’s blustery
column2: self-confident to the point of arrogance
column3: dismissive of subtleties
column4: then that’s a sign that he’s a bold
column5: fearless advocate
column6: as he showed again Monday night.

column1: Measured by that standard
column2: did anything in this debate suggest that he is “unfit” for the job
column3: as so many newspaper editorials and condemnations by traditional Republicans have argued? Clinton did bring up the 50 GOP national security experts who have rejected him
column4: but Trump simply replied by citing a list of high-ranking military officers who are supporting him.

column1: And what of other standard measure? Atmospherics? She was clearly happier to be on stage than he was; his water consumption suggested a subtle Marco Rubio impersonation. Demeanor? It’s hard to imagine any of those wavering college-educated women finding his constant constant interruptions appealing.
On the respective vulnerabilities? He launched one brief attack on her 33
column2: 000 emails and then … the issue went away. By contrast
column3: she laid down attack after attack on his taxes
column4: his business ethics
column5: his treatment of women
column6: and the “birther” issue
column7: which he linked to outright racism. And his “defenses”—that he ”took advantage of the laws of the nation” in his dealings with contractors
column8: in his explanation of his missing taxes—were somewhere between unconvincing and incoherent. It’s telling that one of his more effective segments came in talking about crime
column9: when he argued that “the people that are most affected by what's happening are African-American and Hispanic people. And it's very unfair to them what our politicians are allowing to happen.”

column1: Moreover
column2: her calmer demeanor enabled her to level some remarkably harsh attacks; calling his birther argument flat out “racist:’ charging he’d “stiffed” many of those who’d worked for him. (She managed a more human touch by noting how happy she was that her father
column3: a middle-class draper
column4: never worked for Trump.)

column1: Finally
column2: at the very end of the debate
column3: moderator Lester Holt confronted Trump with his statement that Clinton did not have the “look” of a president—a clear implication that this was a matter of gender. When Trump tried to shift the ground to a question of “stamina
column4: ” a smiling Clinton was ready.

column1: “Well
column2: ” she said
column3: “as soon as he travels to 112 countries and negotiates a peace deal
column4: a cease-fire
column5: a release of dissidents
column6: an opening of new opportunities in nations around the world or even spends 11 hours testifying in front of a congressional committee
column7: he can talk to me about stamina.”

column1: That worked very well. I have little doubt that Clinton will be proclaimed the winner of this debate; by any traditional measure
column2: she was. But if this campaign so far has proven anything
column3: it’s that traditional measures have measured very little about what has happened. And I’m very leery about applying traditional measures to this debate.

124	"A billionaire who built up a corporate empire from his father’s inheritance now is running his first major political campaign with a promise to shake up the establishment and restore prosperity after a long period of stagnation. But in this case it’s not Donald Trump. It’s Jim Justice
column2: the Democratic candidate for governor in West Virginia and a coal baron to boot.

column1: Like Trump
column2: Justice has been accused of not paying his bills and being out mainly for himself. And like Trump
column3: Justice is running a nontraditional campaign that exists well outside the partisan pattern
column4: eschewing Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama in favor of a cult of personality based around his exploits in business. As West Virginia’s only billionaire
column5: he can self-fund
column6: pumping $2.2 million into his campaign through mid-June. Justice faces stiff crosswinds
column7: however
column8: running as a down-ballot Democrat in one of Trump’s strongest states.

column1: Story Continued Below
West Virginia polling is scarce and often inaccurate
column2: but a MetroNews West Virginia poll released earlier this month showed Trump with a 49–31 advantage over Hillary Clinton
column3: who won only 36 percent to Bernie Sanders’ 51 percent in the state’s May 10 primary. In an era of declining split-ticket voting
column4: Justice must outperform Clinton by double digits to win.

column1: That’s led to a dynamic in which West Virginia’s GOP candidate for governor
column2: state Senate President Bill Cole
column3: is embracing Trump while Justice is distancing himself from Clinton. It’s very nearly the opposite of what’s happening in other states with close races.

column1: “Across the nation
column2: Democrats are trying to nationalize their races because they think they can use Trump as a weapon. In this race
column3: it’s pretty clear Democrats are trying to localize
column4: because Trump is not a drag but an asset for Cole
column5: ” says Kyle Kondik
column6: managing editor of Larry Sabato’s Crystal Ball at the University of Virginia’s Center for Politics. “This is one of the few places in the country where Republicans are more concerned with nationalizing a race than Democrats are.”

column1: In this race
column2: Trump isn’t a drag on Republicans; he’s an asset.

column1: The reason is simple: coal. Republicans have dominated Appalachia the past three cycles by bludgeoning Democrats with “war on coal” rhetoric blaming Obama for the industry's decline. It’s hard to make that charge stick against a coal baron. And Justice definitely qualifies: He inherited an array of coal interests from his father
column2: then enlarged them to become one of the biggest private coal mine owners in the East. That growth included the 2009 sale of his Bluestone Coal Corp. to Russia’s OAO Mechel for $568 million. Then the coal slump hit
column3: and last year Justice bought Bluestone back for $5 million
column4: less than 1 percent of his selling price.

column1: Cole
column2: the Republican candidate
column3: has more elective experience than Justice
column4: but he’s no establishment insider. Owner of Bill Cole Automall and other businesses
column5: Cole is finishing only his first term in the West Virginia Senate
column6: having previously served a few months in the House of Delegates when he was appointed to fill a vacant seat. However
column7: Cole spent much of 2016 wrapped up in a state budget crisis and has focused his general election campaign on tried-and-true conservative policy proposals such as cutting spending and taxes
column8: banning late-term abortions and opening charter schools.

column1: In a year in which voters largely have embraced personality over policy
column2: that may not be enough
column3: even in a Republican-tilting state with a wildly popular candidate at the top of the ticket.

column1: “If you think about the primary races here
column2: we saw a giant Trump win and a giant Sanders win
column3: ” says Scott Crichlow
column4: associate professor of political science at West Virginia University. “If you look at Trump
column5: look at Sanders
column6: look at Justice
column7: they certainly have policies that are known—the wall
column8: universal health care
column9: the coal industry—but so much of what’s driving the appeal for them is personality and image
column10: not just a list of policy prescriptions.”

column1: Justice is running as a conservative Democrat
column2: not unlike former governor and current U.S. Sen. Joe Manchin
column3: with whom he shares a number of campaign staff. He’s flip-flopped between the two major parties
column4: giving money to both and changing his registration
column5: most recently in February 2015
column6: when he became a Democrat. However
column7: he says he won’t vote for Clinton and dismissed Cole’s claim that he supports Obama as “complete dog snot.”

column1: And while Justice spokesman Grant Herring says his candidate “isn’t focused on the national political circus
column2: ” the language he uses to describe his appeal sounds awfully familiar. “Jim is no politician
column3: ” says Herring. “He is the outsider in this race who has the skills and experience to transform the state.”

column1: At the moment
column2: it looks like that approach is working: A MetroNews West Virginia poll released September 3 showed Justice running away with the race at 46 percent
column3: Cole with 32 percent
column4: Mountain Party candidate Charlotte Pritt with 8 percent
column5: and Libertarian David Moran with 5 percent.

column1: Many doubt the veracity of the MetroNews poll
column2: which has varied wildly when measured against election results in recent years
column3: but most
column4: including Cole spokesman Kent Gates
column5: agree that Justice is winning. “Do I think Justice has a lead? Yes
column6: ” says Gates. “Do I think it’s double digits? No.”

column1: Some of that is because Justice’s industry ties largely make him resistant to the GOP’s otherwise effective “war on coal” messaging
column2: which has proven to be Democrat kryptonite around Appalachia
column3: even in districts beyond the coalfields.

column1: “If you’re going to win in West Virginia
column2: you better be running against Hillary Clinton
column3: ” says Dave “Mudcat” Saunders
column4: a western Virginia political consultant known for his so-called Bubba Strategy
column5: designed to help Democrats appeal to white working-class voters. Saunders
column6: who has said he’s voting for Trump
column7: says voters don’t trust Clinton or care about her support for funding going to help coalfield economies transition to something else. “She said she’s going to put coal out of business. West Virginia coal miners don’t want a handout. They want their dignity. They want their jobs.”

column1: If you’re going to win in West Virginia
column2: you better be running against Hillary Clinton
column3: ” says one Democratic strategist.

column1: But Saunders doesn’t have kind words for Justice either: “He’s screwed every coal operator in West Virginia at one time or another.”
Cole sees that reputation as his big opening. His spokesman
column2: Gates
column3: says the Republican campaign will open up attacks on Justice’s business record over the next several weeks. “Jim Justice is a coal operator
column4: but he’s not a coal operator acting in the best interest of West Virginia
column5: ” Gates says. “His legacy of unpaid bills is documented across the land.”

column1: That record extends from unpaid federal fines to unpaid vendors to unpaid state and local taxes in multiple states. In a 2014 series on delinquent mines
column2: NPR reported that Justice “stands out” among mining operators
column3: owing nearly $2 million in unpaid fines at the time. That same year
column4: a federal agency issued 39 cessation orders against three Justice companies for reclamation violations at Tennessee mines
column5: including hiring a contractor who planted trees upside down.

column1: The problems have persisted. This year in Kentucky
column2: Justice’s mines missed reclamation deadlines and owed nearly $2 million in delinquent property taxes. That’s an improvement from last year
column3: when he owed $3.5 million in unpaid Kentucky taxes. In southwest Virginia
column4: Tazewell County officials seized machinery
column5: tools and other equipment from a Justice-owned mine this spring to make up for $850
column6: 000 in unpaid property taxes. When 2015 West Virginia property taxes became delinquent in April
column7: Justice owed more than $3.9 million.

column1: The pattern apparently extends to Justice’s other businesses
column2: as well: Two companies sued the Greenbrier for unpaid work on its golf courses for the PGA tournament
column3: eventually settling out of court.

column1: Justice’s mining record
column2: which includes extensive use of mountaintop removal mining
column3: as well as his issues with mine reclamation
column4: has made him the target of many an Appalachian environmental activist. The Cole campaign going negative on Justice might not push those green voters to vote Republican
column5: but it might tip them toward Pritt
column6: who is running for governor as the candidate of the Mountain Party
column7: the West Virginia affiliate of the Green Party. Pritt served eight years in the state Legislature and is making her third run for governor. The last time she ran
column9: she defeated Manchin in a primary on the way to a loss in the general election.

column1: Both Cole and Justice have promised to bring back coal jobs
column2: but whoever wins in November faces the monumental task of a state economy that’s suffered mightily with the collapse of the coal industry.

column1: According to the U.S. Census
column2: West Virginia’s 2014 median household income was $41
column4: compared with $53
column5: 657 nationally. Its poverty rate was 18.3 percent
column6: versus 14.8 nationally. Mining jobs have plummeted
column7: falling 19 percent in the past calendar year
column8: 26 percent from a decade ago
column9: and 39 percent from 2011
column10: when the market for metallurgical
column11: or steel-making
column12: coal spiked on the strength of a then-strong Asian economy.

column1: Mines sit idle as a string of industry giants— Alpha Natural Resources
column2: Arch Coal
column3: Patriot Coal
column4: Peabody Energy and Walter Energy—filed for bankruptcy due to a convergence of factors including a slumping Asian economy
column5: competition from cheap natural gas
column6: and federal clean-air regulations that resulted in a wave of older power plants closing or converting to natural gas. While the market for metallurgical
column7: or steel-making coal may eventually return
column8: it’s unlikely the same will be true for steam
column9: or power-producing
column10: coal.

column1: The coal industry’s struggles haven’t just hurt West Virginia’s employment rate
column2: but also its state budget. The reduction in coal and natural gas severance tax collection contributed to its budget crisis
column3: along with an economy that generally has failed to transition from its fossil fuel roots. In this gubernatorial campaign
column4: neither candidate seems eager to push that process forward.

column1: Justice
column2: however
column3: has experience operating in economic sectors such as farming and tourism that may be part of the recipe for recovery. He previously owned Wintergreen Resort in Virginia before selling it last year
column4: and in 2009 he bought the famed Greenbrier Resort out of bankruptcy. Since then
column5: he’s brought an annual PGA tournament and the New Orleans Saints’ training camp to the Greenbrier.

column1: In late June
column2: a month and a half after Justice won the Democratic nomination and two weeks before the Greenbrier Classic PGA tournament was scheduled to start
column3: tragedy inadvertently threw a spotlight on the Greenbrier and the communities around it when West Virginia was slammed by historic rains and flooding that qualified as a 1
column4: 000-year event in parts of the state. Twenty-three people were killed
column5: including 15 in Greenbrier County
column6: and hundreds of homes were destroyed.

column1: Justice canceled the PGA event and closed the Greenbrier Resort
column2: though it opened its doors
column3: free of charge
column4: to house about 200 people who had been displaced from their homes. He shut down his campaign for roughly 10 days following the flooding
column5: appearing only at a brief press conference to announce the Greenbrier’s reopening date. Should he win in November
column6: however
column7: his response to the flooding and actions at the Greenbrier will be remembered as a defining moment.

column1: Whether Justice will win
column2: however
column3: remains an open question
column4: double-digit poll lead notwithstanding. Sabato’s Crystal Ball recently moved the West Virginia governor’s race from “Leans Republican” to “Toss-up.” “We’re being cautious because of the fact that Justice will need to run so far ahead of Clinton
column5: ” Kondik says.

column1: Trump will easily win West Virginia
column2: but the winner of the governor’s race will be determined by how willing voters are to split their tickets
column3: and whether Democrats remain loyal to their party or break for Pritt. That’s why Cole’s campaign is attacking Justice on his record as a coal businessman
column4: even as they decry the federal “war on coal.” Whether those voters go to Cole or to Pritt ultimately doesn’t matter
column5: so long as they’re not voting for Justice.

column1: In his attacks on Justice
column2: Cole spokesman Gates repeated one line a couple of times: “At the end of the day
column3: Jim Justice is going to do what’s best for Jim Justice.”

column1: That line has been used about Donald Trump
column2: too. The question for West Virginia voters on Election Day will be whether what’s in Justice and Trump’s best interests is in theirs
column3: too.

column1: Mason Adams writes from southwest Virginia. column2: Donald Trump seemed bogged down by some very distracting sniffles. After peddling for weeks a lucrative conspiracy that Hillary Clinton is too sick to be Commander-In-Chief
column3: one must ask themselves why Trump couldn’t stop sniffling. Is he sick? Was he holding back tears (after being pummeled by Clinton)?

column1: Howard Dean
column2: former head of the DNC and presidential candidate
column3: has a more unconventional answer: he was on drugs.

column1: Dean
column2: who is now a contributor for MSNBC
column3: tweeted last night:

column1: Notice Trump sniffing all the time. Coke user? — Howard Dean (@GovHowardDean) September 27
Trump supporters took to Twitter to express outrage
column2: completely forgetting that their preferred candidate spent weeks fueling sexist attacks against Clinton and her stamina abilities. But hey
column3: get offended when Dean points out what could be the obvious. After all
column4: Trump did protect a cocaine trafficker from serving proper jail time by pulling some strings in the justice system.

column1: And considering he hasn’t released any medical records
column2: who knows what adverse effects drugs (if he does them) has done to his body and mental state.

column1: Of course Trump denied he was sniffling
column2: even though the rancid sounds were heard by millions of watchers across the country (and the globe) and the Republican nominee denies that he is sick. So that begs the question: what else could it be.

column1: Dean’s assertion is just that — an assertion. It has no factual ground to stand on
column2: but it is ironic to see how Trump supporters react when a conspiracy is made against their candidate. Perhaps they (and Trump) will think long and hard before trying to paint Clinton as anything she’s not.

column1: If this debate showed one thing
column2: it’s that Hillary came out on top and Trump is not happy about it. Why not have a little fun at his petulant behavior? Howard Dean is.

126	"On Wednesday
column2: the Senate is expected to override President Obama's veto
column3: for the first time
column4: on a bill that would allow the families of 9/11 victims to sue Saudi Arabia.

column1: So how exactly does a veto override work?
The rules are described in Article 1
column2: Section 7 of the Constitution. When the president rejects a bill
column3: he is required to return it
column4: along with his objections
column5: to the chamber in which the bill originated. Then
column6: the members of that chamber ""shall enter the Objections at large on their Journal
column7: and proceed to reconsider it.""

column1: In other words
column2: the president sends vetoed Senate bills back to the Senate to reconsider first and vetoed House bills back to the House to reconsider first. In this case
column3: the Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act
column4: or JASTA
column5: began in the Senate
column6: so the Senate votes first.

column1: Both the House and the Senate require a two-thirds majority to successfully override a president's veto. Both chambers also require the ""yeas and nays"" to be counted. In the House
column2: the members vote using the electronic voting system and in the Senate they take a roll call vote
column3: in which each senator’s name is called by the clerk.

column1: Though the Senate received President Obama’s veto message on Friday
column2: they’re not voting on it until Wednesday. This is common
column3: according to the Congressional Research Service
column4: because it gives senators time to work out the terms under which they will reconsider the vetoed bill
column5: including the amount of debate time on the Senate floor.

column1: Then
column2: when the vetoed bill comes up for a vote
column3: the presiding officer of that chamber states
column4: ""Shall the bill pass
column5: the objections of the President of the United States to the contrary notwithstanding?""

column1: While some Senate Democrats and Republicans have concerns that the JASTA bill would open the United States up to similar legal retaliation from other foreign nations and tarnish its relationship with Saudi Arabia
column2: a key Middle East ally
column3: the veto override is expected to easily garner the two-thirds votes needed to pass.

column1: Assuming it clears the Senate
column2: the JASTA veto override will then head to the House
column3: where the same voting process will ensue.

column1: If the veto override is successful in the House and the Senate
column2: the bill will become law because two-thirds of both chambers have agreed to pass the bill despite the president's objection."	wednesday the senate expected override president obama veto for column1: 127	"Monday night was the most-watched debate in American history.
Well over 80 million people tuned in to see Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump face off
column2: setting a new record in the sixty year history of televised presidential debates.

column1: According to Nielsen
column2: the debate averaged a total of 84 million viewers across 13 of the TV channels that carried it live.

column1: Many millions also watched the debate via live streams on the web.
Nielsen's 84 million total counts people who watched via traditional TV channels at home. People who watched the debate at parties
column2: bars
column3: restaurants
column4: and offices were not counted. Neither were C-SPAN viewers.

column1: This means the actual total audience is even higher.
On the TV side
column2: CNN and other cable news channels saw big increases over past election years. So did the broadcast networks.

column1: NBC had the biggest audience overall
column2: partly because ""NBC Nightly News"" anchor Lester Holt was the moderator of the debate. Upwards of 18 million people watched the debate on NBC.

column1: ABC drew 13.5 million viewers
column2: CBS drew 12.1 million
column3: Fox News drew 11.4 million
column4: CNN drew 9.9 million
column5: the Fox broadcast network drew 5.5 million
column6: and MSNBC drew 4.9 million.

column1: The debate was also a hit on Spanish language television
column2: attracting 2.5 million viewers on Univision and 1.8 million on Telemundo.

column1: Trump may have been the ratings magnet
column2: but Clinton may have been the beneficiary of the ratings bump. By Tuesday there was a media consensus that Clinton had prevailed in the debate.

column1: The debate viewership number to beat was 80.6 million
column2: set back in 1980
column3: when Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan debated just once before the election.

column1: More recently
column2: the first Obama-Romney debate in 2012 averaged 67 million viewers.

column1: Detailed Nielsen data confirms that viewership stayed high the entire time. Contrary to some speculation
column2: there was not a big drop-off after the first 30 minutes of the 98-minute debate.

column1: The vast majority of viewers kept watching until the very end
column2: a fact that the Clinton campaign celebrated on Tuesday.

column1: Earlier story: Ratings expectations for first Trump-Clinton debate are sky high
Anticipation for the Clinton-Trump meeting had been mounting for months. Television industry executives were anticipating a total audience somewhere between 80 and 100 million.
There will be two more debates between the candidates in October.
On Monday night Twitter said the first face-off was the ""most tweeted debate ever.""
Given the rapid growth of streaming options
column2: it was almost certainly the most streamed debate ever
column3: as well.

column1: Various live streams on YouTube together registered more than 2.5 million simultaneous viewers. Live streams on other sites also reached millions of people.
On both Twitter and Facebook
column2: Trump was a livelier subject than Clinton. Twitter said the ""final share of conversation around the candidates on stage"" was 62% for Trump and 38% for Clinton.

column1: On Facebook
column2: the results were even more lopsided
column3: with Trump earning 79% share of conversation and Clinton having the remaining 21%.

column1: Being talked about isn't necessarily a good thing for a candidate. Most commentators gave Clinton the edge over Trump after the debate.
Still
column2: the post-debate coverage on TV focused on Trump
column3: partly because of surprising and confounding comments he made on stage.

column1: CNN's reality check team investigated 26 claims made by Clinton and Trump and found that Trump made a greater number of misleading statements."	monday night was the most watched debate 133	"Washington Since we last updated the CNN battleground map
column2: Donald Trump has clearly improved his poll numbers both in some national polls and in some critical battleground states. The Republican nominee has also upped his game (as have his allied outside group friends) with television ad spending.

column1: And
column2: yet
column3: Hillary Clinton maintains her advantage on the Road to 270 when it comes to piecing together the electoral math needed to win the presidency.

column1: With four days to go before the highly anticipated first presidential debate and just under 7 weeks before all the votes are cast
column2: Hillary Clinton still sits above that key threshold in the latest CNN outlook. When you add up all the states either solidly or currently leaning Clinton's way
column3: she has 272 electoral votes in her column in our new estimate.

column1: Hear CNN Political Director David Chalian explain the new race ratings in his podast:
What's changed?
-- Iowa (6) moves from from ""battleground"" to ""lean Republican""
-- Utah (6) moves from ""lean Republican"" to ""solid Republican""
-- Maine's 2nd Congressional District (1) moves from ""solid Democrat"" to ""battleground""
-- Nebraska's 2nd Congressional District (1) moves from ""solid Republican"" to ""battleground""
Road to 270: Electoral College map
Note: The split congressional district ratings are symbolized with diagonal lines.
The state of play

Donald Trump has improved his standing in our electoral college outlook due to Iowa (a state Barack Obama won twice) and its six electoral votes moving from the true toss-up ""battleground"" category into the ""lean Republican"" category
column2: giving Trump a total of 196 electoral votes either solidly or leaning in his favor.

column1: That leaves 70 electoral votes up for grabs across four states (plus two congressional districts) -- Florida
column2: Nevada
column3: Ohio
column4: and North Carolina.

column1: Maine and Nebraska award individual electoral votes by congressional district in addition to the multiple electoral votes based on statewide results. Both Maine and Nebraska's second congressional district have moved into battleground status in this latest estimate. Maine's second congressional district has moved from ""solid Democrat"" to ""battleground"" and Nebraska's second congressional district has moved from ""solid Republican"" to ""battleground
column2: providing an opportunity for a candidate to pick up a single electoral vote in what otherwise might be hostile territory.

column1: Finally
column2: Utah moves back from ""leaning Republican"" to being solidly being in Trump's column.

column1: There is no doubt that Trump has improved his chances in the last several weeks and that he is extremely competitive in all of the remaining critical battleground states
column2: but Clinton's firewall is not yet showing any significant cracks and that is what makes Trump's path to 270 electoral votes still quite challenging.

column1: For all of the endless talk about Florida
column2: Ohio and North Carolina
column3: it is perhaps most important to keep your eye on Clinton's performance in the states that are leaning her way
column4: but not solidly in her camp. Pennsylvania
column5: Colorado
column6: Michigan
column7: and Virginia are the core of Clinton's current stronger and more viable path to 270. If Trump begins to find significant inroads to any of those blue-leaning states
column8: that will set off some alarm bells at her Brooklyn HQ and suggest a more viable path for Trump.

column1: It is not enough for Trump to simply win the remaining 70 electoral votes in the battleground states -- that only gets him to 266. He still needs to chip away at Clinton's Democratic leaning firewall.
That's why we see both Trump and Clinton and their surrogates returning again and again to Pennsylvania
column2: for example. And that's why Clinton and pro-Clinton forces spent more than $16 million on television ads in the Keystone State compared to the $5.3 million we've seen from Trump and pro-Trump forces. In fact
column3: Pennsylvania is the state with the third-highest number of ad dollars spent this cycle
column4: behind only Florida and Ohio.

column1: Clinton and Trump will surely continue the fully engaged battle for the votes of Floridians and Ohioans
column2: but until and unless Trump can put one of those Democratic leaning states back on the board as a battleground or even make one lean his way
column3: Clinton's electoral college advantage holds.

Obama on Sunday tweeted a photo of himself receiving a putting lesson from Palmer
column3: in the Oval Office and wrote

column1: 137	"""I would encourage our colleagues across the aisle to complete negotiations so we can advance this important matter
column2: Sen. Mitch McConnell said. | Getty McConnell punts budget vote to buy time for deal

column1: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell delayed a procedural vote on a must-pass government spending measure Monday as top lawmakers remained at odds over a handful of provisions in the bill
column2: even with a months-long impasse over Zika funding largely resolved.

column1: The key vote is now scheduled for 2:15 p.m. Tuesday
column2: McConnell said — giving negotiators more time to hammer out the fine print of the continuing resolution that will keep the federal government funded until Dec. 9. For now
column3: however
column4: sources said negotiators have settled on language that would provide money to battle the Zika virus while allowing Planned Parenthood’s partner clinic in Puerto Rico to access the federal grants — a provision that had been a major point of contention.

column1: Story Continued Below
“Senate Republicans stand ready to move forward
column2: ” McConnell (R-Ky.) said Monday. “I would encourage our colleagues across the aisle to complete negotiations so we can advance this important matter.”

column1: McConnell spent about five minutes huddling with Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) on Monday afternoon as they sought to strike a deal that would allow the Senate to recess as soon as the end of the week.
But the tentative resolution on Zika funding sets aside
column2: for now
column3: one of the toughest sticking points in the short-term spending measure. Senate Democrats had repeatedly filibustered a standalone Zika bill over restrictions that barred Planned Parenthood — particularly Profamilias
column4: the health care provider’s partner in Puerto Rico — from the federal funds. But in the CR
column5: the Puerto Rico clinic would have access to the money
column6: which would come through a $95 million social services block grant in a broader $1.1 billion Zika package
column7: multiple sources said.

column1: Language in the emerging deal does not specify which providers are eligible or ineligible for funding
column2: skirting a political landmine that’s delayed Zika aid for months.

column1: Despite the breakthrough on emergency funding for the battle against the mosquito-borne disease
column2: several wrinkles remain in the continuing negotiations. In a brief interview Monday morning
column3: Reid said “no” when asked whether there would be a deal on government funding later in the day.

column1: “Close is relative
column2: ” Reid responded when asked whether an agreement was within reach.

column1: For instance
column2: funding for the water crisis in Flint
column3: Michigan
column4: continues to be in the mix. Democrats on both ends of the Capitol have lobbied for Flint funds to be included in the government spending package
column5: in particular the aid package included in a Senate water resources bill.

column1: But Republicans have similar demands: additional funding for flood-stricken Louisiana in the short-term spending measure. Both issues remained unresolved as of Monday evening
column2: although senior Senate Democrats suggested they wouldn’t accept flood aid without also getting money for Flint. Congressional leaders are also still hashing out how to pay for the Zika funding package.

column1: “Louisiana is not resolved because [Republicans] want to do Louisiana
column2: we want to do Flint
column3: ” Sen. Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) told reporters Monday evening. “They don’t want to do Flint.”

column1: Another issue that remains up in the air is a potential delay in the Obama administration’s proposal to hand over the U.S. government’s authority over the Internet domain system to an international body on Oct. 1 — a push that’s being led by Texas Sen. Ted Cruz and a host of other Republican lawmakers. If no deference is paid to Cruz and those lawmakers
column2: the spending bill could turn into an internecine fight among Republicans — even with some pushback on the provision from Democrats.

column1: “This is the coordination of the domain names. It’s not who has control of the Internet
column2: ” Florida Sen. Bill Nelson
column3: the top Democrat on the committee with jurisdiction over the issue
column4: said Monday. “And every institution
column5: nationally and internationally
column6: have all said that this is the appropriate thing to do.”

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Democrats want to include language restoring the ability of the Export-Import Bank to finance projects greater than $10 million — which it hasn’t been able to do because three of the five seats on the bank’s board are vacant. The Ex-Im issue is similarly toxic among Republicans
column3: making it a difficult matter to take up ahead of an election.

column1: There are other items that could fill up the Senate’s legislative calendar this week before lawmakers return home until the November elections. Sens. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.) and Rand Paul (R-Ky.) plan to force a Senate vote to block a $1.15 billion arms sale to Saudi Arabia that the Obama administration announced last month.
Senate Majority Whip John Cornyn (R-Texas) said the exact timing of that vote was unclear
column2: particularly because he would like to have the government funding measure resolved before moving on to other issues. Cornyn would also like to pair the arms sale vote with a roll call to formally override an expected veto by President Barack Obama of legislation that would allow family members of victims of the Sept. 11
column4: terrorism attacks to sue the government of Saudi Arabia.

column1: Though Obama has not yet vetoed the measure
column2: he has until Friday to do so.

column1: Republicans — who are eager to return home to campaign for reelection
column2: particularly with control of the Senate in the balance — privately believe Democrats will try to drag out the negotiations as long as possible before the Sept. 30 deadline to pass government funding.

column1: Heather Caygle contributed to this report.
