138	"There is a moment at every Donald Trump rally when Donald Trump marvels at the crazy spectacle he’s created. “Is there any place in America as fun as a Donald Trump rally?” he asks with a mischievous pursed-lip grin. The moment always comes after a protester tries to interrupt him
column2: only to be drowned out by an arena full of rowdy white people screaming “TRUMP! TRUMP! TRUMP!” That’s the fun part
column3: the joint release of pent-up fury by thousands of proudly politically incorrect Americans. When you experience it in person
column4: you can feel their catharsis as they vent at the whiners and moochers and Mexicans and Muslims taking over their country
column5: gleefully defying the scolds who call them racist and rude for respecting the police and saying Merry Christmas.

column1: “Donald Trump has singlehandedly untied our tongues
column2: ” a chain-saw artist named Chris Cox
column3: the founder of Bikers 4 Trump
column4: told me at a recent Pensacola rally.

column1: Story Continued Below
When Trump fans are asked about his appeal
column2: the first thing they usually say is that he isn’t a normal politician. And his rambling
column3: fear-mongering
column4: name-calling public speeches
column5: no matter how hard his new handlers try to keep him on his new teleprompter
column6: do not feel like normal political events. They feel like Wrestlemania with a different kind of hero and a different kind of performance art. They feel like revival meetings for the Donald J. Trump Church of Cultural Resentment
column7: with ritual denunciations of Crooked Hillary Clinton
column8: Barack Obama—“We call him President Obama
column9: because we have to treat him with respect
column10: right?”—and other enemies of the congregation. At a time when Americans say they’re tired of politics as usual
column11: Trump offers politics as deeply
column12: often disturbingly
column13: always unapologetically

column1: His opponent does not. Clinton’s events feel exactly like normal political events. She may be the world’s most famous and polarizing woman
column2: but she’s running an almost generic Democratic campaign
column3: politics as very usual.

column1: Tonight
column2: Hillary Clinton will take on Donald Trump in perhaps the most anticipated presidential debate ever
column3: a rhetorical clash of two candidates with diametrically opposed life histories
column4: policy agendas
column5: and bases of support. But their contrasting records and ideas haven’t been the defining divides of this strange political year. What 2016 is really about is conventional versus not. And no matter what happens tonight
column6: when you spend time at their diametrically opposed events
column7: you’re constantly reminded that what makes this year so abnormal is Trump. He is violating all the rules of the political game—rules that promote pandering and artifice as well as rules that promote transparency and decency—and when 2016 is over
column8: it’s not clear whether those rules will still apply.

column1: Whatever you think of Clinton
column2: she tends to observe polite-society political traditions
column3: which is why her events would feel familiar to anyone who’s attended a modern campaign stop. The backdrops are decorated with red-white-and-blue bunting and talking-point slogans like “Love Trumps Hate” or “Stronger Together.” The small venues are selected to target niche groups—millennials last week at Temple University in Philadelphia
column4: the disabled a few days later at a family outreach center in Orlando—and the crowds are carefully curated to avoid protests or other surprises. The speeches are standard campaign fare
column5: dotted with wonky statistics and real-person anecdotes to buttress well-researched policy proposals. The candidate
column6: as she has for nearly four decades in public life
column7: sticks to her prepared text. Her audiences are supportive
column8: though not particularly emotive.

column1: “I thought it was very substantial
column2: very specific
column3: ” Glenn McCoy
column4: an adult educator at a Catholic church who wore a “Hil Yes!” pin to Clinton’s speech about supporting disabled workers in Orlando. “The purpose wasn’t to whip the crowd into a frenzy. We’re not looking to choose a president based on emotion.”

column1: Clinton had better hope not. There’s electricity at Trump rallies that hers can’t match. It’s no coincidence that cable news often ignores her speeches to carry the Trump shows live. His crowds wait with giddy anticipation for him to name and shame enemies
column2: like NASCAR fans waiting for wrecks
column3: and they explode when he calls out the dishonest media
column4: the job-stealing Chinese
column5: the PC sensitivity snobs who think you’re prejudiced if you want to keep illegal immigrants and Islamic terrorists out of the country. It’s entertaining to watch him violate norms
column6: declaring Clinton lacks the stamina to be president
column7: suggesting her security detail ought to disarm
column8: warning the election will probably be rigged. He flings out absurd claims about the skewing of the unemployment rate
column9: the savagery of inner cities
column10: even the temperature at his rallies. (“It’s 100 degrees in here. And that’s considered cool for an auditorium.”) He casually drops one outlandish bombshell—the Federal Reserve is corrupt
column11: the FBI is covering up for Clinton
column12: NAFTA was the worst deal in the history of the world—then moves onto another before the last fully explodes.

column1: Clinton doesn’t do that. Whatever one thinks about her email protocols or Benghazi or her penchant for secrecy
column2: she campaigns like a typical candidate. She has the strengths and weaknesses of a typical public servant
column3: and takes typical measures to try to frame them for the public. Her problem is that Trump’s unique combination of insult comedy and monster-truck rally
column4: despite the flagrant abuse of facts and unsettling whiff of menace
column5: is exposing the focus-grouped
column6: stage-managed
column7: paint-by-numbers nature of typical candidacies. Clinton isn’t getting a lot of credit for following the rules of a game that always seemed inauthentic.

column1: Nobody understands that better than the political savant named Donald J. Trump. He tells a lot of straight-faced falsehoods about Clinton’s campaign
column2: like his accusations that it’s “policy-free
column3: ” when he used to mock it for churning otut too many policy proposals
column4: and when Trump himself recently laid off much of his policy shop. But there’s something to his caricature of Clinton events as the lackluster politics of yesteryear. At a rally in Miami
column5: he did a sly imitation of Clinton's speeches—he claimed with faux specificity that they're only 18 minutes
column6: when they're usually twice that long—with a bored expression that suggested she just phones them in.

column1: “Bom. Bom. Bom. See ya!” Trump smirked. “See ya! I’m going home.”

Many Americans really do seem sick of Bom-Bom-Bom-See-Ya politics. But the live experience of Trump’s say-anything middle-finger alternative can be a bracing advertisement for the mundane traditions he’s shredding every day.
Before attending a recent Trump rally in Pensacola
column2: I watched a video of his last rally there during the Republican primary in January. At the time
column3: the news from the event had been his I’m-just-saying speculation that questions about Ted Cruz’s citizenship might be disqualifying. But starting with the Star Spangled Banner
column4: performed by a kids group that later sued Trump for breach of contract
column5: the entire rally seemed like a trip through the looking glass to an alternative political planet.

column1: Trump spent the first 10 minutes of his hourlong soliloquy bashing the “bad
column2: dishonest
column3: very bad people” in the media for failing to show the public the size of his crowds
column4: a theme he revisited three more times. He criticized a U.S. soldier for using the word “sir” to address the Iranians who briefly captured him. He advised Americans to take their money out of the stock market
column5: which he described as “a big fat bubble
column6: ” and predicted a collapse that would be “beautiful to watch.” He gleefully pointed out a black man in the stands: “I didn’t put him there! I’m not paying him!” He read a long poem about a deadly snake that was supposed to show the danger of Syrian refugees
column7: called himself “more militaristic than anyone in this room
column8: ” complained that Common Core education bureaucrats make $400
column9: 000 a year—actually the president’s salary—and announced the American Dream was dead. Oh
column10: he also unleashed a diatribe about incompetent contractors and staff after his microphone crackled.

column1: “Whoever the hell brought this mic system—don’t pay the son of a bitch!” he seethed. “Don’t pay em. Don’t pay em. You know
column2: I believe in paying
column3: but when somebody does a bad job
column4: like this stupid mic
column5: you shouldn’t pay the bastard. Terrible. You gotta be tough with your people
column6: because they’ll pay
column7: they don’t care. So we’re not going to pay. I guarantee
column8: I’m not paying for this mic.”

column1: So I was ready for more theater of the bizarre when Trump returned eight months later to Pensacola’s 12
column2: 000-seat arena
column3: which was once again packed to capacity. Vendors sold Trump That Bitch t-shirts and Trump 2016 Confederate flags. The pastor giving the invocation shouted: “Tyranny has raised its ugly head! Our constitution is under attack!” The crowd started chanting “LOCK HER UP!” before Trump even appeared. He then took the stage to a tremendous roar
column4: and…well
column5: to be honest
column6: he seemed a lot less provocative than I had expected.

column1: “He’s freeing up our speech
column2: ” said one Trump supporter.

column1: “We can talk about the Muslim invasion. We can be against amnesty… Maybe we’ll be able to say Merry Christmas again.”
Trump was now using a teleprompter
column2: which he had derided as a tool of inauthenticity in January
column3: and while he used it more as a guideline than a script
column4: it was still jarring to hear him regurgitate staff-written clichés and Republican talking points about “encrusted insiders” and “turning the page.” He said the kind of things regular politicians say: “The history books are closing on the failed politicians of yesterday.” And: “Once again
column5: we’ll have a government of
column6: by
column7: and for the people.” He even recited the monotonous details of a military investment plan a conservative think tank had prepared for him
column8: name-checking new naval vessels in a town with a naval base. The crowd was noisier and angrier than a normal political crowd—during one Trump riff about lifting minorities out of poverty
column9: a supporter in a red-white-and-blue trucker hat screamed: “What about white people?”—but the rally still felt at least quasi-normal. Trump did repeat a few of his radical proposals that remain astounding when you think about them
column10: like a 35 percent tax on imports and his Mexico-financed wall—but really
column11: who still thinks about them?

column1: Afterwards
column2: though
column3: I saw a breaking story about an offhand comment Trump had made warning that if Iranian sailors ever made rude gestures at Americans when he was president
column4: as they apparently had during a minor incident a few weeks earlier
column5: their ships would be blown out of the water. Trump had essentially threatened to launch World War 3
column6: and I hadn’t noticed. Back at my hotel
column7: I checked my notes and was reminded that he had also literally accused Clinton of causing “all the problems in the world
column8: ” including North Korean nuclear tests that began under George W. Bush. He had mused that “personally
column9: I think she’s an unstable person
column10: ” and complained that she could walk into the arena and shoot someone “right smack in the middle of the heart—and she wouldn’t be prosecuted
column11: OK?” He had denied cozying up to Russian dictator Vladimir Putin—and then he had cozied up again: “He’s been nice to me
column12: and if he’s nice to me
column13: that’s fine. If we got along with Russia
column15: would it?” And at a time of low unemployment
column17: and new data showing that wages grew and poverty shrunk in 2015 at the fastest rate in decades
column18: Trump had flatly declared that “the country is collapsing.”

column1: Those all would have been jaw-dropping statements during any other campaign from any other candidate
column2: but the Year of Trump has desensitized many of us to his rapid-fire transgressions. We’re normalizing the unprecedented. At a rally a few days later in Asheville
column3: N.C.
column4: Trump called the U.S. military “incredibly weak
column5: ” defended a male spectator who roughed up a 68-year-old female protester
column6: and said the black community—which endured slavery and Jim Crow—was “in the worst shape they’ve ever been. Ever! Ever! Ever!” Yet the main Trump story from the Associated Press focused on how he had refrained from attacking Clinton over her bout with pneumonia
column7: under the headline “Restraint on Clinton Health Shows New Campaign Discipline.” Predictably
column8: Trump mocked Clinton’s health problems later in the week
column9: suggesting she needed more sleep
column10: warning she didn’t have enough energy to handle the rigors of the White House
column11: falsely claiming he was holding four rallies a day and then just as falsely claiming she couldn’t make it through one.

column1: That sort of behavior just hasn’t been seen on the presidential campaign trail. But it’s that defiant you-can’t-tell-me-what-I’m-supposed-to-say spirit that Trump loyalists love. “He’s not a politician. Nobody controls him. A lot of us are tired of worrying about people’s feelings
column2: always watching our P’s and Q’s
column3: so it’s cool to see him speak his mind
column4: ” said Alan Smith
column5: a 43-year-old firefighter from nearby Gulf Breeze who recently retired on his municipal pension. Bill Turpin
column6: a retired Army veteran from Brayton
column7: Iowa
column8: told me at a Trump rally outside Des Moines that while Clinton is a classic politician for whom lying is like breathing—he doesn’t even believe the official story about her health
column9: because he fainted once
column10: and he didn’t stumble around like she did on the video—Trump is a businessman with nothing to fear: “He’ll call a spade a spade
column11: and if you don’t like it you can shove it.” Again and again
column12: Trump supporters told me they appreciated the way he was fighting the forces of political correctness
column13: standing up for their right to primal-scream what they believe about immigrants and terrorists and Black Lives Matter thugs.

column1: “He’s freeing up our speech
column2: ” said Norris Westfall
column3: an auto detailer who wore an Infowars Liberty or Death t-shirt to a recent Trump rally in Asheville
column4: N.C. “We can talk about the Muslim invasion. We can be against amnesty without everyone saying we’re offensive. Maybe we’ll be able to say Merry Christmas again.”

column1: It’s fashionable to attribute the Trump phenomenon to economic anxiety
column2: but the Trump voters I interviewed at four separate rallies almost never mentioned it
column3: unless complaints that the undocumented are getting jobs and welfare benefits counts as economic anxiety. They seemed less anxious about the state of the Obama economy than the rise of the multicultural Obama coalition
column4: and they seemed less anxious than pissed off—at a president many of them still consider a foreign usurper
column5: at thought leaders more worried about Islamophobia than Islamic terror
column6: at racial guilt-trippers who demonize cops while ignoring black-on-black crime. In Asheville
column7: I watched an Air Force veteran named Gary Latham explode at some anti-Trump protesters who were chanting that they didn’t want hate in their state: “Lazy motherfuckers! Get a fucking job!” He explained to me that America was under siege
column8: with “thousands of Syrian refugees embedded in western Carolina
column9: ” and that he was proud to be one of the vigilant Americans Clinton considered “deplorable.”

column1: The Trump voters I interviewed seemed less anxious about the Obama economy than the rise of the multicultural Obama coalition—and they seemed less anxious than pissed off.

One of the speakers before Trump took the stage in Asheville was a white-haired lady who owns a custom frame shop and serves in the state legislature. She used the opportunity to proclaim: “We want our state rights back!”
“We’re sick of the same old racism crap getting shoveled down our throats
column2: ” says Kim Buckner
column3: a nursing assistant who wore a Don’t Tread on Me pin to the Asheville rally. “Trump is saying what we’re all thinking: ‘Screw you! Call us deplorable all you want! Our rights don’t end where your feelings begin!’”

column1: Trump echoes those anti-anti-racism tropes
column2: describing accusations of racism as “the oldest play in the Democratic playbook.” And he’s begun regaling his white audiences with increasingly lurid descriptions of inner-city life
column3: arguing that it’s so hellish blacks might as well vote Trump: “I’ll say it openly
column4: and some people don’t like it
column5: I don’t really care: What do you have to lose?” His long riffs about how he’ll fix neighborhoods so awful that blacks can’t walk down the street without getting shot have been described as outreach to non-racist whites
column6: but in person
column7: they feel much more like creepy concern-trolling for the benefit of jeering Trump fans who want to believe that blacks live like animals. When Trump claims that black youths don’t get an education and have an unemployment rate of 58 percent—the real rate is about one third of that—he’s fueling the kind of ugly stereotypes found all over the white-supremacy sites he retweets every now and then. The Trump supporters I interviewed seemed much less interested in supporting inner-city blacks than criticizing their lifestyles
column8: bemoaning their dependence on government
column9: and blaming their president. Polls show that most Trump supporters still think Obama was born in Kenya—and many I spoke to believe he’s also a Muslim who supports ISIS.

column1: One notable exception was Richard Cohen
column2: a Jewish contractor who attended the rally in Asheville. Cohen told me Trump is pandering to racism
column3: anti-Semitism
column4: and fear of Hispanics among his supporters; he said a white friend with two adopted black sons left an earlier Trump event after hearing spectators yell the N-word. But Cohen supports Trump anyway
column5: because he likes the idea of shaking up the timid
column6: finger-in-the-wind political establishment. “A lot of us who like him don’t like the stuff he says about race
column7: ” Cohen said. “Obviously
column8: some do.”

column1: This really isn’t normal. And while Clinton is an unlikely poster child for normal—a First Lady whose husband was impeached after cheating on her with an intern
column2: a Secretary of State who agreed to serve the younger man who foiled her own presidential dreams—she presents herself on the trail as a dedicated but ordinary public servant who happens to be the alternative to a bigoted freak.

column1: I remember watching her execute a similar strategy in 2000 when she ran for a Senate seat in New York even though she had never lived in the state or pursued public office
column2: even though her husband was still in the White House after his tabloid scandal had transfixed the nation. She simply ignored the weirdness of it all
column3: running as a standard-issue Democrat in a Democratic state
column4: diligently discussing dairy policy and upstate development as if nothing else mattered. And against a basically normal Republican candidate
column5: it worked. A majority of New Yorkers agreed with her agenda
column6: and sent her to the Senate to pursue it.

column2: though
column3: Clinton has struggled to make a case for normal. She’s tried to push a standard-issue Democratic agenda
column4: but in the Year of Trump
column5: the race hasn’t been about standard anything.

column1: Nearly one of every five Americans lives with a disability
column2: and just about everyone else wishes them the best. So Clinton’s Orlando speech about valuing their work made sense politically as well as morally
column3: as an expression of her commitment to helping the vulnerable and creating an “Inclusive Economy
column4: ” to quote the clunky slogan behind her podium. In the I-4 corridor that constitutes the swingiest region of the swingiest state
column5: Clinton spoke to 300 supporters—a much smaller crowd than Trump regularly attracts
column6: but far more diverse—about her goal of an America that recognizes the humanity and supports the potential of all its citizens. She also laid out a four-part plan her policy team had devised to help more disabled Americans flourish in the economy. Just two months before Election Day
column7: the speech was designed to illustrate Clinton’s concern about a worthy issue.

column1: It did that
column2: more or less. Afterwards
column3: her supporters praised her seriousness of purpose
column4: her depth of knowledge
column5: her willingness to listen. Nobody mentioned eloquence or flair
column6: but her people understand that she never hosted a reality show.

column1: “I thought it was a nice speech
column2: ” Lewis Smith
column3: a retired mechanic in Orlando
column4: told me afterwards. “Not very exciting
column5: but I believe she’ll do what she says.”

column1: The speech started slowly
column2: as Clinton spent nearly the first half on shoutouts to key supporters
column3: a few made-for-TV soundbites about the riots in Charlotte
column4: and an abridged version of her broader stump speech about an economy that works for everyone. Her speechwriters clearly cut-and-pasted in some of her standard lines about her middle-class origins
column5: her support for family-friendly policies like paid leave
column6: and a plug for her new book of campaign proposals about everything from Alzheimer’s disease to campus sexual assault to small business incubators.

column1: The rest of the speech was dedicated to the proposition that Clinton is committed to promoting the talents and dreams of disabled Americans who have been undervalued by society for too long. It was a nice sentiment
column2: expressed through the kind of political saccharine that sends viewers scurrying for the remote control: “Across the country
column3: people with disabilities are running businesses
column4: teaching students
column5: caring for our loved ones. They’re holding public office
column6: making breakthrough scientific discoveries
column7: reporting the news
column8: and creating art that inspires and challenges us.” Maybe some disabled Americans create uninspiring art
column9: but not in Hillary Clinton speeches. “In the United States of America
column10: the greatest country in the world
column11: we believe that everyone is created equal
column12: ” Clinton said. This kind of boilerplate scores a lot higher in truth value than in news value.

column1: Clinton did talk about her own work with the disabled
column2: from her push for their right to attend school as a young Children’s Defense Fund lawyer to her appointment of the State Department’s first-ever advisor for disability rights. She mentioned disabled people she’s known—including the “unbelievably good-looking” actor Christopher Reeve
column3: who told her that “family values” should mean that every family has value—and her discussions with advocates who said they want paychecks rather than pity. She then detailed her plan
column4: which
column5: while infinitely more substantive than anything Trump has ever said about disabilities
column6: was mostly placeholders about partnering with schools and businesses
column7: plus an elimination of the “sub-minimum wage” that is currently paid to some disabled workers.

column1: The audience responded with warmth
column2: if not exuberance. But I must confess that after watching Trump claim Obamacare deductibles were so high you need to die a “really slow
column3: vicious death” to exhaust them
column4: accuse the Federal Reserve and the Justice Department of corruption
column5: and tell his supporters he doesn’t feel bad if they’re working harder than ever because he is too
column6: Clinton’s scripted remarks seemed noticeably dull. She gave a laudable and sensible political speech on an overlooked topic
column7: but it felt like a political speech
column8: a combination of virtue signaling and interest-group outreach. Cable covered a Trump rally instead
column9: and was rewarded when boxing promoter Don King dropped an N-bomb in his introduction. There was nothing controversial or unpredictable in Clinton’s remarks; they mostly proved that she and her team had done their homework
column10: and that unlike Trump
column11: who talks mostly about himself
column12: she knows enough to portray herself as part of a team. She didn’t even mention Trump’s reprehensible imitation of a disabled reporter
column13: because she wanted a more positive message that day. She was careful to say nothing impolitic
column15: basically

column1: Geannie Bastian
column2: a student with cerebral palsy
column3: said her political awakening came when Trump made fun of that reporter.

column1: “Believe me
column2: I’ve seen that gesture a lot
column3: but before it was always from children
column4: ” she said. “Trump is every playground bully every disabled kid ever knew.”

column1: In fairness to Clinton
column2: there was a portion of the audience that seemed genuinely touched: The disabled and their families. Joe Kilsheimer
column3: the mayor of a central Florida suburb
column4: has a younger brother who was written off by doctors as a hopeless case when he was a baby
column5: but went on to become the first Eagle Scout with Down’s Syndrome and lead a productive life. “What Hillary said about an inclusive economy really hit home
column6: ” Kilsheimer said. “I know a lot of people don’t trust her
column7: because they see her filtered through politics and media
column8: but she’s got heart.”

column1: Geannie Bastian
column2: a University of Central Florida film student with cerebral palsy who gets around in a wheelchair
column3: said she was moved by Clinton’s message that people like her matter and deserve to fulfill their potential. But she said her real political awakening came when Trump made fun of that reporter
column4: whose hand looks quite similar to hers. “Believe me
column5: I’ve seen that gesture a lot
column6: but before it was always from children
column7: ” she said. “Trump is every playground bully every disabled kid ever knew.”

column1: Political scientists disagree about the importance of enthusiasm; voters only get to vote once
column2: no matter how fired up they are
column3: but they’re less likely to turn out to vote if they aren’t fired up. In any case
column4: even at her own events
column5: it’s a lot easier to find voters fired up to vote against the outrageousness of Trump than it is to find avid Clinton fans. Voters of color seem especially riled. I repeatedly heard from black Democrats offended by Trump’s crusade to deny that the first African-American president was American
column6: and his stereotypes of their families as desperate charity cases with nothing to lose. “My daughter has a doctorate. Her husband is an orthodontist. We’ve got plenty to lose
column7: ” said Betty Edwards
column8: a retired educator in the Orlando suburbs. “There’s never been a candidate who thought so little of us.”

column1: Many Hispanics are similarly energized by Trump’s calls for mass deportations and a wall
column2: sensing not just honest disagreements over immigration policy but a broader push to make them feel like strangers in their own country. Andy Gutierrez
column3: a singer and Puerto Rican voting activist who brought a Boricua Vota sign to the Orlando event
column4: says Trump has been a one-man registration machine. “He thinks we’re all Mexicans
column5: and we’re all bad
column6: ” Gutierrez said. “People aren’t super-excited about Hillary
column7: but trust me
column8: they’ll come out to stop Trump.”

column1: Clinton’s excitement problem is a real problem. At her university event in Philadelphia
column2: millennials who had swooned over Bernie Sanders kept talking about her in the milquetoast terms they might use to describe a reasonably reliable accountant. “She’s OK
column3: I guess
column4: ” said Thomas Davidenko
column5: a freshman at Temple. “My main worry is Trump’s fingers on the nuclear code. But I’d say she knows what she’s doing.” In Orlando
column6: I met more actual Clinton fans
column7: especially older women who admired her as a feminist trailblazer
column8: but even her staunch supporters said they’re struggling to persuade friends. Lou Smith
column9: a union cell-tower technician for AT&T
column10: said many of his Arab-hating white colleagues at work think she’s a typical lying politician
column11: so they’re voting for Trump—and her Bernie-loving daughters think the same thing
column12: so they’re staying home.

column1: “She’s been around so long
column2: and Republicans have thrown so much mud on her
column3: ” he said. “She’s great on the issues
column4: but it’s hard to get people to focus on that.”

column1: Clinton is a policy wonk
column2: and one could imagine that a more normal campaign against a more normal Republican would have been closer to her wheelhouse. She could have focused on taxes and health insurance
column3: climate change and diplomacy. She might have framed the election as the Democratic bottom-up approach that produced prosperity during her husband’s administration and recovery during Obama’s with the trickle-down philosophy that ended in economic collapse under Bush. “When Bill Clinton was in the chair
column4: everybody was doing great
column5: and then everything fell apart before Obama fixed it
column6: ” said Jeneka Lloyd
column7: who owns a small painting business in Orlando. “Man
column8: Hillary should talk about that.”

column1: But Trump is not a normal Republican
column2: and 2016 hasn’t focused on his policies
column3: because they’re so insubstantial and flexible
column4: because he’s trashed Bush as well as Obama
column5: because he has a gift for changing the subject with colorful Fox News interviews or incendiary tweets
column6: and because his business record
column7: charity scams and racial provocations provide such a target-rich environment beyond the issues. It’s a lot harder to persuade Americans of the magical thinking behind Trump’s plan to erase the national debt while expanding the military and slashing taxes than it is to attack him for denigrating a Gold Star family
column8: looting his own charitable foundation
column9: refusing to release his tax returns
column10: and other unheard-of behavior. Meanwhile
column11: the media have balanced the narrative with scandal coverage of her sketchy email situation and her own foundation. Her approval ratings have dropped lower than any modern major-party presidential nominee with the lone exception of Donald Trump.

column1: So Clinton has ended up in the proverbial mud-wrestling match with a pig. They’ve both gotten dirty. And neither she nor the public has liked it.
Tonight on Long Island
column2: Trump and Clinton will meet in a very conventional setting. And as usual
column3: no one really has any idea how Trump will try to handle it
column4: which is a big part of what makes him so compelling on television. His team is already warning moderator Lester Holt not to fact-check the candidates
column5: which makes sense
column6: given Trump’s distant relationship with facts. There will be rules governing the debate
column7: but Trump’s political brand is all about breaking the rules.

column1: What is clear is that Trump will portray himself as the candidate of change
column2: which is exactly what he is. He essentially wants to roll back the Obama era
column3: repealing the president’s health care reforms
column4: Wall Street reforms and climate rules
column5: as well as the Obama approach to the economy and the war on terror. But Trump represents just as dramatic a change from the way politics has been practiced in the TV era
column6: upending every assumption about what is a gaffe
column7: what is disqualifying and what you just can’t say if you want to sit in the Oval Office and represent an entire nation. If he uses tonight’s debate to brag about his genitalia
column8: or invite the Russians to hack his opponent
column9: well
column10: it won’t be normal
column11: but it won’t be the first time
column12: either.

column1: And yes
column2: even though she’s unlikely to put it this way
column3: Clinton represents the status quo—not just a continuation of Democratic policies
column4: but a continuation of the conventional rules of politics. She’s playing the same classical music that previous candidates always played
column5: and it wouldn’t feel so stilted if her opponent hadn’t started playing experimental honky-tonk. The question for 2016 is whether Americans are so disgusted with politics as usual that they’ll turn to the politics of Trump. That question will be decided not by the thousands of Americans who flock to Trump rallies or the hundreds who get invited to see Clinton
column6: but by the millions who will tune in tonight even though they would never attend a political event.

column1: But the question beyond 2016 is what will happen to politics as usual. Americans never liked it
column2: and Trump has helped expose how cautious
column3: contrived
column4: and anodyne it can be. But he has also helped remind those of us who have complained about it for a living that if caution
column5: restraint
column6: premeditated choreography
column7: and other hallmarks of traditional campaigning aren’t the most authentic elements of successful political leadership
column8: they’re part of it. And while politics as usual does have some bogus Kabuki theater qualities
column9: it also reflects some baseline values—showing basic respect to political opponents and people who aren’t like you
column10: staying at least close to the boundaries of plausible facts
column11: recognizing that the things leaders say and do and tweet can have serious consequences—that have constrained politicians in a good way. It’s not clear whether it will be possible to put the norms Trump has shattered back together
column12: and while we may not have liked them
column13: we might miss them when they’re gone. Not many of us would be better at our jobs if we felt unrestrained from saying whatever popped into our head whenever we wanted. And Trump just may have untied the tongues of the politicians of the future.

that’s the fun part the joint release pent up fury thousands proudly politically incorrect americans when you experience person you can feel their catharsis they vent the whiners and moochers and mexicans and muslims taking over their country gleefully defying the scolds who call them racist and rude for respecting the police and saying merry christmas “donald trump has singlehandedly untied The first debate showdown of Republican nominee Donald Trump and Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton was expected to be a brutal altercation between the two candidates.
Instead
column2: the viewing audience was treated to a one-sided destruction with Clinton appearing cool and presidential
column3: while Trump gave the worst debate performance in presidential history. Each candidate had the ability to invite guests for moral support
column4: and Clinton invited billionaire Mark Cuban who has been one of the loudest voices against Trump in the media.

column1: There is no love lost between the two businessmen
column2: and Cuban even said of Trump there was “no bigger jagoff in the world.”

column1: The indebted businessman happily admitted on stage in front of Cuban to being in debt at least $600 million. The shameless Trump
column2: who became more unhinged as the night progressed
column3: freely gave away one of his biggest secrets — that he does not and has not paid any federal taxes in years.

column1: Clinton speculated about this
column2: and like a predictable rube under the hot lights Trump cracked under the pressure. Rather than offer an explanation or deflection to Clinton’s hypothesis Trump agreed he paid no taxes and said
column3: “That makes me smart.” Trump’s cheap explanation sounded like something a third grader on the playground would offer rather than a presidential candidate.

column1: An hour after the debate Trump immediately began walking back his statement
column2: and denied he had ever said it. This type of shamelessness is difficult to combat. When asked
column3: “It sounds like you admitted you haven’t paid federal taxes and that was smart. Is that what you meant to say?” Trump replied
column4: “No
column5: I didn’t say that at all.”

column1: Trump insulted every American who pays their fair share of taxes and Cuban was not amused nor impressed. After the debate Cuban said:
I get audited every year my taxes are — it takes me 45 minutes just to sign all the different taxes that I have to spend. And I tell my tax lawyers and everybody
column2: you know
column3: take advantage of — do what the law recommends. But I’m not against paying taxes. And I’ll give you a perfect example. When the Dallas Mavericks were building a new practice facility which was just opening I had the opportunity to go to Dallas and and play different cities against each other to get different rebates and everything. I didn’t do it. A couple years ago we had some issues in Dallas
column4: I just wrote a check to the general treasury. This year we had
column5: after the shootings in Orlando
column6: I had concerns about the LGBT community in Dallas. I just wrote a million dollar check to the city of Dallas to support a bunch of different programs. I’m
column7: I’m the luckiest guy in the world. There’s nobody who’s been as blessed as me and my family
column8: so far
column9: knock on wood
column10: is healthy
column11: and at some point you have to realize you have to give back. And you have to realize that this is a country that’s been great to us. And you can’t just take
column12: take
column13: take
column15: take

column1: .@mcuban on Trump saying not paying taxes makes him smart #debatenight pic.twitter.com/uPNunatukV — Stefan Becket (@becket) September 27
The contrast between Cuban and Trump could not be more stark. Cuban believes in paying his fair share to society to help those who are less fortunate than him
column2: while admitting he owes his success to society. Trump is content and even proud that he bleeds society for as much money as possible
column3: while offering to pay back nothing. Did Trump say he was interested in paying higher taxes? No. Did Trump say he would like to reform the tax code so that he would be forced to pay higher taxes? No.

column1: Trump has no interest in paying his taxes to help fund schools so that children will grow to be more intelligent
column2: because if they did they would certainly not support him. Trump has no interest in paying taxes to help pay for the roads which are used to deliver the cheaply made Chinese goods to which his name is affixed. In Trump’s world there is a two-tiered system. One for him
column3: and one for everyone else.

Frank says he thinks bipartisanship can return to Congress if Hillary Clinton is elected
The Axe Files
column2: featuring David Axelrod
column3: is a podcast distributed by CNN and produced at the University of Chicago Institute of Politics. The author works for David Axelrod.

column1: Kiev (CNN) He was one of the most effective legislators in Washington
column2: an icon of Democratic politics. Now Barney Frank says the left has been outmaneuvered by the tea party and the populist right.

column1: To my great regret
column2: the tea party movement has had much more impact on American politics than Occupy Wall Street
column3: Frank
column4: former congressman from Massachusetts
column5: said to David Axelrod on ""The Axe Files"" podcast
column6: produced by the University of Chicago Institute of Politics and CNN.

column1: Because the tea party people correctly understood that
column2: for them
column3: what they needed to do was to get control of the political machinery
column4: to register people to vote
column5: to vote in primaries
column6: and influence public policy
column7: Frank continued. ""Occupy Wall Street decided that they would bring about great change by smoking pot and having drum circles
column8: and it turns out voting in primaries is a better way to do it.""

column1: The key to bringing about political change
column2: Frank believes
column3: is not allowing one's ideals to overwhelm the sense of moral duty inherent in public service.

column1: I do believe that
column2: clearly
column3: idealism comes first. You don't belong trying to run other people's lives unless you're committed to ideals
column4: Frank said. ""But the more idealistic you are
column5: the more morally you are obligated to be pragmatic.""

142	"Jeffrey DeLaurentis will serve as America's ambassador to the communist-led country. | Getty Obama nominates ambassador to Cuba in long-shot move
When it comes to picking fights with Republicans over Cuba
column2: Barack Obama has apparently decided he's only a lame-duck
column3: second-term president once.

column1: The president announced Tuesday that he has nominated Jeffrey DeLaurentis
column2: the top U.S. diplomat currently serving in Cuba
column3: to serve as America's official ambassador to the communist-led country.

column1: Story Continued Below
The move is sure to draw howls of protest from some hard-core opponents of the Cuban government
column2: including Sens. Marco Rubio of Florida and Ted Cruz of Texas
column3: who have vowed to block any ambassador nomination for Cuba.

column1: Still
column2: Obama's decision suggests he's willing to take on the risk of a dragged-out fight over a topic — Cuba-U.S. relations — that has increasing bipartisan support.

column1: The island nation restored diplomatic ties with the U.S. in July 2015 after more than 50 years of hostility
column2: and Obama considers America's new relationship with Cuba one of his signature foreign policy achievements.

column1: DeLaurentis is a career member of the U.S. foreign service who has been the chief of mission at the U.S. embassy in Havana since it was re-established in 2015 and headed what was an American interests section there before that. He was widely believed to be the frontrunner for the ambassador's job should Obama select a nominee.
The appointment of an ambassador is a common sense step forward toward a more normal and productive relationship between our two countries
column2: Obama said in a statement announcing his decision.

column1: Among those appaluding Obama's decision was Sen. Jeff Flake
column2: an Arizona Republican who has long advocated for better U.S.-Cuba relations.

column1: Americans traveling & doing business in #Cuba will be well-served by the prompt confirmation of Jeff DeLaurentis to serve as US ambassador
column2: Flake tweeted.

column1: But although a growing number of Republicans have shown support for deepening ties to Cuba
column2: it takes only a single senator to severely slow down a nomination process for an ambassador.

column1: Asked by POLITICO earlier this year whether he still held firm to his denouncement of the rapprochement with Cuba and his vow to block an ambassador confirmation
column2: Rubio said yes.

column1: A U.S. ambassador is not going to influence the Cuban government
column2: which is a dictatorial
column3: closed regime
column4: ” the senator
column5: who is of Cuban descent
column6: said as the one-year anniversary of Cuba-U.S. ties loomed.

column1: Rubio's office subsequently issued a statement assailing the nomination.
This nomination
column2: Rubio said
column3: ""should go nowhere until the Castro regime makes significant and irreversible progress in the areas of human rights and political freedom for the Cuban people.""

column1: 144	"Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi said his wife is looking forward to seeing former President Bill Clinton serve as first gentleman. | AP Photo Italian prime minister jokes about Bill Clinton as 'first gentleman'
Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi joked on Monday that his wife was looking forward to seeing former President Bill Clinton in a new role as first gentleman at the next G-7 meeting
column2: scheduled for next May in Sicily.

column1: Renzi’s joke came at the end of a forum hosted by the Clinton Global Initiative
column2: moderated by the former president and featuring not just the Italian prime minister but also Argentinean President Mario Macri
column3: London Mayor Sadiq Khan and Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala
column4: the chair of Gavi
column5: the Vaccine Alliance and a former Nigerian finance minister.

column1: Story Continued Below
“Mr. President
column2: also [in] the name of my friends
column3: only one thing
column4: thirty seconds to give this message
column5: ” Renzi said after asking Clinton to make one final point at the end of the issues-based discussion. “Those issues will be discussed in the next G-7 in Italy in May 2017 in Sicily. My wife waits for you as first gentlemen in G-7
column6: in G-7 meeting.”

column1: Macri quickly jumped in
column2: adding that he looked forward to seeing Clinton at the next G-20 meeting in 2018.

column1: If Clinton’s wife Hillary Clinton is elected to the White House

146	"Sen. Mitch McConnell said a filed spending measure is the ""result of many
column2: many hours of bipartisan work across the aisle."" | Getty McConnell plays hardball in spending fight

column1: Mitch McConnell is playing hardball — forcing Democrats into a take-it-or-leave-it position on a must-pass government spending bill before funding runs dry at the end of the month.
With spending negotiations still stymied at the Capitol
column2: McConnell filed a new short-term government spending measure Thursday that concedes key priorities to Democrats — yet still isn’t enough to get the minority party on board.

column1: Story Continued Below
Gone is the so-called ICANN provision
column2: an internet-domain issue that had become a top priority for Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas) and other GOP senators and just got the seal of endorsement from GOP nominee Donald Trump. It also includes some funding for a sweeping opioids bill that was signed into law earlier this year
column3: as well as a landmark chemical safety measure that became law in June.

column1: The new spending measure McConnell filed Thursday — which funds the government until Dec. 9 — also includes language already worked out between Democrats and Republicans to deal with additional funding for the Zika virus epidemic. A procedural vote on the measure is slated for Tuesday afternoon
column2: and McConnell used a parliamentary maneuver to block amendments to the bill
column3: ensuring that the legislation he outlined was essentially the only option.

column1: “There have been broad requests for a clean continuing resolution. So that’s what I’ve just offered
column2: ” McConnell said. “It’s the result of many
column3: many hours of bipartisan work across the aisle.”

column1: But Democrats
column2: who have little incentive to agree quickly to a deal that lets vulnerable Republicans leave Washington
column3: say they object to the legislation because while it includes flood aid for states such as Louisiana
column4: West Virginia and Maryland
column5: it doesn’t include money for the long-running water crisis in Flint
column6: Michigan.

column1: “To put Louisiana in without Flint is like waving a red flag. I don't get it
column2: said New York Sen. Chuck Schumer
column3: the third-ranking Senate Democrat. ""I haven’t counted votes but our caucus isn’t going to like having Louisiana and not Michigan.""

column1: It also does not remove language that prohibits the Securities and Exchange Commission from requiring companies to disclose political spending. That is current law
column2: but Democrats have tried to overturn it during the recent negotiations. Democrats also floated a provision related to the Export-Import Bank that would have restored the bank’s full financing authority
column3: but that was not included in the spending measure McConnell filed Thursday. That Ex-Im provision was also important for some Republicans; South Carolina Sen. Lindsey Graham said he would vote against the short-term funding bill because that language was excluded.

column1: “The president does not believe that a short-term budget measure that only exists because Congress hasn’t done their job in the first place should be used to pass ideological riders into law
column2: ” White House Press Secretary Josh Earnest said Thursday
column3: while slamming Republicans for their opposition to the Ex-Im Bank.

column1: Yet McConnell's proposal is also starting to drive a rift through Democrats. While some leading Senate Democrats stood firm in opposing the new funding measure
column2: other Democrats began to side with Republicans. Democratic Sen. Bill Nelson
column3: whose home state of Florida has been the nation's epicenter of the Zika crisis
column4: said he would vote in favor of the new continuing resolution because it sets aside $1.1 billion to combat Zika ""with no political riders.""

column1: While I support the people of Flint
column2: my priority is the people of Florida
column3: Nelson said.

column1: Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) signaled his displeasure with the bill shortly before McConnell went to the floor to unveil it Thursday afternoon.
“We’re in no hurry to go anyplace
column2: OK? We have all a lot of time
column3: ” Reid told reporters. “I’ve talked with [House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi]
column4: she’s not going to agree to this. The president is not going to agree to this. It’s really unfair to the American people.”

column1: During her weekly news conference earlier Thursday
column2: Pelosi said the legislation
column3: “in my view
column4: is not even worthy of a counter. It falls very short.”

column1: Maryland Sen. Barbara Mikulski
column2: the top Democratic appropriator
column3: charged McConnell with filing a “Republican-only bill"" and said Democrats would not support the legislation
column4: although details of the measure were still emerging and some senators had yet to review it.

column1: House Speaker Paul Ryan
column2: for his part
column3: is trying to project an air of calm
column4: telling reporters that lawmakers in his chamber want ""low drama"" in order to solve the government funding impasse. But Cruz is pressuring House lawmakers to fight on behalf of the Internet domain provision that he championed.

column1: I am grateful for my Senate colleagues' vigorous support during this debate
column2: Cruz said in a statement. ""I encourage my colleagues in the House to continue to stand united to ensure that the government funding bill prevents the Obama administration from permanently undermining free speech on the Internet.""

column1: Heather Caygle
column2: Louis Nelson
column3: Burgess Everett and Ashley Gold contributed to this report.

147	"New York (CNN) Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump both met with world leaders in town for the United Nations General Assembly on Monday
column2: but the two presidential contenders did so with vastly different goals.

column1: Both Clinton and Trump met with Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi Monday
column2: as the grueling presidential contest enters its final weeks.

column1: Clinton
column2: who served for four years as President Barack Obama's secretary of state
column3: also met with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko.

column1: While the stakes are high for both candidates
column2: there is likely more on the line for Trump who
column3: as a foreign policy novice
column4: is still looking to prove his chops before the first presidential debate next Monday.

column1: Trump used the meetings to try to convince voters that despite his often explosive personality he is qualified to serve as commander in chief. The key for the blunt businessman is the visuals of the meeting
column2: hoping that voters see a president as they observe him with a world leader.

column1: I will say that with all the folks being in New York
column2: I've had a lot of calls from a lot of different people on the basis that I'm doing well and
column3: you know
column4: they seem to think it's important to maybe meet
column5: Trump said Monday on Fox News. ""I don't want to comment specifically on who but a couple of people are coming over.""

column1: He later said
column2: ""I've already met with a couple
column3: but refused to say which ones.

column1: Clinton used the meetings with the three world leaders
column2: in contrast
column3: to stress her facility with high-level diplomacy gained by years of experience on the world stage. Her meetings are also certain to be watched in various parts of the world for signs of how she would direct US foreign policy as president.

column1: Clinton addressed prickly topics with each world leader
column2: according to aides in the room. Clinton touched on North Korea and the rise of China with Japan's Abe
column3: while Clinton addressing the need for a more vibrant -- and free -- civil society with Egypt while she met with Sisi.

column1: While reporters were in the room
column2: Clinton told Sisi that she looked forward to talking about the ""path we are taking in order to build up a new civil society
column3: a new modern country that upholds the rule of law
column4: that respects human rights and liberties.""

column1: Trump also met with Sisi on Monday evening in New York where the two discussed ""the strategic bilateral relationship between the US and Egypt
column2: according to a Trump campaign statement after the meeting.

column1: Sen. Jeff Sessions of Alabama and Lt. Gen. Michael Flynn (ret.)
column2: two of Trump's top foreign policy advisers
column3: joined Trump for the meeting.

column1: Mr. Trump expressed to President el-Sisi his strong support for Egypt's war on terrorism
column2: and how under a Trump administration
column3: the United States of America will be a loyal friend
column4: not simply an ally
column5: that Egypt can count on in the days and years ahead
column6: the Trump campaign said.

column1: The Republican nominee
column2: who has faced widespread condemnation in the Muslim world for his proposal to ban Muslims from the U.S. and his blanket statements about Islam
column3: also shared his ""high regard for peace-loving Muslims
column4: the campaign added.

column1: The campaign also said Trump called the US-Egypt relationship ""vital to help promote peace and stability in the Middle East.""
Sisi is the second foreign leader Trump has met with since becoming the Republican nominee. He first met with the Mexican president in Mexico last month.
Sitting with Poroshenko
column2: Clinton said she was looking forward to talking about the challenges Ukraine faces
column3: primarily ""the very real problems and threats from Russian aggression."" Clinton added that she was ""anxious to know how we can be supportive of those efforts.""

column1: Clinton's meetings were announced before Trump's

column1: 148	"Ahmad Khan Rahami is pictured in an undated photo provided by the FBI. | AP Photo 28-year-old man sought in Manhattan blast
NEW YORK — Police released a photo of a 28-year-old immigrant wanted for questioning Monday in bombings that rocked a Manhattan neighborhood and a New Jersey shore town
column2: and New York's governor and mayor said the blasts are looking increasingly like an act of terrorism with a foreign connection.

column1: Ahmad Khan Rahami
column2: a naturalized U.S. citizen from Afghanistan with an address in Elizabeth
column3: New Jersey
column4: should be considered armed and dangerous
column5: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio said in one of a series of TV appearances just minutes after the photo was released.

column1: Story Continued Below
In addition to the blast in Manhattan's Chelsea neighborhood on Saturday
column2: a pipe bomb exploded in a New Jersey shore town before a charity 5K race and an unexploded pressure cooker device was found blocks away from the explosion site in Chelsea. On Sunday
column3: five explosive devices were discovered at an Elizabeth train station.

column1: New Jersey State Police said Monday
column2: citing the FBI
column3: that the bombings in Chelsea and the New Jersey shore town Seaside Park were connected. No one was injured in the Jersey blast.

column1: New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo said as investigators gathered information they learned there were ""certain commonalities among the bombs
column2: leading authorities to believe ""that there was a common group behind the bombs.""

column1: We want to get this guy in for questioning
column2: de Blasio said on CNN. ""We need the facts to be able to piece all this together. ... I think we're going to know a lot more in the course of the day. Things are moving very quickly.""

column1: Early Monday
column2: FBI agents swarmed an apartment above a fried chicken restaurant in Elizabeth that's tied to Rahami. The activity came hours after one of five devices found at the nearby Elizabeth train station exploded while a bomb squad robot attempted to disarm it. No one was injured.

column1: Saturday night's blast in the bustling Chelsea neighborhood injured 29 people
column2: and another unexploded device made out of pressure cooker was found several blocks away. In the immediate aftermath of that bombing
column3: de Blasio and Cuomo were careful to say there was no evidence of a link to international terrorism. Both said Monday that appears to be changing.

column1: The more we learn with each passing hour
column2: is it looks more like terrorism
column3: de Blasio said in a later interview on NY1 News.

column1: Cuomo
column2: in a separate interview on MSNBC
column3: said: ""Today's information suggests it may be foreign related but we'll see where it goes. ... My operating premise is anytime
column4: anywhere
column5: seven days a week you could have an incident like this.""

column1: The White House said President Barack Obama was briefed throughout the night and early Monday on the investigation into bombs found in New York City and New Jersey. Spokesman Josh Earnest said Obama will comment publicly later Monday.
On Sunday night
column2: FBI agents in Brooklyn stopped ""a vehicle of interest"" in the investigation of the Manhattan explosion
column3: according to FBI spokeswoman Kelly Langmesser.

column1: She wouldn't provide further details
column2: but a government official and a law enforcement official who were briefed on the investigation told The Associated Press that five people in the car were being questioned at an FBI building in Manhattan.

column1: The officials spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to talk about the ongoing investigation.
No one has been charged
column2: and the investigation is continuing
column3: Langmesser said.

column1: Cuomo
column2: touring the site of Saturday's blast in Chelsea
column3: said the unexploded pressure cooker device appeared ""similar in design"" to the bomb that exploded in Chelsea.

column1: On Sunday
column2: a federal law enforcement official said the Chelsea bomb contained a residue of Tannerite
column3: an explosive often used for target practice that can be picked up in many sporting goods stores. The discovery of Tannerite may be important as authorities probe whether the two New York City devices and the pipe bomb at the Jersey shore are connected.

column1: Cellphones were discovered at the site of both bombings
column2: but no Tannerite residue was identified in the New Jersey bomb remnants
column3: in which a black powder was detected
column4: said the official
column5: who wasn't authorized to comment on an ongoing investigation and spoke to the AP on condition of anonymity.

column1: The pipe bomb exploded Saturday in Seaside Park
column2: New Jersey
column3: before a charity 5K race to benefit Marines and sailors. The race was canceled and no one was injured.

column1: The bombings in New York City and New Jersey happened the same day that a man stabbed and injured nine people at a Minnesota mall before an off-duty police officer fatally shot him. The St. Cloud police chief said the man reportedly made at least one reference to Allah and asked a victim if he or she was Muslim before attacking. The Islamic State group has claimed responsibility.

column2: Obama said at a DNC fundraiser in New York City. ""And it still troubles us in a lot of ways

150	"7.8k SHARES SHARE THIS STORY
A ninety-six-year-old World War II veteran and longtime New Yorker contributor Roger Angell has voted in eighteen elections. As he prepares to vote in his nineteenth
column2: he has published an op-ed in which he shares his wisdom and experience – and sends a dire warning to the American people.

column1: This man
column2: who has lived through the most dangerous threats to ever face our nation
column3: including the prospect of nuclear Armageddon
column4: believes that the election of Republican nominee Donald Trump would be a catastrophe on the same level:

column1: “My country faces a danger unmatched in our history since the Cuban missile crisis
column3: or perhaps since 1943
column4: when the Axis powers held most of Continental Europe
column5: and Imperial Japan controlled the Pacific Rim
column6: from the Aleutians to the Solomon Islands
column7: with the outcome of that war still unknown. “

column1: Angell acknowledges Trump’s long history of outrageously offensive statements but chooses to focus on the one closest to his heart: military service and the lessons of the Second World War
column2: the most destructive conflict humanity has ever fought.

column1: “I stick at a different moment—the lighthearted comment he made when
column2: in early August
column3: an admiring veteran presented him with a replica of his Purple Heart and Mr. Trump said
column4: “I always wanted to get the Purple Heart. This was much easier.” Mr. Trump is saying he wishes that he had joined the armed forces somehow (he had a chance but skimmed out
column5: like so many others of his time) and then had died or been scarred or maimed in combat? This is the dream of a nine-year-old boy
column6: and it impugns the five hundred thousand young Americans who have died in combat in my lifetime
column7: and the many hundreds of thousands more whose lives were altered or shattered by their wounds of war. I take this personally
column8: representing as I do the last sliver of the sixteen million Americans who served in the military in my war…I experienced the loss of more than twenty close friends
column9: classmates
column10: and companions of my youth
column11: who remain young and fresh in memory. I have named them in previous pieces
column12: along with some wounded survivors
column13: like my friend Gardner
column14: an infantry captain who landed at Normandy Beach and fought at Hürtgen Forest and Aachen and the Battle of the Bulge
column15: was twice wounded…my late brother-in-law Neil
column16: who lay wounded on the field for two days during the battle of Belfort Gap
column17: and who hobbled with a cane all his life
column18: and with two canes near the end. Every American of my generation can supply stories like these
column19: and once learned and tried to forget that
column21: seventy million people died in our war.

column1: Far too many people have forgotten the lessons of that dreadful conflict – or never learned them at all
column2: as in Trump’s case. Trump is a selfish coward at his core; a draft-dodger who then had the nerve to compare his promiscuity with the sacrifices of the hundreds of thousands of young Americans who perished in the jungles of Vietnam
column3: a man who mocks war heroes and insults the families of our slain warriors
column4: a man who uses our veterans for cheap propaganda stunts and tosses them aside once they’ve served their purpose.

column1: Trump is uniquely ill-suited for the presidency
column2: a man enslaved by his ego and devoid of principle – negatives that deeply disturb Mr. Angell.

column1: “Mr. Trump is endlessly on record as someone who will not back down
column2: who cannot appear to pause or lose. He is a man who must win
column3: stay on the attack
column4: and who thinks
column5: first and last
column6: “How will I look?” This is central
column7: and what comes after it
column8: for me
column9: at times
column10: is concern for what it must be like for anyone who
column11: facing an imperative as dark and unforgiving as this
column12: finds only the narcissist’s mirror for reassurance.”

column1: On the other hand
column2: Mr. Angell has glowing praise for Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton
column3: a woman who has spent her entire life in public service
column4: who has shown time and time again that she has a backbone of steel and is up to the pressures of the Presidency:

column1: I will cast my own vote for Hillary Clinton with alacrity and confidence. From the beginning
column2: her life has been devoted to public service and to improving the lives of children and the disadvantaged. She is intelligent
column3: strong
column4: profoundly informed
column5: and extraordinarily experienced in the challenges and risks of our lurching
column6: restlessly altering world and wholly committed to the global commonality. Her well-established connections to minorities may bring some better understanding of our urban and suburban police crisis. Ms. Clinton will make a strong and resolute President—at last
column7: a female leader of our own—and
column8: in the end
column9: perhaps a unifying one.

column1: He saves his best criticism for the end
column2: however
column3: as he nervously ponders what a President Trump might be responding to an ordinary day in the White House:

column1: “If Donald Trump wins this election
column2: his nights in the White House will very soon resemble those of President Obama. A new day is arriving
column3: and with it the latest rush of bad news—another police shooting out West
column4: another suicide bomber in Yemen
column5: and other urgent briefings from a world already caught up in the morning’s difficult events. He needs to respond
column6: but the beginning of this President’s response is always reliably at hand: How will I look?”

column1: We absolutely cannot elect a President that will put his own public image above the needs of the American people.

column5: is “a decoration” with limited English-speaking skills.

column1: In an interview with Cosmopolitan magazine published Tuesday
column2: Machado drew a clear line between her own immigration story and that of Melania Trump. Both women are former models
column3: but Machado attacked Melania Trump for failing to do more to help those around her as the wife of a prominent political figure.

column1: Story Continued Below
“I think I speak more English than her
column2: ” Machado said. “I don’t see anything about this girl. She’s a doll. She’s a decoration. That is how I see her.”

column1: Donald Trump was harshly critical of Machado during her tenure as Miss Universe
column2: calling her Miss Piggy and Miss Housekeeping
column3: the latter a reference to her Hispanic heritage. Machado told Cosmopolitan that those remarks triggered a relapse of her bulimia that took several years to escape.

column1: Machado
column2: who was also crowned Miss Venezuela

column6: and

column9: and it was a real problem. We had a real problem. Not only that
column10: her attitude

column13: and found the girl and talked about her like she was Mother Teresa
column14: and it wasn’t quite that way
column15: but that’s OK. Hillary has to do what she has to do.”

Soloway joined a chorus of criticism of the Republican presidential nominee during the awards show

(CNN) One of the big winners at the Emmys on Sunday night delivered some of the harshest criticism of Donald Trump offstage -- comparing the Republican presidential nominee to Adolf Hitler and warning against what she said were efforts to ""otherize"" groups of people.
Jill Soloway
column2: creator of Amazon's ""Transparent"" and winner in the comedy series directing category
column3: spoke to ""Variety"" backstage during the awards show
column4: where she lit into Trump.

column1: Jews were other-ized in Nazi Germany to gain political power for Hitler
column2: and right now Donald Trump is doing the same thing. He's other-izing people. He calls women pigs if they don't look like beauty pageant contestants. He blames Muslims and Mexicans for our problems. He makes fun of disabled people. This is other-izing with a capital 'O
column3: '"" Soloway said.

column1: Jill Soloway accepts Outstanding Directing for a Comedy Series award for 'Transparent' onstage during the 67th Annual Primetime Emmy Awards.

column4: I will.""

column1: CNN has reached out to Trump campaign for comment and not yet received a response.

column1: 155	"Story highlights Ahmad Khan Raham is alleged to have carried out the bombings
Some have said he should be tried as an ""enemy combatant"" rather than a US citizen
(CNN) The arrest of Ahmad Khan Rahami
column2: the man suspected of Saturday's bombing in New York and explosion in New Jersey
column3: is reviving a debate that's become familiar when American citizens are implicated in terrorism post-9/11: Whether or not they can be considered enemy combatants.

column1: Sen. Lindsey Graham
column2: R-South Carolina
column3: and others have suggested that Rahami be detained by the military as an enemy combatant
column4: in part so he would not have be read his Miranda rights.

column1: Here are five common questions about terrorism suspects and the legal system:
1) Do U.S.-citizen terrorism suspects arrested within the United States have constitutional protections in the first place?
Yes. There are ongoing debates over the constitutional rights of non-citizens (and citizens traveling overseas)
column2: but the Supreme Court has never suggested that a US citizen arrested within the United States receives lesser constitutional protection simply because he's a terrorism suspect.

156	"Glenn Beck shares buyer's remorse on Cruz endorsement
Glenn Beck
column2: a former Ted Cruz surrogate
column3: suggested Monday that he’d have been better off backing Marco Rubio in the Republican presidential primary and laced into the Texas senator for throwing his support behind Donald Trump late last week.

column1: “For the very first time
column2: I heard Ted Cruz calculate
column3: and when that happened
column4: the whole thing fell apart for me
column5: and it’s my fault
column6: ” Beck said on his radio show.

column1: Story Continued Below
“It’s my fault
column2: ” Beck continued. “I should have said: ‘You know who can win? You know who could beat Hillary Clinton? Marco Rubio
column3: and I disagree with him on the Gang of Eight
column4: and there’s about 80 percent that I do agree with him on
column5: and he’s kind of a politician
column6: but he’s a different kind of politician. He’s a young politician. He’s a Hispanic
column7: He can win. Let’s go for it.’""

column1: Instead
column2: Beck sought “a truly honorable man” in Cruz — “and that will always let you down
column3: ” he said. But while lamenting the fact that Cruz chose to be a politician Friday
column4: Beck said that he believes the Texas firebrand is still a good man.

column1: “I’m not gonna condemn him. He is still
column2: I believe
column3: a good man
column4: ” Beck said. “He is just a politician first. I’ve never put him into the category of a politician
column5: and that’s my fault. He is a politician.”

column1: For his part
column2: Cruz insisted to Beck Monday that he was trying to show the Trump campaign how to earn his vote with his floor speech at the Republican National Convention in which he encouraged Republicans to vote their conscience in November.

column1: After Beck noted that Cruz failed to answer a question this past weekend about whether the real estate mogul was fit to be president
column2: the senator explained that the presidential election is a binary choice
column3: a conclusion he reached after whittling down five possible options (Vote for Trump
column4: for Clinton
column5: a third-party candidate
column6: write in a candidate or abstain).

column1: “So a man who has principles who says there are lines I will not cross — it’s still a binary choice
column2: so a man who you cannot come on and say
column3: ‘Yes
column4: Glenn
column5: he is fit to be president of the United States
column6: ’ I still am encouraged by you to abandon my principles and vote because it’s a binary choice?” Beck asked.

column1: “You are encouraged by me to do what you believe is right and honorable in principle
column2: ” Cruz shot back
column3: warning of the damage he said Clinton would do to America.

column1: Beck
column2: however
column3: wasn’t satisfied. “This is information that you had in Cleveland — and hang on just a second before you respond — you had all of this information. You had this information the day you dropped out of the race and said that Donald Trump is a sociopathic liar
column4: ” Beck said. “So you had all this information. Have you spent an enormous amount of time with Donald Trump? Do you have new information that has made you say: ‘Oh
column5: my gosh
column6: he’s now not a sociopathic liar. He is not the guy I very eloquently spelled out for over a year
column7: and now suddenly there’s a reason to believe him.’”

column1: Despite his “significant disagreements” with Trump
column2: Cruz said
column3: it’s a binary choice.

column1: “I’m asking for new information. I’m asking you for new information
column2: ” Beck said. “You knew all the things that you’re saying today. The time to do that would have been the day you pulled out or the day that you gave the speech so eloquently. Why now? What’s new?”

column1: Cruz pointed to the Trump campaign’s release of possible conservative Supreme Court nominees
column2: a list that includes Cruz ally Utah Sen. Mike Lee. He suggested he had a hand in the list
column3: noting that the Supreme Court was an issue he raised with vice presidential nominee Mike Pence when he asked the Texas senator what it would take to get him on board.

column1: “We discussed the Supreme Court as being one of the great checks protecting the Constitution and the rule of law
column2: and the Trump campaign committing to nominate from that list was an important change that gave me significant reassurance that helped me get to the point of saying yes
column3: ” Cruz said.

column1: After Stu Burguiere pressed Cruz on why he would believe anything Trump says
column2: he rattled off a series of principles at stake. “Now
column3: with respect to the justices Donald Trump would nominate
column4: I know that he is publicly committing to nominate from a list that is very strong
column5: and if he were to nominate from that list
column6: it would be a major step towards protecting our rights
column7: ” Cruz said. “I hope that he would follow through on that commitment. One never knows if one will
column8: but the fact that he is public promising ‘I will nominate from these 21
column9: ’ I think creates a dynamic where
column10: compared to Hillary
column11: who is promising to put left-wing ideologues
column12: that’s a clear choice.”

column1: Cruz also disagreed with the wide interpretation that his RNC remarks were a swipe against Trump
column2: adding that he’s always been “Never Hillary” but not ever “Never Trump.” He also said he gleaned parts of his speech from what Ronald Reagan said about Gerald Ford and what Ted Kennedy said about Jimmy Carter.

column1: “My speech drew deliberately from both of those speeches
column2: ” Cruz said. “Both of those speeches at the time were treated effectively as endorsement speeches. One of the unfortunate things about the reaction is Cleveland is that for many who were watching
column3: it was perceived that I was essentially embracing Never Trump. I have never been a Never Trumper.”

column1: After Cruz’s appearance
column2: Beck said Cruz would have been better of just telling the truth about why he backed Trump. “He could have come on and said
column3: ‘Look
column4: guys
column5: here’s the thing
column6: my supporters are yelling at me
column7: ’ and I know that
column8: because so are mine
column9: ” he said. “’My donors
column10: who are all in with the GOP
column11: they’re all saying I’ll never fund — I won’t fund you for the Senate. I won’t fund you for the run in 2020. And I have to make a decision. So the question is do I completely shut myself out of this game or do I play the game as much as I possibly can?’”

157	"Washington (CNN) Hillary Clinton is leading Donald Trump by 6 points ahead of the first debate on Monday
column2: according to a new national poll released Wednesday.

column1: A four-way matchup shows Clinton has 43% support of likely voters while Trump has 37%
column2: in the new NBC/Wall Street Journal poll . Libertarian Party nominee Gary Johnson is at 9% and the Green Party's Jill Stein is at 3%.

column1: In a two-way matchup
column2: Clinton leads Trump by 7 points

column1: The poll was conducted after a rough patch for Clinton
column2: highlighted by her temporarily leaving the campaign trail after she was diagnosed with pneumonia.

column1: Despite a recent effort to court African-American voters
column2: Trump garners just 7% support compared to Clinton's 81% with the voting bloc.

column1: On the issues
column2: Trump has the advantage with voters when it comes to the economy -- 46% to 41%. But Clinton leads when it comes to being in charge of nuclear weapons (51% to 25%)
column3: being a good commander in chief (48% to 33%) and on immigration (50% to 39%). Trump and Clinton are virtually tied when it comes to terrorism and homeland security (44% to 43%).

column1: A new CNN Poll of Polls
column2: including the NBC/WSJ data
column3: finds Clinton's edge over Trump has inched up by 1 point. The Poll of Polls averages the results of the five most recent nationwide telephone polls of presidential preference among likely voters and finds her ahead
