column1: 159	"Charlotte-Mecklenburg Police Chief Kerr Putney said earlier in the week that he did not plan to release his department’s video of the shooting
column2: although he has allowed the victim’s family and attorneys to view it. | AP Photo Clinton demands Charlotte police video release 'without delay'

column1: Hillary Clinton called on authorities in Charlotte
column2: North Carolina
column3: on Friday to release the police video showing shooting of Keith Scott ""without delay.""

column1: The former of secretary of state
column2: who made reforming the criminal justice system an early centerpiece of her campaign
column3: wrote that ""we must ensure justice & work to bridge divides."" The post was signed with her initial
column4: H
column5: indicating that the post was written personally by Clinton.

column1: Story Continued Below
Cell phone video showing the shooting released Friday by NBC News and The New York Times does not conclusively show whether the victim was armed when police officers shot him.
The video
column2: recorded by Scott’s wife Rakeyia Scott
column3: does not show him being shot although the sound of gunshots is audible. Keith Scott is not clearly visible in the video until after he has been shot
column4: when officers surround his body lying on the pavement.

column1: Charlotte police said Keith Scott was holding a gun when officers shot him outside of his apartment on Tuesday. In the video
column2: released by the victim’s family
column3: police officers are heard yelling at Keith Scott to “drop the gun” while his wife shouts “he has no weapon” and “he has no gun.”

column1: Attorneys for the family have said that Keith Scott was not holding a gun when he was shot
column2: although police have said they recovered a firearm and photos from the scene appear to show one lying next to the victim’s body.

column1: The video offers a different perspective from the dashboard camera and body camera footage that also captured the shooting but has not yet been released. Charlotte-Mecklenburg Police Chief Kerr Putney said Thursday that he did not plan to release his department’s video of the shooting
column2: although he has allowed the victim’s family and attorneys to view it.

column1: Keith Scott’s shooting by police
column2: along with that of another black man
column3: Terence Crutcher
column4: in Tulsa
column5: Oklahoma
column6: has prompted demonstrations nationwide. In Charlotte
column7: those protests grew violent Wednesday night into Thursday morning
column8: prompting North Carolina Gov. Pat McCrory to declare a state of emergency. With National Guard troops looking on and a midnight curfew in effect
column9: protests Thursday night were mostly peaceful.

160	"When Hillary Clinton attacked Donald Trump for not releasing his tax returns and allegedly paying zero in federal income taxes
column2: the Republican presidential nominee had just four words to say in response.

column1: “That makes me smart
column2: ” Trump said from the debate stage at Hofstra University tonight.

column1: He has said repeatedly he is being audited by the IRS and cannot release his tax statements until the review is concluded. But during the first general-election presidential debate
column2: in Hempstead
column3: New York
column4: the real estate mogul vowed to release his tax returns “against my lawyer’s wishes” if Clinton releases emails she deleted from a private server she used while she was secretary of state.

column1: “As soon as she releases her 33
column2: 000 e-mails that have been deleted
column3: as soon as she releases them
column4: ” Trump said tonight
column5: amid cheers and applause
column6: “I will release my tax returns.”

column1: The White House hopefuls also clashed repeatedly over their tax plans during the debate
column2: with Clinton accusing Trump of proposing the “most extreme version” of “trickle-down economics.”

column1: “The biggest tax cuts for the top percent of the people in county than we’ve ever had
column2: ” the Democratic presidential nominee said from the stage. “I call it trumped-up trickle-down because that’s exactly what it would be. That is not how we grow the economy.”

column1: Before Trump had a chance to defend his tax policy
column2: Clinton took another jab.

column1: “Donald was very fortunate in his life and that's all to his benefit
column2: ” she continued. “He started his business with $14 million
column3: borrowed from his father
column4: and he really believes that the more you help wealthy people
column5: the better off we'll be and that everything will work out from there. I don't buy that.”

column1: Trump
column2: who released his tax plan earlier this month
column3: has proposed tax cuts across the board
column4: including income tax reductions for the top 1 percent and eliminating federal estate tax as well as gift taxes.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Clinton has called for tax hikes for the wealthiest Americans and closing corporate loopholes that allow the rich to evade some tariffs.

column1: Trump fired back
column2: blaming “politicians like Secretary Clinton” for plunging the nation into debt.

column1: “We’re a debtor nation
column2: ” he said. “We have a country that needs new roads
column3: new tunnels
column4: new bridges
column5: new airports
column6: new schools
column7: new hospitals. And we don’t have the money because it’s been squandered on so many of your ideas.”

column1: Clinton suggested that Trump’s alleged failure to pay federal income tax might also be part of the problem. But Trump quickly argued any taxes he would have paid would have gone to waste.
“It would be squandered too
column2: believe me
column3: ” he said.

column1: 161	"Sen. Chuck Schumer’s money could give Democrats some breathing room as they slash expensive ad buys in Florida and Ohio. | Getty Schumer transfers millions to Dems in bid for Senate takeover
Chuck Schumer is sitting on a mountain of cash. And now he’s starting to dole it out to fellow Democrats who might make him majority leader.
The New York senator is transferring $1 million to the Senate Democrats’ campaign arm on Tuesday. He’s also given $3.2 million to state parties over the past week
column2: Democratic sources said.

column1: Story Continued Below
Earlier this month
column2: Schumer shifted an additional $2 million from his campaign war chest to the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee. Altogether in September
column3: Schumer has transferred $6.2 million of the $27 million he has on hand to help Democratic hopefuls.

column1: Republicans control 54 seats
column2: but Democrats are favored to win three back
column3: so control of the chamber is seen as a toss-up. As the party begins making difficult decisions about where to spend and where to cut
column4: a significant transfer from Schumer could go a long way.

column1: “The Kochs do not have a finite amount of money
column2: they have unlimited money. We have a finite amount of money
column3: ” said Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) in an interview on Monday. “We’re just trying to allocate our resources so they’re meaningful to us and our candidates.”

column1: Schumer’s money could give Democrats some breathing room as they slash expensive ad buys in Florida and Ohio and eye instead cheaper races in North Carolina and Missouri. No one has more to gain from a Democratic takeover of the Senate than Schumer
column2: who will ascend to the leader job in 2017 as Reid retires after a 12-year stint as party head.

column1: Schumer’s donation is both a vote of confidence in his party’s candidates and a reflection of Democrats’ future challenges. Democrats are defending 25 seats in 2018 compared with just eight GOP seats
column2: so if Democrats come up short in November they are unlikely to take back the majority this decade.

column1: Schumer has also raised $2 million directly for candidates’ committees
column2: and a joint account that he leads has collected $800
column3: 000 combined for the DSCC and individual candidates. He’s planning a fall event in New York to benefit Senate candidates that’s projected to bring in “upwards of another million
column4: ” according to a person close to the New York senator.

column1: “Schumer has been relentless
column2: ” said a DSCC official.

column1: Schumer and Reid have also appeared at numerous events for Senate Majority PAC
column2: a super PAC backing Democratic Senate hopefuls run by former aides to Reid
column3: including his onetime chief of staff
column4: Susan McCue. The group
column5: which can accept unlimited donations from donors
column6: has spent more than $30 million this cycle. Democrats complain that Republican super PACs have far outspent them.

column1: “Leader Reid and Senator Schumer are working around the clock to raise awareness about the avalanche of money Republicans are pouring into Senate races through independent expenditures. The amounts are staggering
column2: ” McCue said in a statement.

column1: Schumer still will have roughly $20 million on hand after the transfer. He is up for reelection in New York
column2: with the latest polls showing him trouncing his GOP challenger by more than 40 points. However
column3: if past is prologue
column4: Schumer is likely to spend some money on it despite token opposition.

column1: Schumer spent about $13 million in 2010
column2: but that was a historically bad year for Democrats. Schumer’s colleagues won’t rule out the possibility that he’ll donate more to his party’s Senate takeover effort.

column1: “If he thinks it will make a difference
column2: he’ll do it. He’s very calculating
column3: ” said a Democratic senator. “Chuck will be there if you need him.”

column1: Sen. Debbie Stabenow (D-Mich.)
column2: a close ally of Schumer
column3: agreed that the presumptive Democratic leader might provide more.

column1: “He’s going to watch everything closely. It’s my sense he’s 1
column2: 000 percent committed to taking back the Senate
column3: ” Stabenow said.

column1: There’s no decision yet on where the DSCC might allocate the additional money from Schumer. It could go toward races in New Hampshire
column2: Pennsylvania or Nevada
column3: states that are all exceedingly close
column4: or help compete in pricey Florida. Using the cash in red-leaning states is another option.

column1: “We’re going to make some tough decisions
column2: which haven’t been made yet
column3: ” Reid said.

column1: The National Republican Senatorial Committee has been outraised by the DSCC to the tune of $36 million. Outside groups like the Senate Leadership Fund are making up the difference
column2: but Republican officials are leaning on their rank and file to help fill the campaign coffers
column3: with McConnell coming up with nearly $4 million in transfers thus far. Sen. John Thune (R-S.D.) made a big splash with a $2 million transfer
column4: but even though he has millions more on hand
column5: Thune said he’ll need to hang on to the rest of his cash.

column1: “I don’t think I can probably keep pace with Schumer
column2: ” Thune said in an interview.

column1: Republicans are now trying to wring every last bit out of their members
column2: after Sen. Richard Shelby of Alabama spurned transferring any of his $10 million. Now the GOP hopes that NRSC Vice Chairs Dean Heller of Nevada and Tom Cotton of Arkansas may make a last-minute transfer. They have yet to give money directly to the group
column3: GOP sources said
column4: though they have helped raise funds directly for the NRSC. The third vice chair Joni Ernst of Iowa gave last week
column5: an aide said Tuesday morning.

column1: Republicans
column2: however
column3: simply don’t have their own Chuck Schumer. Instead
column4: they are relying on a tightening presidential race
column5: deep-pocketed outside groups and candidates who are running far ahead of Trump to eke out a win.

column1: “He’s a machine
column2: ” Senate Majority Whip John Cornyn of Texas said of Schumer
column3: his workout partner. But “it may not make a difference
column4: ” the Texan added.

column1: 163	"On Monday
column2: Donald Trump fulfilled his duty as a presidential candidate by praising law enforcement for catching Ahmad Khan Rahami
column3: who was responsible for the Saturday bombing in New York City.

column1: This would have normally been a nice gesture
column2: if it hadn’t been a contradiction of something Trump had said just a few minutes before. Fortunately
column3: whenever Trump flip-flops or lies
column4: Americans are able to instantly respond and call him out on his bullsh*t via social media – and they didn’t hesitate to remind Trump that just a few minutes before he congratulated law enforcement for Rahami’s capture
column5: he’d dissed the NYPD for allowing “political correctness” to interfere with catching terrorists. Among the first to point this out was MSNBC’s Christopher Hayes
column6: who tweeted:

column1: Hayes was referring to a disrespectful comment Trump had made on Fox and Friends shortly before he congratulated the police officers
column2: in which he said:

column1: “You know
column2: our police are amazing
column3: our local police. They know who a lot of these people are
column4: they are afraid to do anything about it
column5: because they don’t want to be accused of profiling
column6: and they don’t want to be accused of all sorts of things.”

column1: Yup – Trump had accused the NYPD of being cowards and knowing who terrorists are
column2: yet he has the nerve to congratulate them in almost the same time frame. Other people recognized this epic fail as well
column3: and blasted the Republican nominee for being so untrustworthy and two-faced:

column1: This tweet was particularly funny
column2: and I’m sure there will be some backlash for Trump to deal with:

column1: Throughout his presidential campaign
column2: Trump has defended law enforcement far more fiercely than African American police brutality victims to help paint the picture that he is a “law and order” candidate. But thanks to his asinine comments about law enforcement having blood on their hands by assisting terrorists
column3: Trump has probably just ruined a year of pro-law enforcement campaigning.

column1: 165	"An Ohio judge ordered an attorney jailed for five days after she refused to remove a Black Lives Matter pin she wore to court. The lawyer is appealing the case.
Attorney Andrea Burton of Youngstown
column2: Ohio
column3: was charged with contempt of court and given a five-day jail sentence on July 22 after she refused to take off the pin at Judge Robert Milich's request
column4: the New York Daily News reported.

column1: The judge reportedly called Burton
column2: who was representing a client at the time
column3: into his chambers and spoke privately to her about the matter. When the lawyer continued to wear the pin
column4: he adjourned the proceedings and ordered her to be held on a contempt charge.

column1: Milich told WKBN he made his ruling based on Supreme Court precedent that allows judges to prohibit political expression in courtrooms.
Popular Video This young teenage singer was shocked when Keith Urban invited her on stage at his concert. A few moments later
column2: he made her wildest dreams come true.

column1: “There’s a difference between a flag
column2: a pin from your church or the Eagles and having a pin that’s on a political issue
column3: ” Milich said.

column1: The judge claimed his decision was not influenced by his own personal views.
A judge doesn't support either side
column2: he told WKBN. ""A judge is objective and tries to make sure everyone has an opportunity to have a fair hearing
column3: and it was a situation where it was just in violation of the law.""

column1: Burton has been released pending an appeal on the condition that she refrain from wearing any items that make a political statement in court. If she loses the appeal
column2: she will have to serve five days in jail.

column1: Popular Video This young teenage singer was shocked when Keith Urban invited her on stage at his concert. A few moments later
column2: he made her wildest dreams come true:

column1: The attorney told New York Daily News that her constitutional right to free speech superseded Supreme Court case law and the judge's discretion.
“It's an act of civil disobedience
column2: I understand that
column3: Burton told NY Daily News. ""I’m not anti-police
column4: I work with law enforcement and I hold them in the highest regard
column5: and just to say for the record I do believe all lives matter. But at this point they don’t all matter equally
column6: and that’s the problem in the justice system.""

column1: Mike Brickner
column2: the senior policy director of the American Civil Liberties Union of Ohio
column3: said that judges are generally given a wide latitude in what they allow or don't allow in the courtroom
column4: although their decisions must be reasonable and fairly applied.

column1: There have been cases in the past when people have been given contempt of court for refusing to comply with a judge's order to remove an article of clothing that may have a message on it
column2: Brickner wrote in a July 22 email to WKBN. column1: 167	"UK Begins Construction On “Great Wall” – Meant to Keep Illegal Migrants OUT (VIDEO)
The United Kingdom began construction on what is being called their “great wall” near the border at Calais
column2: France. The wall is being built to prevent illegal migrants from jumping onto vehicles preparing to cross the English Channel. The wall will cost an estimated two million pounds — about $2.5 million — and will be approximately 13 feet high.

column1: There is a nearby migrant camp called “the Jungle” that has been attacking vehicles in an attempt to climb aboard lorries and cars in order to enter the United Kingdom. The wall will be made out of concrete
column2: which is more difficult to climb and will be extended by fences.

column1: 168	"As my 25th wedding anniversary approached
column2: I tried to be creative in buying gifts for my wife. I had the idea of a silver coin that marked 25 years of something or other. I went to a local coin shop
column3: and as I idled over some of the display cases
column4: I noticed a set of coins from the mid-19th century. Oddly
column5: the coins from the 1840s and 1850s were large—up until 1857
column6: when the coins started becoming
column7: at best
column8: half the size of the others.

column1: “Oh
column2: the Panic of 1857
column3: ” the owner said when I asked him about the change of size. “It was really bad. The president didn’t seem to have any solution except to use less gold or silver in the coins.”

column1: Story Continued Below
Now that is inept presidential decision-making. During the current election campaign
column2: there has been a lot of gnashing of teeth over the possibility that—whoever the winner is—he or she will be so terrible as a leader they will bring down the republic as the worst president since independence. And before the current candidates were known
column3: the two most recent White House occupants
column4: Barack Obama and George W. Bush
column5: have been consistently reviled by their detractors as the worst men to lead the country.

column1: But Obama and Bush can both take heart. And Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton can gain solace
column2: perhaps
column3: from knowing that no matter how badly they do
column4: they almost certainly won’t rank last. By my reckoning
column5: that place belongs to James Buchanan
column6: genial a man though he was. I’ve made quite a study of him. My innocent encounter at the coin shop only reinforced my lifelong determination to take an offbeat look at
column7: let’s say
column8: the lesser presidents. My father was definitely the only one in our suburban neighborhood with a biography of Franklin Pierce. Everywhere we went
column9: he forced me to read historical plaques—stopping the car in a shrieking halt at times to view them. If I were to write a book about a president
column10: it surely wouldn’t be about Washington or Lincoln
column11: or even Silent Cal Coolidge. It would have to be about someone as ineffectual as possible.

column1: Buchanan
column2: the only president from my native state
column3: Pennsylvania
column4: turned out to be my man.

column1: Start with his anemic
column2: minimalist solution to one of America’s great financial downturns.

column1: For a long time before Buchanan
column2: in effect
column3: precipitated the Panic of 1857
column4: things were going well for the country
column5: at least in an economic sense. There had been a bad downturn 20 years before
column6: with multiple causes
column7: like war in Europe
column8: the dissolution of the Bank of the United States
column9: and overspeculation in
column10: oddly enough
column11: slaves and Western land. The great acquisition of land under President James Knox Polk
column12: from Oregon to California to Texas
column13: reinvigorated the economy
column14: and a boom lasted for the next two decades. Railroads were the big player
column15: since so many people wanted to move West into the new territories and states. Manufacturing boomed domestically
column16: and then with foreign trade as well
column17: since Europe had quelled many of its hostilities and American items were cheaper than those on the Continent.

column1: Then the day before Buchanan took office
column2: Congress passed what he wanted
column3: the Tariff Bill of 1857
column4: which lowered tariffs on a panoply of items from abroad—Buchanan wanted to stimulate foreign trade—but made American manufactured goods of the same sort less competitive.

column1: Three days later came the real fatal blow
column2: though
column3: the Dred Scott Supreme Court decision
column4: which fell on the shoulders of Buchanan. The case had wound through state and federal courts for at least a decade
column5: but Roger Taney
column6: the Supreme Court chief justice
column7: and a fellow alumnus
column8: with Buchanan
column9: of small Dickinson College
column10: wanted it settled.

column1: Scott was a slave to a military man who at times was stationed not in his native Missouri
column2: a slave state
column3: but in the Northwest Territories
column4: which were nonslave. After his master died
column5: Scott brought the case that he should be free because he had lived in nonslave territory. Buchanan wanted to be a hero
column6: and thought if the case could be decided broadly
column7: it could settle the question of slavery in the Union for good.

column1: Buchanan knew
column2: too
column3: though
column4: that the court had five Southerners and four Northerners
column5: and if the decision were split that way
column6: it would be ineffective. He and Taney had apparently agreed to have a narrower decision
column7: or remand the case back to the Appeals Court
column8: if it were merely sectional
column9: since they felt the need to have some sort of bipartisanship for the decision to be legitimate.

column1: Ignoring the idea of separation of powers
column2: though
column3: Buchanan browbeat Robert Cooper Grier
column4: another Dickinson alumnus and a justice from Pennsylvania
column5: to go along with the majority opinion
column6: which Taney would write. Eventually
column7: a New York native
column8: Justice Samuel Nelson
column9: wrote a concurring opinion
column10: making the vote even less sectional.

column1: Legend has it that Taney
column2: on the Capitol stairs just before he gave Buchanan the oath of office at the inauguration
column3: told Buchanan that the decision would become public in the next few days. Buchanan apparently changed his speech to indicate that—and that he would be all for whatever the court decided.

column1: Two days later
column2: the decision came down. Taney castigated Scott
column3: whom he said was not a citizen
column4: being a slave
column5: and thus could not bring any suit. He also wrote that the Constitution gave no state or territory the power to institute or
column6: conversely
column7: prohibit slavery. Thus all the compromises about it
column8: going back to the 1820s
column9: were invalid
column10: and
column11: in fact
column12: the Fugitive Slave Law
column13: requiring anyone who knew about it to return slaves to their owners anywhere in the country

column1: Historically
column2: experts rate Dred Scott as the worst decision in the court’s history
column3: but short of that
column4: it was at the very least transformational for the country—with not just Taney
column5: but surely Buchanan
column6: responsible for it.

column1: As appalled as most of the country was about the morals of the decision at the time
column2: there was a practical downside
column3: too. Now no one knew whether he or she wanted to go West
column4: to use the railroads
column5: or to start a business that railroads might profit from. Railroad stocks started to decline in value
column6: and then a contagion hit
column7: and it was free fall. By midsummer
column8: no one could take a ride on the Reading
column9: as Uncle Pennybags does in the Monopoly game
column10: since the Reading Railroad had shut down
column11: as did lines now and then famous like the Illinois Central. Several lines
column12: like the Delaware
column13: Lackawanna and Western and the Fond du Lac Railroad in Wisconsin

column1: Thousands were thrown out of work
column2: and banks started foreclosing on loans and property. Senator William Seward
column3: the leader of the new Republican Party
column4: come home from a vacation to find out he had lost most everything he owned—his stock in the Illinois Central
column5: promoted to him by his rival Democrat Stephen Douglas
column6: was virtually worthless.

column1: Every bank in New York City effectively closed—none would convert coins or gold into bank notes. The oldest grain company in New York
column2: N.H. Wolfe and Co.
column3: failed in August
column4: as did the most prominent insurance business in the country
column5: the Ohio Life Insurance and Trust Co.

column1: Buchanan and his administration did nothing to stem the public hysteria. Calm words might have quelled it
column2: but his inaction only made for further runs on banks and
column3: thus
column4: more turmoil in markets.

column1: The residue that mattered most
column2: though
column3: was the reaction caused by Dred Scott. Instead of promoting unity and opening up the West to more settlement
column4: as Buchanan had thought
column5: Dred Scott thwarted it
column6: and brought an end to years of Northern prosperity.

column1: Yet the South did not succumb as badly. Its agrarian culture was self-sustaining
column2: and its cotton still had a market in Europe. There was a surge in arms sales there as well
column3: the economic downturn in the North exacerbating regional tensions. The relative good times in the South caused Northerners of all parties to further blame Buchanan for being a Southern lackey.

column1: Buchanan’s response was underwhelming
column2: almost disdainful. He said the federal government could do nothing. In his Annual Message in December 1857
column3: he said he sympathized with the travails caused by the Panic
column4: but he would do nothing for individual suffering. The government would continue to pay its obligations and would keep going on whatever public works projects it had started
column5: but would begin no new ones. He said too many people had speculated in land and slaves and the like and “deserved the gambler’s fate.” Eventually
column6: he noted
column7: the youth and energy of the rugged American individuals would triumph
column8: though there would clearly be an interim of rough times.

column1: In a sense
column2: he was right
column3: because it took the rugged young Americans who went to war in 1861 to bring the economy back.

column1: Throughout his term
column2: when a fork appeared in the road
column3: Buchanan managed to take the wrong turn. When hostilities flared in Kansas
column4: over whether that territory would enter as a slave or free state
column5: Buchanan wavered over which of two proposed constitutions would be valid
column6: exacerbating the killings
column7: some done by the wild-eyed anti-slavery radical John Brown. When later Brown seized arms with a small cadre of followers in Harpers Ferry
column8: West Virginia
column9: just 40 miles from Washington along the Potomac
column10: Buchanan again diddled before consulting Robert E. Lee
column11: who had fortuitously been home in Arlington on leave from his post in Texas. Lee quickly went to Harpers Ferry to capture Brown and quell the raid.

column1: In other ventures
column2: though
column3: Buchanan dashed troops out on strange and unproductive missions. He caused chaos in Utah
column4: quelling what he thought to be a Mormon revolt
column5: causing villages to be burned to the ground and dozens of lives lost over what was merely a jurisdictional dispute. He supported mercenary William Walker’s forays to conquer Nicaragua and Guatemala
column6: and sent troops to try to annex parts of Paraguay
column7: primarily to acquiesce to his Southern base that wanted more slave states to come into the union. Then there was the little known Pig War
column8: started when a settler along the Canadian border on the San Juan straits in the Northwest
column9: shot a pig owned by the Hudson Bay Co. that wandered onto his property. A standoff ensued until Buchanan sent troops otherwise guarding Kansas
column10: where there was a real problem
column11: out to calm the nonfatal—except to one pig—battle. This was at a time when there were about only 12
column12: 000 soldiers in the U.S. Army
column13: stretched as thin as could be.

column1: As the election of 1860 came close
column2: Buchanan refused to support the one Democrat who could win
column3: Stephen Douglas
column4: because he just plain didn’t like him. That caused the party to split into three factions
column5: each nominating a candidate
column6: virtually ensuring Republican Abraham Lincoln the election.

column1: The Southern states
column2: which had threatened secession
column3: started doing so during the interim between Lincoln’s election and his inauguration in March
column4: thus under Buchanan’s watch. Buchanan took the unusual position that the Constitution did not allow secession
column5: but the president could not do anything to prevent it.

column1: As the first half-dozen states seceded
column2: Buchanan lost several Cabinet members—he had a lot of Southern allies—and refused entreaties by many
column3: including former President John Tyler
column4: who would himself become a Confederate congressman
column5: to find compromises to bring the wastrel states back into the fold.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Buchanan allowed the seizure of armaments and forts by the seceding states and suggested the abandonment of the one major fortified island in the South
column3: Fort Sumter.

column1: Enter Lincoln
column2: who has long been rated in serious surveys and schoolmarms’ speeches as the greatest of presidents. Lincoln no doubt was a man with plans and savvy
column3: but I contend that the bar was set so low by his predecessor that maybe if there were no James Buchanan
column4: the “Worst. President. Ever
column5: ” there would have been a few notches more on the presidential-rating scale for Abe Lincoln to climb.

column1: Today
column2: George W. Bush is often rated one of the worst presidents in history
column3: thanks to his authorship of the Iraq War and his presiding over the Crash of ’08 and the beginning of the Great Recession. Obama is sometimes seen in the same light
column4: especially by the far right. But as happened with Honest Abe and his predecessor
column5: perhaps that low bar will only make it easier for a President Hillary Clinton or a President Donald Trump to shine.

column1: Robert Strauss is author of the forthcoming Worst. President. Ever.: James Buchanan
column2: the POTUS Rating Game
column3: and the Legacy of the Least of the Lesser Presidents."	25th wedding anniversary approached tried creative buying gifts for wife had the idea silver coin that marked years something other went column2: New York (CNN) Hillary Clinton's economic speech on Wednesday in Orlando will focus on how the United States can create an economy that values people with disabilities

Arina Koltsova
column3: was arresting a man on New Year’s Day when the suspect spat in her face
column4: the Daily Mail reported. She didn’t know the man had tuberculosis at the time.

column1: Koltsova went untreated for some time until she collapsed at work one day. She was then diagnosed with tuberculosis and started treatment.
Popular Video This young teenage singer was shocked when Keith Urban invited her on stage at his concert. A few moments later
column2: he made her wildest dreams come true.

column1: “She became ill after New Year's Day
column2: ” Her on-duty partner
column3: Officer Mikhail Kindrakevich
column4: told the Daily Mail. “She had arrested this guy and he spat in her face. Some time later she collapsed. She had received treatment. She underwent chemotherapy
column5: she was fed food through an IV drip and she had lost a lot of weight”

column1: Koltsova died on July 25. She was buried in Kiev two days later.
“This is an irreplaceable loss for the whole of Kiev police
column2: fond memories of Arina will remain in our hearts forever
column3: ” Koltsova’s police department wrote on its social media page.

174	"AP Photo McConnell
column2: Pelosi
column3: Ryan seek deal on government funding impasse A total of $170 million for the Flint water crisis is added to the WRDA bill.

column1: Speaker Paul Ryan
column2: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi are trying to hash out an agreement to break an impasse over government funding as the Sept. 30 budget deadline fast approaches.

column1: In a series of three-way discussions on Tuesday night
column2: the trio of party leaders were forging a compromise to extend government funding until Dec. 9. In turn
column3: Republicans would provide an ""iron-clad commitment"" that funding to address the water crisis in Flint
column4: Michigan
column5: will be included in the Water Resources Development Act
column6: which covers hundreds of federal water projects.

column1: Story Continued Below
Late Tuesday
column2: congressional leaders made headway on at least one part of the multi-layered discussions: Pelosi and Ryan agreed to incorporate an amendment to the sweeping waters legislation that would add about $170 million in federal aid for Flint.

column1: The amendment represents a bipartisan agreement between Speaker Ryan and Leader Pelosi to allow germane authorization language to be added to WRDA as an amendment that will
column2: at the end of the day
column3: provide the necessary funding Flint needs in the final WRDA conference report
column4: a Pelosi aide said late Tuesday night. The water resources legislation could head to the House floor as early as Wednesday.

column1: Pelosi and other Democrats had refused to support any continuing resolution
column2: or a CR
column3: to keep the government open without the Flint funding. Ryan
column4: for his part
column5: faced problems rounding up GOP votes for a short-term funding bill.

column1: With Ryan and Pelosi holding direct talks
column2: a deal was expected soon to break the impasse. McConnell and Pelosi had also held discussions on the Flint-WRDA issue
column3: said GOP and Democratic sources. McConnell had been pushing to include Flint funding in the WRDA package. Meanwhile
column4: Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.) had been making his own insistence for Flint aid clear with Republicans.

column1: Earlier
column2: Senate Republicans had been considering stripping Louisiana disaster aid money from the stalled stopgap spending bill
column3: which in theory could have resolved Senate Democratic objections to the legislation and ultimately stave off a government shutdown at the end of the week. That proposal had come after Democrats voted Tuesday to reject the stopgap spending measure — which would keep the government open until Dec. 9 — because the package provides money for Louisiana and other states but did nothing to address Flint.

column1: McConnell had been expected to unveil a revised legislative text with no Louisiana disaster relief
column2: one senior GOP leadership aide said
column3: but any formal action will now wait until Wednesday. The Kentucky Republican floated the idea at a news conference Tuesday shortly before the procedural vote failed 45-55
column4: far short of the 60-vote threshold.

column1: We keep hearing that their position is no Flint
column2: no floods
column3: McConnell said. ""That's certainly an option worth discussing.""

column1: Informed of that comment
column2: Reid told reporters he wanted to see exactly what McConnell would do
column3: and again said Democrats wanted relief for both Louisiana and Flint.

column1: But other Democrats suggested the move would pave the way to a resolution. ""If Louisiana were not in there
column2: it would reduce the profile of disaster aid in this bill. And that would be helpful
column3: ” said Senate Minority Whip Richard Durbin.

column1: “There's still really deep felt feelings by our Michigan senators and many others that this is just fundamentally unfair to the victims in Flint and we don't trust the House to help at all
column2: ” Durbin added.

column1: House Minority Whip Steny Hoyer also said Democrats wanted assistance for victims in both communities
column2: but that they would likely back a so-called continuing resolution that included aid for neither. “I doubt that we would turn that down
column3: ” he told reporters. Hoyer said Democrats would insist the legislation still contain $1.1 billion to combat the Zika virus
column4: which has long been stalled on Capitol Hill. The measure also includes popular provisions to fund veterans programs and implement a July law to curb prescription opioid addiction.

column1: Senate Republicans had argued that the proper place for Flint aid is water infrastructure bill moving through Congress. The Senate passed the Water Resources Development Act
column2: which includes $220 million for Flint and other communities with failing infrastructure
column3: on a 95-3 vote earlier this month.

column1: “Why do you feel as if you have to punish people in Louisiana who are digging out from a flood — sounds kind of crazy
column2: but they have mud in their home they have to dig out — for Flint when there’s a pathway forward on Flint through the WRDA bill?” argued GOP Sen. Bill Cassidy
column3: who has repeatedly pressed the need for flood aid for his home state of Louisiana.

column1: Still
column2: despite vows from some Senate Republicans that Flint aid will be included in any final bill negotiated by the House and Senate in a lame duck session
column3: Democrats had been skeptical.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Democrats also objected to language in the stopgap bill that continues a prohibition on the Securities and Exchange Commission’s ability to require corporate disclosure of political spending. But that provision has been a secondary issue to the fight over Flint.

column1: McConnell and Reid each accused the other of bringing the federal government to the brink of a shutdown
column2: but few think such a politically-damaging scenario would take place just weeks before the presidential election. If the Senate is able to pass a funding bill
column3: the House would be expected to follow suit relatively quickly.

column1: Among the 45 votes in favor of the bill were four Democrats
column2: including those representing conservative leaning states
column3: like Jon Tester of Montana
column4: Joe Manchin of West Virginia and Joe Donnelly of Indiana
column5: as well as Bill Nelson of Florida
column6: where the Zika virus is spreading quickly.

column1: Thirteen Republicans joined most Democrats in voting against the bill
column2: including conservatives Ted Cruz of Texas and Mike Lee of Utah
column3: and South Carolina’s Lindsey Graham. Cruz led a failed fight to include language blocking the Obama administration from relinquishing oversight of the Internet domain system to an international body. Graham promised to oppose the bill because it would not lift financing restrictions on the Export-Import Bank.

column1: Heather Caygle
column2: Rachael Bade and Annie Snider contributed to this story.

176	"Syrian children look down from a window at a convoy of United Nations and Arab Red Crescent vehicles carrying aid in the rebel-held town of Talbisseh on the northern outskirts of Homs on September 19
column2: 2016 | Mahmoud Taha/AFP via Getty Images UN to resume Syria aid deliveries Trucks will roll into the war-wrecked country ‘as soon as possible.’

column1: The United Nations will resume efforts to deliver aid to besieged areas in Syria after halting all convoys at the Turkish border following an airstrike on its vehicles
column2: heading to the opposition-controlled part of Aleppo earlier this week
column3: the BBC reported Thursday.

column1: Trucks will roll into the war-wracked country “as soon as possible
column2: ” according to the U.N.’s Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs
column3: but will avoid the opposition-controlled Aleppo because it has been under heavy bombardment.

column1: U.S. officials blamed two Russian aircraft for Monday’s attack on the U.N. aid convoy. Russia denied its aircraft were operating in the area at the time and suggested the U.S. was behind the attack
column2: claiming a U.S. Predator drone was in the area when the vehicles
column3: carrying desperately needed supplies to people under siege
column4: were struck.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: officials are scrambling to salvage a U.S.-Russia ceasefire agreement that went into effect September 12
column3: with Washington calling for all war planes operating over Syria to be grounded
column4: the BBC reported.

column1: At the U.N.
column2: U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry said Syria’s future was “hanging by a thread
column3: ” and flights had to be suspended “in order to de-escalate the situation and give a chance for humanitarian assistance to flow unimpeded.”"	syrian children look down from window convoy united nations and arab red crescent vehicles carrying aid the rebel held town talbisseh the northern outskirts homs september 2016 mahmoud taha afp via getty images resume syria aid deliveries trucks will roll into the war wrecked country ‘as soon possible ’ the united nations will resume efforts deliver aid besieged areas syria after halting all convoys the turkish border following airstrike its vehicles heading the opposition controlled part aleppo earlier this week the bbc reported thursday trucks will roll into the war wracked country “as soon possible according the u n ’s office for the coordination humanitarian affairs but will avoid the opposition controlled aleppo because has been under heavy bombardment u s  officials blamed two russian aircraft for monday’s attack the u n  aid convoy russia denied its aircraft were operating the area the time and suggested the u s  was behind the attack claiming u s  predator drone was the area when the vehicles carrying desperately needed supplies people under siege were struck meanwhile officials are scrambling salvage u s  russia ceasefire agreement that went into effect september with washington calling for all war planes operating over syria grounded the bbc reported the u n  u s  secretary state john kerry said syria’s future was “hanging thread and flights had suspended “in order de escalate the situation and give chance for humanitarian assistance flow unimpeded ”	UN to resume Syria aid deliveries – POLITICO	resume syria aid deliveries politico	RealNewsContent	PolitiFact	243	5

column1: 177	"Nate Smith
column2: executive director of the Texas Nationalist Movement
column3: looked uncertain as a man identifying himself as an east Ukrainian resistance fighter pledged solidarity to Smith’s struggle for an independent Texas. Standing in a conference room in the Ritz Hotel in central Moscow on Sunday
column4: Smith nodded noncommittally and handed over his business card.

column1: It wasn’t the only incongruous encounter taking place at the Ritz at what has been dubbed Moscow’s international conference of separatists
column2: an eclectic Kremlin-funded gathering of organizations and sometimes wacky individuals pressing for self-rule for often unlikely territories.

column1: Amidst the heavy glitz of the hotel
column2: Catalonian separatists and dissident Irish republicans listened politely to presentations from east Ukrainian rebels
column3: Azerbaijani minorities and the thoughts of the self-proclaimed ""King of Hawaii
column4: who called in via video link.

column1: And among the few dozen activists comparing ideas for how to achieve self-determination
column2: were two Americans campaigning for Texan and Californian secession from the United States.

column1: The conference
column2: now in its second year
column3: is funded largely by the Kremlin and organized by the Anti-Globalization Movement of Russia
column4: a group that closely follows government positions. The movement says it is unconnected to the Kremlin
column5: but the hotel conference was almost entirely paid for by a charitable fund founded by President Vladimir Putin
column6: which provided close to $546
column7: 000 for the project
column8: according to public records. The attendees
column9: including the Texan delegate
column10: had been offered free flights and accommodation.

column1: The conference’s organizers present it as a platform for marginalized groups
column2: but its agenda overlaps with Kremlin efforts to promote Russia as an alternative guardian for global order
column3: at the head of democratic movement opposed to alleged American imperialism.

column1: “Our main goal is to create a multi-polar world
column2: ” the conference’s creator
column3: Aleksander V. Ionov
column4: told its participants. “Our president
column5: Vladimir Vladimirovich Putin
column6: is probably the main anti-globalist in the world.”

column1: Ionov himself
column2: a relatively little-known businessman
column3: has repeatedly met Syrian President Bashar al-Assad
column4: whom Russia is backing militarily
column5: saying the two discussed humanitarian aid and media activities two weeks ago.

column1: Ionov’s conference plays into Moscow’s own long-time policy of backing separatists in its former Soviet neighbors. While jailing and harassing separatist groups at home
column2: Moscow has leveraged them abroad a pretext for military intervention
column3: most recently fomenting the violent secessionist conflict in eastern Ukraine. A sizable presence of pro-Russian rebel supporters was visible on Sunday
column4: while not a single Russian separatist group took part.

column1: All that and the anti-American flavor sometimes made uncomfortable listening for the groups less used to the atmosphere in the Kremlin’s orbit.
“It’s kind of awkward I guess
column2: ” Smith said after one 30-minute denunciation of American inequity.

column1: ABC News
Smith’s group
column2: the Texas Nationalist Movement
column3: is campaigning for a referendum on whether Texas should exit the United States. Founded over 10 years ago
column4: the group attracted some attention recently when it came within two votes of forcing the Texas state GOP to bring a debate on a secession referendum to the floor of the Republican convention. Smith said he was grateful for the chance to promote his campaign and was eager to clarify his attendance did not mean he was aligning with the Kremlin.

column1: “We’re here to have a dialogue. We’re not in agreement with all the groups that are here
column2: ” Smith said. “We’re here for very specific reasons. We came here to make a statement on behalf of the people of Texas.”

column1: It was a sentiment echoed by Louis J. Marinelli from the YES California Independence Campaign
column2: there to get his message out about his plan to make the Golden State a nation.

column1: “We want to draw attention to our campaign
column2: ” Marinelli said. “We’re not signing an alliance with Russia or anything like that.""

column1: The two secessionists’ urge for independence stems largely from a distaste with American foreign policy and a sense the U.S. has become dysfunctional. A gentle-mannered IT consultant married to a Russian
column2: Marinelli is aiming for a secession referendum by 2019.

column1: “The U.S. government is so dysfunctional it can’t be repaired from within anymore
column2: and if we were a separate nation running our own affairs
column3: we could improve the quality of life for Californians
column4: ” Marinelli said.

column1: Both men were hoping for a Donald Trump victory in the U.S. presidential elections
column2: banking on a surge in people looking to detach themselves from America. The U.K.'s recent ""Brexit"" vote to leave the European Union had also heartened many attendees.

column1: But why exactly the Kremlin had decided to pay to gather them in Moscow
column2: few among the foreign attendees could say. Nor did they appear particularly interested.

column1: “I’m not here to make presumptions about potential reasons for this conference
column2: ” Smith said.

column1: However
column2: the conference -- and its location in one of Moscow’s expensive hotels
column3: within shouting distance of the Kremlin walls -- slots into a recognizable recent Russian strategy. Russia has been backing far right political parties in the West
column4: in particular
column5: reportedly funding France’s anti-European Union party
column6: the Front National
column7: with a $10 million loan. The practice echoes that of the Soviet Union
column8: which secretly supported radical fringe groups around the world
column9: but now coupled with elaborate disinformation campaigns from state media outlets.

column1: “It’s a school-book case
column2: ” said Peter Kreko
column3: a Fulbright visiting professor at Indiana University who has studied Russia’s use of the far right. “The simple reason is that Russia is interested in dividing the Western world. The strategy is not to create new divisions but to take the most from divisions already there.”

column1: Kreko said the idea was to back groups hindering European integration and to undermine faith in Western-style liberal democracy.
“The tool-kit is pretty much the same as in the Soviet Union. Any kind of movements that can cause chaos
column2: ” Kreko said
column3: adding he thought the conference was also a prop for domestic propaganda that state media would use to paint Russia as a champion of democracy.

column1: Few of the conference attendees were concerned they might become Kremlin pawns
column2: seeing it simply as a way to get their message out.

column1: “Everybody’s using everybody
column2: ” Marinelli said. “We’re using this conference for our own purposes. We want the attention so that we can get the word out
column3: they want ..."" he trailed off before finishing. “Everybody’s got their own agenda
column4: right? So
column5: that’s just the way it is.”

column1: For most of the attendees the main pull appeared to be the guaranteed presence of the media
column2: attracted by the conference’s oddity.

column1: “I’ve talked to seven media [organizations] today. I've got to get my story out
column2: ” said Diarmuid Mac Dubhglais
column3: international secretary for Republican Sinn Féin
column4: a tiny Irish republican splinter group that supports the violent removal of British control over Northern Ireland.

column1: In any case
column2: Mac Dubhglais said
column3: he wouldn’t let “Vladimir himself” impose ideas on him.

column1: “I’m not going to start passing out propaganda when I go home and start marching Soviet-style
column2: he said.

column1: Besides
column2: he said
column3: perhaps the Russian motive was altruistic. “Maybe in fairness
column4: they might think the cause is just
column5: ” he said then paused
column6: before adding: “I’m hoping that’s what they think."""	nate smith executive director the texas nationalist movement looked uncertain man identifying himself east ukrainian resistance fighter column1: 178	"Early voting has begun in the battleground state of North Carolina
column2: and after months of contentious litigation
column3: it’s clear why Republicans wanted to squash it: returns are showing Democrats with an eight point advantage over Republicans.

column1: Data analysis from TargetSmart (who partnered with NBC News) shows that of the 4
column2: 000 plus presidential ballots that have been cast
column3: 42 percent come from registered Democrats
column4: 34 percent from Republicans
column5: 25 percent from unaffiliated
column6: and 1 percent from Libertarians.

column1: Contrast that to 2012
column2: when Mitt Romney won North Carolina by two percent: in early voting that year in that state
column3: Republicans held a five percent lead. Now Democrats hold an eight percent lead. In 2008
column4: when President Obama won (by a slim margin of 0.33 percent)
column5: Democrats had an 11 point advantage. In 2004
column6: Democrats had an 11 point advantage
column7: but Kerry lost to Bush by 13 percent.

column1: So while it’s not set in stone that whoever accumulates the most early votes wins
column2: the last two elections (in which early voting has increased tremendously) shows that is the case.

column1: Nate Silver’s FiveThirtyEight currently gives Clinton a 43 percent chance of winning North Carolina (and a 62 percent chance of winning the election overall). Clinton’s chances have gone up almost five percent in the last week
column2: with one reason being a strong showing for Democrats in early voting. The New York Times’ election model gives Clinton a 48 percent chance of winning North Carolina.

column1: Again
column2: no wonder Governor Pat McCory
column3: who is currently losing his re-election bid
column4: and the GOP legislature wanted to do away with it. When Democrats get a head start
column5: that usually means good news in November.

column1: Democrats shouldn’t get too comfortable. Although early voting points to a Democratic-leaning result
column2: Republicans could very well (and chances are great) benefit from in person voting on November 8. President Obama never overcame Romney in the polls in the weeks leading up to the election
column3: almost all the polls for the month of September favored Obama.

column1: With 45 days left until the election
column2: anything can happen
column3: so Democrats need to continue to mobilize
column4: register
column5: and get out the vote for not just early ballots
column6: but for November 8.

179	"As my 25th wedding anniversary approached
column2: I tried to be creative in buying gifts for my wife. I had the idea of a silver coin that marked 25 years of something or other. I went to a local coin shop
column3: and as I idled over some of the display cases
column4: I noticed a set of coins from the mid-19th century. Oddly
column5: the coins from the 1840s and 1850s were large—up until 1857
column6: when the coins started becoming
column7: at best
column8: half the size of the others.

column1: “Oh
column2: the Panic of 1857
column3: ” the owner said when I asked him about the change of size. “It was really bad. The president didn’t seem to have any solution except to use less gold or silver in the coins.”

column1: Story Continued Below
Now that is inept presidential decision-making. During the current election campaign
column2: there has been a lot of gnashing of teeth over the possibility that—whoever the winner is—he or she will be so terrible as a leader they will bring down the republic as the worst president since independence. And before the current candidates were known
column3: the two most recent White House occupants
column4: Barack Obama and George W. Bush
column5: have been consistently reviled by their detractors as the worst men to lead the country.

column1: But Obama and Bush can both take heart. And Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton can gain solace
column2: perhaps
column3: from knowing that no matter how badly they do
column4: they almost certainly won’t rank last. By my reckoning
column5: that place belongs to James Buchanan
column6: genial a man though he was. I’ve made quite a study of him. My innocent encounter at the coin shop only reinforced my lifelong determination to take an offbeat look at
column7: let’s say
column8: the lesser presidents. My father was definitely the only one in our suburban neighborhood with a biography of Franklin Pierce. Everywhere we went
column9: he forced me to read historical plaques—stopping the car in a shrieking halt at times to view them. If I were to write a book about a president
column10: it surely wouldn’t be about Washington or Lincoln
column11: or even Silent Cal Coolidge. It would have to be about someone as ineffectual as possible.

column1: Buchanan
column2: the only president from my native state
column3: Pennsylvania
column4: turned out to be my man.

column1: Start with his anemic
column2: minimalist solution to one of America’s great financial downturns.

column1: For a long time before Buchanan
column2: in effect
column3: precipitated the Panic of 1857
column4: things were going well for the country
column5: at least in an economic sense. There had been a bad downturn 20 years before
column6: with multiple causes
column7: like war in Europe
column8: the dissolution of the Bank of the United States
column9: and overspeculation in
column10: oddly enough
column11: slaves and Western land. The great acquisition of land under President James Knox Polk
column12: from Oregon to California to Texas
column13: reinvigorated the economy
column14: and a boom lasted for the next two decades. Railroads were the big player
column15: since so many people wanted to move West into the new territories and states. Manufacturing boomed domestically
column16: and then with foreign trade as well
column17: since Europe had quelled many of its hostilities and American items were cheaper than those on the Continent.

column1: Then the day before Buchanan took office
column2: Congress passed what he wanted
column3: the Tariff Bill of 1857
column4: which lowered tariffs on a panoply of items from abroad—Buchanan wanted to stimulate foreign trade—but made American manufactured goods of the same sort less competitive.

column1: Three days later came the real fatal blow
column2: though
column3: the Dred Scott Supreme Court decision
column4: which fell on the shoulders of Buchanan. The case had wound through state and federal courts for at least a decade
column5: but Roger Taney
column6: the Supreme Court chief justice
column7: and a fellow alumnus
column8: with Buchanan
column9: of small Dickinson College
column10: wanted it settled.

column1: Scott was a slave to a military man who at times was stationed not in his native Missouri
column2: a slave state
column3: but in the Northwest Territories
column4: which were nonslave. After his master died
column5: Scott brought the case that he should be free because he had lived in nonslave territory. Buchanan wanted to be a hero
column6: and thought if the case could be decided broadly
column7: it could settle the question of slavery in the Union for good.

column1: Buchanan knew
column2: too
column3: though
column4: that the court had five Southerners and four Northerners
column5: and if the decision were split that way
column6: it would be ineffective. He and Taney had apparently agreed to have a narrower decision
column7: or remand the case back to the Appeals Court
column8: if it were merely sectional
column9: since they felt the need to have some sort of bipartisanship for the decision to be legitimate.

column1: Ignoring the idea of separation of powers
column2: though
column3: Buchanan browbeat Robert Cooper Grier
column4: another Dickinson alumnus and a justice from Pennsylvania
column5: to go along with the majority opinion
column6: which Taney would write. Eventually
column7: a New York native
column8: Justice Samuel Nelson
column9: wrote a concurring opinion
column10: making the vote even less sectional.

column1: Legend has it that Taney
column2: on the Capitol stairs just before he gave Buchanan the oath of office at the inauguration
column3: told Buchanan that the decision would become public in the next few days. Buchanan apparently changed his speech to indicate that—and that he would be all for whatever the court decided.

column1: Two days later
column2: the decision came down. Taney castigated Scott
column3: whom he said was not a citizen
column4: being a slave
column5: and thus could not bring any suit. He also wrote that the Constitution gave no state or territory the power to institute or
column6: conversely
column7: prohibit slavery. Thus all the compromises about it
column8: going back to the 1820s
column9: were invalid
column10: and
column11: in fact
column12: the Fugitive Slave Law
column13: requiring anyone who knew about it to return slaves to their owners anywhere in the country

column1: Historically
column2: experts rate Dred Scott as the worst decision in the court’s history
column3: but short of that
column4: it was at the very least transformational for the country—with not just Taney
column5: but surely Buchanan
column6: responsible for it.

column1: As appalled as most of the country was about the morals of the decision at the time
column2: there was a practical downside
column3: too. Now no one knew whether he or she wanted to go West
column4: to use the railroads
column5: or to start a business that railroads might profit from. Railroad stocks started to decline in value
column6: and then a contagion hit
column7: and it was free fall. By midsummer
column8: no one could take a ride on the Reading
column9: as Uncle Pennybags does in the Monopoly game
column10: since the Reading Railroad had shut down
column11: as did lines now and then famous like the Illinois Central. Several lines
column12: like the Delaware
column13: Lackawanna and Western and the Fond du Lac Railroad in Wisconsin

column1: Thousands were thrown out of work
column2: and banks started foreclosing on loans and property. Senator William Seward
column3: the leader of the new Republican Party
column4: come home from a vacation to find out he had lost most everything he owned—his stock in the Illinois Central
column5: promoted to him by his rival Democrat Stephen Douglas
column6: was virtually worthless.

column1: Every bank in New York City effectively closed—none would convert coins or gold into bank notes. The oldest grain company in New York
column2: N.H. Wolfe and Co.
column3: failed in August
column4: as did the most prominent insurance business in the country
column5: the Ohio Life Insurance and Trust Co.

column1: Buchanan and his administration did nothing to stem the public hysteria. Calm words might have quelled it
column2: but his inaction only made for further runs on banks and
column3: thus
column4: more turmoil in markets.

column1: The residue that mattered most
column2: though
column3: was the reaction caused by Dred Scott. Instead of promoting unity and opening up the West to more settlement
column4: as Buchanan had thought
column5: Dred Scott thwarted it
column6: and brought an end to years of Northern prosperity.

column1: Yet the South did not succumb as badly. Its agrarian culture was self-sustaining
column2: and its cotton still had a market in Europe. There was a surge in arms sales there as well
column3: the economic downturn in the North exacerbating regional tensions. The relative good times in the South caused Northerners of all parties to further blame Buchanan for being a Southern lackey.

column1: Buchanan’s response was underwhelming
column2: almost disdainful. He said the federal government could do nothing. In his Annual Message in December 1857
column3: he said he sympathized with the travails caused by the Panic
column4: but he would do nothing for individual suffering. The government would continue to pay its obligations and would keep going on whatever public works projects it had started
column5: but would begin no new ones. He said too many people had speculated in land and slaves and the like and “deserved the gambler’s fate.” Eventually
column6: he noted
column7: the youth and energy of the rugged American individuals would triumph
column8: though there would clearly be an interim of rough times.

column1: In a sense
column2: he was right
column3: because it took the rugged young Americans who went to war in 1861 to bring the economy back.

column1: Throughout his term
column2: when a fork appeared in the road
column3: Buchanan managed to take the wrong turn. When hostilities flared in Kansas
column4: over whether that territory would enter as a slave or free state
column5: Buchanan wavered over which of two proposed constitutions would be valid
column6: exacerbating the killings
column7: some done by the wild-eyed anti-slavery radical John Brown. When later Brown seized arms with a small cadre of followers in Harpers Ferry
column8: West Virginia
column9: just 40 miles from Washington along the Potomac
column10: Buchanan again diddled before consulting Robert E. Lee
column11: who had fortuitously been home in Arlington on leave from his post in Texas. Lee quickly went to Harpers Ferry to capture Brown and quell the raid.

column1: In other ventures
column2: though
column3: Buchanan dashed troops out on strange and unproductive missions. He caused chaos in Utah
column4: quelling what he thought to be a Mormon revolt
column5: causing villages to be burned to the ground and dozens of lives lost over what was merely a jurisdictional dispute. He supported mercenary William Walker’s forays to conquer Nicaragua and Guatemala
column6: and sent troops to try to annex parts of Paraguay
column7: primarily to acquiesce to his Southern base that wanted more slave states to come into the union. Then there was the little known Pig War
column8: started when a settler along the Canadian border on the San Juan straits in the Northwest
column9: shot a pig owned by the Hudson Bay Co. that wandered onto his property. A standoff ensued until Buchanan sent troops otherwise guarding Kansas
column10: where there was a real problem
column11: out to calm the nonfatal—except to one pig—battle. This was at a time when there were about only 12
column12: 000 soldiers in the U.S. Army
column13: stretched as thin as could be.

column1: As the election of 1860 came close
column2: Buchanan refused to support the one Democrat who could win
column3: Stephen Douglas
column4: because he just plain didn’t like him. That caused the party to split into three factions
column5: each nominating a candidate
column6: virtually ensuring Republican Abraham Lincoln the election.

column1: The Southern states
column2: which had threatened secession
column3: started doing so during the interim between Lincoln’s election and his inauguration in March
column4: thus under Buchanan’s watch. Buchanan took the unusual position that the Constitution did not allow secession
column5: but the president could not do anything to prevent it.

column1: As the first half-dozen states seceded
column2: Buchanan lost several Cabinet members—he had a lot of Southern allies—and refused entreaties by many
column3: including former President John Tyler
column4: who would himself become a Confederate congressman
column5: to find compromises to bring the wastrel states back into the fold.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Buchanan allowed the seizure of armaments and forts by the seceding states and suggested the abandonment of the one major fortified island in the South
column3: Fort Sumter.

column1: Enter Lincoln
column2: who has long been rated in serious surveys and schoolmarms’ speeches as the greatest of presidents. Lincoln no doubt was a man with plans and savvy
column3: but I contend that the bar was set so low by his predecessor that maybe if there were no James Buchanan
column4: the “Worst. President. Ever
column5: ” there would have been a few notches more on the presidential-rating scale for Abe Lincoln to climb.

column1: Today
column2: George W. Bush is often rated one of the worst presidents in history
column3: thanks to his authorship of the Iraq War and his presiding over the Crash of ’08 and the beginning of the Great Recession. Obama is sometimes seen in the same light
column4: especially by the far right. But as happened with Honest Abe and his predecessor
column5: perhaps that low bar will only make it easier for a President Hillary Clinton or a President Donald Trump to shine.

column1: Robert Strauss is author of the forthcoming Worst. President. Ever.: James Buchanan
column2: the POTUS Rating Game

column1: 180	"KALLSTADT
column2: Germany — Few places in Germany are as representative of the country’s heartland as Kallstadt
column3: the village in which U.S. Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump’s grandfather was born — and from which he was later deported.

column1: The hamlet of 1
column2: 200 people lies nestled among vineyard-covered hills
column3: about an hour-and-a-half’s drive southwest of Frankfurt. It has one bakery and one butcher. Every year
column4: Kallstadt holds the Saumagenkerwe in celebration of the eponymous local delicacy: pig’s stomach filled with pork
column5: herbs
column6: bratwurst and diced potatoes.

column1: Trump may have captured a large swath of the American electorate with his signature blend of populism
column2: nativism and brazenness. And yet
column3: in the hometown of his forefather
column4: he remains distinctly unpopular.

column1: In fact
column2: few politicians are less popular in Germany than Trump. A study by the Pew Research Center found out that only 6 percent of the country finds him trustworthy.

column1: Since a local newspaper discovered that Johannes Steiniger
column2: a member of the German parliament
column3: was distantly related to Trump
column4: the 29-year-old has done all he can to distance himself from the presidential candidate. “With his statements about gay people and foreigners
column5: or with the language he uses
column6: and with his derogative statements about Hillary Clinton
column7: Trump seems to do everything he can so that we get a negative image of him
column8: ” Steiniger tells POLITICO.

column1: Trump’s rhetoric regarding immigrants and racial minorities is especially unpopular in Kallstadt. “He stands for everything that’s bad
column2: ” says Sarah Bühler
column3: yelling to be heard over the 20-person brass band celebrating the Saumagenkerwe in the town’s main square. Bühler is a former local “wine princess
column4: ” the 2009 victor of a beauty pageant to promote the local wine industry.

column1: This year
column2: a new dish appeared in the town’s annual festival: Saumagen-Döner
column3: a fusion of the local specialty with a Turkish kebab. “Everyone is welcome to join us here
column4: no matter what color they are
column5: ” says Bühler. “Pink
column6: purple
column7: doesn’t matter.”

column1: Tanja Huber
column2: the 24-year-old incumbent regional wine princess
column3: nods her head in agreement. Since the prospect of a Trump presidency first became evident late last year
column4: reporters have descended on Kallstadt
column5: seeking a bit of local color
column6: a quote or two
column7: and perhaps some hometown pride. “They don’t get that we really don’t give a damn about Trump
column8: ” says Huber. “He’s never been here
column9: and he apparently doesn’t care about us
column10: either.”

column1: Donald’s grandfather
column2: Friedrich Trump
column3: was born in Kallstadt into a vintner’s family on March 14
column4: 1869. Previous generations of the Trump family used variant spellings of the name
column5: including “Trump
column6: ” “Dromb” and “Trumpff
column7: ” according to local historians
column8: or even “Drumpf
column9: ” according to a 2000 family history by Gwenda Blair; but by the time Friedrich was born they had settled on “Trump.”

column1: Germany did not yet exist as a nation; Kallstadt was part of the province of Palatinate in the Bavarian Kingdom. The region was going though rough times. Unemployment was high. Those who had the courage
column2: left.

column1: Friedrich’s father died when he was eight years old
column2: and his mother struggled to make ends meet. At 16 years old
column3: Friedrich decided to follow his sister Katharina
column4: who had emigrated to the United States two years earlier. He arrived in New York on board the Eider on October 19

column1: He entered the U.S. through official channels
column2: but he had left Bavaria illegally. “Both he and his mother must have known that he would not have been granted official permission to leave the country unless he had paid a bail guaranteeing that he would later return to do his mandatory military service
column3: ” said Roland Paul
column4: the recently-retired director of the Institute for Palatinate Regional History and Folklife Studies in the city of Kaiserslautern.

column1: According to documents uncovered by Paul
column2: Friedrich was stripped of his Bavarian citizenship “as his own request” four years after arriving in the U.S.

column1: But Friedrich was not done with Palatinate. Seven years after his citizenship was withdrawn
column2: he visited the land of his birth to attend the wedding of his sister
column3: according to the 2000 family history by Blair. Five years after that
column4: he returned once more to Kallstadt
column5: where he met 20-year-old Elisabeth Christ; they were engaged
column6: and Friedrich came back a third time to marry her in August 1902.

column1: But while the couple moved back to New York soon after the marriage and had a daughter
column2: Friedrich had promised his wife that he would sell his property in the U.S. and return to the land of their birth. “My grandmother said
column3: I will marry you
column4: but I will not go back to America with you
column5: ” Donald Trump’s American-born cousin John Walter told German filmmaker Simone Wendel in 2012.

column1: Friedrich seemed intent on keeping his promise. In 1904
column2: he applied for permission to travel to Kallstadt. And although he claimed in his application that he intended “to return to the United States within a year with the purpose of residing and performing the duties of citizenship therein
column3: ” he took all his savings from the U.S. with him
column4: according to Blair’s family history.

column1: Back in Kallstadt
column2: Friedrich attempted to get his citizenship back. But though he secured the support of local authorities
column3: the district government put a halt to his plans. On February 27
column5: a deportation notice was sent to the town office of Kallstadt declaring that Friedrich was “to be told he has to leave Bavarian state territory by May 1 of this year
column6: at the latest.”

column1: Friedrich was able to obtain a three-month grace period because his daughter had fallen ill. But eventually
column2: he and his wife — pregnant once more — had no choice but to board the ship Pennsylvania on July 1
column4: and return to New York. Shortly after that
column5: Donald’s father
column6: Fred Trump Junior
column7: was born.

column1: “[The authorities] said
column2: ‘You are not a German citizen
column3: you gave up your citizenship
column4: you have to leave
column5: ” says Walter. “So they left and they went back to America
column6: and that’s why Donald and I are here.”

column1: Friedrich — now named Frederick — died in May 1918 of the Spanish flu. His widow survived her first husband by 48 years and visited Kallstadt many times during her life.
In February 2012
column2: Simone Wendel
column3: the German filmmaker from Kallstadt
column4: was given an audience with Donald Trump. Roughly two years earlier
column5: she had begun work on “Kings of Kallstadt
column6: ” a documentary about the two most famous sons of her tiny hometown: Donald Trump and Henry John Heinz
column7: the inventor of Heinz Ketchup.

column1: For months
column2: Wendel had tried to arrange a meeting with Trump
column3: but his office had not replied to her letters. She was only able to secure a visit with the help of Walter
column4: Trump’s cousin
column5: who had visited Kallstadt and seemed happy with the attention she was paying to the family history.

column1: On the day of her visit
column2: Wendel stood nervously next to Walter in a conference room on one of Trump Tower’s top floors. She had brought a Linzer torte and two bottles of wine with screw-on tops.

column1: Her plan was to sit down with Walter and Trump for coffee and cake
column2: the traditional afternoon snack in her home region. But when she asked Trump’s staff to make some coffee
column3: the only reaction she got was irritated faces. “His assistant just couldn’t be bothered
column4: ” she says.

column1: “Hello
column2: John
column3: ” Trump said
column4: when he entered the room
column5: shaking his cousin’s hand and looking confused at Wendel in her loose turtle neck and the lonely cake on the huge table in front of her.

column1: Trump sat down in front of a one-meter-long model of his Boeing 757-200 airliner and a panoramic window overlooking New York’s Central Park. Wendel
column2: trying to remedy the situation
column3: pushed the cake in his direction and asked him to smell it. “Afterwards
column4: I just kept on thinking
column5: ‘What on earth did I do?’” she says.

column1: “The cake looks really good
column2: ” Trump said
column3: and he and Wendel ended up talking for almost an hour.

column1: Until 1990
column2: Trump still claimed his family was Swedish
column3: a version of his family history first introduced by his father in reaction to the anti-German sentiment in the U.S. during the two World Wars. But by the time Wendel visited
column4: he had become proud of his German roots. “They grow them well in Kallstadt
column5: ” he told her during their meeting. “They grow them very well. Believe me. It’s good stock.”

column1: “Wow
column2: it’s beautiful
column3: ” Trump said when she handed him a picture of the house where his grandfather was born
column4: an inconspicuous one-story building with a gable roof. “That’s fantastic. See how well-maintained it is? Everything is perfectly maintained. It’s great.”

column1: When their interview was over
column2: Walter took Wendel on a tour of Trump Tower. On one of the floors
column3: they ran into Trump’s son
column4: Eric Trump.

column1: “Have you ever heard the word Kallstadt?” Wendel asked him.
“Kallstadt?” Trump Junior replied
column2: “No
column3: what is it?”"	kallstadt germany few places germany are representative the country’s heartland kallstadt the village which u s  republican presidential candidate donald trump’s grandfather was column1: 181	"An anti-Donald Trump super PAC is going on the offensive ahead of the first presidential debate this Monday at Hofstra University in New York.
The group
column2: the Not Who We Are campaign
