column1: Stop-and-frisk is a type of aggressive policing that allows -- some say encourages -- officers to detain a person on virtually any type of vague suspicion
column2: search that individual without a warrant and arrest the person if any kind of illegal substance or weapon is found.

column1: It grew out of the tough policies of New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani
column2: now a vocal Trump supporter and trusted adviser
column3: under the theory that aggressive enforcement of even minor laws would lead to a reduction of violent crime. Proponents of stop-and-frisk argue that it would be especially effective in getting illegal guns off the streets.

column1: Critics of the program questioned its constitutionality. They also pointed to the fact
column2: documented in several studies
column3: that the policy falls heaviest on black and Latino men.

column1: Hopefully this dramatic shift in tone will be a cue to the rest of the mainstream media to abandon their insistence on treating Trump’s statements with more legitimacy than they deserve out of a desire to remain impartial. But it appears that Trump’s attempt to gaslight the nation and convince us that it was actually Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton that created the “birther” myth (which is decidedly false) was the last straw for the highly respected editors at the New York Times.

column4: where it takes a special kind of person to find whatever message they're looking for.""

186	"On the night of September 26
column2: as the house lights dim in the Mack Complex at Hofstra University and the TV cameras go live
column3: millions of Americans will be riveted to the scene. Will Donald Trump seem well prepared? Will Hillary Clinton’s commanding grasp of policy and nuance dazzle viewers? Will either candidate rise to the challenge and show voters that they have what it takes to be president?

column1: Experience suggests it’s hard to make a positive breakthrough—especially with two candidates so well known and so widely disliked. But what is possible is a serious unforced error.
Story Continued Below
Over the 56 years that presidential debates have been televised
column2: one of their great legacies has been the sudden
column3: public gaffe—a mistake live on TV that permanently cements the way voters see the candidate.

column1: Despite the hopeful aspirations of those voters who welcome a few hours of substantive deliberation on the major issues of the day
column2: the truth is that these are televised performances. What the candidates say often matters less than how they look and what they do with their bodies: Every breath they take
column3: every expression they make
column4: and every emotion they convey can play a major role in determining how Americans evaluate their performances. And although debates don’t usually transform how most voters think of the candidates
column5: they do confirm voters’ impressions—which matters on Election Day.

column1: For both candidates
column2: this will be a particularly big challenge. Donald Trump is a larger-than-life presence who likes to intimidate
column3: cajole and verbally bully his opponents by saying things long considered out of bounds—which could lead to an unforced error by Hillary Clinton. Hillary Clinton
column4: who sometimes betrays an aversion to letting too much emotion show
column5: has a steely temperament and stinging wit that could easily get under Trump’s skin
column6: instigating him into losing control with the cameras rolling. If either of these happens
column7: it will join the long line of memorable
column8: campaign-changing moments that candidates fumbled into.

column1: 1. 1960: Nixon sweats while debating JFK
Famously
column2: the very first televised presidential debate offered early evidence that all future debates would be visual affairs. After eight years as vice president
column3: Richard Nixon was running to inherit the White House from the enormously popular Dwight Eisenhower. His challenger was John F. Kennedy
column4: the charismatic young Massachusetts senator whose eloquence and matinee-idol looks captivated much of the nation.

column1: On September 26
column2: at the candidates’ first debate
column3: Nixon proved to be in strong command of policy. But he looked terrible. Famously
column4: prior to the debate
column5: he declined to have any makeup applied to his face. But that decision was made worse by the fact that for much of the previous two weeks
column6: Nixon had been away from the campaign trail nursing a knee infection. As a result
column7: he looked peaked.

column1: Video: The Biggest Unforced Errors in Debate History From Richard Nixon sweating on camera during the first presidential debate to George H.W. Bush checking his watch before an audience question—here are some of the most prominent debate gaffes in U.S. history.
During their televised rumble
column2: Nixon could be seen sweating and
column3: on camera
column4: wiping his brow with a handkerchief. His pale color and five o'clock shadow didn’t help. All of which undercut his performance against Kennedy
column5: who was a vision of youthful vigor.

column1: 2. 1976: Ford and Carter freeze in a moment of crisis
A more dramatic moment occurred on September 23
column3: when the sound system malfunctioned in Philadelphia’s Walnut Street Theater
column4: forcing a 27-minute delay during the debate
column5: during which President Gerald Ford and then-Governor Jimmy Carter awkwardly stood still on stage. The broadcast continued as the television crew worked furiously to fix the technical problems.

column1: Neither candidate wanted to move
column2: fearing that it would somehow look bad to audiences at home
column3: so instead they stood frozen in a comic parody better than anything that “Saturday Night Live” could imagine. Moderators Robert McNeil and Jim Lehrer kept talking as the candidates “stood helplessly like two Hollywood stand-ins
column4: ” wrote Jules Witcover in the Washington Post.

column1: Years later
column2: Ford admitted that “I suspect both of us would have liked to sit down and relax while the technicians were fixing the system
column3: but I think both of us were hesitant to make any gesture that might look like we weren’t physically or mentally able to handle a problem like this.” In the end
column4: both men were diminished; they seemed less like leaders than deer caught in headlights.

column1: 3. 1980: Carter’s grim-faced critiques seem too self-serious
In politics
column2: brevity can be a virtue. During his only debate with Ronald Reagan in the fall of 1980
column3: Jimmy Carter didn’t get that lesson.

column1: In front of a record-breaking 80.6 million viewers
column2: Carter was hoping to paint Ronald Reagan as a creature of the far right—someone like Barry Goldwater
column3: the GOP nominee whom Lyndon Johnson so successfully branded as an extremist some 16 years earlier. As Reagan sought to present himself as a more moderate
column4: relatable Republican
column5: Carter tried to forcefully punch back in the form of a lengthy and detailed monologue about health care and how Reagan had opposed Medicare in 1964.

column1: While Carter looked grim on the attack
column2: Reagan grinned like a mildly disappointed father and shot back with just one phrase: “There you go again
column3: ” he said with a laugh. The line undercut Carter’s entire argument
column4: making Reagan look like the bigger man.

column1: 4. 1984: Mondale lets Reagan’s one-liner negate a serious weakness
During 1984’s first debate
column2: Reagan
column3: then 73
column4: aroused concern when he seemed to have trouble remembering his answers or following the questions. He stumbled over his words and lacked clarity with each statement. His opponent
column5: former Vice President Walter Mondale
column6: was crisp and sharp. In contrast
column7: Reagan rambled through his closing statement to the alarm of his advisers. Lou Cannon wrote that Reagan left the stage admitting to campaign adviser Stu Spencer “that he had flopped.” The Wall Street Journal’s headline the next morning captured the zeitgeist: “New Question in Race: Is Oldest President Now Showing his Age?”

column1: Fortunately for Reagan
column2: he came back with a vengeance. In a later debate
column3: when Baltimore Sun journalist Henry Trewitt asked Reagan if his age would prevent him from fulfilling the rigors of the presidency
column4: Reagan had a quip for the ages: “I will not make age an issue in this campaign. I will not exploit
column5: for political purposes
column6: my opponent’s youth and inexperience.”

column1: The audience erupted in laughter
column2: including Mondale
column3: which completely undercut the seriousness of the underlying charge.

column1: 5. 1988: Dukakis seems cold in the face of a deeply personal question
Perhaps the most shocking and controversial opening question in any presidential debate was posed by CNN anchor Bernard Shaw to Massachusetts Gov. Michael Dukakis at the second debate of 1988.
Dukakis was widely seen as a technocrat
column2: a man whose inner character remained a mystery to many voters. The night before the debate
column3: at 2 a.m.
column4: Shaw thought of the question that could crack that shell and elicit passion from the candidate. And so he began the debate with it: “Governor
column5: if Kitty Dukakis were raped and murdered
column6: would you favor an irrevocable death penalty for the killer?”

column1: Reporters were shocked
column2: but Dukakis seemed unperturbed. In a clinical and dispassionate manner
column3: Dukakis simply said “No
column4: I don’t Bernard
column5: and I think you know that I’ve opposed the death penalty during all of my life. I don’t see any evidence that it’s a deterrent
column6: and I think there are better and more effective ways to deal with violent crime.”

column1: It was as though Dukakis was talking about a stranger
column2: answering in the same tone that a professor might use to explain a basic point of fact in the classroom. Voters were taken aback by how little passion the candidate seemed to have. “It was a question about Dukakis’s values and emotions
column3: ” his campaign director
column4: Susan Estrich
column5: later recalled. “When he answered by talking policy
column6: I knew we lost the election.”

column1: 6. 1992: Bush checks his watch while an audience member asks a question
During the 1992 campaign
column2: few moments were more devastating to George H.W. Bush than his decision to look at his wrist watch in the middle of a town-hall debate with Bill Clinton and Ross Perot.

column1: Right before an audience member asked the candidates how the national debt personally affected the lives of the candidates and how they could relate to the economic challenges of average Americans
column2: Bush was seen looking down to figure out how many minutes were left. “Only 10 more minutes of this crap
column3: ” Bush would later say he was thinking at the time.

column1: Checking the time would’ve been unflattering in a normal debate setup
column2: but coming as it did—during a debate in which ordinary Americans posed questions to the presidential candidates—it seemed like Bush was bored and uninterested in hearing what real people had to say. For a candidate already under attack for not being concerned about domestic policy
column3: his glance seemed to confirm everything that was said about him.

column1: 7. 2000: Gore sighs
column2: eye-rolls and miscalculates in a confrontation with Bush

column1: Entering the debates in 2000
column2: Vice President Al Gore and his supporters were pretty confident that they were up against a political lightweight in George W. Bush. Gore had been in high-profile debates before
column3: and his team was confident that the debates would show American voters that Bush
column4: a relative lightweight known to stumble over his words
column5: lacked the clarity and gravitas needed to be president.

column1: During the first debate
column2: Gore’s overdramatic attempts to emphasize how exasperated he was with Bush backfired big time. At several points
column3: microphones caught Gore loudly sighing in response to Bush’s answers
column4: which played into Republican arguments that he was arrogant and condescending. And as Bush criticized the Democrat’s plans for their “fuzzy math
column5: ” Gore was seen on the split screen rolling his eyes and shaking his head in frustration.

column1: At the third debate
column2: a town-hall-style affair
column3: one of the oddest moments of this or any other debate happened: Gore walked right up to Bush as he was speaking
column4: as if to physically intimidate him. Looking up with an annoyed glance
column5: Bush seized the moment
column6: nodding his head with a smirk
column7: and continuing on with his statement
column8: making Gore’s action look odd as the audience laughed.

column1: Donna Brazile
column2: who ran Gore’s campaign
column3: believed that Gore won the debates on policy but “on mannerisms and the takeaway
column4: he ended up losing … many of us remember the split-screen
column5: and Al Gore was sitting there
column6: rolling his eyes
column7: perhaps
column8: looking at George Bush
column9: and basically he started to sigh.”

column1: 8. 2004: Bush cannot contain his irritation at Kerry
After the first debate of the general election in 2000
column2: President Bush came under criticism when he couldn’t contain how annoyed he was by some of the comments his opponent
column3: Senator John Kerry
column4: made about Bush’s record.

column1: Though Bush had benefited from the visuals of his 2000 debates against Vice President Al Gore
column2: the critics weren’t so kind to Bush in 2004
column3: when cameras caught him scowling
column4: clenching his jaw and leaning tensely over his lectern
column5: as he listened to Kerry speak. The Democratic National Committee didn’t wait long to pounce on the president. In their online video
column6: “Faces of Frustration
column7: ” viewers were treated to a repeat of the split screen showing Kerry calmly speaking on the left side of the screen with Bush’s angry looks on the right side.

column1: Appearances are not the only thing that matters in the debates
column2: of course. What the candidates say will be endlessly scrutinized with the media
column3: while the quality of the one-line zingers
column4: particularly in the viral age of Twitter
column5: Facebook and YouTube
column6: are important in shaping perceptions of the event.

column1: And on September 26
column2: 56 years to the day since Nixon awkwardly sweated his way through the debate with JFK
column3: we’ll see what happens.

column1: Julian E. Zelizer is a political historian at Princeton University and a Political Reform Fellow at New America. He is the author of The Fierce Urgency of Now: Lyndon Johnson

column1: 187	"NEW YORK – All politics is geopolitical in this year's presidential race -- and top Democrats and Republicans fear that will reshape America’s relationships around the world no matter who wins.
This week
column2: the uncertain state of those relationships will be on full display in New York as the United Nations General Assembly gathers and the presidential contenders stage meetings meant to project which alliances they favor and which expertise they want to claim.

column1: Story Continued Below
On Monday
column2: Hillary Clinton will meet with Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko—a clear dig at the developing partnership between Vladimir Putin and Donald Trump. She’ll also sit with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe
column3: her campaign announced Sunday night
column4: rejecting the suggestion that her opponent is better positioned to guide the global economy or to counter the rise of China and North Korea while reminding Americans of Donald Trump’s suggestion that America should pull its support from Japan and South Korea.

column1: Clinton and Trump both have scheduled meetings with Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi—an American ally
column2: though one with dictatorial tendencies. The Democratic nominee set hers up first
column3: aiming to project to voters that she’s up-to-speed on counter-terrorism and other issues roiling the region. Trump’s came second and was an attempt by Sisi to ensure even dealings
column4: according to Egypt’s state news agency. Nonetheless it might offer the Republican nominee a chance to frame up a position on Middle East issues that goes beyond simply banning Muslim immigrants from America.

column1: Keeping presidential politics domestic has long been more stated tradition than reality: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu not so subtly telegraphed support for Mitt Romney four years ago and Obama’s summer 2008 foreign tour was built around a 200
column2: 000-person rally in Berlin that was projected to voters at home that they should catch up to the forward-looking Europeans and support the upstart young senator.

column1: But none of this compares to the degree to which this year’s race is defined by global affairs – the result of the first former secretary of state in 200 years to be nominated for president and the challenges Trump has made throughout his campaign to fundamentals of American foreign policy.
Clinton is already planning
column2: if elected
column3: to concentrate on convincing foreign capitals that Trump and the number of votes he gets in November isn’t a sign that they need to be worried about America turning away from them.

column1: “She’s very concerned
column2: ” said a Clinton aide. “There’s no doubt that when you have a major presidential candidacy saying what he’s said
column3: it has an effect on foreign policy.”

column1: Certainly
column2: presidential politics simply no longer stops at the water’s edge
column3: and this year
column4: it has lapped aggressively
column5: perhaps dangerously
column6: over America’s borders.

column1: “It will have lasting impact
column2: ” said Sen. Ben Cardin (D-Md.)
column3: the ranking member on the Foreign Relations Committee

column1: “It has been changed
column2: ” agreed Rep. Peter King (R-N.Y.)
column3: a former chairman of the Homeland Security Committee and a Trump supporter. “It gets a little bit risky when you try to bring foreign support into it.”

column1: There has been a long list of international never-befores in 2016
column2: including Trump’s decision to accept an invitation from Mexico’s president and then commandeer a joint press conference at the presidential palace to declare America’s sovereign right to build a wall separating the two countries. And that’s hardly all.

column1: There was the alleged Russian-led hacking of Democratic campaign committees to dump emails and other information through WikiLeaks
column2: Trump operatives pulling tougher language about the invasion of Crimea from the GOP party platform
column3: Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi saying he’s personally rooting for Clinton
column4: Vice President Joe Biden saying Trump doesn’t “understand” NATO on a trip to Latvia last month
column5: President Barack Obama getting asked by foreign leaders for a year to weigh in on the presidential election.

column1: And just Friday
column2: London Mayor Sadiq Khan
column3: speaking in Chicago
column4: accused Trump of “playing into the hands” of ISIL.

column1: Officials openly wonder what Clinton’s approach as president would be now to Mexican President Enrique Peña Nieto
column2: or how quickly and forcefully NATO would restructure if Trump wins. What if China or Russia or North Korea moves to test the new president right after Inauguration Day? What if an international economic or humanitarian crisis erupts?

column1: While many in Washington’s diplomatic community say they have a clearer sense of how Clinton
column2: as opposed to Trump
column3: would want to respond
column4: doubts are growing that either would be able to summon the national resolve to do.

column1: Her meetings this week are about twisting the knife politically on Trump
column2: the aide acknowledged
column3: but they’re also about thinking through what being on the job on Jan. 20 might entail.

column1: Take Poroshenko
column2: who is rebuking Putin just by being in office: “It’s impossible not to read politics into it somewhat
column3: but because of the way Trump’s been talking over the course of the campaign
column4: Secretary Clinton thinks it’s important from a policy standpoint
column5: ” the aide said.

column1: If Trump wins
column2: he’ll have to quickly confront leaders around the world who would be shocked that U.S. voters had elected him
column3: and afraid that he would ushering in a new and dangerous world order.

column1: “They will certainly want to see where we’re coming from
column2: ” King said. “He will have to clarify and make it clear where he’s coming from.”

column1: If Clinton wins
column2: she’ll have a clean-up that Cardin and others compare to the repair mission Obama first gave her as secretary of state after the global souring on George W. Bush.

column1: Cardin
column2: who’s firmly behind Clinton
column3: ran through a litany: sitting in Harare earlier in the year
column4: watching Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe laughing as the conversation turned from his own human rights abuses to Trump’s success
column5: the conversations with leaders in bilateral meetings who quickly ditching the old diplomatic decorum to start griping
column6: drinks afterward with officials who are even blunter.

column1: “Can you imagine if Trump were president and we’re trying to get a coalition against ISIL and we need to get the support of moderate Sunni states
column2: and we need to do things that are perhaps against their local popular position? Can you imagine what Donald Trump’s comments about Muslims coming to America would have on a leader of a moderate Muslim state?” Cardin said. “It’s that type of problems that have now been caused.”

column1: This has all made for tricky travels for Obama
column2: as he’s spent significant time abroad this year nailing down his foreign policy legacy as president as the campaign has intensified. Being abroad doesn’t stop people from asking for his take on Trump and the race
column3: whether in closed bilateral meetings or at press conferences. Obama tends to draw his own line for where to stop himself
column4: but critics and even occasionally his own aides can feel like he goes too far.

column1: “It's not a mystery to people overseas that Democrats and Republicans in the United States have their differences
column2: ” said a senior administration official. “So that's why leaders traveling overseas don't make as much of an effort to conceal it.”

column1: From the beginning of his presidency
column2: Obama saw himself as embodying a generational shift in the world order
column3: from shifting more of the burden in the Middle East to Arab nations to the kind of interlocking international effort that put sanctions on Putin and brought the Iranians to the nuclear negotiating table
column4: to reopening Cuba.

column1: He’ll make that case and the case for going forward in his own speech to the U.N. General Assembly Tuesday morning.
But the argument is going to be largely defined by who his successor is. Trump didn’t run his Mexico trip by the White House. Clinton didn’t run her meetings this week by the White House either.
“We’re having a serious debate
column2: ” said Ivo Daalder
column3: now the president of the Chicago Council on Global Affairs
column4: and Obama’s first U.S. permanent representative to NATO. “We’re going to live with the consequences and the impact of the debate.”

Earlier this week
column2: as part of an interview he gave to Fox News
column3: Donald Trump announced he had just learned that Ford Motor Company was about to “fire all their employees in the United States and…move to Mexico.” Trump went on to add that when he becomes President
column4: Ford would have to pay a 35 percent tax on any car they send back to the United States for sale.

column1: Wow! That’s big news! It’s also
column2: like 99.9 percent of what Donald Trump says
column3: a gigantic lie
column4: according to Ford CEO Mark Fields
column5: who told CNN:

column1: “It’s really unfortunate when politics get in the way of the facts.”
CNN host Poppy Harlow then asked Fields
column2: would Ford cut any American jobs as part of its plans to build a new manufacturing plant in Mexico? To that
column3: Fields replied:

column1: “Absolutely not. Zero. Not one job will be lost. Most of our investment is here in the US. And that’s the way it will continue to be.”
Continue reading below the advertisement
Ford has 85
column2: 000 workers in the United States
column3: and that number has risen by 50 percent over the last five years. It currently employs 8
column4: 800 people in Mexico
column5: and the new plant will create 2
column6: 800 additional jobs there.

column1: So once again we see that Donald Trump will say anything at all in order to muddy the waters and make it appear that he is the savior of the American economy. That’s a powerful message
column2: especially in the industrial heartland–states like Michigan
column3: Ohio
column4: Pennsylvania
column5: and Wisconsin–where Trump is hoping to score big on Election Day. But Trump has financially screwed over thousands of small businesses and vendors over the years to have any legitimate clout on the economic issue. All he offers is more tax cuts for the rich and empty words. And lies. Lots and lots of lies. Tax those and we could pay off the national debt.

189	"Donald Trump's campaign isn't alone in patronizing his own businesses: taxpayers are indirectly doing so
column2: too.

column1: Federal Election Commission records show that the U.S. Secret Service has paid the Trump campaign about $1.6 million to cover the cost of flying its agents with the candidate on a plane owned and operated by one of his companies.
Story Continued Below

It’s standard practice for the agency — which is tasked with protecting presidential candidates as well as presidents and other federal officials — to reimburse presidential campaigns for the cost of traveling with the candidates.
In fact
column2: the Secret Service has reimbursed the Clinton campaign
column3: too: $2.6 million so far this cycle.

column1: The difference with Trump is that one of his companies
column2: TAG Air
column3: Inc.
column4: owns the plane
column5: so the government is effectively paying him.

column1: The Clinton campaign
column2: by contrast
column3: mostly has been chartering planes from a private company called Executive Fliteways in which the Clintons do not have any ownership interest.

column1: “The taxpayers are actually reimbursing Trump for the travel of the Secret Service agents
column2: said Brett Kappel
column3: a campaign finance lawyer at the law firm Akerman LLP. ""It's just another example of how the Trump campaign has taken an unprecedentedly large amount of its money and spent it at Trump-owned facilities.""

column1: Trump campaign spokeswoman Hope Hicks responded to questions about the Secret Service payments by saying “everything was done in accordance with FEC guidelines and regulations. Please direct further questions to USSS.”
Secret Service spokeswoman Nicole Mainor said the FEC “specifically requires security personnel such as the Secret Service to reimburse campaigns for seats” on charter aircraft.
A POLITICO analysis of FEC records found that
column2: through the end of August
column3: Trump’s campaign has spent at least $8.2 million at Trump's own businesses
column4: including to hold events at his hotels
column5: buy food from his restaurants and rent office space for its headquarters in his Manhattan office tower.

column1: But the biggest chunk of the expenses
column2: almost $6 million
column3: were to TAG Air
column4: Inc.

column1: Trump
column2: who once said “I could be the first presidential candidate to run and make money on it
column3: ” has attracted criticism for mixing business and politics to an unprecedented degree. He has made a point of highlighting his properties on the campaign trail
column4: leading opponents to accuse him of using his presidential bid to promote his brand and line his pockets.

column1: The campaign in a statement on Thursday rejected that criticism as “misleading and flat out wrong
column2: ” pointing out that the amount the campaign spent at Trump's businesses is far less than the $54 million of his own money that Trump has pumped into the campaign.

column1: The statement explained the campaign’s payments to TAG Air and other Trump-owned companies by saying “the campaign has used known quantities as far as event space
column2: air travel and accommodations
column3: and has fulfilled all FEC requirements throughout the campaign.”

column1: The government's practice of reimbursing campaigns for costs incurred by their Secret Service details dates from an era when campaigns were lower-budget affairs
column2: the logic being candidates shouldn't have to use their own resources on required security
column3: according to Craig Engle
column4: a political lawyer at Arent Fox who helped draft the provision as a staffer at the Federal Election Commission.

column1: It's basically just calling it even
column2: Engle said. ""It's either Trump making a contribution to the U.S. government
column3: or the U.S. government reimburses the Trump campaign for its expenses.""

column1: The same rationale applies to journalists who travel with the presidential candidates. The journalists or their employers reimburse the campaigns for travel costs. So it’s conceivable that media outlets might end up paying the Trump campaign for the cost of staying in a Trump-owned hotel or flying on a Trump-owned plane.

The Secret Service could also end up paying Trump's hotels to put up his agents when the candidate stays there. But those expenses don't appear in FEC reports because the government pays them directly.
The agency paid the Trump campaign an additional $724
column2: 000 for air travel that was refunded
column3: according to the FEC reports
column4: which do not offer an explanation for the refund.

column1: Of course
column2: Trump also travels on the campaign trail with his own robust private security detail. In August
column3: Trump’s campaign spent $232
column4: 800 on security-related costs
column5: including payments to private companies such as Xmark LLC
column6: Black Tie Protection Services and KS Global Group
column7: as well as local police in places he visited.

190	"Donald Trump is calling for one of the most controversial and racially charged policies enacted by police departments to be expanded across the entire country. The city of New York recently ended “stop and frisk
column2: ” but Trump is pushing for it
column3: apparently egged on by his top campaign surrogate
column4: former New York City mayor Rudy Giuliani. From Politico:

column1: In a pre-taped interview on Fox News scheduled to air Wednesday night
column2: Trump was asked by an audience member what he would do to address “violence in the black community” and “black-on-black crime.” Trump responded by proposing that “stop-and-frisk” policing
column3: in which an officer is empowered to stop an individual and frisk them for weapons or any other illegal contraband
column4: be adopted nationwide. “I would do stop-and-frisk. I think you have to. We did it in New York
column5: it worked incredibly well and you have to be proactive and
column6: you know
column7: you really help people sort of change their mind automatically
column8: ” Trump told the questioner.

column1: Stop-and-frisk was repeatedly called out and protested against by New York City residents because the policy was shown time and time again to disproportionately target black and Latino residents. They were singled out for examination and interrogation by police officers
column2: in what some felt were quotas set up by police management.

column1: When the city stopped using stop-and-frisk
column2: they did not see an increase in crime
column3: despite claims from its supporters that there would be a spike in criminal activity. Most people who had been subject to stop-and-frisk were let go
column4: because they hadn’t done anything wrong.

column1: Former US District Court Judge Shira Scheindlin
column2: who had ruled the procedure unconstitutional in federal court
column3: described it as “destructive” in an interview with Buzzfeed. She added:

column1: “In short

191	"Toby Keith has been forced to cancel his show in South Carolina and it was totally unexpected.

Toby Keith was scheduled to perform at the Florence Civic Center in South Carolina on September 22 and he was forced to cancel. Unfortunately the night before the concert Toby Keith sent out an update to all of his fans sharing the heartbreaking news.

The good news is that Toby Keith didn’t have to cancel his concert because he was ill or hurt. The bad news is that there are huge fuel shortages in South Carolina and the gas prices are continuing to rise in the Southeast. The General Manager of the Florence Civic Center
column2: Kendall Wall
column3: shared that the venue had received many messages from fans stating that they weren’t going to be able to make it because of the fuel cancern.

column1: Both Keith’s managers and the Florence Civic center decided that it was best for the fans if the concert was postponed to a later date. They wanted it to be fair for everyone who had already purchased their tickets.
“This is a major show for the region which attracts fans within a one- to two-hour drive and beyond…We understand the growing concerns for Toby’s fans and our own fans
column2: as we’ve been receiving distress messages over the past couple days…It would be unfair for these fans and unrealistic for them to travel given the current dismal situation with gas prices and availability.”

column1: The rescheduled concert date is March 7
column2: 2017 and the tickets will be honored for that concert. If any fan is unable to make the rescheduled concert date
column3: there will be refunds made but only for a short amount of time.

column1: Toby Keith is one of the most respected country artists and we hope that those fans who could have made the concert are understanding of the cancelation.
I’m glad that everyone is okay
column2: but it is such a bummer that these things have to happen. 193	"John Kerry says Washington cannot be successful alone. | AP Photo Kerry says Syrian diplomacy at impasse after truce collapses

NEW YORK — The United States and Russia ended any pretenses Thursday of their cease-fire for Syria remaining in force after days of increased violence and the Syrian military's announcement of a new offensive in Aleppo.
We can't go out to the world and say we have an agreement when we don't
column2: Secretary of State John Kerry said after meeting the top diplomats from Russia and more than a dozen European and Middle Eastern countries.

column1: Story Continued Below
Kerry's statement
column2: after three days of private and public diplomacy on the sidelines of the U.N. General Assembly
column3: provided an ominous endnote to a week diplomats had hoped would be a major capstone toward peace. Instead
column4: Kerry and Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov
column5: who negotiated the truce two weeks ago
column6: went their separate ways as violence in Syria flared anew and the relationship between the two key foreign powers in the conflict appeared to reach a new low.

column1: No one spoke of being able to quickly resuscitate the cease-fire. While Kerry and Lavrov were set to hold more talks Friday
column2: even confidence-building measures seem beyond their reach at this point.

column1: As the diplomats huddled in a New York hotel
column2: Syria's military command said it would restart operations in the northern city of Aleppo
column3: scene of some of the most bitter fighting in recent months.

column1: According to one official present in the gathering
column2: Kerry was informed of the news when his chief of staff showed him a headline on his BlackBerry. A furious Kerry then told the entire room
column3: Lavrov included
column4: that ""even while we are meeting here
column5: they are doing this
column6: said the official
column7: who wasn't authorized to speak publicly on the matter and demanded anonymity.

column1: Lavrov told Russian media that consultations would continue to ""guarantee"" the cease-fire.
But even as Kerry vowed to press on with all efforts to find a peaceful solution to the war between Syrian President Bashar Assad's Russian-backed government and U.S.-backed rebels
column2: he acknowledged the current strategy wasn't working.

column1: We can't be the only ones trying to hold this door open
column2: Kerry told reporters. ""Russia and the regime must do their part or this will have no chance.""

column1: He called for the immediate grounding of planes and helicopters that have launched airstrikes
column2: including a Russian one earlier this week that the U.S. says hit an aid convoy
column3: killing 20 civilians. Russia has denied responsibility
column4: while raising a range of ulterior scenarios for how the caravan might have been struck.

column1: Absent a major gesture like this
column2: we don't believe there is a point to making more promises or issuing more plans or announcing something that can't be reached
column3: Kerry said
column4: describing a ""moment of truth"" for Syria
column5: Russia and all those trying to halt the bloodshed.

column1: The meeting came after Assad told the AP in an interview in Damascus that the United States was to blame for the deal's failure. He cited U.S. inability to control ""terrorist"" groups and a weekend attack that killed dozens of Syrian soldiers. The U.S. apologized for what it described as a mistake.
Lavrov had sought a three-day pause in fighting to revive the cease-fire.
But U.S. officials said there was no point returning to a situation in which rebels would be pressed to hold fire
column2: while the Syrian and Russian military's could violate the agreement.

194	"Nine years ago
column2: a driver lost control of his pickup truck and crashed into the Confederate monument on the front lawn of the Franklin County Courthouse
column3: decapitating the marble soldier. Some locals who found the monument offensive said they were glad to see it go
column4: but there was never much doubt that once the money was raised
column5: the soldier would be back.

column1: The rededication ceremony in 2010 drew a crowd of about 500 people—women wore hoop skirts and men donned the gray uniforms of Confederate soldiers. “We’re very proud of it
column2: ” says Linda Stanley
column3: managing director of the Franklin County Historical Society in Rocky Mount
column4: Virginia
column5: 25 miles southeast of Roanoke. “This whole county’s very
column6: very patriotic.”

column1: Story Continued Below
This was the way skirmishes over Confederate history have often gone—history is replaced
column2: not rewritten. That is
column3: until last year
column4: when white supremacist Dylann Roof gunned down nine people at an African-American church in Charleston
column5: South Carolina. The massacre set off a national debate about Confederate symbols in public places
column6: leading to an intense and ultimately successful campaign to permanently remove the Confederate flag from the South Carolina capitol grounds
column7: where it had flown for decades.

column1: But for every nationally publicized debate like the one over South Carolina’s flag
column2: there are dozens of smaller battles in places like Franklin County. And this is especially true in Virginia
column3: which
column4: as the former home to the capital of the Confederacy
column5: has more Confederate monuments—223—than any other state. Virginia
column6: increasingly diverse and progressive
column7: embodies the friction between the economic aspirations of the “New South” and the still powerful nostalgia of the Old Dominion
column8: and it’s a drama that is playing out in town squares across the state.

column1: Though a Quinnipiac University poll last summer found Virginians evenly divided on the governor’s decision to remove the Confederate flag from state license plates
column2: pride in local monuments remains strong. When city leaders in Danville
column3: on Virginia’s southern border
column4: voted to remove a Confederate flag from the grounds of the Sutherlin Mansion—known as the Last Capitol of the Confederacy—Confederate preservationists struck back. They filed a lawsuit seeking to have the flag reinstated
column5: arguing that it was part of a war memorial
column6: and that Virginia law protected all war memorials in the state. Last fall
column7: a circuit court judge ruled against them.

column1: That ruling—along with the increasingly frequent threats to monuments around the state—prompted the Republican delegate from Franklin County to demand in January a blanket protection for what has been a feature of Southern urban landscapes for more than a century. Charles Poindexter introduced a bill in the General Assembly to prevent the removal of all war monuments
column2: regardless of when they were built. “If you eliminate these monuments and memorials
column3: you’re taking away the opportunity to learn the history of the country—to learn the good
column4: the bad and ugly
column5: ” Poindexter says.

column1: Many of his colleagues in the Virginia Legislature agreed with him. But in March
column2: Democratic Governor Terry McAuliffe vetoed the bill
column3: saying cities and towns should decide what to do with their Confederate monuments
column4: based on their individual histories. Some historians and civic leaders think the debate over Confederate symbols in public spaces
column5: which began in the 1960s
column6: will take decades to play out.

column1: “Every little statue’s a part of a much larger discussion and movement
column2: ” says Edward Ayers
column3: former president of the University of Richmond and noted Civil War historian. “African-Americans now have a political voice
column4: and this is one of the things that they’re using it for.”

column1: Mark Whitaker remembers walking by the 30-foot-tall Confederate monument in Portsmouth
column2: Virginia
column3: when he was a kid. Shopping at a store across the street
column4: he resented looking at the obelisk guarded by stone soldiers; his parents had told him what it represented. “My ancestors could not say a thing in the face of that indignity
column5: ” Whitaker says.

column1: Now
column2: as an African-American City Council member in a city that is 53 percent black
column3: he wants to remove the monument from the center of Olde Towne
column4: and perhaps put it in a cemetery. “These monuments are really a rally and a celebration [of] the rise of an institution that oppressed black people
column5: ” he says.

column1: Many of the Confederate monuments were built from the 1880s through the 1920s
column2: an era when Civil War veterans were dying and their descendants were eager to honor them. It was also the era immediately following Reconstruction
column3: when federal troops abandoned the South and whites aimed to reassert power through Jim Crow laws
column4: lynchings and groups such as the Ku Klux Klan. Granite and marble monuments proclaimed that power
column5: often in the center of town.

column1: But even in a majority-black city on the eastern shore of the state
column2: Whitaker has battled to get Portsmouth’s monument removed. Last summer
column3: attorney Fred Taylor
column4: who also represented Confederate preservationists in the Danville case
column5: warned the city that state law prohibited it from moving the monument. “We believe the monument protection act covers the monument in Danville
column6: covers the monument in Portsmouth
column7: ” Taylor says. He argues that the original Virginia statute protecting war monuments dates back to 1902
column8: so “there has been protection all along.”

column1: When the circuit court judge ruled against him in Danville
column2: Taylor appealed the case to the Virginia Supreme Court. So far
column3: the court has not agreed to hear the case.

column1: Back in Portsmouth
column2: the debate continues. Some residents don’t want the city to spend upward of $100
column3: 000 to move the monument—a position Whitaker finds ridiculous. “Why now
column4: when we talk about moving a symbol of racism
column5: we’re concerned about cost?”

column1: He says the Portsmouth City Council had been waiting to hear the outcome of the Danville court case but could resume its discussion of the monument after the November elections. “We’re on solid legal grounds to remove it
column2: ” he says. “We just need four votes.”

column1: Other Virginia cities have struck a middle ground
column2: forming committees to figure out what to do with their Confederate monuments. In May
column3: Charlottesville convened a Blue Ribbon Commission on Race
column4: Memorials
column5: and Public Spaces. Although the move was sparked by a controversial statue of Robert E. Lee in a public park
column6: Mayor Mike Signer was determined to broaden the conversation
column7: with an eye toward changing the city’s entire historic landscape.

column1: He asked the commission to look at several landmarks
column2: from an African-American cemetery that had fallen into disrepair to the statue of a Confederate boy in front of the courthouse. Members of the panel have discussed rehabbing and creating new historic interpretations for these sites
column3: building new monuments to African-American leaders and linking all the sites so that visitors can see how they are connected. There might even be a virtual
column4: mobile educational component to help people navigate the sites. The goal
column5: Signer says
column6: is to change the narrative of Charlottesville “by telling the full story of race through our public spaces.” The commission is slated to give its recommendations to the City Council in December.

column1: In the wealthy
column2: heavily Democratic city of Alexandria
column3: a similar advisory group decided not to remove the Appomattox statue in the middle of Old Town
column4: which depicts a defeated Confederate soldier with his eyes downcast. The United Daughters of the Confederacy owns the monument
column5: and moving it would require approval from the Virginia General Assembly. Also
column6: as the advisory group noted
column7: Appomattox is one of the rare Confederate statues that marks a historic site—the place where the 17th Virginia Regiment gathered to withdraw from Union occupation of the city in 1861. The group recommended labeling the statue with more historical context instead of taking it down.

column1: “Black Lives Matter” is spray painted on a monument to former Confederate President Jefferson Davis in Richmond
column2: Virginia
column3: in June 2015. | AP Photo

column1: Richmond
column2: the former capital of the Confederacy
column3: has an entire street lined with monuments to Confederate leaders. It’s also a majority-black city. In June 2015
column4: someone scrawled “Black Lives Matter” on the statue of former Confederate President Jefferson Davis. Yet Mayor Dwight Jones has not called for the monuments’ removal. Instead
column5: he suggested adding more statues of prominent black leaders—such as the bronze of tennis legend Arthur Ashe
column6: who was born in Richmond
column7: that the city erected in 1995. “Rather than tearing down
column8: we should be building up in ways that establish a proper sense of balance and fairness by recognizing heroes from all eras to tell a richer and more accurate story of Virginia’s history
column9: ” Jones said in a statement last summer.

column1: Delegate Poindexter tends to agree with Jones
column2: although he’s fuzzy on the specifics. Asked whether he would be in favor of adding more historical context to existing Confederate monuments
column3: he says
column4: “It’s far better than tearing down the current ones.”

column1: In his eyes
column2: the era in which the Confederate monuments were erected is “irrelevant.” “They need to be respected
column3: ” he says. “They didn’t know what we know today. That’s why these monuments are important.”

column1: Ayers says many people who push to preserve Confederate monuments share this attitude. “The white South has always been on the defensive ever since it tried to leave the United States
column2: ” he says. “They’ve taken what ground they can get
column3: and what they can get is personal memory and memorialization. It’s an amalgam of power and weakness.”

column1: “They’re meant to do work
column2: ” Ayers says. “The work that they were meant to do
column3: in some ways they’re still doing: Saying that this is a place where local white people call the shots.”

column1: In Franklin County
column2: the power struggle is deeply personal. Stanley says the area sent about 3
column3: 000 Confederate soldiers to what she calls “The War Between the States.” Veterans who returned home became mayors and town clerks and delegates. Beginning in 1902
column4: the local chapter of the United Daughters of the Confederacy started raising money for a memorial to honor the sons
column5: fathers and husbands who never made it home. They dedicated the monument in front of the courthouse in 1910.

column1: One of the people who agreed to donate money to the project was Booker T. Washington
column2: the famed African-American educator who was born into slavery on a farm in Franklin County in 1856. In 1905
column3: he wrote a letter offering to contribute funds for the Confederate memorial
column4: in honor of the family that owned him. As far as Stanley knows
column5: Washington did contribute some amount
column6: “we just don’t have a copy of the actual check.”

column1: Poindexter says Franklin County “lost hundreds of its best men” in the Civil War
column2: and for decades afterward
column3: Reconstruction was “a horrible process” that had a big impact on the region.

column1: Today
column2: Franklin County is home to about 56
column3: 200 people
column4: 90 percent of whom are white. They elected Poindexter
column5: a conservative Christian with an “A” rating from the National Rifle Association
column6: to the General Assembly for the first time in 2007. In 2014
column7: the county had a median household income of $44
column9: far below the state’s median of $64
column10: 792. Its residents voted Republican in the past three presidential races
column11: and many supported Poindexter’s efforts to save war monuments. “We didn’t want anybody pulling any monuments down
column12: ” Stanley says.

column1: Soon after the county replaced the Confederate memorial in front of the courthouse
column2: the local chapter of the NAACP suggested that a statue of Booker T. Washington be erected beside it. Other community leaders wanted to put up a pedestal honoring African-Americans who contributed to the county’s Civil War effort. The county board of supervisors tabled their request
column3: saying the community needed more time to discuss it.

column1: Civil War memorials are not generally a big tourist draw in the Roanoke region
column2: says Landon Howard
column3: president of Visit Virginia’s Blue Ridge. “To be candid
column4: we really do not get hardly any American Civil War visitation here.”

column1: Yet locals have their own loyalties. Every year
column2: the Franklin County Historical Society celebrates Veterans Memorial Day
column3: honoring all local casualties of military conflicts. According to the society’s website
column4: “Special emphasis is placed on veterans of the War Between the States as this war touched literally every household in the county.”

column1: Confederate General Jubal Early was born in Franklin County
column2: and he’s known as one of the rebels who never surrendered. “He became the primary spokesman for the Lost Cause and became the overwhelming authority on published Confederate history
column3: ” says the website of the Jubal A. Early Homeplace.

column1: Speaking by phone from his farm in Franklin County
column2: Poindexter isn’t ready to surrender
column3: either. He doesn’t know whether he’ll propose his monument protection bill again next year
column4: but he hasn’t ruled it out. “If you start tearing down monuments ... where do you stop?” he says. “You can’t change what was
column5: but you can learn from it and not make that mistake again.”

column1: Lisa Rab is a journalist in Charlotte
column2: N.C. Her work has appeared in Mother Jones and The Village Voice
column3: among other outlets. virginia law protected all war memorials the state last fall circuit court judge ruled against them that ruling—along with the increasingly frequent threats monuments around the state—prompted the assembly prevent the removal all war monuments regardless when they were built “if you eliminate these monuments and memorials you’re taking away the opportunity learn the history the country—to learn monuments proclaimed that power often the center town but even majority black city the eastern shore the state whitaker has battled get portsmouth’s monument removed last summer attorney fred taylor who also represented confederate preservationists the danville case warned the city that state law prohibited from moving the monument “we believe the monument protection act covers the monument danville covers the monument portsmouth taylor says argues that the original virginia statute protecting war monuments dates back 1902 “there has been protection all along ” when the circuit court judge ruled against him danville taylor appealed the case the virginia supreme court far the court has not agreed hear the case back portsmouth the debate continues some residents don’t want the city spend upward 100 000 move the monument—a position whitaker finds ridiculous “why now when talk about moving symbol racism we’re concerned about cost says the portsmouth city council had been waiting hear the outcome the danville court case but could resume its discussion the monument after the november elections “we’re solid legal grounds remove says “we just need four votes ”     other virginia cities have struck middle ground forming committees figure out what with their confederate monuments may charlottesville convened blue ribbon commission race memorials and public spaces although the move was sparked controversial statue robert lee public park mayor mike signer was determined broaden the conversation with eye toward changing the city’s entire historic landscape asked the commission look several landmarks from african american cemetery that had fallen into disrepair the statue confederate boy front the courthouse members the panel have discussed rehabbing and creating new historic interpretations for these sites building new monuments african american leaders and linking all the sites that visitors can see how they are connected there might even virtual mobile educational component help people navigate the sites the goal signer says change the narrative charlottesville “by telling the full story race through our public spaces ” the commission slated give its recommendations the city council december the wealthy heavily democratic city alexandria similar advisory group decided not remove the appomattox statue the middle old town which depicts defeated confederate soldier with his eyes downcast the united daughters the confederacy owns the monument and moving would require approval from the virginia general assembly also the advisory group noted appomattox one the rare confederate statues that marks historic site—the place where the 17th virginia regiment gathered withdraw from union occupation the city 1861  the group recommended labeling the statue with more historical context instead taking down “black lives matter” spray painted monument former confederate president jefferson davis richmond virginia june 2015 photo richmond the former capital the confederacy has entire street lined with monuments confederate leaders it’s also majority black city june 2015 someone scrawled “black lives matter” the statue former confederate was born richmond that the city erected 1995 “rather than tearing down should building ways that establish proper sense balance and fairness recognizing heroes from all eras tell richer and more accurate story virginia’s history jones said statement last summer delegate poindexter tends agree with jones although he’s fuzzy the specifics asked whether would favor adding more historical context existing confederate monuments says “it’s far better than tearing down the current ones ” his eyes the era which the confederate monuments were erected “irrelevant ” “they need respected says “they memorials are not generally big tourist draw the roanoke region says landon howard president visit virginia’s blue ridge “to candid really not get hardly any american civil war visitation here ” yet column1: 195	"A 22-year-old Muslim man from Afghanistan proudly declared that he was a superstar in Afghanistan after he sodomized and orally raped a 2-year-old boy. The worst part is that he was only charged with sexual assault and only sentenced to two years in prison.
The UK’s Express reports:
Jama B.
column3: showed no remorse as he was sentenced to just two years and four months behind bars on the milder charge of sexual abuse of the four-year-old boy at the centre in Boostedt
column4: Schleswig-Holstein.

column1: The toddler
column2: from Iraq
column3: was lured into a toilet cubicle at the home in March this year. The court heard the Afghani forced his penis into the child’s mouth. Afterwards the distraught youngster was returned to his father with his trousers down around his ankles.

column1: During the trial Jama B. boasted: “I’m a superstar in Afghanistan
column2: a singer.”

column1: Judge Stefan Becker refused to comment on the verdict but Peter Boysen
column2: the lawyer who represented the family of the child
column3: said: “it was a one-off act that did not take very long and hopefully will not have harmful long-term effects on the child.

column1: “Therefore there is no reason to complain
column2: even if the sentence could have been maybe half a year longer. I have not therefore advised the parents to appeal against the verdict. He’s better again
column3: the boy
column4: but is still in therapeutic treatment of a child and adolescent psychiatrist.

column1: Jama showed absolutely no remorse for his crime.
A second man
column2: Sohrab S.
column4: allegedly stood guard outside the toilet during the assault
column5: which was really rape. He was acquitted for lack of evidence.

column1: Prosecutor Axel Bieler said
column2: “Rape charges are brought only if it was enforced with violence or the threat of violence. We do not assume this was the case.

column1: “Therefore he was indicted on a charge of serious sexual abuse. The penalty doesn’t matter – it is between two and 15 years in jail for rape or for serious sexual abuse.”
Say what? How about the fact that it was forced and that it was upon a child? What kind of mind does Axel Bieler have? I can tell you it is not a critically thinking judicial mind for sure.
Karin Witt is not better. The spokeswoman of the Kiel court said
column2: “The court found no reasons for an increased penalty
column3: such as for example a criminal record for the accused.

column1: “The fact that he was under the influence of alcohol and the high sensitivity towards detention of the offender were both factors in the sentence
column2: ” she added. “He is young
column3: knows no German and has already been attacked in pre-trial detention. The victim has also dealt well with the experience of what happened to him and there are no serious consequences to be expected.”

column1: What’s even worse is the comments by the family’s attorney.
“It was a one-off act that did not take very long and hopefully will not have harmful long-term effects on the child
column2: ” Peter Boysen said. “Therefore there is no reason to complain
column3: even if the sentence could have been maybe half a year longer. I have not therefore advised the parents to appeal against the verdict. He’s better again
column4: the boy
column5: but is still in therapeutic treatment of a child and adolescent psychiatrist.

column1: Really
column2: Mr. Boysen? How about if this was your little boy? Would you still have the same cold-hearted response at this crime? I think not.

column1: Germans were outraged at the charges and the sentencing.
“The incredible verdict of the prosecutor and the court
column2: ” wrote the Bild am Sonntag newspaper. “This is the verdict that shames you all.”

column1: People continuing to make excuses for criminal sexual crimes
column2: especially for those who are most innocent among us are a part of the larger problem. Allowing the foreign god of Islam in what was once a Christian country is problematic enough. Excusing the pagans that practice the ideology of Muhammad and engaging in these kinds of crimes is just adding fuel to the fire.

column1: Don’t think it won’t be happening in the united States either. Our own military kicked out Sgt. Charles Martlandfor defending a boy that was raped in Afghanistan and told other members of our military to keep silent about such abuses. Do you really think our representatives are going to stand up for the children when they’ve allowed them to be slaughtered by the millions? I think not.
In a biblical society
column2: this man would have been put to death
column3: and rightly so.

column1: 196	"Story highlights Ivanka Trump will be attending a roundtable hosted by Washington Rep. Cathy McMorris Rodgers
Trump will hear about the issues GOP House members and Senators are working on in Congress
Washington (CNN) Ivanka Trump will join female Republican House members and senators Tuesday in Washington to promote the GOP nominee's proposals on child care
column2: in a continued effort by father's presidential campaign to reach out to women voters.

column1: The highest-ranking female House GOP leader
column2: Washington Rep. Cathy McMorris Rodgers
column3: is hosting the roundtable at the Republican National Committee
column4: according to Donald Trump's campaign and a GOP congressional source. McMorris Rodgers worked closely with Trump's daughter on the plans that were officially unveiled last week at an event in suburban Philadelphia. McMorris Rodgers is the only House member to give birth three times while in office.

column1: Ivanka Trump is a top adviser and surrogate for her father's campaign and frequently mentions his record of hiring female executives in top positions in his businesses. As a mother of three Trump did several interviews with national outlets about the campaign's new proposals for paid maternity leave and more affordable child care. But she abruptly ended an interview with Cosmopolitan Magazine when the reporter pressed her on previous comments by Donald Trump on pregnant employees
column2: accusing the interviewer of bias.

column1: Tuesday's session will cover workplace flexibility
column2: child care
column3: equal pay and the policies the campaign rolled out last week. Trump will also hear from the roughly 15 House members and senators about the issues they are working on in Congress
column4: according to two GOP sources familiar with the plans.

197	"President Obama is right — it appears the people running the Trump campaign skipped their history and civics classes.
After Donald Trump got a lashing from black activists after claiming it’s “never been worse” for them than it is right now
column2: one would think the campaign would have gotten the message and moved on accordingly.

column1: Wrong.
As usual
column2: no one in the Trump campaign learns their lesson. And their sheer ignorance has cost them a key staff member in a key swing state.

column1: Trump’s campaign chair in the prominent Mahoning County in Ohio
column2: Kathy Miller
column3: has resigned from her position after denying there was any racism in the 1960s and that if black people weren’t successful in the last 50 years
column4: it’s their own fault. She also said there wasn’t “any racism until Obama got elected” and skirted problems under the table:

column1: If you’re black and you haven’t been successful in the last 50 years
column2: it’s your own fault. You’ve had every opportunity
column3: it was given to you. You’ve had the same schools everybody else went to. You had benefits to go to college that white kids didn’t have. You had all the advantages and didn’t take advantage of it. It’s not our fault
column4: certainly.

column1: Miller then doubled down
column2: calling the Black Lives Matter movement a “stupid waste of time” and said low voter turnout in the African American community as due to “the way they’re raised.”

column1: What does “the way they’re raised
column2: ” supposed to mean? Maybe Miller should take a look at the fact that the Trump kids didn’t vote (and couldn’t even vote for their dad) before speculating on how an entire race raises their kids.

column1: Miller resigned
column2: gave a half-ass apology
column3: and distanced herself from the campaign. Of course Trump’s Ohio state director
column4: Bob Paduchik stressed that Miller’s comments were not reflective of the campaign
column5: and reduced her position to that of a simple “volunteer” to steer away any influence she once held.

column1: Once again
column2: the Trump campaign deflects
column3: blames
column4: and dodges responsibility. Oh
column5: and it once again shows that it’s being run by a bunch of entitled white racists.

198	"NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg looks on during a press conference | Adem Altan/AFP via Getty NATO chief counterattacks against Donald Trump The alliance ‘has been fighting terrorism for years
column2: ’ says Jens Stoltenberg.

column1: BRATISLAVA — NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg struck back Tuesday at Donald Trump over the U.S. presidential candidate’s claim that the Atlantic alliance is now fighting terrorism only because of his criticism.
“NATO has been focused on the fight against terrorism for many
column2: many years and it’s not a result of the U.S. elections campaign
column3: ” said Stoltenberg in a press conference during a gathering of European defense ministers in Bratislava.

column1: Trump
column2: who has been critical of NATO and even gone so far as to question the U.S. membership of it
column3: said Monday night in a debate with his presidential opponent Hillary Clinton that he now supported the alliance.

column1: “I’m all for NATO
column2: ” Trump said. “But I said they have to focus on terror
column3: also. And they’re going to do that. And that was — believe me
column4: I’m sure I’m not going to get credit for it — but that was largely because of what I was saying and my criticism of NATO.”

column1: Stoltenberg
column2: a former Norwegian prime minister
column3: defended NATO’s track record of fighting terrorism.

column1: “We went into Afghanistan to prevent Afghanistan from becoming a safe heaven for international terrorists
column2: ” he said
column3: stressing that it was “our biggest military operation ever.” NATO “has and is playing a key role in the fight against terrorism” and the organization has “stepped up our efforts to support the U.S.-led coalition to fight ISIL.”

column1: Stoltenberg also said that NATO’s newly created position of assistant to the secretary-general for intelligence “will also be a tool in our efforts to fight terrorism
column2: to share intelligence.” But he insisted the role is “something which has been planned and discussed for a long time and is not a result of the U.S. election campaign.”"	nato secretary general column1: 199	"Reps. John Lewis (D-Ga.)
column2: Brenda Lawrence (D-Mich.)
column3: Maxine Waters (D-Calif.) and Cedric Richmond (D-La.)
column4: along with other members of the Congressional Black Caucus
column5: hold a news conference after marching to the Department of Justice on Thursday. | Getty Black Caucus marches to DOJ to protest shootings

column1: More than a dozen members of the Congressional Black Caucus marched down to the Department of Justice midday to demand federal intervention to stymie police shootings of unarmed African-Americans.
The killing of unarmed black men and women by police is a crisis
column2: said Rep. Maxine Waters (D-Calif.).

column1: Story Continued Below
The letter calls on Lynch to “aggressively pursue investigations
column2: indictments and prosecutions through the Office of Civil Rights against any and all law enforcement officers who harm or kill innocent
column3: unarmed black men
column4: women and children.”

column1: CBC members said it’s also time for Congress to act.

“We are going to make sure that we push for legislation so we’re going to be calling on [House Speaker] Paul Ryan to come up with some legislation that we can work on and put forward to change this. But in the meanwhile
column2: we want the attorney general to utilize her powers
column3: ” Rep. Gregory Meeks (D-N.Y.).

column1: But other lawmakers said the proposals are already out there
column2: they just need a push from leadership.

column1: A lot of what we need has already been drafted
column2: mostly by members of this caucus
column3: said Rep. Cedric Richmond (D-La.)
column4: specifically mentioning criminal justice reform and police accountability legislation.

column1: Ryan (R-Wis.) said earlier this week he still hopes to pass criminal justice reform in the lame duck.
“I think people have lost trust
column2: they’ve lost hope in some instances
column3: ” said Charlotte Rep. Alma Adams (D)
column4: who flew back from North Carolina this morning.

column1: “They see hope here with the attorney general and they want her to step in to use her power to make sure people are treated fairly and there is some justice and there is some transparency
column2: ” she added.

column1: The members didn’t actually walk all the way from the Capitol to DOJ headquarters
column2: which is about a mile away. Instead
column3: lawmakers boarded a bus at the Capitol and disembarked about two blocks from DOJ
column4: walking the rest of the way.

200	"Wouldn’t it be nice if we could just kick bigots out of our country? Well
column2: that’s exactly what happened when anti-gay Arizona pastor Stephen Anderson stopped by Botswana for a visit and decided to preach hate.

column1: Anderson’s road to Botswana was an eventful one
column2: with the United Kingdom banning him from so much as getting on a connecting flight in their country. This forced him to find a “roundabout” way to get to Botswana
column3: where he intended to spend quite some time preaching. But after he suggested that homosexuals be stoned to death in a radio interview
column4: Anderson learned that his hatred is not tolerated everywhere.

column1: “I have identified Steven Anderson as an undesirable person to travel to South Africa
column2: ” Home Affairs Minister Malusi Gigaba told the BBC. The country’s Constitution
column3: unlike ours

column2: in Wonsan
column3: North Korea. | AP Photo DOJ: Chinese company tried to evade U.S. sanctions against North Korea

column1: A Chinese company and four of its employees accused of attempting to evade U.S. sanctions against North Korea were the target of a set of enforcement actions announced Monday morning by the Department of Justice.
Chinese trading company Dandong Hongxiang Industrial Development Co. Ltd.
column2: its majority owner and three of its managers are charged with conspiring to violate the International Emergency Economic Powers Act and Weapons of Mass Destruction Proliferators Sanctions Regulations. They are also charged with attempting to defraud the United States and conspiring to engage in international money laundering.

column1: Story Continued Below
The charges arise from financial transactions using U.S. dollars between Dandong Hongxiang Industrial Development and Korea Kwangson Banking Corporation
column2: which is under both U.S. and UN sanctions. Those transactions
column3: according to the Justice Department
column4: were conducted both by Dandong Hongxiang Industrial Development as well as by “numerous front companies” that it controlled.

column1: The Justice Department also announced a civil complaint
column2: seeking the civil forfeiture of all the money held in the 25 Chinese bank accounts of Dandong Hongxiang Industrial Development and its front corporations. Those accounts are subject to forfeiture
column3: the Justice Department said
column4: because they received hundreds of millions of dollars that arrived via the United States. Because the money was routed through the U.S.
column5: it falls under American jurisdiction
column6: the department said.

column1: Pressure has mounted on President Barack Obama’s administration to crack down on China
column2: North Korea’s largest trading partner and international protector
column3: since the isolated nation’s latest nuclear test earlier this month. Republicans and even Obama’s own former secretary of state Hillary Clinton have urged the president to more forcefully pressure China to enforce international sanctions against North Korea.

column1: Rep. Ed Royce (R-Calif.) has specifically called on Obama to put to use the North Korea Sanctions and Policy Enhancement Act
column2: a law signed by the president earlier this year that affords his administration authority to sanction any individual who ""imports
column3: exports
column4: or re-exports luxury goods to or into North Korea"" or ""engages in money laundering
column5: counterfeiting of goods or currency
column6: bulk cash smuggling
column7: or narcotics trafficking that supports the government of North Korea or its senior officials.""

column1: Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump has blamed Clinton for North Korea’s most recent nuclear launch. Jason Miller
column2: Trump’s senior communications adviser
column3: labeled it “one more example of Hillary Clinton's catastrophic failures as secretary of state
column4: and added that ""Clinton promised to work to end North Korea’s nuclear program as secretary of state
column5: yet the program has only grown in strength and sophistication.""

204	"We are absolutely heartbroken to hear about the death of someone that was so special to everyone in country music.
She always had a smile on her face and she lit up any room that she walked into. Jean Shepard was 82 years old and after only a couple of days in hospice care we had to say our goodbyes.

Jean Shepard was a Grand Ole Opry member and she wasn’t just any member. Shepard was known as the “Grand Lady”. In 1955 she was inducted and in 2015 she was the only female that had ever been a member of the Opry for 60 years – which is how she earned the name.
The Grand Lady was also inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame a couple of years ago in 2011. She was passionate about country music
column2: and loved what it stood for.

column1: Of course
column2: like many older stars she felt like country music just isn’t the same as what it used to be. In one of her final interviews with Women Of Country at the Grand Ole Opry she told all.

column1: “Sixty years ago
column2: I loved what the Grand Ole Opry stood for
column3: …I still love what it stands for
column4: but not quite so much. Isn’t it terrible being so truthful?”

column1: The Grand Lady passed away from complications due to Parkinson’s disease on September 25
column2: 2016. Jean’s publicist shared about her life in a press release and we are heartbroken.

column1: “Jean was born Ollie Imogene Shepard in Oklahoma and raised one of ten children in Visalia
column2: California. At age 14 she was spotted by country star Hank Thompson singing and playing bass in the all-girl band she’d formed called the Melody Ranch Girls. Thompson brought her to the attention of Capitol Records and soon the trailblazing Shepard was setting the precedent in country music for a young woman recording and touring on her own rather than as a member of a family act
column3: a duo
column4: or a band’s ‘girl singer.'”

column1: There is truly no one like Jean
column2: and there never will be another Grand Lady. She was survived by her husband and her 3 sons.

column1: Please continue to pray for this family during their time of loss.

RIP JEAN SHEPARD"	are absolutely heartbroken hear about the death someone that was special everyone country music she always had smile her face and she lit any room that she walked into jean shepard was years old and after only couple days hospice care had say our goodbyes jean shepard was grand ole opry member and she wasn’t just any member shepard was known the “grand lady” 1955 she was inducted and 2015 she was the only female that had ever been member the opry for years which how she earned the name the grand lady was also inducted into the country music hall fame couple years ago 2011  she was passionate about country music and loved what stood for course like many older stars she felt like country music just isn’t the same what used one her final interviews with women country the grand ole opry she told all “sixty years ago loved what the grand ole opry stood for still love what stands for but not quite much isn’t terrible being truthful the grand lady passed away from complications due parkinson’s disease september 2016  jean’s publicist shared about her life press release and are heartbroken “jean was born ollie imogene shepard oklahoma and raised one ten children visalia california age she was spotted country star hank thompson singing and playing bass the all girl band she’d formed called the melody ranch girls thompson brought her the attention capitol records and soon the trailblazing shepard was setting the precedent country music for young woman recording and touring her own rather than member family act duo band’s ‘girl singer there truly one like jean and there never will another grand lady she was survived her husband and her sons please continue pray for this family during their time loss rip jean shepard	America Just Tragically Lost A Country Music Icon
