column1: 205	"Story highlights Boy sent letter to Barack Obama
column2: offering to take in five-year-old Syrian refugee Omran.

column1: After posting the letter on Facebook
column2: the US President urged readers: ""We should all be more like Alex.""

column1: (CNN) A six-year-old boy from New York has won the respect of US President Barack Obama and thousands of others after he offered to take in Omran Daqneesh
column2: a little boy who was injured after his home in Aleppo
column3: Syria
column4: was bombed.

column1: The image of five-year-old Omran sat alone in an ambulance
column2: covered in dust and blood
column3: shocked the world and inspired six-year-old Alex
column4: from Scarsdale
column5: New York
column6: to take action.

column1: In a handwritten letter sent to the White House
column2: Alex asked Obama to go and collect Omran and bring him to his house where ""we will be waiting for you guys with flags
column3: flowers
column4: and balloons.""

column1: In his letter to Obama
column2: Alex offered to teach Omran how to ride a bike.

column1: Alex said that Omran could be part of his family
column2: and offered to be his brother. He said he would teach him how to speak English
column3: to ride a bike and added that his sister Catherine would share her toys with him.

column1: Obama read Alex's words aloud in a speech he gave at the United Nations earlier this week
column2: before posting a video of Alex reading the letter himself to Facebook.

column1: 206	"President Barack Obama has never had a great relationship with Saudi Arabia.
Now
column2: he’s the last man standing between the wealthy desert kingdom and billions of dollars in potential liabilities.

column1: Story Continued Below

Obama has cast the Saudis as ""so-called"" allies; bemoaned the terrorist-inspiring version of Islam they practice; and even suggested the oil-rich Arab state learn to ""share"" the Middle East with rival Iran. The Saudis
column2: meanwhile
column3: consider Obama naive
column4: sparring with him over the Iran nuclear deal and questioning his hands-off approach to Syria’s bloody civil war.

column1: Despite these differences
column2: Obama has promised to veto a bill that Congress passed unanimously allowing families of 9/11 victims to sue Saudi Arabia over alleged links to the 2001 terrorist attacks.

column1: That Obama and Riyadh find themselves on the same side against Congress underscores the bizarre evolution of U.S.-Saudi ties over the past eight years. An alliance once unquestioned in Washington now faces an extraordinary level of criticism
column2: but the two countries still need each other enough that a breakup is simply not in the cards.

column1: This is clearly a relationship in transition
column2: said Jon Alterman
column3: an analyst with the Center for Strategic and International Studies. ""Nobody really has a sense of what they’re trying to transition it to.""

column1: Just how tricky is the relationship? Two more examples: Obama is supporting the Saudis in their fight against Iran-backed rebels in Yemen
column2: even though U.S. officials worry the fight there is distracting from the more important battle against the Islamic State. And many of the same U.S. lawmakers happy to make it easier to sue the Saudis just this week green-lit a $1.15 billion arms sale to the country. ""Does no one sense the irony?” asked Republican Sen. Rand Paul of Kentucky
column3: one of a handful of lawmakers who tried to block the weapons deal in the Senate.

column1: The back and forth in Washington is ""schizophrenic behavior"" that has deeply frustrated leaders in the Middle East for years
column2: said a former senior U.S. official deeply familiar with the Arab world.

column1: Congress passed the lawsuit bill under intense pressure from families of victims and just ahead of the 15th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks. The Saudis
column2: through direct contacts as well as a powerful set of lobbyists
column3: have tried hard to stop it
column4: waging a major PR effort that included releasing a white paper detailing the kingdom's efforts to stop terrorists. The Saudis deny any government role in the attacks and note that the U.S. has never found proof of it
column5: either. The Saudis also have warned they will sell off billions of dollars in U.S. assets to protect themselves against lawsuits.

column1: Administration officials downplay the idea that Obama will veto the bill merely to protect Saudi Arabia. Normally
column2: U.S. citizens aren't allowed to sue foreign governments under the concept of sovereign immunity. Obama's concern
column3: officials say
column4: thus goes well beyond the Saudis; he's worried that the bill erodes the sovereign immunity principle and could lead other countries to allow the U.S. to be sued over its actions abroad.

column1: To pass a piece of legislation that would open up our diplomats and our service members and even American businesses to potential lawsuits in courts all around the world is foolish
column2: White House spokesman Josh Earnest said in a recent press briefing.

column1: The perception in many quarters
column2: however
column3: is that Obama is coming to the aid of a country with much to hide. Fifteen of the 19 hijackers on Sept. 11
column5: were Saudi nationals. And the recent declassification of roughly 30 pages from a 2002 congressional probe into the 9/11 attacks raised more questions about Saudi government ties to Islamist extremists.

column1: We are disappointed that the president is not standing with us
column2: said Mindy Kleinberg
column3: who lost her husband in the attacks and was meeting with lawmakers Thursday to push for a veto override. ""We have been waiting a very long time for justice
column4: and we feel that this bill will go a long way toward accountability.""

column1: Whatever his motivation
column2: Obama's decision to veto the bill is unlikely to do much to ease Saudi suspicions.

column1: The Saudis' wariness of Obama has its roots in his comments in 2002
column2: well before he ran for president
column3: referring to the monarchy in Riyadh as a so-called ally. It grew after Obama sided against Egyptian strongman Hosni Mubarak during the 2011 Arab Spring movements
column4: leading Saudi royals to question whether America would have their backs in a domestic political crisis of their own.

column1: It deepened in 2013
column2: after Obama decided not to stage a military strike against Syrian President Bashar Assad
column3: who is despised by the Saudis
column4: even after Assad apparently crossed Obama's ""red line"" by using chemical weapons. And it reached a new peak in 2015 after Obama struck a nuclear deal with Iran
column5: a Shiite theocracy that Sunni-majority Saudi Arabia views as a growing threat in the Middle East.

column1: Still
column2: Obama
column3: cognizant of the need for the U.S. to maintain alliances with stable countries in the Middle East
column4: has otherwise tried hard to allay Saudi concerns. He cut short a trip to India to rush to see the newly crowned Saudi king
column5: Salman
column6: in January 2015
column7: after the previous monarch died. He also has pushed for new weapons and other security agreements with the Saudis
column8: in part to assuage Saudi concerns about the Iran nuclear deal.

column1: But earlier this year
column2: in comments to the Atlantic magazine that infuriated the Saudis
column3: Obama appeared to reverse decades of U.S. policy that tilted heavily toward Riyadh and against Tehran.

column1: “The competition between the Saudis and the Iranians — which has helped to feed proxy wars and chaos in Syria and Iraq and Yemen — requires us to say to our friends as well as to the Iranians that they need to find an effective way to share the neighborhood and institute some sort of cold peace
column2: ” Obama said.

column1: Prince Turki Al-Faisal
column2: the former head of Saudi intelligence
column3: wrote in an extraordinary open letter soon afterward that Obama had ""thrown us a curve ball"" and criticizing the president for saying America’s Gulf allies were “free riders” wholly dependent on the U.S. for their security.

column1: And in April
column2: weeks after the Atlantic piece was published
column3: Saudi Arabia appeared to snub Obama when he visited Riyadh for a summit by sending a lower-level official to greet him at the airport and not broadcasting his arrival on state TV. The readouts from those meetings in Riyadh also suggested the president hadn't done much to assuage Saudi concerns
column4: with the two sides saying they'd ""discussed"" and ""exchanged views"" more than agreeing on anything.

column1: The president also hosted Saudi Arabia’s deputy crown prince
column2: Mohammed Bin Salman
column3: when he visited Washington this summer on a trip aimed at improving the kingdom’s image in Washington. Obama made sure to praise the prince's plan to transform the Saudi economy
column4: dubbed Vision 2030. He also tried to reassure the Saudi royal that the U.S. will back the Saudis against interference by Iran
column5: which remains an official enemy of the United States.

column1: But some constants in the U.S.-Saudi relationship have turned into variables
column2: meaning that even after Obama leaves office in just a few months
column3: the alliance could prove rocky.

column1: The low price of oil
column2: for example
column3: is forcing the kingdom to rethink its economy; the U.S. also relies more now on its own energy reserves
column4: reducing America’s addiction to Saudi oil. Some observers also point to cultural changes in deeply conservative Saudi Arabia — women
column5: though still facing severe segregation
column6: make up a growing share of the workforce; young people are more exposed than ever to the Internet and the outside world; and thousands of Saudis educated in the U.S. are now capitalizing on that experience in their country.

column1: By all accounts
column2: the U.S. and Saudi Arabia still maintain a strong security relationship
column3: and U.S. officials privately say the Saudis are helpful partners in the fight against terrorist groups such as Al Qaeda
column4: which the Saudi monarchy views as a threat to its own rule. U.S. officials also say the Saudis have taken steps in recent years to silence the most radical of their Islamist preachers and change their school curricula to be more tolerant.

column1: The close cooperation on countering violent extremists like [the Islamic State]
column2: the continued Saudi preference for American arms
column3: the important role that Saudi Arabia plays in international energy markets and the $70 billion dollars worth of annual trade between the two countries are enough to sustain this relationship for the foreseeable future
column4: said Fahad Nazer
column5: a former political analyst with the Saudi Embassy in Washington who now does similar work for JTG Inc.

column1: In many ways
column2: what Obama thinks about the Saudis matters less and less as his time in the Oval Office draws to an end. But while the Saudis will be happy to see him leave
column3: there's great uncertainty in Riyadh about how the next president will deal with them.

column1: Both Democrat Hillary Clinton and Republican Donald Trump have voiced grave concerns about Saudi Arabia's track record of producing Islamic extremists; Clinton has said she supports the 9/11 lawsuit bill. But while Clinton would likely be a more predictable partner
column2: the Saudis see Trump — who has called for a ban on Muslims entering the United States — as a wild card.

column1: For now
column2: however
column3: the Saudis are nervously watching Congress to see exactly how unhappy lawmakers are with them.

column1: Already
column2: some members of Congress are hinting that they are not comfortable with the 9/11 legislation after all
column3: and that they may consider voting to uphold Obama's veto. Their hesitation comes as a growing number of foreign countries and blocs
column4: including the European Union
column5: voice opposition to the bill. The original bill passed on voice vote in both Houses
column6: making a veto override especially sensitive because members will have to go on the record. And with the presidential election looming
column7: the politics are even more fraught than normal.

column1: “Saudi Arabia has never been an especially popular actor in Washington — a powerful one
column2: but not popular
column3: the former senior U.S. official said. ""And now
column4: nobody in Congress wants to stick their neck out for the Saudis two-and-a-half months before the presidential election.”

column1: 207	"As Donald Trump courted African-American voters in Cleveland on Wednesday at a town hall taped by Fox News to air Thursday evening
column2: he seemed to express support for establishing the stop and frisk policing policy on a national level.

column1: When asked by an audience member how he would stop violence in the black community
column2: Trump responded
column3: ""I would do stop and frisk. I think you have to. We did it in New York. It worked incredibly well. And you have to be proactive
column4: and you know
column5: you really help people sort of change their mind automatically.""

column1: He added
column2: ""New York City was incredible
column3: the way that worked
column4: so I think that could be one step you could do.""

column1: The law enforcement policy — in which police officers stop and question pedestrians regardless of whether they believe a crime has been committed
column2: then search the pedestrians if the officers suspect violations — has been extremely controversial
column3: particularly in communities of color
column4: and has been the subject of several legal challenges alleging racial profiling and discrimination. The policy gained prominence in the 1990s under New York City Police Commissioner Bill Bratton and Mayor Rudy Giuliani
column5: who is now a close confidant of Trump's.

column1: Trump previously expressed his support for the policy
column2: praising Giuliani for its success in New York. Trump has as of late also been an ardent supporter of profiling regarding immigration
column3: believing it is a helpful tactic in stopping terrorism.

column1: He has drawn the ire of some African-Americans not only for praising stop and frisk but also for painting a grim portrait of black life.
On Tuesday night
column2: Trump said
column3: ""Our African-American communities are absolutely in the worst shape that they've ever been in before
column4: ever
column5: ever
column6: ever"" — seeming not to take into account slavery
column7: institutional segregation or the often violent reactions in the civil rights movement.

column1: On Thursday morning
column2: however
column3: in an interview on ""Fox & Friends
column4: he sought to amend his position
column5: saying he never meant to suggest that stop and frisk should be implemented nationally.

column1: Now Chicago is out of control. I was referring to Chicago with stop and frisk
column2: Trump said.

column1: His initial answer came in response to a question that did not mention Chicago
column2: though Trump cited the city in a previous answer as a place that is ""out of control.""

column1: Of course
column2: as president
column3: Trump would not be able to unilaterally implement the policy in a single city; he would have to defer to local officials and law enforcement.

column1: During a press conference
column2: the members of the Congressional Black Caucus were asked about Trump's stop-and-frisk remarks. ""The notion that stop and frisk had anything to do with the improving public safety numbers in New York is ludicrous
column3: and Donald trump needs to check his facts
column4: said Rep. Hakeem Jeffries
column5: D-New York.

column1: We would ask Donald Trump to bone up on his knowledge of what is constitutional and what is unconstitutional
column2: said Rep. Yvette Clarke
column3: D-New York."	donald trump courted african american voters cleveland wednesday town hall taped fox news air thursday evening seemed express support for establishing the stop and frisk policing column1: 208	"Story highlights Michelle Obama was a guest on ""The Late Show"" with Stephen Colbert on Tuesday night
The first lady discussed being a political spouse and promoted some of her signature issues
(CNN) Michelle Obama on Tuesday joked about the plagiarism controversy that engulfed Melania Trump during the Republican National Convention
column2: delivering a dry retort when ""The Late Show"" host Stephen Colbert asked the first lady if she was sympathetic to the plight of a fellow political spouse.

column1: Melania Trump was criticized for using what turned out to be a portion of your speech -- but do you have any sympathy? Because there are people around her creating things
column2: and you know
column3: I have sympathy for her. Do you understand how that might be sympathetic
column4: for what happened to her?"" the CBS host asked.

column1: Yeah
column2: that was tough
column3: Obama deadpanned
column4: prompting laughs from the audience.

column1: Colbert also asked the first lady if she was sympathetic to political spouses who are required to stand behind partners whose political beliefs are antithetical to their own -- a premise Obama flatly rejected.
Do you have any sympathy for the people who have to go there and stand by the person running for president?""

column1: 209	"Talks of hiring Rex Elsass come as Donald Trump is getting walloped on the airwaves. | Getty Trump team talking to veteran GOP ad man Elsass
Donald Trump’s campaign
column2: hoping to counter Hillary Clinton’s air assault
column3: is in talks with veteran GOP ad maker Rex Elsass
column4: according to three sources familiar with the discussions.

column1: Elsass
column2: according to one of the sources
column3: met with Trump officials in New York City last week.

column1: Story Continued Below
Elsass has deep connections to the Trump campaign. He previously served as a top strategist to vice presidential nominee Mike Pence
column2: and in 2012 he worked with Trump campaign manager Kellyanne Conway for Missouri Senate candidate Todd Akin
column3: who came under widespread criticism after making controversial remarks about rape. Elsass is a partner at Strategy Group for Media
column4: a firm that has also counted Jim Murphy
column5: Trump’s national political director
column6: as an employee.

column1: Trump’s advertising campaign has been led by Jamestown
column2: a prominent political consulting firm with an anti-establishment edge. Two Jamestown employees
column3: Jason Miller and Larry Weitzner
column4: have taken senior roles in the campaign. Also helping to lead the Trump ad effort is Rick Reed
column5: a veteran GOP strategist who assisted the Swift Boat Veterans for Truth campaign against John Kerry in 2004.

column1: Discussions about bringing aboard Elsass come as Trump is getting walloped on the airwaves. On Sept. 12
column2: Smart Media Group
column3: a media buying firm that works with the Republican National Committee
column4: detailed in an email to Trump campaign officials how Clinton was outspending the Republican nominee on TV by an astonishing seven-to-one margin. With polling in many battlegrounds suggesting the race is tight
column5: many Republican strategists are concerned that Trump’s lack of commercial spending could pose problems as the contest enters its final seven weeks.

column1: The Ohio-based GOP operative has a long history in Republican politics
column2: having worked for a number of presidential candidates over the years. During this year’s primary season
column3: Elsass advised Rand Paul and
column4: following Paul’s departure from the race
column5: John Kasich. In 2012
column6: he worked for Michele Bachmann and Newt Gingrich.

column1: Neither Elsass nor a Trump spokesperson responded to requests for comment.

column1: 211	"16.8k SHARES SHARE THIS STORY

Hillary Clinton just called out the fact that Donald Trump cheered for the housing crisis in anticipation of its collapse – which is absolutely true. Trump told The Globe and Mail in March of 2007: “People have been talking about the end of the cycle for 12 years
column2: and I’m excited if it is. I’ve always made more money in bad markets than in good markets.”

column1: In fact
column2: Trump thought the housing crisis was much-ado-do about nothing for high-end investments
column3: and told investors: “I don’t see the subprime problems affecting the higher-end stuff…In fact
column4: he is advising investors that there are now great deals in buying subprime mortgages at a discount and repossessed houses at low prices.”

column1: Of course
column2: on one level
column3: Trump wasn’t wrong­­—in that the subprime crisis affected mostly poorer Americans who lost their homes and jobs and the ability to support their families. The collapse of home prices caused by the housing bubble cost roughly seven million Americans more than $7 trillion in equity during the Great Recession.

column1: This recession most severely impacted low-income folks – people who are burdened with payments in excess of 50 percent of their income – Trump’s response is just “That’s called business.”

213	"Trump hints Obama to blame for Charlotte unrest But he also presented himself as someone who could heal America's racial divide.
Donald Trump on Thursday pinned the blame for the turmoil in Charlotte
column2: North Carolina
column3: on President Barack Obama
column4: suggesting that the violent protests there show a “wounded country” that “looks bad to the world.”

column1: Pausing for roughly 10 minutes during an energy speech in Pittsburgh to address the Charlotte unrest
column2: Trump also presented himself as the man to heal America’s racial divide.

column1: Story Continued Below
“Before going any further today
column2: I want to address the turmoil unfolding right now in our country
column3: and it seems to be a never-ending problem
column4: ” Trump said. “America desperately needs unity
column5: and it needs the spirit of togetherness that has not really only got us through our toughest times
column6: and we’ve had some tough times
column7: but which has lifted us up in the past to our greatest achievements as a nation.”

column1: He called for a swift end to violence against citizens and law enforcement
column2: insisting that such actions hurt law-abiding African-American families most
column3: and proposed a national anti-crime agenda to address what he characterized as a “national crisis.”

column1: He also vowed to make American cities safer by appointing “the best prosecutors
column2: investigators and federal law enforcement officers” and sympathized with police officers
column3: who carry an “immense responsibility” but must be trained properly
column4: respect the public and be held accountable for any wrongdoing. And he took a shot at Obama’s leadership
column5: or lack thereof.

column1: “We all have to walk a mile in someone else’s shoes
column2: see things through their eyes and then get to work fixing our very wounded country. I mean
column3: it’s — we have some real problems
column4: and we do have a wounded country
column5: ” Trump said. “Many Americans are watching the unrest in Charlotte unfolding right before their eyes on the TV screens. Others are witnessing the chaos and the violence firsthand. Our country looks bad to the world
column6: especially when we are supposed to be the world’s leader. How can we lead when we can’t even control our own cities?”

column1: Trump
column2: who emphasized that it will be the 45th president’s responsibility “to address this crisis and save African-American lives
column3: ” has made an attempt to gain support from African-Americans in recent weeks
column4: albeit through a narrative of poorly educated
column5: impoverished black people who live in crime-ridden inner cities and who
column6: after years of Democratic policies he says has failed them
column7: have nothing to lose by supporting his campaign.

column1: Trump's overtures to black voters — often made in front of overwhelmingly white audiences — have done little to dent Hillary Clinton's 80-point advantage among African- Americans. And his sometimes ham-fisted appeals have come along with statements that have done himself further damage: Only hours earlier
column2: he recommended a controversial stop-and-frisk policy
column3: a policing tactic that has been found to disproportionately targets minorities
column4: to curb violence in Chicago
column5: Obama's hometown
column6: and made the unsubstantiated claim that “drugs are a very
column7: very big factor” in what's happening in Charlotte.

column1: Still
column2: Trump has tried to cast himself as a unifying figure. Earlier Thursday
column3: during a phone interview with “Fox and Friends
column4: ” the Republican presidential nominee said there “just seems that there’s a lack of spirit between the white and the black.”

column1: “I mean
column2: it’s a terrible thing that we’re witnessing
column3: ” he continued. “You’re seeing it. I'm seeing it
column4: and you look at what went on last night in Charlotte — a great place — and you just see it.”

column1: Protests over the killing of Keith Lamont Scott
column2: a black man who was fatally shot by police on Tuesday
column3: turned violent on Wednesday night
column4: leading North Carolina Gov. Pat McCrory to declare a state of emergency in Charlotte.

column1: By Thursday
column2: Charlotte officials and Scott's family were arguing over whether he had been carrying a gun when he was shot.

column1: Charlotte-Mecklenburg Police Chief Kerr Putney told reporters that police believe Scott was armed
column2: though he acknowledged that a video of his encounter does not prove that conclusively. Putney said the video would be shown to Scott's family but did not commit to releasing it to the public.

column1: At a press conference Thursday afternoon
column2: attorneys for Scott’s family refused to commit to calling for the video to be made public or to addressing the media after viewing it. Charles Monnett
column3: one of the family’s lawyers
column4: said the family's decision would depend on whether the video ""can somehow help us reach that truth.""

column1: Justin Bamberg
column2: another of the family’s attorney’s
column3: said he had not seen any evidence that a gun was present at the scene where Scott was shot. Bamberg dismissed photos showing a gun at the scene by remarking that “pictures pop up online all the time. They come from different sources.” He said that as far as he was aware
column4: Scott did not own a gun. Bamberg also confirmed that Scott’s wife was present when he was shot.

column1: “At the end of the day
column2: my priority is the greater good of this family first. That has to be understood
column3: ” Bamberg said when asked why the family’s legal team would not commit to calling for the video to be made public. “Yes
column4: we want transparency. We don't create the facts. We live with the facts. But you can't take the burden that is placed on law enforcement as sworn officers and public servants and put that on a deceased person for their family who is in mourning.”

column1: The Obama administration
column2: meanwhile
column3: urged calm -- but the president himself had not made a statement as of 5:00 p.m. ET on Thursday.

column1: Attorney General Loretta Lynch addressed the “difficulties” her home state faces but warned against any violent reactions. “I know that these are difficult times
column2: and I know that the events of recent days are painfully unclear and they call out for answers
column3: ” she said. “But I also know that the answer will not be found in the violence of recent days. Let us seek all peaceful way forward.”

column1: White House press secretary Josh Earnest said that the vast majority of people had demonstrated peacefully.
“Unfortunately
column2: we've seen situations in which a small number of people take advantage of that peaceful public protest to engage in criminal activity and
column3: in some cases
column4: violence
column5: ” he said. “We've often heard from the families of those who were killed urging people with concerns to express those concerns peacefully and to not perpetuate the cycle of violence. Those have often been quite powerful calls and those are calls that the president has strongly supported.”

column1: Wednesday's violence erupted as residents
column2: outraged over Scott's death and that of an unarmed black man in Tulsa
column3: Oklahoma
column4: last week
column5: looted and vandalized cars and businesses in downtown Charlotte. According to reports
column6: police in riot gear used tear gas to try to calm protesters
column7: several of whom were injured
column8: including one who was shot by another protester
column9: police said.

column1: “I see it even going out. There’s such a lack of — there’s a lack of spirit
column2: ” Trump said. “There’s a lack of something. Something’s going on that’s bad
column3: and what’s going on between police and others is getting worse.”

column1: The real estate mogul renewed his call for law and order
column2: pitching it as the solution to the unrest in Charlotte and outrage nationwide over police-involved shootings of black men
column3: who in many cases have been unarmed when they were fatally shot.

column1: “Well
column2: it’s wow
column3: here we go again
column4: ” Trump said. “It’s very sad. When you look at what’s going on
column5: it’s very sad. It’s very divided
column6: our country
column7: and it’s getting worse. I’m not overly surprised to see it
column8: but it’s happening.”

column1: Trump argued that a dialogue between police and the communities they serve won’t solve this problem
column2: pointing to the ambush in Dallas this summer
column3: when a black man killed five officers and injured a dozen more.

column1: “If you look at Dallas
column2: there was a dialogue. They prided themselves on dialogue
column3: ” Trump said. “And they were constantly talking and meeting and having community groups and
column4: you know
column5: that was — that was a pretty rough situation
column6: to put it mildly. A terrible
column7: terrible situation. That sounds good. It sounds right
column8: but there’s something deeper than that.”

column1: What’s necessary
column2: Trump maintained
column3: is a combination of law and order and leadership that can unify a divided nation
column4: leadership he intimated is lacking from America’s current leader.

column1: “Well
column2: it really has to be — you have to have law and order at the time
column3: you have to have
column4: you know
column5: you have to have a certain spirit
column6: a certain unity
column7: and there’s no unity
column8: ” Trump said. “You look at the level of hatred
column9: the
column10: you know
column11: the rocks being thrown and everything happening. It’s so sad to see. You know
column12: this is the United States of America. I mean
column13: it’s so sad to see. But there’s just no unity. There has to be a unity message that has to get out

column1: But what Trump didn’t say explicitly
column2: his surrogates did. Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich and former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani appeared in separate Fox News segments in which they both slammed Obama’s lack of leadership.

column1: “First of all
column2: it’s a tragedy that eight years after our first African-American president took office
column3: eight years after we’ve had two African-American attorney generals
column4: the gap and the hostility
column5: if anything
column6: is worse
column7: and I think that’s a tragic failure of leadership
column8: ” Gingrich said.

column1: “But my guess is he was afraid it’d make him a black president in a narrowing sense
column2: ” he added. “He could have launched a program to try to rebuild and reopen and re-engineer hope in these communities. And instead
column3: he became the person who talked about
column4: you know
column5: the Cambridge policeman was wrong
column6: and
column7: you know
column8: Ferguson was wrong and why Florida was wrong.”

column1: Giuliani said Obama should have lectured Americans on constitutional law Wednesday. Referring to last Friday’s shooting death of Terence Crutcher
column2: who was unarmed with his hands raised when he was fatally shot by a white police officer
column3: the former New York mayor acknowledged that that incident was “a more difficult situation” than what transpired in Charlotte that belongs in the “ambiguous
column4: troubling category.”

column1: “But even there
column2: you gotta say to people
column3: ‘Wait
column4: let the investigation play out.’ The president of the United States should have said that yesterday
column5: ” Giuliani said. “The president of the United States should have given people a teeny bit of a lecture on constitutional law
column6: that we presume people innocent
column7: and that same presumption exists for police officers as everyone else.”

column1: 215	"Donald Trump is turning to Snapchat to drum up support from young voters ahead of tonight's presidential debate.
The Republican candidate's campaign launched a nationwide filter on the popular social network Monday.
While some candidates including Hillary Clinton have paid for local Snapchat filters during regional events in the past
column2: this is the first sponsored political filter available nationwide.

column1: Snapchat users now have the option to take selfies and photos with a picture frame design that says ""Debate Day: Donald J. Trump vs. Crooked Hillary"" before sharing with friends.
The filter also features fireworks on the sides and a banner at the bottom with his campaign slogan
column2: ""Make America Great Again.""

column1: Related: Say hello to Snap Inc.
Anyone can create a filter on Snapchat using the app's Geofilters feature
column2: but its availability is typically limited to proximity to an event
column3: location or community. It's unclear how much Trump's campaign paid for the filter to show up for users nationwide.

column1: A spokesperson for the Trump campaign did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
Sponsored filters have long been a way for Snapchat -- now rebranded as Snap Inc. -- to bring in ad dollars
column2: in addition to showing sponsored videos within the app.

column1: Related: 100 million? Ratings expectations for first Trump-Clinton debate
Trump and Clinton have used other social media networks
column2: including Twitter (TWTR
column3: Tech30) and Facebook (FB
column4: Tech30)
column5: to target younger audiences. But Snapchat is notoriously popular with teens and millennials -- a core group of voters both candidates hope to win over.

column1: Rather than actually try and persuade people
column2: the Trump campaign is throwing money into a fire pit
column3: the Clinton campaign said in a statement. ""[This features] a joke that
column4: given Trump's deep unpopularity with young voters
column5: will be used mainly at their own expense.""

column1: Looks like @BernieSanders campaign bought sponsored @Snapchat geotag filter at @HillaryClinton event pic.twitter.com/Yk6ZEMLUH1 — Noah Gray (@NoahGrayCNN) January 25
Recent polls suggest Clinton has failed to gain the kind of enthusiasm that drove younger voters to the polls four and eight years ago.
Between the two major party candidates
column2: Clinton has used Snapchat more so far. Earlier this year
column3: Clinton's camp launched a filter which targeted those attending a Trump rally in California. Clinton also released one during the Republican National Convention
column4: which featured a quote from Trump about how Clinton would make a great president.

column1: 216	"Hollywood loses yet another one of their dearest actresses
column2: and we are heartbroken.

column1: She was born in Chicago Illinois on December 27
column2: 1942 and loved by anyone and everyone who came in contact with her. Many of you probably remember the legendary actress as Liesl Von Trapp from “The Sound of Music.” Charmian Carr definitely left an imprint on Hollywood
column3: and she will never be forgotten.

column1: TMZ reported the death of the 73-year-old on Sunday September 18
column2: 2016. Carr’s rep stated that she died from complications from dementia. Apparently she was battling a rare form of the disease.

column1: Carr’s story was a very unique one
column2: which makes her acting journey so special. At the time that she auditioned for “The Sound of Music” she was a student at the San Fernando Valley State College. She was studying speech therapy and philosophy
column3: and was also working for a doctor.

column1: “I was going to college and getting extra spending money by modeling in fashion shows in one of the stores. One of the girls who modeled with me knew that Robert Wise
column2: producer-director of The Sound of Music had been conducting a four-month search for someone to play the part of 16-year-old Liesl. My friend
column3: without my knowing it
column4: sent in my picture and explained in a note that I sang and danced. I received a call from Mr. Wise to come for a tryout. It took me completely by surprise…”

column1: After completing “The Sound of Music” and several other acting parts
column2: Carr left her career in acting and pursued another life-long dream of hers. Charmian started her own interior design business “Charmian Carr Designs” and surprisingly it took off a lot easier than she expected – especially after being hired by Michael Jackson.

column1: Carr married Jay Brent who was a dentist in 1967 and 24 years later the couple got a divorce. They had two beautiful daughters together. She is survived by all of her siblings
column2: her daughters and her grandchildren.

column1: She brought joy to everyone around her and even still today she is known and loved by those who watch her shows. Her smile lit up every room she walked into and her positive personality was contagious. Please continue to keep this family in your prayers as they mourn the loss of their loved one.
I can’t help but watch this over and over and think that there will never be anyone who could replace this woman!

RIP CHARMIAN CARR."	hollywood loses yet another one their dearest actresses and are heartbroken she was born chicago illinois december 1942 and loved anyone and everyone who came contact with her many 217	"KALLSTADT
column2: Germany — Few places in Germany are as representative of the country’s heartland as Kallstadt
column3: the village in which U.S. Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump’s grandfather was born — and from which he was later deported.

column1: The hamlet of 1
column2: 200 people lies nestled among vineyard-covered hills
column3: about an hour-and-a-half’s drive southwest of Frankfurt. It has one bakery and one butcher. Every year
column4: Kallstadt holds the Saumagenkerwe in celebration of the eponymous local delicacy: pig’s stomach filled with pork
column5: herbs
column6: bratwurst and diced potatoes.

column1: Trump may have captured a large swath of the American electorate with his signature blend of populism
column2: nativism and brazenness. And yet
column3: in the hometown of his forefather
column4: he remains distinctly unpopular.

column1: In fact
column2: few politicians are less popular in Germany than Trump. A study by the Pew Research Center found out that only 6 percent of the country finds him trustworthy.

column1: Since a local newspaper discovered that Johannes Steiniger
column2: a member of the German parliament
column3: was distantly related to Trump
column4: the 29-year-old has done all he can to distance himself from the presidential candidate. “With his statements about gay people and foreigners
column5: or with the language he uses
column6: and with his derogative statements about Hillary Clinton
column7: Trump seems to do everything he can so that we get a negative image of him
column8: ” Steiniger tells POLITICO.

column1: Trump’s rhetoric regarding immigrants and racial minorities is especially unpopular in Kallstadt. “He stands for everything that’s bad
column2: ” says Sarah Bühler
column3: yelling to be heard over the 20-person brass band celebrating the Saumagenkerwe in the town’s main square. Bühler is a former local “wine princess
column4: ” the 2009 victor of a beauty pageant to promote the local wine industry.

column1: This year
column2: a new dish appeared in the town’s annual festival: Saumagen-Döner
column3: a fusion of the local specialty with a Turkish kebab. “Everyone is welcome to join us here
column4: no matter what color they are
column5: ” says Bühler. “Pink
column6: purple
column7: doesn’t matter.”

column1: Tanja Huber
column2: the 24-year-old incumbent regional wine princess
column3: nods her head in agreement. Since the prospect of a Trump presidency first became evident late last year
column4: reporters have descended on Kallstadt
column5: seeking a bit of local color
column6: a quote or two
column7: and perhaps some hometown pride. “They don’t get that we really don’t give a damn about Trump
column8: ” says Huber. “He’s never been here
column9: and he apparently doesn’t care about us
column10: either.”

column1: Donald’s grandfather
column2: Friedrich Trump
column3: was born in Kallstadt into a vintner’s family on March 14
column4: 1869. Previous generations of the Trump family used variant spellings of the name
column5: including “Trump
column6: ” “Dromb” and “Trumpff
column7: ” according to local historians
column8: or even “Drumpf
column9: ” according to a 2000 family history by Gwenda Blair; but by the time Friedrich was born they had settled on “Trump.”

column1: Germany did not yet exist as a nation; Kallstadt was part of the province of Palatinate in the Bavarian Kingdom. The region was going though rough times. Unemployment was high. Those who had the courage
column2: left.

column1: Friedrich’s father died when he was eight years old
column2: and his mother struggled to make ends meet. At 16 years old
column3: Friedrich decided to follow his sister Katharina
column4: who had emigrated to the United States two years earlier. He arrived in New York on board the Eider on October 19

column1: He entered the U.S. through official channels
column2: but he had left Bavaria illegally. “Both he and his mother must have known that he would not have been granted official permission to leave the country unless he had paid a bail guaranteeing that he would later return to do his mandatory military service
column3: ” said Roland Paul
column4: the recently-retired director of the Institute for Palatinate Regional History and Folklife Studies in the city of Kaiserslautern.

column1: According to documents uncovered by Paul
column2: Friedrich was stripped of his Bavarian citizenship “as his own request” four years after arriving in the U.S.

column1: But Friedrich was not done with Palatinate. Seven years after his citizenship was withdrawn
column2: he visited the land of his birth to attend the wedding of his sister
column3: according to the 2000 family history by Blair. Five years after that
column4: he returned once more to Kallstadt
column5: where he met 20-year-old Elisabeth Christ; they were engaged
column6: and Friedrich came back a third time to marry her in August 1902.

column1: But while the couple moved back to New York soon after the marriage and had a daughter
column2: Friedrich had promised his wife that he would sell his property in the U.S. and return to the land of their birth. “My grandmother said
column3: I will marry you
column4: but I will not go back to America with you
column5: ” Donald Trump’s American-born cousin John Walter told German filmmaker Simone Wendel in 2012.

column1: Friedrich seemed intent on keeping his promise. In 1904
column2: he applied for permission to travel to Kallstadt. And although he claimed in his application that he intended “to return to the United States within a year with the purpose of residing and performing the duties of citizenship therein
column3: ” he took all his savings from the U.S. with him
column4: according to Blair’s family history.

column1: Back in Kallstadt
column2: Friedrich attempted to get his citizenship back. But though he secured the support of local authorities
column3: the district government put a halt to his plans. On February 27
column5: a deportation notice was sent to the town office of Kallstadt declaring that Friedrich was “to be told he has to leave Bavarian state territory by May 1 of this year
column6: at the latest.”

column1: Friedrich was able to obtain a three-month grace period because his daughter had fallen ill. But eventually
column2: he and his wife — pregnant once more — had no choice but to board the ship Pennsylvania on July 1
column4: and return to New York. Shortly after that
column5: Donald’s father
column6: Fred Trump Junior
column7: was born.

column1: “[The authorities] said
column2: ‘You are not a German citizen
column3: you gave up your citizenship
column4: you have to leave
column5: ” says Walter. “So they left and they went back to America
column6: and that’s why Donald and I are here.”

column1: Friedrich — now named Frederick — died in May 1918 of the Spanish flu. His widow survived her first husband by 48 years and visited Kallstadt many times during her life.
In February 2012
column2: Simone Wendel
column3: the German filmmaker from Kallstadt
column4: was given an audience with Donald Trump. Roughly two years earlier
column5: she had begun work on “Kings of Kallstadt
column6: ” a documentary about the two most famous sons of her tiny hometown: Donald Trump and Henry John Heinz
column7: the inventor of Heinz Ketchup.

column1: For months
column2: Wendel had tried to arrange a meeting with Trump
column3: but his office had not replied to her letters. She was only able to secure a visit with the help of Walter
column4: Trump’s cousin
column5: who had visited Kallstadt and seemed happy with the attention she was paying to the family history.

column1: On the day of her visit
column2: Wendel stood nervously next to Walter in a conference room on one of Trump Tower’s top floors. She had brought a Linzer torte and two bottles of wine with screw-on tops.

column1: Her plan was to sit down with Walter and Trump for coffee and cake
column2: the traditional afternoon snack in her home region. But when she asked Trump’s staff to make some coffee
column3: the only reaction she got was irritated faces. “His assistant just couldn’t be bothered
column4: ” she says.

column1: “Hello
column2: John
column3: ” Trump said
column4: when he entered the room
column5: shaking his cousin’s hand and looking confused at Wendel in her loose turtle neck and the lonely cake on the huge table in front of her.

column1: Trump sat down in front of a one-meter-long model of his Boeing 757-200 airliner and a panoramic window overlooking New York’s Central Park. Wendel
column2: trying to remedy the situation
column3: pushed the cake in his direction and asked him to smell it. “Afterwards
column4: I just kept on thinking
column5: ‘What on earth did I do?’” she says.

column1: “The cake looks really good
column2: ” Trump said
column3: and he and Wendel ended up talking for almost an hour.

column1: Until 1990
column2: Trump still claimed his family was Swedish
column3: a version of his family history first introduced by his father in reaction to the anti-German sentiment in the U.S. during the two World Wars. But by the time Wendel visited
column4: he had become proud of his German roots. “They grow them well in Kallstadt
column5: ” he told her during their meeting. “They grow them very well. Believe me. It’s good stock.”

column1: “Wow
column2: it’s beautiful
column3: ” Trump said when she handed him a picture of the house where his grandfather was born
column4: an inconspicuous one-story building with a gable roof. “That’s fantastic. See how well-maintained it is? Everything is perfectly maintained. It’s great.”

column1: When their interview was over
column2: Walter took Wendel on a tour of Trump Tower. On one of the floors
column3: they ran into Trump’s son
column4: Eric Trump.

column1: “Have you ever heard the word Kallstadt?” Wendel asked him.
“Kallstadt?” Trump Junior replied
column2: “No

column4: and Charlotte

column2: Pence said at a pastors' roundtable at Radiant Church here. ""And in difficult and life-threatening situations

220	"Giuliani slams Lester Holt for fact-checking like Candy Crowley
Presidential debate moderator Lester Holt pulled two Candy Crowleys
column2: former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani said Tuesday
column3: accusing of the “NBC Nightly News” anchor of mirroring Crowley’s infamous Mitt Romney fact-check twice on Monday night.

column1: In an interview with “Fox and Friends
column2: ” Giuliani said he watched the debate two times — once live
column3: “and then I went home and I watched Lester Holt do Candy Crowley at least twice.”

column1: Story Continued Below
Donald Trump
column2: who had suggested a debate without a moderator ahead of Monday’s faceoff
column3: warned Holt last week not to be like Crowley
column4: who interrupted Romney in 2012 after the then-Republican nominee said it took President Barack Obama 14 days to call the attack in Benghazi
column5: Libya
column6: an “act of terror.” (PolitiFact rated Romney’s criticism “half true
column7: ” noting that Obama did say “act of terror” right after the attacks but that the administration did not speak “consistently in the days that followed."")

column1: Giuliani took issue with Holt “ignorantly” attempting to fact-check Trump on the constitutionality of stop-and-frisk and the real estate mogul's false assertion that he never supported the Iraq War.
A federal judge in New York ruled the application of the practice unconstitutional
column2: not the policy itself
column3: as Holt suggested
column4: Giuliani argued.

column1: “The thing that’s wrong is Lester Holt said straight out: Stop-and-frisk is unconstitutional. Lester Holt is not a lawyer
column2: ” Giuliani said. “He’s wrong. It was decided in 1959 by Earl Warren. It is still the law of the land.”

column1: The former mayor maintained that “every cop does stop-and-frisk in every part of America” but gave Hillary Clinton a pass for siding with Holt “because she failed the bar exam.”
“But I’m not gonna allow him to play lawyer and contradict our candidate
column2: ” he continued. “And I’d like to know: When did a moderator become a fact-checker? And if you’re gonna be a fact-checker
column3: you better darn be right.”

column1: “I’m a lawyer. I’m not a moderator who misrepresents on television
column2: ” Giuliani said
column3: after co-Steve Doocy noted that Giuliani was fact-checking Holt. “I’m a lawyer. Am I angry about it? I thought after Candy Crowley we saw the last of it. What Holt did last night — if journalism has ethics
column4: if it has ethics
column5: he violated the rules of ethics. Now if you’re gonna interrupt and you’re gonna correct me in front of 100 million people
column6: you better be right. He is dead wrong.”

column1: Giuliani continued this verbal broadside
column2: slamming Holt for being “completely unprofessional” and “totally unethical” and suggesting that “he should have had enough energy to check the sources” regarding whether Trump supported the Iraq War.

column1: “I saw the tape
column2: and he opposed the Iraq War before the Iraq War
column3: ” Giuliani said
column4: despite numerous fact-checks that note Trump voiced support for the war during a 2002 interview with Howard Stern.

column1: “A hundred million last night were misled by Lester Holt and so-called lawyer Hillary Clinton
column2: ” Giuliani said.

221	"Police and protesters carry a seriously wounded protester into the parking area of the the Omni Hotel during a march to protest the death of Keith Scott September 21. | Getty McCrory calls state of emergency in Charlotte after unrest

North Carolina Gov. Pat McCrory called for a state of emergency in Charlotte Wednesday night after violence escalated as residents continued to protest the fatal shooting of an African-American man by a police officer a day prior.
I have declared a State of Emergency & initiated efforts to deploy the Nat'l Guard & Highway Patrol to assist local law enforcement in CLT
column2: McCrory tweeted late Wednesday night.

column1: Story Continued Below
Civil unrest surged Tuesday as reports of the fatal shooting of Keith Lamont Scott spread
column2: prompting mass protests that went into the night. A dozen officers were injured during the unrest
column3: according to a tweet from the local police department early Wednesday morning.

column1: As protests continued Wednesday
column2: reports emerged of a shooting that left a protester critically wounded
column3: according to the Associated Press. Charlotte officials at first announced the man was dead but later amended the statement to say he was on life support. The police department has said the shooting was not committed by an officer.

column1: These police officers are showing a tremendous amount of courage and there's obviously a few hundred people who have come to our town center in Charlotte
column2: North Carolina
column3: which is a great city in and their major goal seems to be destruction and harm and that's wrong and it's unacceptable
column4: McCrory said Wednesday night on CNN shortly after making the announcement.

column1: We cannot tolerate violence or tolerate the destruction of property and will not tolerate the attacks towards our police officers occurring right now and I feel very strongly about that right now
column2: McCrory added. ""That is not the American way.""

column1: The North Carolina governor added that though the state of emergency did not include a curfew
column2: the possibility of one remained ""a very strong option.""

column1: According to local reports
column2: police officers saw Scott getting out of his car while holding a gun. The Charlotte-Mecklenburg Police Department said Scott posed an imminent danger to officers
column3: and an officer shot the man.

224	"A Louisiana deputy city marshal is in hot water after body cam footage revealed him shooting at a suspect who had his hands up in the air. This is
column2: sadly
column3: becoming too common a story in the news as awareness of problems with officers who have hair-trigger fingers grows. What makes this story sadly and horrifically unique
column4: though
column5: is that Deputy Derrick Stafford also shot and killed the suspect’s six-year old son.

column1: And Stafford is claiming self-defense for that
column2: because of course he is:

column1: “Stafford
column2: out of fear for his life and that of his fellow officers
column3: began shooting at the vehicle to prevent any further actions by [Christopher] Few which would put the officers in imminent danger.”

column1: Officers went after Christopher Few after watching an argument between him and his girlfriend outside a bar just before the 2015 shooting. They claimed witnessing domestic abuse as the reason they decided to chase down Few
column2: whose six-year old son
column3: Jeremy
column4: was in the front passenger seat.

column1: 18 rounds were fired although Few had his hands up
column2: but no firearm was found in the car
column3: and Few and Jeremy were both shot while still in the car. Stafford and his partner
column4: Norris Greenhouse
column5: said that after Few drove forward and then backed up
column6: they were in fear for their lives
column7: so they fired.

column1: That’s always the story
column2: though. It makes us wonder just what police departments are teaching that so many officers shoot first and ask questions later
column3: claiming they were in fear for their lives when it’s obvious that their suspects were unarmed
column4: and even had their hands in the air.

column1: Reports claim that neither Stafford nor Greenhouse knew Jeremy was in the car when they opened fire. Few was critically wounded
column2: and Jeremy
column3: who was autistic
column4: non-verbal and in a special-needs first-grade class
column5: was murdered.

column1: Stafford’s plea of “self-defense” is a huge middle finger to Few and the rest of Jeremy’s grieving family. Arguments will be heard in court next week
column2: where Judge William Bennett will decide whether the indictments stand.

column1: Driving the Day

HAPPY DEBATE DAY! Bloomberg is out with a poll this morning that tracks with practically every public survey that’s been released: the race for the White House is basically tied. http://bloom.bg/2dlw162 Donald Trump leads Hillary Clinton in a four-way race
column3: and the two are tied with 46 percent in a head-to-head race.

column1: A NEW CNN poll has Hillary Clinton up one point -- 45-44 -- in Pennsylvania

column1: Story Continued Below
It’s with that backdrop that the nation turns to HOFSTRA UNIVERSITY on LONG ISLAND for the first matchup between Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump.

The debate begins at 9 p.m. and will run for 90 minutes without commercial interruption. NBC’s Lester Holt is the moderator -- he’s done practically no press in the leadup to what could be the biggest moment of his career. The topics for the debate are: “America’s Direction
column2: ” “Achieving Prosperity” and “Securing America.” Clinton and Trump are scheduled to face off for a second time on Oct. 9 at Washington University in St. Louis. The final debate is Oct. 19 in Las Vegas.

The two million women and men who work for America's banks safeguard $12.9 trillion in deposits and originate $2.4 trillion in home loans. They provide $331 billion in loans to small businesses and $175 billion in loans to farmers and ranchers. Banks' fraud protection measures stop at least $11 billion in attempted fraud each year. And thousands of banker volunteers deliver financial literacy lessons annually to millions of young Americans to help them become financially successful adults. Find out more at www.aba.com/AmericasBanks
column2: #AmericasBanks ******

column1: WASHINGTON INC. -- JOHN BUCKLEY joins Subject Matter as its first CEO. Buckley comes on board from strategic communications firm the Harbour Group
column2: where he has served as managing director since 2008. The veteran GOP operative worked as deputy press secretary to Reagan-Bush ‘84
column3: as press secretary to Jack Kemp in Congress and for his 1988 presidential campaign. He also worked in senior level communications positions at AOL and Fannie Mae.

column1: PLAYBOOK METRO SECTION -- “Metro chairman Evans: Board is so unwieldy that we ought to scrap it altogether
column2: ” by WaPo’s Robert McCartney: “Metro board Chairman Jack Evans is so frustrated trying to lead the transit system’s cumbersome
column3: 16-member governing body that he would prefer to scrap it and start fresh … He conceded that would be ‘extreme’ and it won’t happen. But he said members of such a board would not be ‘beholden to the local jurisdictions’ and thus could do what’s best for Metro as a whole … Divided allegiances at the top have hobbled Metro since its creation. The problem has arisen again as the board wrestles over cutting subway hours and studying how to raise billions of dollars in coming years to rebuild the system and cover pension costs.” http://wapo.st/2dkm5cv

column1: THE PLAYBOOK INTERVIEW: Stephanie Schriock
EMILY’S List President Stephanie Schriock is leading the effort to turn out women voters in the 2016 election. Schriock
column2: who serves as a top Clinton surrogate
column3: is crisscrossing the country to stump for Clinton and other Democratic candidates in the lead up to the election. And
column4: she’s also been responsible for the group raising more money to achieve that goal — $26.8 million as of July — than ever before.

column1: “This really is EMILY’s List’s moment
column2: ” Schriock said. “We are having our most successful fundraising cycle and we are going to have by far the largest women voter program
column3: which is our independent expenditure arm
column4: that we’ve ever had.”

column1: The bar at the debate is higher for Hillary Clinton: “This is a really important moment and the first time that Americans have seen a woman standing on that stage for a presidential debate and I think she’s going to be ready. I know there is no one who prepares harder than Hillary Clinton
column2: but the stakes are high and the bar is really high for her. I don’t think there is anything they can do about that. Like so many of our women candidates they just have to deal with it.”

column1: Stunned at Trump’s comments on women: “I think it is really really important for all of the women in this country… to know that Donald Trump has these views and has no problem just letting these really offensive words come off his tongue.”

Trump’s policy targeting women is a sham: “It was atrocious policy. It was the kind of thing that a campaign throws together with less than 60 days left when they know they are losing particularly women voters. Women voters and Americans in general are obviously not going to fall for something like that.”
Female candidates will determine Senate majority: “Catherine Cortez Masto of Nevada
column2: Maggie Hassan in New Hampshire
column3: Katie McGinty in Pennsylvania
column4: and now Deborah Ross
column5: who we are so proud of in North Carolina
column6: those four races are the keys to the majority and they have incredibly strong candidates we’ve been working on since day one
column7: or even before as we tried to recruit them and got them in these races.”

column1: LGBT44 LAUNCHES -- One hundred and fifthy LGBT appointees in the Obama administration held their first-ever “LGBT44 Family Reunion.” “The weekend began with a Friday night reception at Republic Restoratives distillery
column2: co-owned by former DHS official Pia Carusone
column3: where Army Secretary Eric Fanning and Arcus Foundation CEO and former Education Department leader Kevin Jennings gave remarks emphasizing the importance of public service and reflecting upon the change they've seen in their careers. Saturday’s day-long event at the Human Rights Campaign building included remarks by Gay and Lesbian Victory Institute Vice President Ruben Gonzales and federal CTO Megan Smith - the highest ranking out woman in the Administration -- as well as a surprise drop-by from HUD Secretary Julián Castro.”

column1: ****** A message from the American Bankers Association: America's banks play a critical role in generating economic growth while delivering safety and convenience for customers. The two million women and men who work for America's banks safeguard $12.9 trillion in deposits and originate $2.4 trillion in home loans. They provide $331 billion in loans to small businesses and $175 billion in loans to farmers and ranchers. Banks' fraud protection measures stop at least $11 billion in attempted fraud each year. And thousands of banker volunteers deliver financial literacy lessons annually to millions of young Americans to help them become financially successful adults. Find out more at www.aba.com/AmericasBanks

For the past week rioters have been wrecking havok all across Charlotte. The riots are in response to the police shooting of Keith Lamont Scott
column2: which has been cited as just the latest example of an unarmed black man killed by racist police brutality. Scott’s wife
column3: who filmed the shooting
column4: told police that he wasn’t armed and was only carrying a book.

column1: As usual
column2: the shooting happened under circumstances much more murky than those citing this as an unjustified act of police violence would like to admit. There was in fact a gun recovered at the scene
column3: and there was a holster on Scott’s leg spotted in the police dash-cam footage. Those citing this as yet another “proof” that police are racist should know that the officer who shot Scott was black himself
column4: so race was not a motivating factor in the shooting.

column1: As it turns out
column2: Scott has a history of violence
column3: and there’s no reason to think he wouldn’t have used his firearm if he had the chance. As Bearing Arms reported:

column1: Rakeyia Scott’s cry to CMPD officers that her husband
column2: Keith Lamont Scott
column3: did not own a gun—even as he brandished a gun in front of them—now appears to be a calculated lie
column4: according to Rakeyia Scott. On Oct. 5
column5: a Gaston County District Court judge granted his wife a temporary restraining order. The court order told Scott not to go near his wife
column6: three of their children and the children’s schools. He was not allowed near their Gastonia apartment they’d called home since April 2014
column7: according to court documents. He was told to turn over a black 9mm handgun he owned illegally. Eleven days later
column8: Rakeyia Scott voluntarily dismissed the order against her husband
column9: writing
column10: “He is no longer a threat to me and my family.” But three days before she got the order
column11: Keith Scott had kicked her
column12: punched their 8-year-old in the head three times and threatened to kill her with the gun
column13: she had written. “He said he is a ‘killer’ and we should know that
column14: ” she wrote. She said the man she’d been married to since she was 18 did not have a gun permit and was a felon
column15: having been incarcerated from April 2004 to April 2011. She checked a box saying her husband had threatened her with the gun before.

column1: The Scott family is now trying to claim that the head injuries suffered by Scott left him a changed man
column2: and yet
column3: he was still an armed felon
column4: brandishing a gun
column5: if not threatening with her at this time. Yeah – OK.

column1: Scott’s wife told officers he didn’t own a firearm during the altercation
column2: which was clearly a lie
column3: and one that could’ve gotten them killed. While rioters destroy Charlotte
column4: they’re doing so over a man who could’ve killed those officers
column5: and had a wife that he himself once threatened would’ve been an accomplice to their murders."	2 1k shares facebook twitter for the past week rioters have been wrecking havok all across column1: 228	"Donald Trump mocked Hillary Clinton's planes and needled her for ""taking the day off."" | Getty Trump needles Clinton: ‘Sleep well Hillary — see you at the debate!’
Hillary Clinton is a copycat who’s probably sleeping because she needs to rest
column2: Donald Trump suggested Tuesday.

column1: In a pair of tweets bookended by a post announcing “two big rallies” in North Carolina
column2: Trump accused the Democratic presidential nominee of “copying my airplane” and continued his assault over her stamina
column3: or alleged lack thereof.

column1: Story Continued Below
“Do people notice Hillary is copying my airplane rallies — she puts the plane behind her like I have been doing from the beginning
column2: ” Trump mused in a tweet Tuesday morning.

column1: “Hillary Clinton is taking the day off again
column2: she needs the rest
column3: ” he added minutes later. “Sleep well Hillary — see you at the debate!”

column1: Trump’s critical comments come shortly after Clinton warned voters during a radio interview with Steve Harvey
column2: “The next 50 days will determine the next 50 years.”

column1: Clinton also previewed what she expects from Trump in Monday's presidential debate in New York
column2: telling Harvey she will do her “very best to communicate as clearly and fearlessly as I can in the face of the insults and the attacks and the bullying and bigotry that we’ve seen coming from my opponent.”

column1: “You know
column2: I can take it
column3: Steve. I can take that kind of stuff
column4: ” she added. “I’ve been at this and
column5: you know
column6: I understand it’s a contact sport.”

column1: Trump also attacked Clinton earlier Tuesday
column2: questioning her effectiveness against the Islamic State as head of the State Department.

column1: “Crooked Hillary has been fighting ISIS
column2: or whatever she has been doing
column3: for years
column4: ” he said. “Now she has new ideas. It is time for change.”

column1: Clinton has no public events planned for Tuesday and has opted to stay at home in Chappaqua
column2: New York
column3: as she prepares for the debate with Trump.

column1: She had a full campaign schedule on Monday — between holding a news conference in White Plains
column2: New York
column3: a campaign speech and a fundraiser in Philadelphia
column4: and three meetings with foreign leaders in New York City. She is scheduled to return to Florida for a campaign rally and fundraiser on Wednesday.

column1: Gabriel Debenedetti contributed to this report.

column1: 230	"New York (CNN) Hillary Clinton is visiting only two battleground states this week -- hardly a sign of confidence at her standing 49 days before the election
column2: but an acknowledgement that one task reigns above all: Preparing for her first face-to-face confrontation with Donald Trump.

column1: While she is set to make a quick trip to Florida on Wednesday
column2: after dipping into Pennsylvania on Monday
column3: Clinton will devote the lion's share of her time huddling with her debate team
column4: gaming out how she will confront Trump next Monday night at Hofstra University.

column1: The lead Clinton enjoyed for months in swing state and national polls has all but evaporated
column2: raising the stakes for the first debate. The terrorism investigation in New York and New Jersey has also added to the urgency of her first meeting with Trump
column3: which will touch on a litany of economic and security issues.

column1: Clinton
column2: who has participated in more debates than any presidential candidate in recent history
column3: faces a new challenge with Trump. She is preparing for Trump to confront her on a litany of uncomfortable subjects
column4: ranging from her email scandal to Bill Clinton's infidelity to her health.

column1: Trump showed he was willing to go there Tuesday when he tweeted
column2: ""Hillary Clinton is taking the day off again
column3: she needs the rest. Sleep well Hillary - see you at the debate!""

column1: JUST WATCHED They can't say that on a debate stage...can they? Replay More Videos ... MUST WATCH They can't say that on a debate stage...can they? 01:23
Clinton
column2: in a radio interview Tuesday
column3: said she was ready to deal with Trump's attacks.

column1: I am going to do my very best to communicate as clearly and fearlessly as I can in the face of the insults and the attacks and the bullying and the bigotry that we have seen coming from my opponent
column2: Clinton said Tuesday on the Steve Harvey Radio show. ""I can take it
column3: Steve. I can take that kind of stuff. I have been at this
column4: I understand it is a contact sport.""

column1: To knock Trump off his game
column2: people advising Clinton have been looking for a one-line retort that will be a memorable moment from the contest.

column1: Clinton has spent hours watching a highlight reel of Trump's Republican primary debates
column2: according to several people familiar with her debate preparation. She took notes on what agitated him
column3: particularly in his exchanges with rival Ted Cruz
column4: and studied his style.

column1: But Democrats worry the first debate will give Trump a chance to show a more moderate
column2: controlled side
column3: while millions of people watch
column4: possibly for the first time. This
column5: according to people who have recently talked with the former secretary of state
column6: is not lost on Clinton.

column1: Clinton told supporters at an August fundraiser that a friend told her: ""There will be about 100 million people watching and 60 million will be paying attention to the campaign for the first time. So don't assume they have followed anything.""
There will be a lot of new impressions to be made that night
column2: Clinton said.

column1: A team of veteran advisers are leading her debate effort
column2: including Ron Klain
column3: who advised Obama
column4: and Karen Dunn
column5: a long-time lawyer and aide. She is not setting up a formal ""debate camp
column6: aides said
column7: but intends to be secluded at her home in Chappaqua
column8: New York
column9: in the days leading up to the debate to prepare for her showdown on Monday.

column1: Clinton has also spent considerable time reading briefing books about Trump's policy
column2: personality and politics
column3: including receiving input from Tony Schwartz
column4: who was the co-author for ""Art of the Deal
column5: the best-seller about Trump.

column1: Expectations game
Clinton aides worry that they can't lower expectations enough ahead of the event.
For all his lack of substance
column2: Trump's showmanship
column3: as ex-reality TV star
column4: makes him a formidable debate foe. He thrashed his rivals in GOP debates
column5: Brian Fallon
column6: Clinton's national press secretary
column7: tweeted in August.

column1: With her Senate contests in 2000 and 2006
column2: along with more than two dozen debates with Barack Obama in 2008 and nine meetings with Bernie Sanders in this primary campaign
column3: she has stood on a debate stage more than 40 times.

column1: Trump will not be the first unconventional opponent Clinton has faced in a debate. Clinton all-but ended her 2000 Senate race against Rick Lazio during one of their debates when she stood strong as the Republican representative approached her lectern with a piece of paper and demanded she pledge to support stricter campaign finance rules. Lazio's bizarre move was seen as bullying and rude and Clinton handily beat him by 12 points in November.
JUST WATCHED Debate expectations game is serious business Replay More Videos ... MUST WATCH Debate expectations game is serious business 02:46
Her debate last fall against four Democratic primary opponents was seen as an outright win for the secretary of state because of the way she handled prickly questions
column2: including about whether she is progressive enough for the current bent of the Democratic Party.

column1: I'm a progressive. But I'm a progressive who likes to get things done
column2: Clinton said
column3: rolling out a line she would later use repeatedly while campaigning.

column1: Clinton's performances have not been without missteps
column2: however. The former senator from New York cited the September 11
column4: terrorist attacks when asked about her ties to Wall Street
column5: a response that aides later said came because their candidate was somewhat flustered by Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders attacking her on the issue.

column1: Which Trump will show up?
In the last few weeks
column2: as Clinton has publicly turned to a more affirmative message
column3: the former secretary of state has started to focus on how to present her own policies and defend herself against attacks.

column1: Clinton and her campaign aides have tried to keep a lid on leaks about Clinton's debate process
column2: preferring not to telegraph to the Trump campaign how the former secretary of state will go after the businesses magnate.

column1: When asked about the debates
column2: Clinton has tried to laud Trump's debating skill while admitting that it is for her to have a strong showing at Hofstra.

column1: I do not know which Donald Trump will show up
column2: Clinton said at an August fundraiser in New York. column1: 231	"Trump: 'I was going to say something extremely rough' to Clinton
Hillary Clinton didn't hold back in her attacks on Donald Trump Monday night
column2: but Donald Trump intimated that he pulled a key punch — passing on making a reference to Bill Clinton's past infidelities.

column1: “I was going to say something extremely rough to Hillary
column2: to her family
column3: and I said to myself
column4: I can't do it
column5: ” Trump said in reply. “It's inappropriate. It's not nice.”

column1: Story Continued Below
Trump's veiled reference followed a tough attack from Clinton
column2: who referenced his past comments about women being “pigs” and “dogs” and said Trump “loves hanging around beauty contests” during Monday night’s debate.

column1: “He tried to switch from looks to stamina. But this is a man who has called women pigs
column2: slobs and dogs
column3: ” Clinton said.

column1: Trump also said that Clinton has been hitting him “with tremendous commercials. Some of it's in entertainment.” Trump added that Rosie O’Donnell
column2: the focus of some of his comments has “been very tough to me.”

column1: Clinton has spent “hundreds of millions of dollars on negative ads ... many of which are untrue
column2: and they're misrepresentations
column3: and I will tell you this
column4: Lester
column5: it's not nice
column6: and I don't deserve that
column7: but it's certainly not a nice thing that she's done
column8: ” Trump added.

column1: “I’m very happy that I was able to hold back on the indiscretions with respect to Bill Clinton
column2: ” Trump told reporters after the debate. “Because I have a lot of respect for Chelsea Clinton and I just didn’t want to say what I was going to say.”

column1: And what exactly

column1: “I’ll tell you maybe at the next debate
