232	"AP Photo Backtalk Robert Kennedy Would Have Hated Donald Trump The GOP candidate is not the man of peace my former colleague makes him out to be.
Writing as a former legislative assistant to Senator Robert F. Kennedy and an enthusiastic supporter of Hillary Clinton for president
column2: I was disappointed to see in Politico the screed written by my former colleague
column3: Adam Walinsky
column4: excoriating Clinton’s record on foreign policy and national security and going on to conclude that Donald Trump should therefore be elected president. It is one thing to disagree with Secretary Clinton
column5: which Walinsky does heatedly
column6: and quite another to turn to Donald Trump.

column1: We should be clear that Walinsky’s critique is not confined to Clinton. He lays out (and massively overstates) a dark view not just of Clinton but also of President Obama and almost the entire Democratic Party. The analysis is overwrought
column2: but even one who buys the argument defies all logic in imagining that the solution is Trump.

column1: Story Continued Below

The question is not whether there is a military-industrial complex in our country. President Eisenhower called us out on that and there is enough responsibility to go around among both parties for it. The 21st century version begins with the Iraq War
column2: which was originated by a Republican President. I am not interested in adjudicating the issue of which party is the war party except to say that Presidents Obama
column3: Clinton and Carter have stood for peace in important and tangible ways. The question here is whether Donald Trump can claim in any way that he is the candidate who stands for a foreign policy of restraint and the answer is that he cannot.

column1: Walinsky finds in Trump a rationality and consistency that do not exist. Any reasonable observer of the presidential campaign has seen that at one moment
column2: Trump will represent himself as an isolationist who wants to end ties with NATO and other allies; at another
column3: he will lash out at any perceived insult to the U.S. or to himself
column4: and pledges that America’s pride needs to be vindicated militarily. “America First
column5: ” Trump says regularly
column6: bringing the isolationism of Charles Lindbergh to mind—before excoriating President Obama for not using greater force in any number of venues and then insinuating that he has a secret plan to obliterate the Islamic State.

column1: To compare John F. Kennedy and Robert F. Kennedy to Donald Trump is—well
column2: I won’t finish the sentence. Yes
column3: Robert Kennedy turned against the Vietnam War
column4: but not because he felt that America should retreat from the world. He opposed the war because it was unjust and was based on a flawed notion of American interests. The result
column5: as we know
column6: was the death of Vietnamese and Americans and others who should not have died. JFK and RFK were internationalists. They understood that World War II left the United States with a responsibility to play an active and constructive role in the world. They understood that America must stand together and dependably with allies who also are committed to pursue a peaceful world. They understood that the use of force was sometimes necessary and that brave men and women would be put at risk. They made those difficult
column7: often excruciating
column8: decisions carefully and as transparently as possible
column9: never rashly
column10: impulsively
column11: or vindictively.

column1: Walinsky quotes Robert Kennedy’s statement that if any member of the ExComm other than John F. Kennedy had been president during the Cuban Missile Crisis
column2: we would have had a nuclear war. Ask yourself what a President Trump might have done in that moment. “Restraint” is not the word that comes to mind.

column1: This is a man who said he would order the military to kill the families of Muslim terrorists and use interrogation techniques worse than waterboarding and opined that the United States should have seized Iraq’s oil resources as “spoils to the victor.”
Yes
column2: we have put too much power in the hands of militarists and profit seekers in both the public and private sectors. But electing Donald Trump is not the answer; it would only compound the problem in new and dangerous ways. The answer is an active citizenry that speaks out against the inappropriate use of force and opposes interference in conflicts that involve neither American security interests nor egregious human rights violations—a topic in which Donald Trump has shown an ostentatious indifference
column3: as his fondness for Vladimir Putin reflects.

column1: All the evidence
column2: provided again and again by Donald Trump’s own mouth
column3: tells us not that he is a man of peace
column4: but that he is a man of no principle—a man who will say
column5: and possibly do
column6: whatever happens to cross his mind at a given minute. He is like the weather in New England: If you don’t like it
column7: wait a minute. We do not know what he believes because he does not know what he believes. We do not know what he knows because
column8: from all we can see
column9: he does not know much.

column1: Even if Walinsky’s diatribe is correct
column2: which it most certainly is not in its breadth and depth
column3: there is nothing in it that justifies turning to Donald Trump. Of all occasions to break ranks with the Democratic Party
column4: this is the most inappropriate. Of all the ways to misappropriate the memory of John and Robert Kennedy
column5: two of our greatest public servants
column6: this is the most egregious I have ever seen.

column1: To say that I am disappointed by what Walinsky has done is an understatement. America
column2: in this election
column3: faces an existential question—and history will judge us by our answer. Walinsky has chosen the wrong side of the struggle.

column3: poll finds

column1: Gov. Chris Christie has the third-worst approval ratings of any governor in the country
column2: according to a poll released Tuesday.

column1: According to Morning Consult
column2: New Jersey voters give Christie a 29 percent approval rating and 68 percent disapproval rating. That's down from a 36 percent approval rating in the spring
column3: and not far behind the two worst ranked governors.

column1: Story Continued Below
Republican Sam Brownback of Kansas fares the worst
column2: with a 23 percent approval rating and 71 percent disapproval rating. Democrat Dan Malloy of Connecticut has a 26 percent approval rating and a 70 percent disapproval rating.

column1: The numbers in the Morning Consult poll are actually slightly better for Christie than a Rutgers-Eagleton poll released Monday
column2: which showed 26 percent of voters approving of his job performance and 69 percent disapproving
column3: while just 23 percent said they had a favorable opinion of the governor.

column1: Both surveys were conducted before the Bridgegate trial got underway on Monday — a spectacle that has already proven embarrassing for Christie amid the prosecution's claims that he knew of the George Washington Bridge access lane closings as they happened.

There is a potential consolation for Christie in the Morning Consult poll. Two Republicans he helped elect in blue states against long odds as chairman of the Republican Governors Association are among the most popular in the country. Massachusetts Gov. Charlie Baker and Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan both have 70 percent approval ratings and disapproval ratings of 18 percent and 17 percent
column2: respectively. Only Republican South Dakota Gov. Dennis Daugaard is more popular
column3: with a 74 percent approval rating.

column1: The margin of error for the New Jersey poll results is plus or minus 2 percentage points.

column1: Ri's comments came as the US and Asian nations gathered in New York Friday with a fresh reminder of what they consider the gravest threat facing the region: North Korea's announcement this week that it had successfully tested its most powerful rocket engine yet.
The test Tuesday was followed by a US show of force
column2: as the Pentagon on Wednesday flew two B-1B bombers alongside the demilitarized zone separating North and South Korea
column3: setting the the stage for US-South Korea joint military exercises in October that will include a simulated nuclear facility strike.

column3: Ri said. ""We will never remain onlookers at it and the United States will have to face tremendous consequences beyond imagination.""

column1: Meanwhile

column3: a 10-member bloc dedicated to economic

column2: Kerry told the ASEAN meeting.

Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe made a blunt call for international action at the UN Wednesday. ""Right before our eyes

236	"If you want to watch a conservative throw a temper tantrum just mention slavery and grab your popcorn.

Because when First Lady Michelle Obama talked about slavery and the great progress our country has made since the Civil War during an interview at the new Smithsonian Institution’s National Museum of African American History and Culture
column2: conservatives took to Twitter to whine.

column1: Mrs. Obama told Good Morning America host Robin Roberts about how she feels about visiting the museum
column2: which opens this weekend. And one of the things that struck her the most is the fact that a lot of the history the museum presents happened during the lives of the three generations of her family who visited the museum that day. And she expressed astonishment at how fast progress has been made.

column1: “When you think about the fact that my great-great grandfather was a slave and today I live in the White House
column2: that progress is huge and it’s fast
column3: ” the First Lady said.

column1: Here’s the video via Twitter.
FLOTUS: “My great-great grandfather was a slave and today I live in the White House. That progress is huge.” https://t.co/A4RwUHYR5z pic.twitter.com/vvhgrtxoYu — ABC News (@ABC) September 23

237	"Former President Bill Clinton and his Clinton Health Access Initiative (CHAI) distributed “watered-down” HIV/AIDs drugs to patients in sub-Saharan Africa
column2: and “likely increased” the risks of morbidity and mortality
column3: according to a draft congressional report obtained by The Daily Caller News Foundation.

column1: The congressional report
column2: titled
column3: “The Clinton Foundation and The India Success Story
column4: ” was initiated by Rep. Marsha Blackburn
column5: a Tennessee Republican and vice-chair of the House Energy and Commerce Committee.

column1: The CHAI program to help AIDS victims is considered one of the Clinton Foundation’s most important contributions and is probably its best known initiative.
The congressional report focused on Clinton’s decade-long relationship with a controversial Indian drug manufacturer called Ranbaxy
column2: which CHAI used as one of its main distributors of HIV/AIDS drugs to Third World countries.

column1: It also highlighted the work of Dinesh Thakur
column2: a former Ranbaxy employee who became a star whistleblower and permitted the U.S. government to launch a landmark lawsuit against the Indian firm. The company was vulnerable to U.S. prosecution because it also sold its generic drugs on the U.S. market.

column1: Ranbaxy ultimately pleaded guilty in 2013 to seven criminal counts with intent to defraud and the introduction of adulterated drugs into interstate commerce.
The Department of Justice further levied a $500 million fine and forfeiture on the company.
“This is the largest false claims case ever prosecuted in the District of Maryland
column2: and the nation’s largest financial penalty paid by a generic pharmaceutical company
column3: ” said U.S. Attorney for the District of Maryland Rod J. Rosenstein when Ranbaxy pleaded guilty.

column1: “When companies sell adulterated drugs
column2: they undermine the integrity of the FDA’s approval process and may cause patients to take drugs that are substandard
column3: ineffective
column4: or unsafe
column5: ” said Stuart F. Delery
column6: acting assistant attorney general for the civil division of the Department of Justice
column7: when the government announced its action against the Indian company.

column1: The Department of Justice stated in its final settlement
column2: “alleged due to the company’s diluted drugs
column3: it ‘subjected patients to increased risks of morbidity and mortality
column4: ’” according to the report.

column1: “The question becomes
column2: ‘how many people lost their lives
column3: how many people found it was a false promise
column4: ’” asked Blackburn in an interview with TheDCNF.

column1: The possibility that CHAI distributed adulterated and diluted AIDS drugs to Third World victims could shake the foundations of the Clinton charity and spark a new round of scrutiny in the final weeks of presidential candidate Hillary Clinton’s campaign.
Blackburn said she delivered the report to the inspector generals at the Department of Health and Human Services and to the Department of State
column2: where Hillary served as secretary of state during President Barack Obama’s first term.

column1: The congressional study also highlighted the unseemly ties between Bill and two controversial Indian-Americans who have been investigated and sanctioned by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The most troubling revelations concern the Clinton Foundation’s vigorous promotion of Ranbaxy despite mounting evidence the Indian firm had persistently poor quality control and attempted to cover it up through either faulty or fraudulent reporting to the FDA.
It is unclear at this juncture how many AIDS patients received the “watered-down” drugs.
ProPublica estimated that in 2007 alone
column2: the U.S. Agency for International Development allocated $9 million to Ranbaxy and delivered “more than $1.8 million packages.”

column1: “Substandard HIV medicines cause health problems for patients
column2: perhaps even accelerating death from HIV-related infections
column3: ” Roger Bate
column4: an economist at the American Enterprise Institute who researches substandard and counterfeit medicines
column5: told TheDCNF.

column1: Thakur told TheDCNF that many of the company’s anti-retroviral drugs were used to stabilize platelet and white blood cell counts in AIDS patients.
“These drugs allow it to stabilize and essentially provide immunity to patients. If the content of the medicine is not what is listed on the label
column2: you will not see the platelet levels or the WBC levels stabilize
column3: ” he said.

column1: Ranbaxy’s first public hint of problems occurred in August 2004
column2: one year after CHAI began working with the firm. The World Health Organization reported irregularities involving three Ranbaxy drugs in South Africa
column3: according to the report.

column1: The FDA sent a public “warning letter” to Ranbaxy in 2006 about reported irregularities in the company’s quality control efforts. It concluded that the drugs
column2: which included anti-retroviral HIV/AIDs medications
column3: “show much lower potencies in these batches.”

column1: Although Ranbaxy’s generic drugs are now barred from being sold in the U.S.
column2: CHAI and the former president continue to praise Ranbaxy and distribute the company’s HIV/AID drugs to patients abroad.

column1: Bill heaped praise on Ranbaxy in 2013 during a speech in Mumbai
column2: saying
column3: the drugs saved millions of lives.

column1: Neither CHAI nor the Clinton Foundation have announced they severed ties with Ranbaxy.
Thakur said he’s now a public health activist who tries to get global health charities to focus on the quality of drugs rather than simply on “access” to patients.
The whistleblower tried to meet with CHAI and Clinton Foundation officials
column2: but was only met with silence. “I have tried to reach out to them
column3: ” he told TheDCNF. “But I haven’t had a great amount of success with the Clinton Foundation.”

column1: CHAI was a part of the Clinton Foundation until 2010
column2: when it spun off into a separate entity. The groups still have some overlapping board members and staff
column3: and they continue to operate in close coordination. Bill Clinton
column4: for example
column5: is deeply involved with both organizations.

column1: Charles Ortel
column2: a Wall Street analyst who has been an outspoken critic of the legal missteps by the Clinton Foundation
column3: claims their separation was “deeply suspect.”

column1: “In the application
column2: trustees of the new entity
column3: including Bill Clinton
column4: falsely claim the entity is not a successor to previous efforts. This is not true. They purposefully obscure the fact that a similar operation called ‘CHAI’ was by far the largest piece of the original Foundation
column5: ” Ortel told TheDCNF.

column1: The congressional study suggests Bill may have relaxed quality standards in a 2000 executive order.
He signed an executive order that
column2: “relaxed intellectual property policy standards
column3: ” promising the U.S. government “would not revoke or revise the intellectual property laws of any ‘Sub-Saharan country’ relating to HIV/AIDS medicines or technologies
column4: ” the report states.

column1: CHAI announced in October 2003 it was going to distribute generic
column2: low-cost HIV drugs from four foreign drug manufacturers: Ranbaxy; Cipla of Mumbai
column3: India; Matrix Labs of Hydrabad
column4: India; Aspen Pharmacare of Johannesburg
column5: South Africa.

column1: CHAI’s endorsement also allowed Ranbaxy to manufacture HIV drugs that would be bought by the U.S. government under the President’s Emergency Plan for AIDS relief — a $15 billion initiative proposed by former President George W. Bush.
The flow of U.S. funds combined with Clinton’s endorsement allowed the four foreign drug manufactures to become “good acquisition targets
column2: ” according to the study.

column1: Ranbaxy filed 10 abbreviated new drug applications
column2: three of which were approved by the FDA
column3: according to the congressional study. Eventually
column4: the firm would produce 13 generic HIV drugs.

column1: The companies enjoyed great financial profits and they “exploded as they partnered with the Foundation for several years
column2: ” the report states.

column1: The study also examined the key players in the Clinton-CHAI orbit
column2: the potential for corruption and how the program ultimately benefited the Clinton Foundation in terms of donor contributions.

column1: One relationship unearthed by the report was the American Indian Foundation
column2: which Clinton co-founded with Indian-American businessmen Rajat Gupta and Vinod Gupta in 2001.

column1: Rajat was convicted of insider trading in 2012 in a sensational trial.

Vinod eventually was forced to resign as CEO and chairman of the company InfoGroup and was fined $9 million in a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation. One of the charges stated Vinod had awarded Bill $3.3 million without board approval.
Blackburn says the worst part of the story were the “false hopes” offered by the Clinton Foundation.
“You think about the emotional state of health care workers as they are dealing with these individuals and the emotional state of the patients. To me it’s disturbing and very sad
column2: ” she said.

238	"North Carolina's governor has dropped a lawsuit asking a federal court to preserve the state's HB2 law limiting civil rights protections for LGBT people and regulating who uses which public bathrooms.
In court documents Friday
column2: Gov. Pat McCrory cited ""substantial costs to the State"" as one reason for dropping his lawsuit against the federal government
column3: writing that it did not serve the ""interests of judicial economy and efficiency.""

column1: Businesses
column2: performing artists and event organizers have boycotted the state since House Bill 2 was passed. In July
column3: the NBA announced it was pulling its February All-Star Game out of Charlotte
column4: saying in a statement
column5: ""We do not believe we can successfully host our All-Star festivities in Charlotte in the climate created by the current law.""

column1: This month
column2: the NCAA and the Atlantic Coast Conference both moved championship sporting events out of the state.

column1: McCrory sued the federal government in May
column2: after U.S. Attorney General Loretta Lynch said HB2 violated both the Civil Rights Act and Title IX and threatened to withhold federal funding to the state. The Department of Justice countersued
column3: seeking to ban enforcement on the grounds that the law is
column4: as Lynch said at the time
column5: ""impermissibly discriminatory.""

column1: Did You Know It's Legal In Most States To Discriminate Against LGBT People?
IT'S ALL POLITICS
Did You Know It's Legal In Most States To Discriminate Against LGBT People?
North Carolina Passes Law Blocking Measures To Protect LGBT People
THE TWO-WAY
North Carolina Passes Law Blocking Measures To Protect LGBT People
This action is about a great deal more than just bathrooms. This is about the dignity and respect we accord our fellow citizens and the laws that we
column2: as a people and as a country
column3: have enacted to protect them — indeed
column4: to protect all of us
column5: Lynch said at a news conference.

column1: North Carolina is also fighting another lawsuit challenging the law's constitutionality. That suit
column2: brought by the American Civil Liberties Union
column3: was filed in March on behalf of Joaquin Carcaño
column4: a 27-year-old transgender man who works at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and is banned from using public men's restrooms under the law.

column1: Some local support for the law is waning
column2: as well. After months of bad business news and widespread condemnation by other state governments
column3: at least two state legislators who helped pass the law now want it repealed.

column1: North Carolina state Sens. Tamara Barringer and Rick Gunn have both backed off their initial support for the law. Barringer says she voted for the law out of concern about ""safety and particularly privacy in bathrooms."" But last week
column2: she told NPR she has changed her mind:

column1: There's several factors that have changed my mind. It is having a tremendous adverse economic impact on the families of North Carolina. These are jobs. These are the way we support our families
column2: the way we fund education.

column1: It is also creating the wrong impression of North Carolinians in the world or across the nation. Last week
column2: I had the privilege of representing North Carolina on an education mission to Arizona State University.

column1: But at lunch
column2: someone asked the question
column3: 'Senator Barringer
column4: what is this HB2 thing?' And that really caught me in my tracks
column5: that
column6: all the way across the country
column7: someone is asking this.

column1: And then
column2: finally
column3: the other thing that has galvanized me is we have talked hundreds of hours... since April about HB-2. And yes
column4: it is an important issue
column5: but we need to move on to the business of North Carolina.""

column1: McCrory has said he still stands by the ideas in the law
column2: which makes it illegal for local governments in the state to pass laws protecting LGBT people from discrimination. But his office said last week that the governor would repeal the law if the city of Charlotte repeals a local ordinance protecting LGBT people from discrimination
column3: according to the Charlotte Observer.

column1: That local ordinance
column2: which never took effect because the state law overruled it
column3: would have prevented businesses from discriminating against gay
column4: lesbian
column5: bisexual and transgender people in Charlotte
column6: and allowed people to use the locker rooms and bathrooms corresponding to the gender with which they identify.

column1: North Carolina Sues DOJ Over LGBT Law; DOJ Sues Back
THE TWO-WAY
North Carolina Sues DOJ Over LGBT Law; DOJ Sues Back
The Charlotte City Council considered such a repeal in May
column2: but it was voted down. The city's mayor
column3: Jennifer Roberts
column4: said the issue of whether to repeal the ordinance will not be on the agenda when the city council meets Monday evening.

column1: While city leaders ""applaud the governor for recognizing the state should overturn HB2
column2: Roberts wrote in a statement Monday
column3: she argued that Charlotte does not bear responsibility for the state law

column1: 239	"Story highlights The House Oversight panel voted 19-15 to hold Bryan Pagliano in contempt
Pagliano failed to show for a second hearing on Clinton's emails and private server

Washington (CNN) Members of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee voted along party lines Thursday to hold the architect of Hillary Clinton's private email server in contempt for failing to appear before them.

The panel's 19-15 vote came after Bryan Pagliano failed to attend a second hearing on Clinton's emails and use of a private server while leading the State Department. Republicans blasted his decision as an act of defiance
column2: but Pagliano's lawyers said the demand that he appear ""betrays a naked political agenda.""

column1: House Oversight Chairman Jason Chaffetz
column2: a Utah Republican
column3: argued that previous testimony from another one of Clinton's IT workers
column4: Justin Cooper
column5: made it imperative for Pagliano to testify.

column1: I explained Mr. Pagliano was uniquely qualified to provide testimony to help the committee better understand Secretary Clinton's use of a private email server. This is indisputable
column2: Chaffetz said. ""I also made clear the committee would consider all options regarding Mr. Pagliano's failure to appear
column3: including consideration of recommending he be held in contempt.""

For a little over a decade today’s millennials have been described as being part of the “everyone gets a trophy generation.” Effort and standards are a thing of the past
column2: so much so that even the standard to be a victim is at historic lows.

column1: Would you believe that the man behind Saturday’s NJ and NYC bombings once claimed to be a victim of “Islamophobia?” This was allegedly such a problem that the attacker Ahmad Khan Rahami and his father once sued the police in Elizabeth New Jersey for discrimination
column2: and also accused other members of the community of discrimination based on religion.

column1: The journalists over at the Daily Mail did some digging into the lawsuit
column2: and here’s what they found (courtesy of Louder With Crowder):

column1: The prime suspect in the New York and New Jersey bombings sued his local police force and claimed they were persecuting him for being a Muslim. Ahmad Rahami said in a lawsuit that cops in Elizabeth
column2: New Jersey subjected his and his family to discrimination and ‘selective enforcement’ based on their religion. The family claimed that police tried to shut down their chicken restaurant
column3: called First American
column4: too early each night with ‘baseless’ tickets and summonses. Ahmad
column6: his father Mohammad Sr
column8: and his brother Mohammad
column9: brought the lawsuit together and said that local residents also racially abused them and said: ‘Muslims don’t belong here’. The lawsuit was filed in 2011 and reveals that Ahmad has a long history of grievances with city officials
column10: their local police force and people who lived close to them.

column1: No
column2: you’re not living in an episode of the Twilight Zone right now
column3: this is real life.

column2: it had nothing to do his with ethnicity or religion
column3: ” Bollwage said
column4: adding
column5: “It had to do with noise and people congregating on the streets.”

column1: Rahami’s family owns a fried chicken restaurant in Elizabeth
column2: NJ called First American Fried Chicken. This is also the same town where five bombs were found at a train station Monday morning. His lawsuit went nowhere
column3: so apparently his strategy in that particular case was that if you can’t beat them in the courts: bomb them instead.

243	"I can’t wait for “Weekend at Chelsea’s” to hit the big screen. CNN and the rest of Hillary Clinton’s slobbering media sycophants have already written the script. If this woman
column2: God forbid
column3: dropped dead on the sidewalk tomorrow
column4: these doting suck-ups – these mass media strumpets whose voter trust has
column5: understandably
column6: reached an all-time low – would dutifully parrot the Clinton campaign talking points and call it a “minor setback” to her “inevitable” victory.

column1: The American people aren’t buying it. This is a severely ill woman. No more “conspiracy theory” dismissals. Mrs. Clinton’s “mild cold
column2: ” er
column3: “seasonal allergies
column4: ” I mean “heat exhaustion
column5: ” that is to say “minor case of pneumonia” is
column6: evidently
column7: of the rare kind that requires a permanent traveling physician and a “mystery man” who rushes to her side whenever she has one of her frequent and uncontrollable “episodes” (or otherwise freezes up with a brain “short-circuit” during a speech).

column1: This guy has been spotted with the Clintons during medical emergencies going back to 2003 when Hillary suffered a brain blood clot (also covered up) and carries in hand what many medical experts say is a Diazepam pen. Diazepam is an intravenous drug used to treat seizures.

Blue tinted glasses of the sort Mrs. Clinton was wearing Sunday when she collapsed are also worn by patients who suffer seizures. These therapeutic specs are likewise used to relieve symptoms of Parkinson’s disease – a neurological disorder from which a number of doctors indicate Mrs. Clinton likely suffers (since when has “pneumonia” required a neurological squeeze test?).
The Clinton campaign needs to come clean. They won’t
column2: but they should. I wonder what official “diagnosis” we’ll get the next time she seizes up and collapses into the arms of eerily calm Secret Service agents acting as though they’ve been there a hundred times before. “Nothing to see here
column3: folks. Secretary Clinton’s sciatica is just acting up a bit from the 30 miles she ‘powered through’ yesterday going door-to-door.”

column1: The point is that
column2: once more
column3: by lying about illness Mrs. Clinton has reinforced (and justified) concerns about both her physical and moral fitness to serve as president. She’s proven
column4: yet again
column5: that she can’t be trusted. She has confirmed a number of pre-conceptions that voters
column6: as revealed by her historically low approval ratings
column7: have formed relative to her health and character. She’s a liar. That’s her default mode. She’s corrupt. And she’s sick. Very sick. She puts her own personal political ambition and lust for power above all else – including the best interests of the nation
column8: and even her own life.

column1: Do I take joy in Mrs. Clinton’s sufferings and plummeting poll numbers? Well
column2: no on the first
column3: yes on the second. “Do not gloat when your enemy falls; when they stumble
column4: do not let your heart rejoice” (Proverbs 24:17).

column1: Indeed
column2: Mrs. Clinton has had a very bad week
column3: but her poll numbers were already trending downward. Her medical crisis over the weekend
column4: coupled with her stepping in it by smearing half of Donald Trump’s supporters as a “racist” and “irredeemable” “basket of deplorables
column5: ” has only served to accelerate the plunge.

column1: Perhaps this is because of the glaring hypocrisy associated with such a statement – especially by this particular woman. This is the same Hillary Clinton who once called the late Sen. Robert Byrd
column2: D-W.Va.
column3: her “friend and mentor.” Sen. Byrd
column4: of course
column5: was a recruiter for the actually deplorable KKK. This is the same Hillary Clinton whose husband
column6: former president Bill Clinton
column7: was caught jokingin 2008 that President Obama should be carrying his bags – the same woman whose Democratic Party opposed the 1964 Civil Rights Act while Republicans
column8: not unlike those she just slandered
column9: worked hard to pass it. Finally
column10: and going back a bit further
column11: this is the same Hillary Clinton whose party fought a war to maintain slavery in the U.S. while hundreds-of-thousands of Republicans gave up their lives to free them.

column1: Who’s the racist?
I’m praying for Hillary Clinton. Despite what her campaign and worshipful media disciples are peddling
column2: and notwithstanding her being caught in lie after lie
column3: our eyes have been telling us the truth for months
column4: maybe even years now. To watch this increasingly frail
column5: bitter and elderly woman stiffen up
column6: convulse and collapse into the arms of well-practiced staffers is hard to stomach. You can’t help but feel some modicum of compassion for her
column7: wicked though she may be.

column1: It’s almost tragic to witness. Hillary Clinton has lived her entire life for this moment. Everything she’s ever done or said
column2: and the mounding piles of lecherous BS she’s put up with from her sexually predatory partner-in-crime
column3: has been designed to place her in the Oval Office
column4: not as first lady
column5: but as president of the United States. Proverbs 19:21 says
column6: “Many are the plans in a person’s heart
column7: but it is the LORD’s purpose that prevails.”

column1: Am I saying there’s no chance Hillary Clinton will win? Not at all
column2: though I think it unlikely. Between her devoted media harpies
column3: her team of around-the-clock doctors and a campaign staff well versed in the practice of propaganda and cover-up
column4: there’s always a chance they might just literally carry her over the finish line to victory.

column1: Still
column2: it remains my humble prayer that this past week signals the beginning of the end for Hillary Clinton’s political aspirations. Even so
column3: I also pray she might live a long and healthy life in the private sector – a life with plenty of time to bounce cute little grandkids on her knee.

column1: When they visit her in prison.

How can you tell when a man is so far gone that he’s obviously not fit to stand on a stage for 90 minutes? That opinion would likely differ from psychologist to psychologist
column2: but certainly there are warning signs.

column1: Donald Trump has been running full-steam now for months. He’s constantly on the campaign trail
column2: under the hot lights of the cameras with little time for rest. He’s a 70-year-old man and he refuses to let up. He’s been not only preparing for a debate with a world-class politician (no matter how much he denies it he knows the truth) and to “relax” he flies to Roanoke last-minute to hold a rally.

column1: It’s obviously catching up to him. Sunday night
column2: less than 24 hours before he’s set to walk into the hall to get ready for the most important night of his life
column3: Donald Trump is showing signs that he’s simply taken this thing too far and gone off the deep end. This incoherent tweet covers three topics that are completely unrelated. It shows that Trump’s mind is prone to wandering and while each topic by itself may have been a talking point used to pander to somebody
column4: together it’s just gibberish:

column1: Five people killed in Washington State by a Middle Eastern immigrant. Many people died this weekend in Ohio from drug overdoses. N.C. riots! — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) September 26
Just…what is he talking about? If you’re trying to court the people you want to scare into voting for you
column2: you talk about terrorism. If you want to court moderates concerned that drugs are seeping into the middle-class like never before you talk about opioid deaths. If you want to pander to your low-hanging fruit and court the racists you talk about riots in North Carolina.

column1: Talking about them together shows just one thing: Trump is coming unhinged. He’s obviously not ready and maybe even unfit to debate Hillary Clinton. This could be the end of the line for the Trump train.

column1: 275	"11.3k SHARES SHARE THIS STORY
During a Republican primary debate in September 2015
column2: now-Republican nominee Donald Trump said that he never lobbied Florida Governor Jeb Bush for casino gambling because “he would’ve gotten it
column3: if I wanted it.” But if that is true
column4: then Donald Trump committed yet another yet another felonious offense by the racist mogul – this time for for lying under oath in a civil court deposition
column5: which is perjury
column6: as Newsweek reports:

column1: One of these stories is a lie—a detailed
column2: self-serving fabrication. But unlike the mountain of other lies he has told
column3: this time the character trait that leads to Trump’s mendacity is on full display: He makes things up when he doesn’t want to admit he lost.

column1: Assume the story he told at the debate is the lie. Even though Bush’s story reinforced what Trump was saying at rallies—he had played the “cash for outcomes” political game for years—he could not admit he had tried to do the same in Florida because he could not bring himself to say that he had lost. Instead
column2: he looked America in the eye and lied. And then he felt compelled to stack on another boast: His people are so wonderful that they would have gotten casino gambling in Florida
column3: regardless of Bush’s opposition—if Trump had wanted it.

column1: The transcripts below will show you there was a dispute of fact between two candidates
column2: but not just any fact
column3: a fact which Jeb Bush would’ve full well known
column4: as would have Trump. Because after Trump’s naïve attempt to muscle gambling into Florida over the objections of an anti-gambling Republican governor failed
column5: he sued his former employee for his own failure. Eichenwald’s point is that either Trump lied baldly to the face of a former elected official on national television (and moderators let him get away with it unchecked) or:

column1: Now consider the other option
column2: that Trump committed perjury in the 2007 testimony. There
column3: he admitted pushing for casino gambling in Florida
column4: but said he would have gotten what he wanted if he hadn’t been tricked by Fields. The rationale for the perjurious testimony is simple—Trump wants money from a man who stopped working for him and
column5: once again
column6: the story lets him deny he is anything less than perfect.

column1: Why is all of this important? In the late 1990s
column2: House Republicans impeached Democratic President Bill Clinton for allegedly lying in a deposition about a sensitive personal offense to his wife. The entire media hounded President Clinton over the Whitewater “scandal” for half of the decade and it was the only thing they could find.

column1: Republicans selected a nominee who is legendary for his lies
column2: but unlike Trump’s other tall tales and obvious gaslighting
column3: this lie was either told to a Florida court of law under oath (it does seem like Trump lives in the Florida court system at times) or to national television and his party’s base to discredit his opponent by turning the truth on it’s head.

column1: Trump’s penchant for turning the truth upside down is not only a disastrous character flaw
column2: but it’s a mortal danger to our national safety that he is even on the ballot as a major party candidate for President.

column1: See for yourself the two transcripts Newsweek published and decide for yourself if Trump perjured himself to the court or lied to the Republican debate audience. Compare the two options presented by Eichenwald
column2: there’s no third option here:

column1: Bush: “The one guy that had some special interests that I know of that tried to get me to change my views on something—that was generous and gave me money—was Donald Trump. He wanted casino gambling in Florida.” Trump interrupted Bush: Trump: I didn’t— Bush: Yes
column2: you did. Trump: Totally false. Bush: You wanted it
column3: and you didn’t get it
column4: because I was opposed to— Trump: I would have gotten it. Bush: Casino gambling before— Trump: I promise
column5: I would have gotten it. Bush: During and after. I’m not going to be bought by anybody. Trump: I promise
column6: if I wanted it
column7: I would have gotten it. Bush: No way. Believe me. Trump: I know my people. Bush: Not even possible. Trump: I know my people.

column1: Transcript of 2007 Trial Deposition:
A lawyer asked Trump
column2: “Did you yourself do anything to obtain any of the details with respect to the Florida gaming environment
column3: what approvals were needed and so forth?” Trump: A little bit. Lawyer: What did you do? Trump: I actually spoke with Governor-Elect Bush; I had a big fundraiser for Governor-Elect Bush…and I think it was his most successful fundraiser
column4: the most successful that he had had up until that point
column5: that was in Trump Tower in New York on Fifth Avenue. Lawyer: When was that? Trump: Sometime prior to his election. Lawyer: You knew that Governor Bush

column1: 282	"A Daisy of a Rerun
I am of an age which includes probably the first major political distortion in Presidential campaigning. That being the TV advertisement of an innocent little girl
column2: sitting in a field picking daisy petals one by one
column3: while a mushroom cloud arises in a most sinister fashion behind her.

column1: The year was 1964 and the incumbent President Lyndon B Johnson “approved” that message. Only problem was that he followed the course in Vietnam which he was trying to assign onto his supposedly “war mongering” opponent
column2: Barry Goldwater.

column1: Today
column2: as our history books find difficulty in revisiting Johnson’s deceitful war policies
column3: Goldwater’s vindication is now generally accepted without any acknowledgment from our Nation’s media.

column1: I mention this as a backdrop of our current Presidential campaign. Just maybe another daisy advertisement could be made
column2: only this time
column3: that little girl should be picking those daisy petals for each Clinton failure. Such a rendering
column4: depicting reasons why Clinton is unworthy of the Presidency
column5: would be shattering to her campaign.

column1: Obviously
column2: this version will never make it to our living rooms yet there are rumors that a “Daisy” remake aimed against Trump
column3: has been mentioned. That being said
column4: such considerations demonstrate just how desperate are the Clinton staffers.

column1: Somehow
column2: if those daisy petals could be offered against Clinton as I previously mentioned
column3: its message could outweigh Goldwater’s 1964 deception
column4: when based upon the accuracy of recent events.

column1: Instead
column2: today’s voters continue to wrestle with or just ignore the printed garbage which is masquerading as “news and views.” With the recent about-face announcement from Ted Cruz
column3: the media’s reaction of ridicule was to be expected.

column1: Now
column2: another unbalanced AP report unfolded
column3: this one detailing Ted’s “dramatic about-face that may help unite a deeply divided Republican Party.” This in addition to previous statements in which Cruz called Trump a “pathological liar” and “utterly amoral.”

column1: As the article relates
column2: Trump countered with his nickname of “’Lyin Ted
column3: ’ insulted his wife
column4: and linked his father to the John F. Kennedy assassination.” These actual quotes were selected for public consumption for one reason and although highly slanted and selective
column5: it grades out under the sanctions of fair journalistic fodder.

column1: Schools of journalism teach that Americans are famous for both their short memories and their short attention spans. So
column2: is it any wonder that our media pundits often place the more critical details far into an article
column3: even within the closing paragraph
column4: since many readers turn off after one paragraph?

column1: Another safeguard of a derogatory story
column2: which must unavoidably be reported is that its coverage is short-lived. I say “derogatory” when regarding the democratic and liberal policies and/or individuals. This exclusive slanting has been so prevalent that the “liberal press” moniker has now everyday acceptance.

column1: It is to this unbalance that the informed and curious must either work on their retention skills or record the scanty details from a pertinent event. This extra correlation is my fountain for the following excerpts which will never qualify for the public’s re-airing. Also
column2: the blatant public disservice
column3: when comparing the above cited quotes verses what the AP ignores
column4: needs no further explanation.

column1: Also
column2: with the first debate squarely in view
column3: the caliber of moderating will now and forever pivot upon the Candy Crowley faux pas. Especially annoying is the unchanged format and résumés of the personnel who will rule this forum. In an effort to tone down or balance this slanted presentation
column4: choice commentary against the protected candidate can offer a logical alternative and demonstrates reasons for its AP exclusion.

column1: These quotes become especially prominent since both commentators are democrats themselves
column2: and who have now reversed their opinions and are vigorously campaigning for the recipient of their former objections.

column1: With that
column2: consider the President’s past considerations of today’s democrat candidate
column3: his hopeful successor
column4: when back during the 2008 primary
column5: Obama stated of Hillary
column6: “She will say anything and change nothing. Hillary can’t be trusted and isn’t qualified to be President.”

column1: Obviously
column2: the deception and the intentional abandonment
column3: along with the two weeks of lying about Benghazi had yet to occur. Not only is this pertinent
column4: it’s damning
column5: given the time frame.

column1: Also during that same campaign
column2: future first lady Michelle offered this opine: “If you can’t run your own house
column3: you certainly can’t run the White House.”

column1: Apparently
column2: that one shortcoming continues to this day and while concerning if not pertinent
column3: it is omitted from an equal public review.

column1: Again
column2: wouldn’t it be ironically significant to rerun that daisy commercial
column3: only this time with documentation for each petal? That type of accounting may be even more withering than that long ago false imaging of a mushroom cloud!

column1: 283	"It was late one night in the White House when Obama first came up with the idea for ISIS. He hadn’t been sleeping well. Michelle told him to take some deep breaths
column2: have some hot milk
column3: and rewatch Princess Bride
column4: but he’d made it all the way to the Billy Crystal scene
column5: and he was out of milk
column6: and Michelle had started snoring. The snoring was loud and nasty and kind of wet-sounding
column7: like a broken boat was giving birth to another boat. He had to get out of there.

column1: First
column2: he headed down to the Oval Office and tried to sleep on the couch
column3: but it wasn’t long enough for his legs
column4: and it smelled like generals’ butts. For a long time
column5: he just wandered around the West Wing alone. He was sad and tired and had the nervous feeling that he was doing something he shouldn’t. He peeked into people’s desk drawers and found pictures of cats and dogs and babies. He was thinking about stealing a Kind bar off one of his interns’ desks
column6: when suddenly a word appeared to him: ISIS. He grabbed a Post-It note and wrote it down. What was it? What did it mean?

column1: It wasn’t until months later
column2: at Coachella
column3: that the idea started to take shape. Obama loved electronic music — the beats
column4: the lights
column5: the DJs
column6: the wonderful fans — and every year
column7: for just one day
column8: the Secret Service allowed him to go to the music festival. They would hang back
column9: and he would wear sunglasses
column10: a flower crown
column11: a neon tank top
column12: and a tight European-style bathing suit and just dance. The people who did recognize him were too drunk and high to convince anyone of what they’d seen. (“Hey
column13: bro
column15: bro!”) The president would block it all out and surrender to the thumping
column16: sick beat. He had done a tiny bit of molly with a French Canadian woman named Bonjour when the word “ISIS” came back to him. Ever since he was a little boy
column17: he had wanted to start an international terrorist organization of his own. He’d just never had the right idea. People had been starting terrorist groups for years
column18: and he knew that if he wanted to break into the market
column19: he needed some big new shtick. Wait. Of course. He went into his wallet and dug out the crumpled Post-It note. Yes. He would be the first American president to start an international terrorist organization
column20: and it would be called ISIS. Bonjour was naked now
column21: trying to bend a glow stick around one of her breasts. He gave her his flower crown
column23: and drove straight back to Washington. By the time he got home

column1: At first it was difficult to get people to believe he wasn’t kidding. “I want to be the founder of a new terrorist group
column2: ” he’d tell them. They’d laugh and say something like
column3: “Hey
column4: Mr. President
column5: please don’t ever say that again publicly!” Obama felt like one of the characters trying to start a luxury denim business on the HBO show How to Make It in America. Then
column6: finally
column7: he decided the only person who could really help him was Hillary.

column1: They were down in the kitchen one night eating Popsicles and staring into each other’s eyes when he asked if he could tell her a secret. Hillary laughed and said
column2: “Is it about how you’re really a terrorist?” He looked at her and said
column3: “Yes
column4: actually.” She stopped eating her Popsicle. “Donald Trump was right about you?” He nodded. “About everything.”

column1: He explained that he had actually been born in Kenya in 1919
column2: and that he was 97 years old. He’d made an American birth certificate out of simple graph paper and aged it with tea bags. (“Honestly
column3: it took me
column4: like
column5: 20 minutes.”) He explained that his parents told him from an early age that he should grow up to become the president of the United States so that he could eventually destroy the country from the inside.

column1: “Isn’t that the plot of the first season of Homeland?” Hillary asked. Obama nodded. “Kind of. Also a little bit of The Americans.”
No one had come close to guessing his secret
column2: until Donald Trump. He didn’t know what had given it away. He’d been so careful. Had Donald Trump figured out the secret messages he was sending through his Portuguese water dog
column3: Bo? “Wait
column4: what?” Hillary asked. She was starting to freak out. Obama explained that Bo was actually a supercomputer programmed to bark out messages in Morse code to terrorist organizations around the world
column5: and he thought there was a chance that Donald Trump had seen that Bo’s eyes were really tiny LED screens. “Did you know that when Bo barks
column6: ” Obama said
column7: “he’s just repeating the word dog over and over again in a robot voice?”

column1: Hillary was quiet for a long time. She had stopped eating her Popsicle
column2: and the whole thing had just melted away. Now her fingers were stuck together
column3: and it looked like she had one weird fish-hand. When she finally spoke
column4: it was almost a whisper. “You’re a 97-year-old Kenyan Muslim man who was sent here by your ancestors to destroy America?” Obama nodded. Hillary made a strange sound and cried out
column5: “I feel like I’m short-circuiting!” Obama did his best to comfort her. “Bo does that sometimes. Then he’ll go outside and poop out a printer cartridge.”

column1: Hillary was breathing hard. She walked the length of the kitchen
column2: then walked the width of the kitchen
column3: and then surprised herself by doing the first tumbling pass in Aly Raisman’s floor routine. Obama knew it was dangerous to tell someone his secrets
column4: but it was such a relief. He felt light and loose. He felt 87 again. He took her hands into his. “I’m sorry my fingers are stuck together like a fish-hand
column5: ” Hillary apologized. “Do you mean a fin?” Obama asked. They both chuckled with their mouths closed. Hillary told him that she would probably need more time to process everything. Then he leaned down and said in a soft
column6: strong voice: “But I haven’t even told you the best part yet. I’m going to start my own terrorist group and call it ISIS.”

column1: “Isis?”
“No
column2: ISIS. All caps.”

column1: Hillary and Obama talked for hours that night. When they got tired of the kitchen
column2: they moved outside to the Rose Garden with a six-pack
column3: a joint
column4: and
column5: like
column6: a ton of cheese. They lay with their backs on the wet grass and looked up into the hazy Washington sky as Obama told her everything he imagined for the new terrorist group
column7: and she listened and laughed and gradually finished the beer. When she felt sleepy
column8: she put her head just inside one of his arms
column9: closed her eyes

column1: 286	"Pennsylvania Republicans are trying to jam a bill through the statehouse that would go into effect immediately to allow voter intimidation across the state on Election Day in support of Donald Trump.
First proposed in June
column2: House Bill 29 would give outsiders the ability to watch the polls in districts in which they do not reside and would give them the power to challenge voters
column3: which would disrupt the voting process and cause delays that could prevent people from exercising their right to vote.

column1: In other words
column2: it would legalize voter intimidation.

column1: As Brennan Center for Justice counsel Adam Gitlin told ProPublica earlier this month
column2: poll watchers
column3: especially those who decide they are going to challenge voters based on their race or religion

column1: “There’s actually a risk that

column3: people are going to be showing up to the polls
column4: they won’t know the law
column5: and they’ll be engaging in discriminatory challenges
column6: ” Gitlin said. “That can create the potential for a lot of disruption
column7: longer lines because each voter takes longer to vote
column8: and potentially discouraging and intimidating voters from coming to the polls.”

column1: As we all know
column2: conservatives who support Trump are racists who think their brand of Christianity should be the law of the land

column3: we’re not going to lose. The only way we can lose
column4: in my opinion – I really mean this
column5: Pennsylvania – is if cheating goes on.”

column1: Trump even has a place on his website where his supporters can sign up to be poll watchers to “Stop Crooked Hillary From Rigging This Election!”

column2: Pennsylvania Republicans have tacked an amendment on the bill that would make it go into effect immediately if it is passed and signed by the governor. Originally

column1: Throughout all of this
column2: Trump has insisted that he has no business ties to Russia. “For the record
column3: I have ZERO investments in Russia” he tweeted in July. Now – brace yourself
column4: this might come as a shock – it appears he’s been lying to us the whole time.

column1: An ABC News investigation has found that Donald Trump has “numerous ties” to Russian interests both here in the United States and in Russia. “The level of business amounts to hundreds of millions of dollars — what he received as a result of interaction with Russian businessmen. They were happy to invest with him
column2: and they were happy to work with Donald Trump. And they were happy to associate—[and] be associated with Donald Trump” says Sergei Millian
column3: who heads a U.S.-Russia business group.

column1: Trump has reaped huge profits off his business deals with Russian oligarchs that stretch from hosting the 2013 Miss Universe contest in Moscow and selling Trump-branded real estate to “large numbers” of Russian buyers – so many that the Sunny and Hollywood Islands in Florida became known as “Little Moscow.”
The oligarchs of Russia made their fortunes by making deals to acquire huge numbers of shares in the state-owned companies of the former Soviet Union as the country shifted to a free-market economy
column2: turning them into billionaires overnight. Towards the end of the Boris Yeltsin era
column3: the oligarchs controlled 50% to 75% of all Russian finance. Now
column4: they use their influence and wealth to prop up the Putin regime
column5: while he turns a blind eye as they rob the country blind. Putin himself has amassed a fortune of $70 billion that could be as high as $200 billion.

column1: The oligarchs are constantly looking to funnel their ill-gotten gains out of the country
column2: and it turns out purchasing Trump properties was a favored way to do so. It makes sense – they are all men cut from the same gold cloth. They are self-entitled narcissistic materialists who care for nothing but increasing their own personal wealth.

column1: “I think material wealth for them is a highly emotional and spiritual thing. They spend a lot of money on their own personal consumption…They don’t read books. They don’t go to [art] exhibitions. They think the only way to impress anyone is to buy a yacht” says former KGB agent Alexander Lebedev
column2: who went on to describe them as “cultural ignoramuses…not interested in social justice.” Sound like anyone we know?

column1: When the US State Department leveled sanctions on the Russian oligarchs in 2014 following Moscow’s annexation of the Crimea
column2: the oligarchs had one of their key money-laundering tools cut off. If Trump were president
column3: however
column4: he could end the sanctions and allow them to continue to enrich themselves – and Trump himself. “We’ll be looking at that
column5: yeah we’ll be looking” said Trump on the issue of sanctions in July.

column1: These business dealings obviously present a great conflict of interest between the personal finances of a potential President and the foreign policy of our nation
column2: which seeks to curtail the disruptive and corrupting influences of the Russian oligarchs and put a check on Russian territorial aggression in Eastern Europe. Would President Trump be able to put his personal profits aside? If this election has taught us anything at all
column3: it’s that Trump cares about nothing but himself. We cannot allow him and his Russian cronies to take their corruption to the White House.

304	"Former President Bill Clinton and his Clinton Health Access Initiative (CHAI) distributed “watered-down” HIV/AIDs drugs to patients in sub-Saharan Africa
column2: and “likely increased” the risks of morbidity and mortality
column3: according to a draft congressional report obtained by The Daily Caller News Foundation.

column1: The congressional report
column2: titled
column3: “The Clinton Foundation and The India Success Story
column4: ” was initiated by Rep. Marsha Blackburn
column5: a Tennessee Republican and vice-chair of the House Energy and Commerce Committee.

column1: The CHAI program to help AIDS victims is considered one of the Clinton Foundation’s most important contributions and is probably its best known initiative.
The congressional report focused on Clinton’s decade-long relationship with a controversial Indian drug manufacturer called Ranbaxy
column2: which CHAI used as one of its main distributors of HIV/AIDS drugs to Third World countries.

column1: It also highlighted the work of Dinesh Thakur
column2: a former Ranbaxy employee who became a star whistleblower and permitted the U.S. government to launch a landmark lawsuit against the Indian firm. The company was vulnerable to U.S. prosecution because it also sold its generic drugs on the U.S. market.

column1: Ranbaxy ultimately pleaded guilty in 2013 to seven criminal counts with intent to defraud and the introduction of adulterated drugs into interstate commerce.
The Department of Justice further levied a $500 million fine and forfeiture on the company.
“This is the largest false claims case ever prosecuted in the District of Maryland
column2: and the nation’s largest financial penalty paid by a generic pharmaceutical company
column3: ” said U.S. Attorney for the District of Maryland Rod J. Rosenstein when Ranbaxy pleaded guilty.

column1: “When companies sell adulterated drugs
column2: they undermine the integrity of the FDA’s approval process and may cause patients to take drugs that are substandard
column3: ineffective
column4: or unsafe
column5: ” said Stuart F. Delery
column6: acting assistant attorney general for the civil division of the Department of Justice
column7: when the government announced its action against the Indian company.

column1: The Department of Justice stated in its final settlement
column2: “alleged due to the company’s diluted drugs
column3: it ‘subjected patients to increased risks of morbidity and mortality
column4: ’” according to the report.

column1: “The question becomes
column2: ‘how many people lost their lives
column3: how many people found it was a false promise
column4: ’” asked Blackburn in an interview with TheDCNF.

column1: The possibility that CHAI distributed adulterated and diluted AIDS drugs to Third World victims could shake the foundations of the Clinton charity and spark a new round of scrutiny in the final weeks of presidential candidate Hillary Clinton’s campaign.
Blackburn said she delivered the report to the inspector generals at the Department of Health and Human Services and to the Department of State
column2: where Hillary served as secretary of state during President Barack Obama’s first term.

column1: The congressional study also highlighted the unseemly ties between Bill and two controversial Indian-Americans who have been investigated and sanctioned by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The most troubling revelations concern the Clinton Foundation’s vigorous promotion of Ranbaxy despite mounting evidence the Indian firm had persistently poor quality control and attempted to cover it up through either faulty or fraudulent reporting to the FDA.
It is unclear at this juncture how many AIDS patients received the “watered-down” drugs.
ProPublica estimated that in 2007 alone
column2: the U.S. Agency for International Development allocated $9 million to Ranbaxy and delivered “more than $1.8 million packages.”

column1: “Substandard HIV medicines cause health problems for patients
column2: perhaps even accelerating death from HIV-related infections
column3: ” Roger Bate
column4: an economist at the American Enterprise Institute who researches substandard and counterfeit medicines
column5: told TheDCNF.

column1: Thakur told TheDCNF that many of the company’s anti-retroviral drugs were used to stabilize platelet and white blood cell counts in AIDS patients.
“These drugs allow it to stabilize and essentially provide immunity to patients. If the content of the medicine is not what is listed on the label
column2: you will not see the platelet levels or the WBC levels stabilize
column3: ” he said.

column1: Ranbaxy’s first public hint of problems occurred in August 2004
column2: one year after CHAI began working with the firm. The World Health Organization reported irregularities involving three Ranbaxy drugs in South Africa
column3: according to the report.

column1: The FDA sent a public “warning letter” to Ranbaxy in 2006 about reported irregularities in the company’s quality control efforts. It concluded that the drugs
column2: which included anti-retroviral HIV/AIDs medications
column3: “show much lower potencies in these batches.”

column1: Although Ranbaxy’s generic drugs are now barred from being sold in the U.S.
column2: CHAI and the former president continue to praise Ranbaxy and distribute the company’s HIV/AID drugs to patients abroad.

column1: Bill heaped praise on Ranbaxy in 2013 during a speech in Mumbai
column2: saying
column3: the drugs saved millions of lives.

column1: Neither CHAI nor the Clinton Foundation have announced they severed ties with Ranbaxy.
Thakur said he’s now a public health activist who tries to get global health charities to focus on the quality of drugs rather than simply on “access” to patients.
The whistleblower tried to meet with CHAI and Clinton Foundation officials
column2: but was only met with silence. “I have tried to reach out to them
column3: ” he told TheDCNF. “But I haven’t had a great amount of success with the Clinton Foundation.”

column1: CHAI was a part of the Clinton Foundation until 2010
column2: when it spun off into a separate entity. The groups still have some overlapping board members and staff
column3: and they continue to operate in close coordination. Bill Clinton
column4: for example
column5: is deeply involved with both organizations.

column1: Charles Ortel
column2: a Wall Street analyst who has been an outspoken critic of the legal missteps by the Clinton Foundation
column3: claims their separation was “deeply suspect.”

column1: “In the application
column2: trustees of the new entity
column3: including Bill Clinton
column4: falsely claim the entity is not a successor to previous efforts. This is not true. They purposefully obscure the fact that a similar operation called ‘CHAI’ was by far the largest piece of the original Foundation
column5: ” Ortel told TheDCNF.

column1: The congressional study suggests Bill may have relaxed quality standards in a 2000 executive order.
He signed an executive order that
column2: “relaxed intellectual property policy standards
column3: ” promising the U.S. government “would not revoke or revise the intellectual property laws of any ‘Sub-Saharan country’ relating to HIV/AIDS medicines or technologies
column4: ” the report states.

column1: CHAI announced in October 2003 it was going to distribute generic
column2: low-cost HIV drugs from four foreign drug manufacturers: Ranbaxy; Cipla of Mumbai
column3: India; Matrix Labs of Hydrabad
column4: India; Aspen Pharmacare of Johannesburg
column5: South Africa.

column1: CHAI’s endorsement also allowed Ranbaxy to manufacture HIV drugs that would be bought by the U.S. government under the President’s Emergency Plan for AIDS relief — a $15 billion initiative proposed by former President George W. Bush.
The flow of U.S. funds combined with Clinton’s endorsement allowed the four foreign drug manufactures to become “good acquisition targets
column2: ” according to the study.

column1: Ranbaxy filed 10 abbreviated new drug applications
column2: three of which were approved by the FDA
column3: according to the congressional study. Eventually
column4: the firm would produce 13 generic HIV drugs.

column1: The companies enjoyed great financial profits and they “exploded as they partnered with the Foundation for several years
column2: ” the report states.

column1: The study also examined the key players in the Clinton-CHAI orbit
column2: the potential for corruption and how the program ultimately benefited the Clinton Foundation in terms of donor contributions.

column1: One relationship unearthed by the report was the American Indian Foundation
column2: which Clinton co-founded with Indian-American businessmen Rajat Gupta and Vinod Gupta in 2001.

column1: Rajat was convicted of insider trading in 2012 in a sensational trial.

Vinod eventually was forced to resign as CEO and chairman of the company InfoGroup and was fined $9 million in a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation. One of the charges stated Vinod had awarded Bill $3.3 million without board approval.
Blackburn says the worst part of the story were the “false hopes” offered by the Clinton Foundation.
“You think about the emotional state of health care workers as they are dealing with these individuals and the emotional state of the patients. To me it’s disturbing and very sad
column2: ” she said.

column1: 308	"Someone had to say it. Okay
column2: liberals have been saying it for years. Fox News (and increasingly
column3: the other news channels) have been promoting fear for so long that they have become the terrorists. Pope Francis agrees. Channeling Franklin Delano Roosevelt’s infamous line
column4: “we have nothing to fear but fear itself
column5: ” the Pope chastised fear-based media.

312	"I woke up this morning to find a variation of this headline splashed all over my news feed:
Bill Clinton: ‘Natural’ For Foundation Donors to Seek Favors
Here’s Google:
Naturally
column2: my reaction was “oh
column3: s**t
column4: what did Bill Clinton do to damage his wife’s campaign now?”

column1: Of course
column2: the headline sounds really
column3: really awful. It plays right into the idea that the Clinton Foundation is all about pay to play
column4: just like Donald Trump has been saying all along. Unfortunately
column5: it takes reading beyond the headlines
column6: which is something most people don’t do
column7: to find out the real story – and the real story is that there is no pay to play.

column1: “It was natural for people who’ve been our political allies and personal friends to call and ask for things. And I trusted the State Department wouldn’t do anything they shouldn’t do
column2: ” Clinton told NPR in an interview that aired Monday morning. Source: CNN

column1: In other words
column2: people can ask for favors
column3: but that certainly doesn’t mean they’ll get them. Leaked emails have shown that some Clinton Foundation donors have gotten meetings with Clinton and that others were turned down. There is zero evidence of pay to play. In other words
column4: people might have asked for favors
column5: but there’s no evidence they got them.

column1: Now
column2: let’s talk about the foundation the media doesn’t like to mention
column3: the Trump Foundation. Trump hasn’t given to his own foundation since 2008. He does collect money from others
column4: though
column5: and gives it in his name. He also takes from the charity and allegedly buys things like oil paintings and football helmets
column6: all for himself
column7: but out of charity money.

column1: New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman said in a September 13 CNN interview that his office is investigating Trump’s charitable foundation over concerns that it “engaged in some impropriety” as related to New York charity laws. The investigation launched amid reports from The Washington Post that Trump spent money from his charity on items meant to benefit himself
column2: such as a $20
column3: 000 oil painting of himself and a $12
column4: 000 autographed football helmet
column5: and also recycled others’ contributions “to make them appear to have come from him” although he “hasn’t given to the foundation since 2008.” Source: Media Matters

column1: Media Matters goes on to talk about the double standard and about how clearly the mainstream media is trying to promote Trump at the cost of Clinton’s candidacy:
Journalists have been criticized for the “double standard” in the ways they cover Trump and Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton. Earlier this month
column2: cable news programs devoted 13 times more coverage to Clinton’s pneumonia diagnosis as The Washington Post’s reporting about the Trump Foundation. This week
column3: both the Trump Foundation and Trump Organization stories were given short shrift by the broadcast news programs in favor of coverage of Donald Trump’s Dr. Oz stunt.

column1: All of this biased coverage is hurting Clinton and helping Trump. Trump has seen major gains over the last few weeks
column2: largely because the media covers every minor Clinton “scandal” (if you call getting sick a “scandal”) while ignoring every scandal in Trump’s closet
column3: and trust me
column4: there are a lot.

313	"7k SHARES SHARE THIS STORY
Last night
column2: the city of Charlotte was rocked with protests for a second straight night as massive crowds protested the police killing of Kenneth L. Scott. During the protests
column3: a civilian was shot in the head and critically injured. The police quickly told the media that the shooter was also a civilian
column4: but a number of eyewitness reports seem to indicate that the police are lying – and that the shot came from law enforcement.

column1: One key eye witness report emerged from Charlotte on Twitter
column2: along with a graphic photo of the bloody aftermath and a haunting statement from Todd Zimmer
column3: who claims to have assisted in the emergency response: “I didn’t want to post about this
column4: but my city is lying about what happened tonight. Let the record show.”

column1: My friend @neutralized was on the ground in Charlotte. He saw the shooting. Here's his account. pic.twitter.com/H5cQXrAn37 — Max Berger (@maxberger) September 22
We interviewed Kahran Meyer
column2: who is a North Carolina criminal defense lawyer and a key eye witness on the scene. The 29-year-old published this tweet just an hour after witnessing the shots and noticing that the weapons discharge did not sound like a typical firearm:

column1: I watched a man die tonight with my own two eyes. It was NOT by a civilian. I don't care WHAT CNN tells you. I was right fucking there. — BLACK MATLOCK (@KahranAtLaw) September 22
“I didn’t realize that I was standing next to someone from CNN at the time. It started when everybody met at the park and marched from there down a couple of city blocks
column2: when somebody said let’s march to the police station. It was peaceful
column3: people had signs that said “Hands Up
column4: Don’t Shoot
column5: ” Kahran Meyers told me at 1:50am tonight.

column1: “The protest then marched to College Street and Trade Street in front of the Omni Hotel. At that time
column2: police were not at all directing traffic
column3: just keeping the peace
column4: ” Meyer told me almost breathlessly
column5: “I’ve been told that the idea was to walk into the Omni and hold our hands up [in protest] and chant ‘hands up
column6: don’t shoot’ and there was a crowd of roughly 1
column7: 000 people. We wanted to demonstrate to the upper class
column8: the bourgeoisie that there is a problem.”

column1: “After leaving ‘The Epicenter
column2: ’ police made a human barrier to block a return to the main square
column3: so the crowd was facing the hotel. At that point
column4: all of the protests were completely peaceful – and that’s when the riot police arrived. I swear to god
column5: you could feel the temperature go up by 10 degrees.”

column1: Meyers had a brief interaction with one of the riot officers at that point
column2: and asked them whose idea it was to send out police in heavy armor. The Charlotte officer coyly nodded his head upward as if to indicate brass. Meyers told him that it was an unnecessary escalation and he replied
column3: “oh
column4: absolutely.”

column1: Five minutes later
column2: a protester lay near death in a pool of blood in the street.

column1: “It wasn’t a gunshot
column2: ” she told us. “It was much louder. It wasn’t a civilian injury. The way people scattered. No way. At least a dozen people exclaimed loudly ‘They just shot him’ and people in the crowd were familiar with him [the protester shot by police]. At that point
column3: the peaceful protesters who hadn’t already left
column4: exited.”

column1: At that moment
column2: Meyers says that Charlotte-Mecklenberg police then read the riot act to the protesters. As she made it to the next block
column3: police opened up with teargas from two directions into the already retreating crowd of peaceful protesters.

column1: It took Meyers fifteen minutes to leave the scene
column2: and as she was departing she spotted a news crew reviewing live video
column3: it was a split-screen. According to Meyer
column4: that videographer was from CNN and had been standing next to the lawyer
column5: and when reunited said it was ‘entirely too loud for a gunshot too. It was so loud it shook my tripod and all of my equipment.’

column1: CNN reports
column2: “Police say the person was shot by a civilian.”

column1: The City of Charlotte began spinning the protester’s grave injuries immediately on Twitter:
ALERT: Fatal shot uptown was civilian on civilian. @CMPD did not fire shot. — City of Charlotte (@CLTgov) September 22

Two additional eye witness reports have emerged on Twitter refute the Charlotte police’s claim that a civilian shot and severely injured a protester. The first is from the Charlotte Clergy Coalition for Justice
column2: who issued a press release of sorts through a widely followed Palestinian rights activist.

column1: “I saw the man go down on the pavement
column2: ” said Minister Steve Knight of Missiongathering Christian Church in Charlotte whose written statement points the finger squarely at Charlotte-Meckenberg Police for the shooting
column3: “It was an ambush. The victim was shot while he stood between two ministers
column4: and we believe he was shot by police.”

column1: #Charlotte Clergy question media & police accounts of tonight's shooting of protester. #CharlotteProtest #KeithLamontScott pic.twitter.com/TlVOwveYAV — Linda Sarsour (@lsarsour) September 22
Lastly
column2: a man named Eddie Thomas posted on Facebook – which was also shared via twitter – that
column3: “within 5 mins (no exaggeration a dude lay bleeding on the ground
column4: eye rolling in the bakc of his head. he got shot with something
column5: maybe a rubber bullet. I yelled at the bike cops for help and they did nothing.”

column1: When African-Americans attempt to express their frustration and anger and the violence inflicted upon them by the state
column2: the state responds the only way it knows how – with more violence.

column1: Original story by Grant Stern at PINAC News: “WITNESS: Charlotte Riot Police Did Shoot Protester
column2: Deny Involvement Blaming Civilians“
