column2: the moderator for the first presidential debate between Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton
column3: will not be fact checking the candidates. This
column4: of course
column5: will allow Trump to say anything he pleases without being held accountable – except by Hillary Clinton.

column1: But to make matters worse
column2: all cable news networks (including those critical of Trump) are pledging to be completely spineless
column3: and will not offer any on-screen fact checks to any comments made by the candidates that are wrong:

column1: While on-screen fact-checking could help expose inaccurate or misleading assertions without interrupting the flow of the debate
column2: nearly all of the major cable or broadcast networks
column3: including Univision and Telemundo
column4: said that they would not use any sort on screen fact check or graphics …. Thus
column5: the burden of keeping the candidates honest will likely come down to Holt
column6: the only other person on the stage.

column1: After Politico documented that Trump lies on average every three-and-a-half minutes
column2: one would think a fact checking process would be paramount to an honest
column3: open debate on the issues. But sadly
column4: the media
column5: realizing their ratings are on the line
column6: would rather kowtow to Donald Trump and his band of deplorable surrogates.

column1: The Clinton campaign has been forceful in its effort to hold Trump accountable
column2: with Clinton Campaign Communications Director Jennifer Palmieri telling reporters:

column1: For the moderator to let lies like that that come out of his mouth at this debate to go unchallenged would give Donald Trump an unfair advantage. We do believe it is the role of the moderator … to call out those lies and to do that in real time.
Unfortunately
column2: with Trump’s impending lies already on the brink of not being checked for falsehoods
column3: it’s somehow up to Hillary Clinton to “shine” at the debate if she hopes to “win.” This double standard that the most qualified woman to every run for office has to go above and beyond that most unqualified nominee in history
column4: just to look slightly better than him
column5: is abhorrent.

column1: Hopefully

column3: if not already dead.

One of former President Bill Clinton’s oldest friends has come forward and said what she believed was wrong with Democrat presidential nominee Hillary Clinton
column2: and if she’s right

column1: Dolly Kyle
column2: author of “Hillary the Other Woman
column3: ” said Clinton has been “’cruisin’ for a bruisin’
column4: ” because she’s so angry and driven by rage. “People like that eventually break down
column5: physically.”

column1: “Hillary Clinton is not physically fit to be president
column2: ” Kyle told WND. “Anyone who believes that she is has their eyes closed. If she was in a wheelchair or blind or something like that
column3: she could still do the job. But she is losing her mental capabilities
column4: she’s suffering from real cognitive impairment.”

column1: Advertisement - story continues below

column2: an award-winning lawyer
column3: also said Clinton is showing evidence of emotional instability
column4: memory loss and difficulty carrying out tasks.

“That paranoia
column2: that tendency to be a control freak
column3: has always been a part of her personality
column4: ” Kyle said
column5: and it’s simply not a good combination for anyone — much less the president of the United States.

column1: Advertisement - story continues below

Clinton is addicted to power

column3: according to Kyle.

column1: “She has been running for president ever since she took hold of Billy Clinton’s coattails so many decades ago in 1971

column1: Topics for first presidential debate announced
Lester Holt
column2: ""NBC Nightly News"" anchor and moderator of the first presidential debate scheduled for next Monday announced the topics that will serve as a jumping off point for his questions.

column1: The topics include ""America's Direction
column2: ""Achieving Prosperity"" and ""Securing America."" The announcement came with a caveat that the topics could change due to news developments.

column1: The debate
column2: which will be held at Hofstra University on Long Island
column3: New York
column4: will feature six 15-minute segments over a 90 minute period with no commercial breaks. Two of the 15-minute segments will focus on each of the announced topics.

column1: Hadas Gold is a reporter at Politico.

333	"Getty Images Fourth Estate In Defense of ‘He Said/She Said’ Journalism Why we must give the devil his due.

The “he said/she said” method of reporting—in which journalists observe the profession’s convention and get at least two sides of every story—has been taking it on the chin ever since New York University journalism professor Jay Rosen placed it in his gunsights in 2009 and started ack-acking it with regularity.
But the ""he said/she said"" debate didn’t move from the margins to the mainstream until last week when the New York Times abandoned mechanical balance and published a Page One
column2: above-the-fold piece by Michael Barbaro
column3: shredding Donald Trump as a pitiful serial liar and obfuscator for his latest “birther” declaration. The Times piece elated critics of the ""he said/she"" said construct. In an Atlantic piece titled “The Death of ‘He Said
column4: She Said’ Journalism
column5: ” Peter Beinart pronounced Barbaro’s work a journalistic sea change. Trump had broken all the rules of political conduct
column6: Beinart stated
column7: and the Times had rightly ditched a few of its own. Abandoning the usual journalistic etiquette
column8: which calls for mendacious politicians to be described as committing a falsehood when what they’re actually doing is lying
column9: the Times piece dealt with Trump with “astonishing bluntness
column10: ” Beinart wrote
column11: repeatedly calling Trump’s birther nonsense a “lie.” Trump was given no opportunity in the piece to deny the charges
column12: which sits just fine with the ""he said/she said"" critics.

column1: Story Continued Below
While I consider Trump to be a first-rate liar and don’t mind saying so
column2: I’m not convinced that jettisoning the ""he said/she said"" blueprint is such a good idea. Every politician lies. If we were to police all politicians in the news pages the way Barbaro did Trump
column3: it would be entertaining. But political journalism as we know it could expire as profiles and news stories collapsed into spreadsheets grading the truth value of political utterances. Isn’t that what the fact-checker columns are for?

column1: In his widely applauded critiques of ""he said/she said"" journalism
column2: Rosen holds that by reflexively seeking the “other side” of every public dispute and shying away from expressing the truth
column3: the media creates a bogus symmetry between the “he said” voices in a story and the prevaricators serving up the “she said” dissent. “Do users really want to be left helpless in sorting out who’s faking it more?” Rosen asked
column4: proposing that journalists put a higher premium on seeking truth and avoiding distortion. The ""he said/she said"" structure constitutes “one of the lowest forms of journalism in existence
column5: ” he would later remark.

column1: Donald Trump
column2: the thinking goes
column3: has gamed the ""he said/she said"" convention to contaminate the political debate with his lies
column4: obfuscations and double-talk whenever the press seeks comment on an issue
column5: a clarification of something he’s said
column6: or a response to a point raised by his opponent
column7: Hillary Clinton. This is true. In speeches and interviews
column8: he’s expressed a broadband stream of lies
column9: such as denying that he’s used terms like “fat pig” to describe women
column10: insisting that he never called George W. Bush a liar
column11: claiming that he opposed the Iraq War
column12: making fallacious boasts about his acts of philanthropy
column13: asserting that the NFL had contacted him about the debate schedule
column15: much more. But they are lies
column16: all lies. And every time the media quotes one of Trump’s “she said” lies without a correcting fact-check
column17: it undermines the truth of the “he said” side of the debate. At least

column1: But has journalists' practice of giving Trump the right of reply
column2: allowing him to pearl his lies with another coating of deceit really been such a disaster? One result of the straight
column3: ""he said/she said"" coverage of the Trump style has been his record lows in the Washington Post/ABC News favorability poll. Thanks to this coverage
column4: many voters are able to see through Trump’s “post-truth” style of politics and don’t need the news pages directly calling him a lying liar who lies every time he speaks. Among his supporters
column5: many don’t care that he mangles the facts and others take secret glee in the trickster’s campaign he’s waging for the presidency: He’s serving baloney and his supporters can’t get enough of it.

column1: As bracing and as full of truth-telling as the Barbaro piece was
column2: I hope it doesn’t embolden other news pages to abandon convention. The formula
column3: when properly executed
column4: forces reporters to perform due diligence in their articles. The form is even more useful for skeptical “show me” readers
column5: who want those extra bits of evidence to help them make up their mind about a candidate or an issue. This
column6: I realize
column7: can be especially challenging with Trump because the Mouth of Manhattan has made a career of taking both sides on nearly everything. He is the hermaphrodite of opinion makers—both ""he said and she said""—and
column8: like any good circus freak
column9: that makes him too exceptional to build rules from.

column1: One reason I admire ""he said/she said"" journalism is that I often find myself sympathizing with the ""she-said"" side of the equation
column2: and its presence assures me that the reporter is conducting something approximating an open inquiry. Whenever the ""she-said"" component of a story goes missing
column3: leaving only the dominant position expressed
column4: I get the feeling I’m being fed bunk. Even the Holy Bible gives Satan a forum for his dastardly views. So why not news stories?

column1: I don’t believe a story must balance out like a chemistry equation until both sides (or multiple sides) hover in the ether in perfect equilibrium. But intellectual history informs us that the dominant positions in any field—ruling paradigms
column2: if you don’t mind the language—have a tendency to erode over time when exposed to minority critiques. In order for thought to progress
column3: the minority report—however seemingly misguided—must be heard.

column1: The history of science is pockmarked with paradigms that were blown away by she-saiders. Early in the last century
column2: for example
column3: the scientific and cultural elites espoused the misguided philosophy of eugenics
column4: which held that feeblemindedness was directly inheritable and that forced sterilization
column5: institutionalization or lobotomization for these lessers was right and just. To oppose eugenics was to place yourself outside the established consensus
column6: to define yourself as a crackpot
column7: to be reduced to a ""she-said"" if you were lucky enough to get quoted in a news story. Today
column8: we think of the eugenicists as troglodytes.

column1: Or consider the story of Alfred Wegener. He 1912
column2: he proposed his plate tectonic theory much to the derision of the scientific establishment who laughed at the idea of continental drift. Not until the 1960s did his ideas gain proper respect
column3: and his critics take his place as geology’s crackpots. Or take the example of Australian doctor Barry Marshall
column4: who conjectured in the early 1980s that bacteria and not stress was the cause of ulcers
column5: a condition that afflicted up to 10 percent of all adults. Even after Marshall induced an ulcer in his own stomach by drinking a potion containing Helicobacter pylori he was still derided and marginalized by the establishment. “You think
column6: ‘It’s science; it’s got to be accepted
column7: ’” Marshall told Discover magazine. “But it’s not an absolute given.” By the mid-1990s
column8: the idea finally took root
column9: undermining the business model of thousands of gastroenterologists who treated and retreated the affliction with ineffective drugs and surgery. In 2005
column10: Marshall and a colleague were awarded the Nobel Prize in medicine for their Helicobacter pylori work. Science abounds with equally dramatic stories.

column1: Obviously
column2: the critiques of every she-saider don’t automatically end in the triumphs Wegener and Marshall enjoyed. But when you catalog the ruling paradigms in science and technology that have been toppled in recent years
column3: the toppler was almost always marginalized in the early going. Fracking has all but destroyed the peak oil hypothesis. The “one-size
column4: fits all” advice on mammograms has been abandoned. Our views on saturated fat
column5: once almost holy writ
column6: have been chucked. Until 1973
column7: the American Psychiatric Association classified homosexuality as a mental disorder. (All is not progress: Some now argue that “homophobia” is an indicator of a disorder.) Marijuana makes you mad. (Today
column8: the equally suspicious paradigm is that marijuana is good for whatever ails you.) Coffee
column9: once thought to be bad for you
column10: turns out to be good for you
column11: at least for now. Moving over to the policy realm
column12: the once dominant “super-predator” thesis was once supported across partisan lines. It is now discredited. Remember how Japan’s economy was supposed to overtake the United States’? Remember how Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan said the U.S. economic system was stable? Experts predicted wild inflation after quantitative easing. Others posited that housing prices would never decline nationwide. And so on.

column1: The dissents of the she-saiders are generally beneficial. Whether right or wrong
column2: the dissenters have a way of increasing everybody’s knowledge. If they are wrong
column3: as Michael Shermer has written
column4: their untruths force the dominant paradigm to self-examine
column5: and if warranted
column6: use new evidence to improve its position. If the she-saiders are right
column7: they advance human thought. That’s how science works
column8: and I believe journalism should work that way
column9: too. Vaccine pioneer Jonas Salk summarized the predictable moves of the knee-jerk paradigm-defenders with this progression. “First
column10: ” Salk writes
column11: they say “that it can’t be true.” Second phase: “Well
column12: if it’s true
column13: it’s not very important.” Third phase: “Well

column1: Before anybody puts words in my mouth
column2: this is not my long-winded way of saying I don’t subscribe to the global warming hypothesis. I do—but at the same time
column3: I keep my options open. The protectors of the ruling paradigm have an intellectual responsibility to mount disciplined defense against all comers. Even against crackpots.

column1: The last and best reason for supporting “he said/she said” journalism: So many readers and viewers have self-segregated by limiting their news consumption to outlets that reflect their personal views. These days
column2: many readers get only the ""he said"" side of the story or just the ""she said"" side
column3: remaining deliberately oblivious to the vibrant debate that might actually be going on. While I value partisan media
column4: I also value nonpartisan news operations—like POLITICO—that make ideas duel in their news pages. NPR News Director Michael Oreskes puts this practical spin on why his organization shies away from calling liars liars: “[I]f you present the facts calmly and without a tone of editorializing
column5: you substantially increase the chance that people will hear you out and weigh the facts. That is why the tone of journalism matters so much. We need potential listeners and readers to believe we are presenting the facts honestly
column6: and not to confirm our opinions.”

column1: If you’re not getting a steady diet of ""she said"" quotations in your news consumption
column2: you’re at risk of starving to death. ""He said/she said"" keeps journalists honest
column3: even if
column4: on occasion
column5: it looks like it’s only accruing to the benefit of a beast like Donald Trump.

column1: A sumptuous meal of news
column2: news
column3: news. Make mine extra rare
column4: garcon. Send news recipes via email to Shafer.Politico@gmail.com. My email alerts are breakfast. My Twitter feed is lunch. And my RSS feed is a stingy snack.

334	"Donald Trump was in Pittsburgh
column2: Pennsylvania Thursday for a campaign speech. He took time to address the unrest around the country in the wake of recent officer-involved shootings. Here’s what he said:

column1: “Before going any further today
column2: I want to address the turmoil unfolding right now in our country. And it seems to be a never-ending problem. America desperately needs unity
column3: and it needs the spirit of togetherness
column4: that has not only gotten us through our toughest times – because we’ve had some tough times – but which has lifted us up in the past to our greatest achievements as a nation.

column1: “Everyday I see people of different backgrounds working together for common good
column2: and we need to bring that spirit to every part of our country and become one American nation
column3: united by shared values and principles as American citizens. We have to do it. And we have to respect our flag. We have to respect our flag.

column1: “We all have to walk a mile in someone else’s shoes and see things through their eyes
column2: and then get to work fixing our very wounded country. We have some real problems. And we do have a wounded country.

column1: “Many Americans are watching the unrest in Charlotte unfolding right before their eyes on the TV screen. Others are witnessing the chaos and the violence firsthand. Our country looks bad to the world
column2: especially when we are supposed to be the world’s leader. How can we lead when we can’t even control our own cities?

column1: “We honor and recognize the right of all Americans to peacefully assemble
column2: protest
column3: and demonstrate. But there is no right to engage in violent disruption or to threaten the public safety and peace of others.

column1: “Every single American in our country is entitled to live in a safe community. The violence against our citizens and our law enforcement must be brought to a very rapid end.
“The people who will suffer the most as a result of these riots are law-abiding African-American residents who live in these communities where the crime is so rampant. It’s their jobs
column2: housing market
column3: schools
column4: economic conditions that will suffer. And the first duty of government is to protect their wellbeing and safety. We have to do that.

column1: “There is no compassion in tolerating lawless conduct. Crime and violence is an attack on the poor and will never be accepted in a Trump administration.
“Our job is not to make life more comfortable for the violent disrupter
column2: but to make life more comfortable for the African-American parent trying to raise their kids in peace
column3: to walk their children to school and get their children great educations. We have to cherish and protect those people.”

335	"On Saturday
column2: September 17 at 8:30 pm EST
column3: an explosion rocked West 23 Street in Manhattan
column4: in the neighborhood commonly referred to as Chelsea
column5: injuring 29 people
column6: smashing windows and initiating street closures. There were no fatalities. Officials maintain that a homemade bomb
column7: which had been placed in a dumpster
column8: created the explosion. The explosive device was removed by the police at 2:25 am and was sent to a lab in Quantico
column9: Virginia for analysis. A second device
column10: which has been described as a “pressure cooker” device similar to the device used for the Boston Marathon bombing in 2013
column11: was found on West 27th Street between the Avenues of the Americas and Seventh Avenue. By Sunday morning
column12: all 29 people had been released from the hospital. The Chelsea incident came on the heels of an incident Saturday morning in Seaside Heights
column13: New Jersey where a bomb exploded in a trash can along a route where thousands of runners were present to run a 5K Marine Corps charity race. There were no casualties. By Sunday afternoon
column14: law enforcement had learned that the NY and NJ explosives were traced to the same person.

column1: Given that we are now living in a world where acts of terrorism are increasingly more prevalent
column2: when a bomb goes off
column3: our first thought usually goes to the possibility of terrorism. After all
column4: in the last year alone
column5: we have had several significant incidents with a massive number of casualties and injuries in Paris
column6: San Bernardino California
column7: Orlando Florida and Nice
column8: to name a few. And of course
column9: last week we remembered the 15th anniversary of the September 11
column10: 2001 attacks where close to 3
column11: 000 people were killed at the hands of terrorists. However
column12: we also live in a world where political correctness is the order of the day and the fear of being labeled a racist supersedes our natural instincts towards self-preservation which
column13: of course
column14: includes identifying the evil-doers. Isn’t that how crimes are solved? Law enforcement tries to identify and locate the perpetrators of the crime or the “bad guys.” Unfortunately
column15: our leadership – who ostensibly wants to protect us – finds their hands and their tongues tied. They are not allowed to be specific about their potential hypotheses for fear of offending anyone.

column1: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio – who famously ended “stop-and-frisk” profiling in his city – was extremely cautious when making his first remarks following the Chelsea neighborhood explosion. “There is no specific and credible threat to New York City from any terror organization
column2: ” de Blasio said late Saturday at the news conference. “We believe at this point in this time this was an intentional act. I want to assure all New Yorkers that the NYPD and … agencies are at full alert”
column3: he said. Isn’t “an intentional act” terrorism? We may not know whether it is from an international terrorist group such as ISIS
column4: or a homegrown terrorist organization or a deranged individual or group of individuals. It is still terrorism. It is not an accident. James O’Neill
column5: the New York City Police Commissioner had already ruled out the possibility that the explosion was caused by a natural gas leak at the time the Mayor made his comments. New York’s Governor Andrew Cuomo was a little more direct than de Blasio saying that there was no evidence of international terrorism and that no specific groups had claimed responsibility. However
column6: he did say that it is a question of how the word “terrorism” is defined. “A bomb exploding in New York is obviously an act of terrorism.” Cuomo hit the nail on the head
column7: but why did need to clarify and caveat before making his “obvious” assessment?

column1: The two candidates for president Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump also weighed in on the Chelsea explosion. Clinton was very generic in her response saying that “we need to do everything we can to support our first responders – also to pray for the victims” and that “we need to let this investigation unfold.” Trump was more direct. “I must tell you that just before I got off the plane a bomb went off in New York and nobody knows what’s going on
column2: ” he said. “But boy we are living in a time—we better get very tough folks. We better get very
column3: very tough. It’s a terrible thing that’s going on in our world
column4: in our country and we are going to get tough and smart and vigilant.”

column1: Unfortunately
column2: an incident like the Chelsea explosion reminds us how vulnerable our country is particularly in venues defined as “soft targets.” Now more than ever
column3: America needs strong leadership which is laser-focused on protecting her citizens from terrorist attacks of all genres and is not afraid of being politically incorrect.

336	"“He didn’t say the document was legitimate
column2: Joe Arpaio said of Donald Trump's recent announcement. | Getty Joe Arpaio: Trump didn’t call Obama’s birth certificate ‘legitimate’

column1: Donald Trump finally acknowledged President Barack Obama’s American birthplace last week
column2: but one of his supporters
column3: controversial Arizona Sheriff Joe Arpaio
column4: sees a silver lining for the ""birther"" movement: Trump didn't take a position on whether Obama’s birth certificate was forged.

column1: “If he says the president was born here
column2: maybe he has information I don’t have
column3: ” Arpaio told POLITICO of the GOP nominee's statement. “He didn’t say the document was legitimate. He didn’t go that route.”

column1: Story Continued Below
Of Trump’s statement on Obama’s birthplace
column2: Arpaio added: “It didn’t bother me.”

column1: Arpaio
column2: a prominent Trump supporter known for his hard-line views on immigration
column3: opened an investigation into the legitimacy of Obama’s birth certificate in August 2011
column4: several months after the White House published it online
column5: further demonstrating that he was
column6: in fact
column7: born in Hawaii.

column1: Trump rose to political prominence in part through insinuating
column2: falsely
column3: that Obama was not born in the United States — a claim the president’s supporters have long decried as racist. He backed down from it under pressure last week
column4: in a short statement at an otherwise drawn-out press conference at his new luxury hotel in Washington. Trump also attempted to blame his opponent
column5: Hillary Clinton
column6: for starting the rumor
column7: another claim independent fact checkers have debunked.

column1: But while Trump has sought to sidestep the birther issue
column2: Arpaio has refused to back down from his own claim that Obama’s birth certificate was forged. On Tuesday in Phoenix
column3: Arpaio addressed the conservative group that requested he investigate the document
column4: saying that “we are looking at a forged document. Period.”

column1: On Wednesday
column2: Arpaio told POLITICO the investigation into the document is ongoing. He declined to detail what evidence that effort has turned up
column3: but he claimed that his office has found nothing “to say it’s a legitimate document.”

column1: Arpaio also tried to separate himself from the birther movement
column2: arguing that his investigation is focused on the document itself
column3: rather than the president’s birthplace
column4: and denied that his skepticism is motivated by racism.

column1: Still
column2: he would not say that he believes Obama was born in the U.S.

column1: “I have no idea now where he was born
column2: ” Arpaio said. “You hear a lot of stories.”

column1: He and Trump did not discuss the birth certificate issue before the nominee held the press conference last week
column2: Arpaio said.

column1: “I didn’t know he was going to say it
column2: ” he said.

337	"Peaceful protesters crowded Charlotte's first city council meeting since the cop shooting of Keith Lamont Scott
column2: with over 50 people speaking out against police violence.

column1: But none of them stood out Monday quite as much as a young girl.
Zianna Oliphant
column2: her hair done up in braids and tears streaking her face
column3: brought into focus the stress police shootings place on children
column4: as well as the pain the black community of Charlotte has suffered in the wake of Scott's death last week.

column1: “I’ve been born and raised in Charlotte. And I never felt this way until now and I can’t stand how we’re treated
column2: ” the grade-school girl said
column3: wiping away tears.

column1: David T. Foster III/The Charlotte Observer via AP Photo
She expressed the hardship that children face when a parent dies. Scott himself
column2: who was African-American
column3: had seven children.

column1: “It’s a shame that we have to go to their graveyard and bury them. And we have tears. We shouldn’t have tears. We need our fathers and mothers to be by our side
column2: ” she said.

column1: Zianna
column2: as well as the protesters in the room who chanted ""no justice
column3: no peace"" after she spoke
column4: helped to underscore the degree to which communal wounds have been slow to heal in North Carolina’s most populous city since the shooting.

column1: Protests started on the streets of Charlotte after news of Scott's shooting broke last Tuesday and
column2: occasionally
column3: became violent as they continued deeper into the week.

column1: David T. Foster III/The Charlotte Observer via AP Photo

The scene grew especially tense Wednesday night when police clad in riot gear fired tear gas and rubber bullets at demonstrators. Some people in the crowds threw bottles and rocks at officers and passing cars
column2: blocked an interstate highway
column3: surrounded and jumped on vehicles
column4: looted businesses and stormed the entrance of a Hyatt hotel
column5: injuring two of its employees.

column1: At the city council meeting
column2: Charlotte Mayor Jennifer Roberts called for decorum at several points during public remarks. At several points
column3: protesters yelled criticism of her and Police Chief Kerr Putney.

column1: After the meeting wrapped up
column2: The Charlotte Observer reported
column3: more than 20 protesters moved to the lobby of the Government Center.

column1: “Release. Release. The whole damn tape
column2: ” the protesters chanted
column3: according to the newspaper.

column1: David T. Foster III/The Charlotte Observer via AP Photo
Ray Dotch
column2: Scott's brother-in-law
column3: Monday called for the release of the entire video of his shooting in an interview with ABC News.

column1: Chief Putney has released body and dashboard camera videos of the fatal police shooting of Scott
column2: answering to demands made by community leaders
column3: protesters and politicians. But it is not entirely clear from those videos or from the one taken by Scott's wife
column4: Rakeiya Scott
column5: that the victim had a gun on his person
column6: as the police allege. column1: 338	"Last week I wrote an article titled “Donald Trump’s Amazing Week” which must have been incredibly annoying to liberals and “Never Trumpers” everywhere. Guess what? This past week has been even better for the 2016 Republican nominee for president
column2: the man whose candidacy was considered a vanity exercise a year and a half ago. Well no one is laughing anymore.

column1: The latest round of polls shows that the support for the Trump presidency is growing rapidly. The latest Fox News Poll
column2: which was taken from September 11-14
column3: shows Donald Trump polling at 46%
column4: a one-point lead over Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton at 45%. The LA Times/USC poll taken from September 9-15 shows Trump at 47% with a six-point lead over Clinton at 41%. The gap between the two candidates is also narrowing in the key battleground states. The Suffolk University Poll which was taken from September 12-14 shows Trump at 42%
column5: leading by 3 points with Clinton at 39%. The CNN/ORC poll
column6: which was taken September 7-12 shows Trump with a 4-point lead over Clinton in Florida. Clinton still has about a 3-5 point lead over Trump in other key battleground states
column7: including Pennsylvania and Michigan
column8: but those gaps are getting narrower every day. Other states such as Nevada and New Hampshire which were initially perceived to be likely wins for Clinton have moved to the “toss up state” category.

column1: Donald Trump also continued his efforts to layout his policy framework with the introduction of another signature platform
column2: his childcare plan at a speech in Aston PA
column3: just outside of Philadelphia. Spearheaded by his daughter Ivanka Trump
column4: Trump’s childcare policy offers something for everyone across the economic spectrum. The plan offers six weeks paid maternity leave to all mothers who do not receive this benefit through their employers. This benefit will be funded by closing gaps in our existing unemployment insurance program. Lower income families will also benefit from the plan’s offering of childcare rebates through the Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) program up to $1
column5: 200 per year. Middle class families will benefit from being able to fully deduct all childcare expense on their tax returns. Families will also have the ability to establish Dependent Care Savings Accounts (DCSAs) to put money aside tax free for childcare. Low income families will receive a 50% match of the first $1000 deposited per year
column6: generating up to an additional $500 per eligible family per year. DCSAs can be applied to pay for childcare
column7: after school enrichment programs and school choice. Families can also use the funds in a DCSA to care for an elderly parent’s expenses including in home nursing and long-term care. Finally
column8: Trump’s childcare plan provides a tax deduction for stay-at-home parents
column9: effectively eliminating the tax punishment for a parent’s decision to leave the workforce to be a full time caregiver for child or an elderly parent.

column1: Donald Trump followed his childcare policy speech with another economics speech to the Economic Club of New York which includes some of New York’s most powerful movers and shakers in the world of business and finance. Trump’s excellent week continued with his visit to the Dr. Oz Show where he released a letter from his long term doctor revealing the results of his most recent medical visit and other relevant pieces of his medical history. Other than carrying an extra 15-20 pounds
column2: Trump appears to be in excellent health. Of course
column3: Trump’s unveiling his medical records on a television show comes on the heels of the recent concerns about Hillary Clinton’s health following her fainting at last week’s September 11 memorial event and the subsequent revelation that she was suffering from pneumonia. Again
column4: only Donald Trump can turn the literal opening of an envelope into an event. Well
column5: it is an event alright particularly if that envelope is opened on The Dr. Oz Show
column6: a program which is reportedly watched by four million viewers daily with a large percentage of female viewers. During the one hour program
column7: the discussion of Trump’s health was followed by the appearance of Ivanka Trump who was able to deliver yet another pitch about the newly announced childcare proposal to the aforementioned audience of women. So yes
column8: somehow all this concern about Hillary Clinton’s health and capacity to serve as president has created multiple free publicity events for Donald Trump.

column1: Trump followed up the Dr. Oz interview with a visit to the Tonight Show with Jimmy Fallon. During the visit
column2: Trump permitted the late night comedian to do something “unpresidential”. That is to say
column3: he told Fallon that he could “mess up his hair”. While most pundits would speculate that the moment was completely pre-planned
column4: the fact that Trump said “yes” to the display speaks volumes. He demonstrated that he has the ability to laugh at himself and that he is not afraid to have a bad picture taken. Furthermore
column5: The Tonight Show is popular with Democrats and millennials of all political persuasions. Once again
column6: Trump had an opportunity to make a connection with millions of people who more than likely were not on the “Trump Train”. Oh and one more thing
column7: by letting Jimmy Fallon touch his hair on national television
column8: Trump has finally set to rest all rumors that his hair is not his. However small
column9: it’s another check mark in the honesty and transparency box.

column1: Now if all of this was not enough
column2: Donald Trump capped his week off with an opening event ceremony at his new hotel in the former post office site in Washington DC where he received endorsements from military flag officers and fourteen Medal of Honor recipients. Trump used the event to not only promote his hotel project as being completed “two years early and under budget”
column3: a metaphor for how he would manage the US economy
column4: he also seized the moment to put an end to the “birther issue”. Trump took the microphone and said “Not to mention her in the same breath
column5: ” (as the Medal of Honor recipients who had just endorsed him) “Hillary Clinton and her campaign of 2008 started the birther controversy. I finished it. I finished it
column6: ” he said. “President Barack Obama was born in the United States
column7: period. Now we all want to get back to making America strong and great again.” Trump said.

column1: Once again
column2: political correctness be damned
column3: Donald Trump has had another “amazing week.”

339	"Off Message Is Donald Trump qualified to be president? In the most pivotal moment of 2016
column2: these are the questions he must answer.

column1: H.L. Mencken declared there was only one way to look at a politician — “down.”
Likewise
column2: there’s really only one way to look at the first presidential debate on Monday: as the first serious job interview for potential President Donald John Trump — an opaque candidate who has hidden behind a steel curtain of one-liners
column3: faux familiarity and universal celebrity.

column1: Story Continued Below
Yeah
column2: yeah
column3: yeah
column4: it’s a big night for Hillary Clinton too. She’s got a lot to prove
column5: for real
column6: namely that she’s not the lying
column7: self-dealing crook many Americans think she is — or at least convince the 55 percent of voters who don’t like her that her virtues (temperament and experience) compensate for decades of assorted ick. She needs to prove she can stand up to Trump
column8: answer the usual email/foundation questions
column9: convince whoever’s still sellable on the idea (stop Instagramming a picture of your lunch
column10: millennials
column11: and listen up) that she’s not some scheming granny who will just sell everybody out the second John Roberts drops the swearing-in Bible.

column1: But the spotlight belongs on Trump
column2: who is in need of a rigorous job interview. Clinton deserves the same
column3: but she is already the single most scrutinized
column4: parsed
column5: vetted
column6: investigated
column7: attacked and plaudited non-incumbent to ever seek the presidency. She’s been around forever
column8: making enemies since the internet was dial-up
column9: cell phones were the size of skateboards and Trump was engaged to Marla Maples.

column1: Everyone makes the orange jokes
column2: but Trump is something of a black box — running on a few big and broad ideas (curbing illegal immigration
column3: ditching bad trade deals
column4: restoring American prosperity to the working class and obliterating political correctness). He’s bad with facts and the truth
column5: and perhaps worse
column6: takes perverse pride in being a D student who doesn’t read books
column7: has the sketchiest sense of history
column8: doesn’t read briefing materials
column9: and
column10: according to aides and ghostwriters
column11: can’t even sit still long enough to be given a thorough verbal briefing.

column1: These are not nasty
column2: biased
column3: liberal opinions. They are facts based on reporting and Trump’s own public performances. Here are five questions Trump needs to address on Monday — but taken together
column4: they add up to one big one: Is Donald Trump qualified to be President of the United States?

column1: 1. Does he actually know — or care to know — the basic information needed to competently run the country?
Only one verdict of presidential fitness counts
column2: of course
column3: and that’s a candidate’s capacity to get to 270 electoral votes. In recent days
column4: Trump — who swooned after Clinton’s superb convention in Philly — has closed to within the margin of error in many (though not all) national polls
column5: and jumped to serious leads in battlegrounds like Ohio and Iowa since Aug. 1. He’s still the most unpopular candidate in recent history (although Clinton is number two with a bullet) and seems to have a ceiling of between 40 and 44 percent nationally. But he can win. Fivethirtyeight.com
column6: the arch-aggregator
column7: gives Trump nearly a 50 percent chance of prevailing.

column1: His resurgence proves three political points — two of them we knew
column2: the third is a surprise to everyone except Trump and his team: The country (especially the white working-class parts) is pissed
column3: Clinton is a perennially lousy candidate and — lastly
column4: but not leastly — Trump has proven to be a resilient and flexible candidate with the capacity (developed late in the game) to shift shape and shut up when he needs to.

column1: The first debate should be a pivot — from politicking to president-ing. Being a cunning candidate isn’t remotely the same thing as being ready to rule — and we should be moving to the Doris Kearns Goodwin phase of the campaign
column2: where the top priority is fitness to govern in a time of trial. It probably won’t happen
column3: but a boy can dream.

column1: This is not to suggest that Trump can’t do the job (Ronald Reagan
column2: another entertainer who forayed into politics
column3: was mostly a success)
column4: but he’s been judged as a performer up to this point
column5: and not subjected to the cold fluorescent scrutiny of managerial competence.

column1: Trump has repeatedly flubbed tests of his basic understanding of domestic and foreign affairs — apparently he wasn’t aware Russia had annexed Crimea until George Stephanopoulos informed him recently. He obliterated Jeb Bush
column2: that humbled patsy of the GOP establishment
column3: in the debates — but Bush (if anyone had cared to listen) punctured Trump’s bully-boy promise to impose tariffs on Chinese products
column4: correctly pointing out that such a move would certainly spark countermeasures by Beijing that could lead to a global depression. Trump wasn’t aware of that fact
column5: or just didn’t care.

column1: The caring part is kind of important
column2: if history is any guide. In April
column3: I sat down with one of his longtime advisers
column4: Roger Stone
column5: who described what it was like to brief an executive whose prime attributes were supreme self-confidence and supreme impatience. “All you can do is present information and let him either assimilate it or not
column6: ” said Stone
column7: who has known the GOP nominee for decades. “When you write something for him
column8: keep it short and staccato. He's not going to read a 40-page white paper on the economy; zero chance of that. It's just too boring. Don't blame him; I don't like it either. So keep it simple and direct because that's the way he communicates.”

column1: Stone argued that Trump isn’t an ignoramus — just a cut-to-the-chase decision-maker who is a lightning-quick study. But George W. Bush’s advisers
column2: speaking to biographer Peter Baker
column3: said that Bush’s unwillingness to ask probing
column4: informed questions led to some of his disastrous decisions in Iraq. And during the nadir of the 2009 global economic meltdown
column5: President Obama added a daily economic briefing to his daily national security rundown to keep tabs on the rapidly shifting metrics of crisis.

column1: Trump’s capacity to intuitively assimilate information might render such processes useless — but there’s not a single presidential historian drawing oxygen who believes a lack of intellectual curiosity is an asset for the job.

Many Americans might not give a damn that he knows what HUD’s Section 8 program is — and his failure to answer informational questions that Clinton would parry with ease will endear him to his screw-the-media base. But don’t people have the right to know what he actually knows? Trump has gleefully trashed the rules of presidential campaigns
column2: so why should a moderator treat him with the deference of someone who abides by the norms — by assuming he possesses the basic knowledge traditionally required of a presidential candidate?

column1: 2. Does Trump understand and respect the basic principles and traditions of American Constitutional government?
Again
column2: this is not a given. Hillary Clinton despises the press
column3: and dodges them as if they were a pack of feral rats
column4: but she has never suggested they be stopped from doing their jobs through the courts. Trump (who banned news outlets
column5: including this one
column6: from his events for most of the campaign) routinely threatens litigation against publications that publish unflattering articles and
column7: in February
column8: went so far as to say: “We're going to open up those libel laws. So when The New York Times writes a hit piece which is a total disgrace … we can sue them and win money instead of having no chance of winning because they're totally protected.”

column1: That’s a new one for a presidential nominee. As Corey Brettschneider wrote in POLITICO Magazine last month: “For more than 50 years
column2: the Supreme Court has held that for a public figure to prove libel against a news outlet
column3: they must show that the outlet acted with ‘actual malice’ — that is
column4: with knowledge that it was false or with reckless disregard of whether it was false or not.”

column1: During a private meeting with Hill Republicans earlier this year
column2: the populist real estate developer expressed his fondness for “Article 12 of the Constitution.” The framers stopped at seven. “He was just listing out numbers
column3: ” said Congressman Blake Farenthold (R-Texas)
column4: a Trump backer at the time. “I think he was confusing Articles and Amendments.”

column1: OK
column2: let’s write that one off as a gotcha — you can understand Constitutional principles without citing literal chapter and verse. But consider his reaction to the Paris bombings last November when Trump told FOX News he thought the government should shutter some mosques where “some bad things are happening.” The comment was decried by Constitutional scholars of all stripes as a radical measure that would violate the “Free Exercise” clause of the First Amendment
column3: a pillar of protection for faiths of all kinds.

column1: 3. Why won’t Trump forthrightly answer the most basic questions about his businesses and debts?
Hillary Clinton has
column2: appropriately
column3: has come under intense scrutiny for her six-figure speeches to big Wall Street firms like Goldman Sachs — and has refused to release the transcripts of her prattles to the plutocrats. And serious questions remain about the lack of boundaries between the Clinton Foundation
column4: the State Department
column5: and big-money foreign donors who blurred the line between influence peddling and altruism.

column1: But the Clintons have released all of their tax returns (in part because
column2: for many years
column3: they were required to do so as government employees) and Trump is the first major presidential candidate in the modern era to thumb his nose at handing over a single one.

column1: Why does it matter? Because a guy whose purchase on the presidency is rooted in his private-sector acumen needs to back up his claims with proof
column2: in the same way that Clinton needs to be held accountable for her purported record of accomplishment in the White House
column3: Senate and State Department. At issue is Trump’s fundamental personal narrative
column4: and his claim that he’s “very
column5: very rich.” He is
column6: but maybe not quite as much as he claims (he says he’s good for $11 billion; Forbes and other outlets say he’s worth less than half that much).

column1: More serious is the issue of Trump’s debts: The Clinton campaign
column2: citing press reports that he owes large sums to overseas creditors in China and elsewhere
column3: has attacked him for being in the pocket of foreign financial overlords. If that’s a lie
column4: there’s an easy way to prove it — by releasing the returns.

column1: This isn’t a liberal media witch-hunt: Many Republicans
column2: including supporters like House Speaker Paul Ryan
column3: say he needs to cough them up
column4: and fast.

column1: 4. What’s the deal with his charitable foundation? Then there’s the matter of Trump’s sloppily run
column2: and less-than-magnanimous foundation. In exposé after exposé
column3: Washington Post reporter David Fahrenthold has reported on a pattern of over-promising donations and the misuse of funds (including a quarter-million payment to cover legal fees for Trump’s businesses and sports memorabilia) that Trump himself has conceded might be illegal.

column1: The problem
column2: yet again
column3: is that Trump has refused to release a comprehensive accounting of his giving
column4: and his surrogates have routinely misstated the magnitude of his generosity
column5: according to the reporting of Fahrenthold and others.

column1: 5. Why lie? These days
column2: the polygraph is used sparingly as part of the vetting process for employment
column3: mostly for sensitive national security or law enforcement jobs. If presidential candidates were subjected to that level of scrutiny
column4: the only person allowed on the debate stage at Hofstra would be the technician testing the sound system.

column1: But if Trump is to be vetted for the presidency
column2: he needs to be asked not only about individual statements he’s made in the past
column3: but his pattern of lying
column4: stretching the truth and bungling facts.

column1: Hillary Clinton (“Crooked Hillary” in Trump’s parlance) it bears repeating
column2: is no saint — far from it — and her early answers on the email scandal were misleading
column3: bordering on the untruthful
column4: and flat-out lies in the view of GOP congressional investigators.

column1: But it’s a crowning irony of 2016 that the Republican Party
column2: whose base revolted against its leadership for untruthfulness — especially George W. Bush’s claims about Iraq — would nominate the most brazenly truth-challenged candidate in recent history. (A recitation of Trump’s whoppers would take up too much space – read POLITICO’s comprehensive “Donald Trump’s Week of Misrepresentations
column3: Exaggerations and Half-Truths” for a taste.)

column1: In an attempt to defend Trump
column2: buddy Newt Gingrich
column3: who lobbied to be Trump’s running mate
column4: tweeted what amounted to an indirect admission that his man has a trouble with all those pesky facts. “Clinton
column5: ” the former speaker wrote
column6: “is a fox who knows many things you can fact check. Trump is a hedgehog who knows one big thing…”

column1: But getting the facts right — and telling the truth — is a big thing. It’s the only way citizens will ever look up to
column2: and not down on
column3: their leaders.

340	"I’ve watched every presidential debate ever broadcast
column2: including the little-remembered John F. Kennedy-Hubert Humphrey contest just before the 1960 West Virginia primary
column3: and for nearly 40 years I've analyzed how candidates win and lose them. But when I ask myself what kind of strategy I would devise for Hillary Clinton tonight against Donald Trump
column4: I’m pretty much baffled.

column1: The problem is not just the unpredictable (to put it mildly) nature of her opponent. (Will Trump be low-key and calm? Will he attack her honesty? Will he turn on Lester Holt after the first tough question and walk off the stage?) The problem is that almost all of Hillary Clinton’s strengths
column2: in this strange election year
column3: can so easily be turned into her weaknesses—especially her vast experience in government. The more she emphasizes her qualifications
column4: the more Trump is likely to respond with some version of: “You’ve been at the center of power for 25 years? Then you’re one of those who’s created the mess we’re in.” So reciting her work with foreign leaders
column5: for example
column6: and contrasting it with Trump's utter lack of grounding in the world
column7: doesn't seem to be promising.

column1: Story Continued Below
Indeed
column2: this debate offers Trump the chance to perform what I’ve called “political judo”—turning an opponent’s strength against her. (“Yes
column3: Mrs. Clinton
column4: your experience helped drag us into Iraq
column5: and turned Syria
column6: Libya
column7: the whole Middle East into a staging ground for ISIS. Maybe that’s why your husband's CIA director
column8: and Bobby Kennedy’s chief speechwriter
column9: are backing me.”)

column1: Further
column2: there's a sense—a highly limited sense—in which Trump is in something like the position Ronald Reagan was in back in 1980. Among college-educated whites
column3: who have resisted him so far
column4: his task is to use the debates to say
column5: “I'm a reasonable person who knows what's gone wrong and who has the instincts to fix it.” It's a second cousin of the 1980 situation where many voters did not want Carter
column6: but needed reassurance about Reagan
column7: which they got. (There is a limit to this analogy
column8: because for all of her difficulties
column9: Clinton is in a much stronger position than President Carter was).

column1: By contrast
column2: how does she try to gain strength on the issue of “honest and trustworthy”? If Trump can be convinced by his handlers—assuming they exist—to avoid overkill here
column3: all he has to do is to note what the FBI director or the New York Times editorial page has said. She can of course cite chapter and verse on Trump—bankruptcies
column4: Trump University
column5: David Farenthold's expose of his charities in the Washington Post—but those issues are ill-suited
column6: I think
column7: to a face-to-face debate. One of her problems
column8: longstanding
column9: is that the stuff of which campaign collapses are made have been leveled at Trump—and he's still standing.

column1: Does any of this mean that Clinton is facing doom Monday night? No. It does suggest that her campaign should remember what debates do and don’t do
column2: based on a half-century or so of history.

column1: The Focus Is on “Moments”—But They’re Not Always The Key
Ask any political journalist to recite the history of debates
column2: and it would go something like this:

column1: “Nixon looked pale and drawn; Ford prematurely liberated Poland from Soviet Control; Reagan said to Carter ‘there you go again
column2: ’ then asked Americans ‘are you better off?’ Four years later
column3: he was incoherent
column4: but then recovered by joking about Mondale’s ‘youth and inexperience.’ Dukakis was insufficiently emotional at the prospect of his wife’s rape and murder. Lloyd Bentsen told Dan Quayle was no Jack Kennedy. George H.W. Bush looked at his watch. Al Gore stalked George W. Bush
column5: who froze him with a nod.”

column1: These are the moments that are played over and over again in the run-up to debates. They illustrate the fact that these events are watched intensely for the quip
column2: the gaffe
column3: the thrust
column4: the parry that can sum up 90 minutes. It’s why debate prep spends an inordinate amount of time trying to come up with punchy
column5: memorable lines—“zingers”—to win the attention and admiration of the audience. (It’s also why the late political journalist Lars Erik-Nelson scornfully said of his colleagues
column6: “You’ve all become theater critics.”)

column1: But in fact
column2: this view of debates is not the whole story. Sometimes
column3: it’s the cumulative effect of the exchanges that can determine who prevails. Look back at the first Romney-Obama debate in 2012. There was no one exchange
column4: no one Obama stumble or Romney answer
column5: that provided the ”aha!” moment that journalists wait for the way hounds wait for the first call of the fox. It was
column6: rather
column7: Obama’s petulant
column8: defensive
column9: sometimes indifferent answers that made even the president’s most ardent supporters believe he had been badly beaten.

column1: The presence of Trump clearly raises the odds that we may see a “moment” unlike any in debate history; that’s clearly what an army of reporters and tens of millions of viewers will be waiting for. But it may just be that it will be the totality of the hour and a half that will persuade a viewer to say: “he seemed pretty reasonable” or “she knows what she’s talking about and he doesn’t.” This has special relevance for Clinton
column2: who
column3: as her longtime friend and one-time aide Patti Solis-Doyle observed
column4: always seems as if she is testing every word before it leaves her mouth. A sustained
column5: relaxed presentation over the course of the debate could be her best weapon against a Trump
column6: whose ability to stay within himself when untethered to a Teleprompter is questionable.

column1: There Are Three Debates
column2: Not One—And That Can Matter A Whole Lot

column1: One key reason why the 1980 Reagan-Carter debate was so important is that it was the only debate between the two. Carter had refused to debate with third-party candidate John Anderson
column2: so Reagan faced off against Anderson on September 21st. When the independent fell below the polling threshold
column3: Carter and Reagan met for the first and last time on October 28th—barely a week before the election.

column1: Every other time
column2: there have been three debates; which has meant there is a chance to make up for a less than successful debut. That’s what happened with Reagan in 1984
column3: and with George W. Bush in 2004; it’s also what happened last time out
column4: when Obama emerged from his daze and outperformed Romney in their two other meetings.

column1: Here
column2: I think
column3: is an opening for Clinton—especially in the town hall meetings
column4: where she should be able to turn a question—and they are usually very lame ""what can you do for my daughter?"" questions—into answers that fuse personal concern with a command both of her proposals
column5: and of Trump’s astonishing inability to remember what he has proposed from one day to the next. The danger for her is channeling her inner Al Gore
column6: who challenged Bush’s commitment to health care by repeatedly demanding: ""What about Dingell-Norwood?"" The opportunity for her is to argue—from experience—that what she has worked for in public life has made the lives of real people better. (Further
column7: the Town Meeting format—with dozens of “real” people as participants—makes the resort to personal insults highly risky).

column1: Trump Is Not the Only One Who Can Deploy Political Judo
The potential for Trump to turn strength into weakness has its roots in the most singularly successful use of political judo. It came in 1992
column2: when independent Ross Perot was asked if voters should be bothered by his lack of experience.

column1: “Well
column2: ” he said
column3: “they've got a point. I don't have any experience in running up a $4 trillion debt. I don't have any experience in gridlocked government where nobody takes responsibility for anything and everybody blames everybody else. I don't have any experience in creating the worst public school system in the industrialized world
column4: the most violent
column5: crime-ridden society in the industrialized world.”

column1: Judo
column2: however
column3: can cut both ways. There’s a clear opening for Clinton if Trump were to boast of his leadership skills
column4: and his business success.

column1: “Well
column2: you might be successful
column3: Donald
column4: but we really don’t know because you’re the first presidential candidate ever who won’t show us his taxes. But you know
column5: you should look at the business leaders who support me: Mike Bloomberg
column6: who’s worth four times what you claim to be worth
column7: and who didn’t start with millions from his father
column8: says you’re a con
column9: a fake. So does Marc Cuban
column10: who built his success from the ground up. But I do have to admit—you’re way
column11: way ahead of them in
column12: unpaid workers
column13: fleeced contractors and lawsuits.”

column1: Debates Are NOT Decisive

One last note. It’s easy to assume that the fate of the world is at stake Monday night. A lot of post-election narratives over the years have located debates as the center of the story (“Reagan recovered from his first debate-gaffe and went onto win a landslide.” “Obama was far more effective in the later debates and was re-elected…”). But is correlation really causation? Maybe the economic boom of 1984 has a lot more to do with Reagan winning 49 states; maybe the clear if modest economic recovery played the key role in Obama’s clear if modest popular vote victory.
In their influential 2013 book
column2: The Gamble
column3: political scientists John H. Sides and Lynn Vavreck tried to measure the impact of debates
column4: gaffes
column5: and other “game-changers” with real-time public opinion measurements. What they found was that even a dramatic event like Romney’s first debate performance had a relative small
column6: and relatively short-lived
column7: impact. Compared to the “fundamentals”—economic performance and the ever-growing impact of a polarized electorate—the stuff of which a hundred overwrought post-debate analyses are made may be of only marginal significance.

column1: Of course
column2: this cycle the “fundamentals” point to a very close race. So you’ll probably want to tune in anyway

Iranian President Hassan Rouhani on Wednesday expressed confidence that the landmark nuclear deal between his country and a group of world powers will be able to weather the volatile U.S. election season.
MSNBC's Chuck Todd asked Rouhani whether he'd rather work with Hillary Clinton or Donald Trump
column2: citing comments they've made on the nuclear deal. Rouhani said
column3: ""Of course
column4: throughout the atmosphere of presidential elections in the United States
column5: candidates can bring up any topic that they see best suits the needs of their campaigns. But the reality remains that when the joint comprehensive plan of action was passed based on the United Nations Security Council resolution 2231
column6: and it was approved unanimously
column7: that became an international agreement.""

column1: Story Continued Below
Trump has repeatedly criticized the Iran nuclear deal
column2: calling it a ""bad deal"" and previously said he would tear it up. He's also called the Obama administration incompetent over it.

column1: Clinton
column2: on the other hand
column3: has said she would respect the deal
column4: yet be cautious in dealing with Iran
column5: in what's come to be known as her ""distrust and verify"" strategy.

column1: No one can say here or there that I don't accept this agreement
column2: I want to renegotiate it. This has purely an electoral effect for some
column3: Rouhani said.

Jimmy Kimmel had an opportunity to bash Donald Trump in front of an audience of millions at the Emmys and he did not disappoint. He even went after Trump’s enablers who were sitting in the audience.
Kimmel opened the ceremony by poking fun of Hollywood’s elite and making several sarcastic but pointed jokes about diversity.
“This year’s nominees are the most diverse ever. And here in Hollywood
column2: the only thing we value more than diversity is congratulating ourselves on how much we value diversity. The Emmys are so diverse this year
column3: the Oscars are telling people we’re one of their closest friends.”

column1: But his greatest moment came when he mocked Trump. And called out the guy who made him a reality television celebrity.
Kimmel sarcastically riffed about the existence of television making it possible for such self-aggrandizing and bombastic egotists like Trump to thrive.
“If it weren’t for television
column2: would Donald Trump be running for president? No. He would be at home right now quietly rubbing up against his wife Malaria
column3: while she pretends to be asleep.”

column1: And when it came to who was responsible for creating the five-alarm dumpster fire that is Donald Trump’s presidency
column2: Kimmel singled out Mark Burnett
column3: the brainchild behind Celebrity Apprentice.

column1: “That’s right. That guy. Mark Burnett
column2: the man who brought us ‘Celebrity Apprentice. Thanks to Mark Burnett
column3: we don’t have to watch reality shows anymore
column4: because we’re living in one. Thank you
column5: Mark.”

column1: Perhaps only the guy who invented the infomercial is responsible for more suffering than Mark Burnett. That’s why Kimmel nominated Burnett to be the first one tossed over Trump’s wall
column2: should Trump convince enough deplorables to vote against their economic self-interests.

344	"Critical Counties is a CNN series exploring 11 counties around the country that chief national correspondent John King has identified as key in the 2016 election. These counties could play an outsize role in the election and offer an instructive example of what the political parties have accomplished. Wake County is the fourth county in the series
column2: which runs through Election Day. Explore the other critical counties.

column1: Washington (CNN)
Few counties could prove more decisive in this election than Wake County
column2: North Carolina.

column1: A historically competitive county whose fortunes are on the rise
column2: Wake could help deliver Hillary Clinton a win in a key battleground state -- or dash her hopes for the presidency. Simply put
column3: if Clinton performs well in the highly educated research triangle
column4: then election night bodes well for her. If Wake County doesn't come out for Clinton
column5: Donald Trump's path to the White House would grow much clearer.

column1: The county is rapidly expanding
column2: and the influx of new people and industries could reshape the race. Meanwhile
column3: the turmoil across the state in Charlotte after a police officer shot and killed a black man could add another focal point in the election — search data from Google Trends shows Wake County's spiking interest in ""police brutality"" this week.

column1: Keep your eye on Wake County
column2: and take a look at the fundamentals below.

column1: Population
Wake County is fairly representative of the country in terms of race and ethnicity
column2: but it has a more highly educated population
column3: bigger incomes and a better job picture than the rest of the nation.

column1: 345	"“[Ahmad Khan Rahami] should go to jail and be somebody’s girlfriend.” — Rock Legend Gene Simmons commenting on recent NY/NJ bomber Ahmad Khan Rahami
Hall of Fame rock legend Gene Simmons made a name for himself playing the bass guitar and singing for the pop-rock band KISS. In more recent years he’s been a reality TV star
column2: a cultural icon
column3: and an outspoken defender of the free market system and personal liberty. The combination of these things has made Simmons marketing gold among more conservative NASCAR loving
column4: flag waving Americans. The folks at TMZ recently ran into Simmons in the airport security line and asked him for his thoughts on the recent bombings.

column1: Simmons told TMZ that he thought the Muslim terrorist bomber
column2: Rahami
column3: “should go to jail and be somebody’s girlfriend.” Ouch. TMZ then asked Simmons how he would solve the problem of Islamic terrorism in America
column4: to which Simmons replied
column5: rather politically incorrectly
column6: that we needed to do more profiling.

column1: “Nobody says the word ‘profile.’ Everyone needs to get smart. I’m ok with profiling. I want you to stop me first. I want you to stop me because I look a certain way. And if I’m clear
column2: then profile someone else. It’s emergency powers during war. There’s a war going on.”

column1: But what about the people who were being “unfairly” profiled
column2: TMZ wondered. Simmons held nothing back in his perfect response. “It is unfair. That’s why the words ‘too bad’ exists.”

column1: BOOM.
Thank you for being awesome
column2: Mr. Simmons. Maybe when Donald Trump gets elected President he’ll consider making Gene Simmons the director of Homeland Security? Ooh
column3: and then KISS could play at all of the White House State functions! Hey

column1: It is important that charitable funds be used for charitable purposes

column1: Washington (CNN) Michigan Democratic Rep. Sander Levin called on the IRS Wednesday to audit The Trump Foundation
column2: following a report that the billionaire used charity money to pay off legal settlements.

column1: It is important that charitable funds be used for charitable purposes
column2: rather than promote the business ventures of those affiliated with the charity. I therefore request an immediate audit of the Donald J. Trump Foundation

column1: The Washington Post reported earlier this week that Trump used $258
column2: 000 from his charity to pay off settlements in a pair of lawsuits. The Post reported that Trump used the charity to pay for a $100
column3: 000 settlement with the city of Palm Beach in 2007 and used another $158
column4: 000 from his charity to settle a lawsuit filed in 2011 about a hole-in-one claim at a charity golf tournament.

column1: The revelation immediately drew accusations from Democrats of Trump self-dealing. Messages left with the Trump campaign and the IRS were not immediately returned Wednesday.
But New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie
column2: a top Trump surrogate
column3: warned Hillary Clinton's campaign Wednesday of using the allegations against the Trump Foundation for a political attack.

350	"The recent connected bombings in New York and New Jersey and the stabbing attack at a mall in Minnesota have increased interest in how the presidential candidates would handle national security.
Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump have spoken out since the attacks
column2: which left dozens of people injured.

column1: John Cohen
column2: a former counterterrorism coordinator for the Department of Homeland Security
column3: said he believes that the terrorist attacks that have occurred during the campaign ""have a significant impact"" on voters.

column1: When events occur like this ... you tend to have people become more fearful
column2: and when people are more fearful
column3: they tend to gravitate towards a candidate who appears to be more strong
column4: said Cohen
column5: who currently works as an ABC News consultant.

column1: Three of the latest national polls — all conducted before the attacks this weekend — had Clinton leading when respondents were asked whom they trust to handle the issue of terrorism.
In an ABC News/Washington Post poll released Sept. 11
column2: Clinton led
column3: 50 percent to Trump's 41 percent among all adults and 48 percent to Trump's 45 percent among likely voters when asked about who was more trusted to handle terrorism.

column1: A CBS/New York Times poll released Sept. 14 had Clinton doing ""a better job handling terrorism and national security"" according to 49 percent of respondents
column2: compared with Trump's 45 percent.

column1: The split was closest in a Quinnipiac poll released Sept. 15
column2: in which respondents were asked who they thought would do a better job keeping the country safe from terrorism
column3: ""regardless of how you intend to vote."" In that poll
column4: Clinton got 49 percent to Trump's 47 percent.

column1: Traditionally
column2: it's been the Republican Party who has projected strength and awareness in the area of law enforcement and homeland security
column3: but today that's kind of flipped because
column4: despite his rhetoric
column5: there are a number of national security experts who have raised concerns about the level of understanding that Donald Trump has as it relates to terrorism and national security threats
column6: Cohen said.

column1: Andres Kudacki/AP Photo
Current events are factoring into the political campaigns
column2: with the candidates scheduling speeches about national security in the wake of attacks. But Cohen said political rhetoric could also be affecting and even motivating the attacks themselves.

column1: He said Trump's rhetoric and calls to bar foreign Muslims from entering the United States ""may even serve to further along those who are becoming inspired to act on [ISIS'] behalf.""
James Campbell
column2: a professor of political science at the University at Buffalo in New York who has written a book about political polarization
column3: told ABC News that he believes the attacks translate to a potential advantage for Trump.

column1: I have to think that terrorist events in this country help Trump and hurt Clinton. For these events to be occurring with the frequency they do may be read by many as a failure of the current administration and particularly its foreign policy team to effectively deal with the problem
column2: he said.

column1: It may also suggest that we need a tougher approach to dealing with terrorism
column2: an approach associated with Trump. When suspects are identified who have Muslim-sounding names
column3: then that may further fuel support for tougher immigration standards and scrutiny

column1: 351	"Obama wears hat
column2: breaking ‘Politics 101’ rule on headgear

column1: President Barack Obama violated the longstanding
column2: albeit unofficial
column3: rule against presidential headgear on Monday when he accepted a hat and blanket at the White House Tribal Nations Conference.

column1: The president was given the hat and blanket by Native American leaders as he took the stage ahead of remarks at the conference. He wore the blanket around his shoulders as a song was played in his honor
column2: but took the hat off after just a few moments.

column1: Story Continued Below
“What an amazing honor and what a kind gesture
column2: for the honor song and the blanket and the hat
column3: ” Obama said once he took the podium. “I have to say that I am very glad that you also have a blanket for Michelle so she doesn’t steal mine. She would
column4: too. I’m just saying.”

column1: “That was very moving
column2: and is a reminder of the great friendships that we’ve developed over the last eight years
column3: ” he added.

column1: The unofficial rule against presidents wearing unusual hats is widely credited to Democratic presidential nominee Michael Dukakis
column2: whose decision to wear a tank-commander’s helmet during a ride in an M1A1 Abrams Main Battle Tank has been widely ridiculed to this day.

column1: Obama himself acknowledged the rule during a 2013 visit from the Naval Academy’s football team
column2: which presented him with one of its helmets.

column1: “Here’s the general rule: You don’t put stuff on your head if you’re president
column2: ” Obama said
column3: explaining his refusal to put on the helmet that had been fitted for him. “That’s Politics 101. You never look good wearing something on your head.”
