column1: 353	"Newark (CNN) Former Port Authority executives and New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie staffers planned to make the traffic from the September 2013 lane closures at the George Washington Bridge ""as bad as possible
column2: according to testimony heard in federal court Monday.

column1: David Wildstein
column2: former Port Authority director of Interstate Capital Projects
column3: testified that in June 2013
column4: Bridget Kelly
column5: Christie's former deputy chief of staff
column6: was upset that their office had not secured the endorsement of the Democratic mayor of Fort Lee New Jersey
column7: Mark Sokolich
column8: for Christie's reelection campaign.

column1: Wildstein
column2: who has previously pleaded guilty to one charge of conspiracy to commit fraud on federally funded property and one civil rights violation
column3: told Kelly that shutting down access lanes to the George Washington Bridge to put some political pressure on Sokolich was an option
column4: according to his testimony.

column1: Wildstein is testifying as part of his plea deal. Sokolich testified last week that being a ""Democrat in a Democratic town"" put him in an uncomfortable position vis-a-vis a Christie endorsement
column2: and he eventually declined because he did not want to ""alienate anyone.""

column1: On August 13
column3: and as CNN has previously reported
column4: Wildstein received an email from Kelly saying: ""Time for some traffic problems in Fort Lee.""

column1: Got it
column2: Wildstein responded.

column1: A phone call with Kelly the same day established the lane closures would go forward
column2: it was revealed in testimony Monday.

column1: I did not question senior officials in the office of the governor
column2: Wildstein said in court when asked if he questioned the decision.

column1: Wildstein became the de facto organizer of the eventual lane closures
column2: and communicated every step of the way with Kelly and his then-boss
column3: former Port Authority deputy executive director
column4: Bill Baroni
column5: according to his testimony.

column1: Wildstein and Kelly discussed and agreed that there would be no advance notice of the closures to Fort Lee officials or the public. They discussed how the Port Authority would respond to any inquiries
column2: and agreed that all calls would be directed to Baroni's office and Baroni would not return the calls
column3: testimony revealed.

column1: This ""radio silence"" policy was discussed with and approved by Baroni
column2: Wildstein said.

column1: Wildstein testified that that lack of advance notice was to ""maximize the impact on Fort Lee."" Wildstein also recalled discussing the timing of the closures with Baroni and Kelly.
Baroni asked when the first day of school in Fort Lee was
column2: and when Wildstein told Baroni it was September 9
column3: Baroni smiled and said
column4: ""Fantastic
column5: according to Wildstein's testimony. Kelly agreed on the September 9 date.

column1: Wildstein testified that his initial plan was to shut down all three Fort Lee access lanes
column2: but after discussing the matter with Port Authority engineers who feared this could cause ""sideswipe crashes
column3: Wildstein recommended to Baroni and Kelly that they shut down two lanes.

column1: On Friday
column2: September 6
column4: Wildstein informed several Port Authority staffers of the closures that were scheduled to begin on Monday
column5: September 9.

column1: Bob Durando
column2: Port Authority general manager of the George Washington Bridge expressed concern
column3: telling Wildstein that the closures would cause a ""mess.""

column1: Wildstein told Durando the closures would be going forward
column2: and to prepare accordingly.

column1: I told him not to say anything to anybody
column2: Wildstein testified. Wildstein told Durando to direct any inquiries he gets during the closures to Baroni's office.

column1: Wildstein then informed former Port Authority chief engineer
column2: Peter Zipf
column3: of the closures
column4: and asked Zipf to organize a way to get ""some numbers"" on the traffic patterns.

column1: Wildstein also informed Cedrick Fulton
column2: Port Authority director of Tunnels
column3: Bridges and Terminals. Fulton asked if Port Authority executive director
column4: Patrick Foye
column5: was aware. Wildstein testified that he told Fulton ""yes
column6: but that this was a lie.

column1: All of these staffers were under the impression that the closures were part of a traffic study.
On the day the closures began
column2: Wildstein watched the traffic build up on screens inside a Port Authority administration building on the Fort Lee side of the George Washington Bridge.

column1: I knew the plan that I had set into motion was working
column2: Wildstein testified.

column1: A Port Authority lieutenant also drove Wildstein around Fort Lee so Wildstein could see the traffic on the ground.
Wildstein testified that he called Kelly that morning to tell her that traffic was building up
column2: and ""she was pleased.""

column1: Several calls and emails began coming in to Baroni and Wildstein from Fort Lee officials
column2: including the mayor
column3: Sokolich
column4: but their plan of ""radio silence"" was put into effect and no messages were returned.

column1: Last week
column2: Wildstein testified that Baroni's role at the bi-state agency was essentially to be a representative of Christie's administration and that their top priority was to represent Christie's office's interests.

column1: Wildstein said he created a phrase that he and Baroni often used
column2: ""the one constituent rule."" This referred to the fact that Governor Christie's opinion or good favor was the only one that mattered when it came to Port Authority affairs. Wildstein and Baroni used the ""one constituent rule"" as a barometer by which decisions would be made.

column1: Kelly and Baroni face conspiracy and fraud charges in connection with Bridgegate. Their attorneys have previously said they will both testify in their own defenses."	newark cnn former port authority executives and new jersey gov chris christie staffers planned make the traffic from column1: Magistrate won't order federal arraignment for bombing suspect

A federal magistrate has turned down a request from defense lawyers that the man accused of the weekend bombings in New York and New Jersey be immediately arraigned on a set of federal charges he is facing.

Manhattan-based U.S. Magistrate Judge Gabriel Gorenstein agreed with federal prosecutors that suspect Ahmad Rahami need not have an initial federal court appearance until he is taken into federal custody. And
column2: by all appearances
column3: he's currently in the custody of local officials in New Jersey
column4: the magistrate said.

column1: The [federal] Government explicitly denies that it has arrested the defendant. There is no evidence to the contrary
column2: Gorenstein wrote in a two-page order released Wednesday evening.

column1: Gorenstein noted that defense lawyers said ""it is undisputed that federal law enforcement are involved in detaining and questioning"" Rahami.
In fact
column2: this question is very much in dispute
column3: the magistrate wrote. ""The Government asserts unequivocally that the defendant 'is not in federal custody ... Whether there are federal authorities questioning defendant does not address the issue of custody. At this point
column4: the Court has no evidence whatsoever from anyone with personal knowledge that the defendant is being detained by any federal officer.""

column1: The magistrate also rejected defense lawyers' claims that a federal court rule requires Rahami be promptly arraigned on the federal charges even if he is arrested by state authorities.
Gorenstein not only declined to schedule a court appearance for Rahami
column2: who's at a Newark hospital and could have been arraigned there
column3: but said he lacks authority to appoint the court's indigent defense providers at the Federal Defenders of New York to formally represent Rahami.

column1: Attorney General Loretta Lynch said Wednesday morning that Rahami will be brought to New York City in the ""near future"" to face the federal complaint there
column2: which is expected to take precedence over attempted murder charges filed in county court in New Jersey and another federal complaint in the Garden State.

column1: A spokesman for U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara’s office declined to comment on the decision
column2: saying the ruling could speak for itself.

column1: The defense attorney who asked for the arraignment
column2: James Patton
column3: did not immediately respond to a request for comment on the magistrate’s decision.

column1: PARIS — France has apparently become the first country in the world to ban plastic plates
column2: cups and utensils
column3: passing a law that will go into effect in 2020. Exceptions will be allowed for items made of compostable
column4: biosourced materials.

column1: The new law is a part of the country’s Energy Transition for Green Growth Act
column2: the same legislation that also outlawed plastic bags in grocery stores and markets beginning in July. Although plastic bags are forbidden in other countries — including in some U.S. states — no country seems to have embraced a plastic ban as sweeping as France’s will be.

column1: The general idea behind the law — following the landmark conference held in Paris last fall on curbing global warming — is to promote a “circular economy” of waste disposal
column2: “from product design to recycling
column3: ” French lawmakers say.

column1: [A Maryland county’s nickel tax for plastic bags is paying off
column2: but not as planned]

column1: Objections to plastic as a material are well known. For one
column2: it does not biodegrade and only breaks down into smaller and smaller particles
column3: which pose a significant danger for wildlife that cannot always distinguish it from food sources
column4: particularly in oceans. Aside from ecosystem disruptions
column5: millions of barrels of oil are used every year in manufacturing plastic bags and utensils
column6: playing what environmental activists call a significant role in climate change.

column1: In the words of French President François Hollande
column2: the ban is part of a larger push intended “to make France … an exemplary nation in terms of reducing greenhouse gas emissions
column3: diversifying its energy model and increasing the deployment of renewable energy sources” -- starting
column4: it would seem
column5: with the forks and knives distributed at fast-food restaurants and the coffee cups in vending machines.

column1: Not all share the enthusiasm of France’s Socialist government
column2: which has made environmental progress one of its main goals. In Brussels
column3: some argue that the laws violate existing European Union legislation regarding the free movement of goods and the protection of manufacturers.

column1: Eamonn Bates
column2: the secretary general of Pack2Go Europe
column3: a Brussels-based association that represents packaging manufacturers on the continent
column4: told the Associated Press that his organization will challenge France’s ban.

column1: “We are urging the European Commission to do the right thing and to take legal action against France for infringing European law
column2: ” he said. “If they don’t
column3: we will.”

column1: Supporters of the ban wanted it to be introduced earlier
column2: possibly as soon as 2017. But Ségolène Royal
column3: the French environment minister
column4: had initially considered it an “anti-social” provision
column5: on the grounds that low-income families relied on plastic utensils and plates.

column1: Trump-Clinton debates will stream on Twitter
Twitter and Bloomberg Media are teaming up to stream the upcoming presidential debates live on Twitter.
The social media site had similar arrangements for the conventions with CBS News
column2: and is also streaming Thursday night NFL games and other sporting events. The debates will be available at debates.twitter.com
column3: in Twitter Moments or on @bpolitics.

column1: The stream will also include thirty minute shows before and after the debate with Bloomberg Politics Managing Editors Mark Halperin and John Heinemann. Twitter and Bloomberg already have a deal for live streaming three Bloomberg TV shows.
On Tuesday
column2: Facebook announced it was teaming up with ABC for a similar streaming arrangement for the debates
column3: along with commentary from the ABC News team before and after the debates.

364	"Less than a day after protests over the police killing of an African-American man turned violent in North Carolina
column2: Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump placed some of the blame for the turmoil on the impact of drugs.

column1: If you're not aware
column2: drugs are a very
column3: very big factor in what you're watching on television at night
column4: said Trump in a speech to the Shale Insight 2016 Conference in Pittsburgh today.

column1: On Wednesday night
column2: Charlotte experienced its second night of protests after the death of Keith Lamont Scott on Tuesday afternoon. Officers in riot gear confronted demonstrators in a downtown commercial area and employed tear gas to control crowds. One person is in critical condition after suffering an apparent gunshot wound.

column1: The Republican nominee condemned the violence
column2: calling for unity.

column1: Our country looks bad to the world
column2: especially when we are supposed to be the world's leader. How can we lead when we can't even control our own cities? We honor and recognize the right of all Americans to peacefully assemble
column3: protest and demonstrate
column4: but there is no right to engage in violent disruption or to threaten the public safety and peace of others.""

column1: He continued to praise law enforcement officers
column2: citing the challenges they face and calling for better training.

column1: It's tough being a police officer
column2: Trump said. ""Police are entrusted with immense responsibility
column3: and we must do everything we can to ensure that they are properly trained
column4: that they respect all members of the public and that any wrongdoing is always — and it will be by them — vigorously addressed.""

column1: But aside from that one reference
column2: amid his heavy-handed praise for law enforcement and condemnation of protesters
column3: Trump never acknowledged any pattern of violence against African-Americans at the hands of police
column4: which is precisely why so many protesters say they have taken to the streets. They cite the shooting deaths of dozens of other black Americans by police as cause to protest a system they say is dangerous and discriminatory and fails to prosecute far too many officers who kill African-Americans
column5: in many instances unarmed.

column1: Trump in recent days has appealed to black Americans
column2: asking them what they have to lose by voting for him
column3: even as he paints an exceptionally grim portrait of black poverty and crime.

column1: During a rally earlier this week in North Carolina
column2: Trump said
column3: ""We're going to rebuild our inner cities because our African-American communities are absolutely in the worst shape they've ever been in before. Ever
column4: ever
column5: ever

column1: Many African-Americans have bristled at that broad assertion. While many inner cities are plagued by crime and poverty
column2: according to census data from 2015
column3: 52.9 percent of black Americans age 25 or older hold some sort of college degree. A Pew report released in December shows that black adults experienced the largest income increase from 1971 to 2015 and were the only racial group to see a decrease in the percentage of low-income earners. And according to the Census Bureau
column4: almost 73 percent of black Americans do not live in poverty.

column1: Trump
column2: in an effort to reach out to the black community
column3: visited Cleveland earlier this week
column4: appearing at a black church. And during a town hall on the Fox News Channel Wednesday night
column5: he was asked about the threat of violence.

column1: I would do stop and frisk. I think you have to

column3: you know
column4: you really help people sort of change their mind automatically.""

column1: But this morning in an interview on ""Fox & Friends"" he stepped back from the statement
column2: claiming he was referring to a strategy only for Chicago.

column1: 365	"There may be a few women out there who enjoy a man telling them to be more joyous in their presence
column2: but as for the rest of us
column3: there’s nothing a woman hates more than being told to smile.

column1: Do men smile all the time? No. Because if they did

column1: Not every situation calls for a smile at all times. Especially when discussing foreign policy and our military. So
column2: when RNC Chair Reince Priebus thought it appropriate to criticize Hillary Clinton for not smiling enough during the NBC forum hosted by Matt Lauer
column3: it didn’t exactly go over well.

column1: One person who definitely had a lot to say about Priebus and his request of a smile from Hillary was none other than Chelsea Handler on her hit Netflix show Chelsea.
Chelsea began by asking Priebus:
“Who the f*ck are you to tell someone to smile?”
Adding:
“This is just another example of how men feel the can belittle every woman in the world and order up a smile.”
Chelsea then said:
“Stop telling women to smile. We don’t like that. It’s not an icebreaker
column2: it’s a deal breaker.”

column1: Going for Priebus’ jugular
column2: Chelsea absolutely destroys him and his ridiculously corny smile
column3: then says:

column1: “You know when women will smile? When Hillary kicks that pneumonia and trounces Trump in November.”
And that’s exactly right.

366	"As police today captured the man wanted for questioning in connection to a series of explosive devices in New York City and New Jersey
column2: new information about him has begun to emerge.

column1: The man
column2: Ahmad Khan Rahami
column4: was born in 1988 in Afghanistan and is a naturalized U.S. citizen
column5: according to the FBI. He was discovered and captured in Linden
column6: New Jersey
column7: not far from his last known address in Elizabeth.

column1: New Jersey State Police
A U.S. official initially told ABC News Rahami came to the U.S. in 2000
column2: but his father later said the family came over in 1995. Court records indicate Ahmad Rahami was from a large family and may have as many as seven siblings.

column1: Former classmates said he attended Edison High School in New Jersey.
One of them
column2: Chris Konya
column3: said Rahami was quiet but funny and a ""pretty normal guy."" Konya and another former classmate said Rahami had a child with his high school girlfriend.

column1: Rahami was enrolled at Middlesex County College from fall of 2010 to fall of 2012
column2: where he worked toward an associate's degree in criminal justice but did not graduate
column3: according to school officials.

column1: New Jersey State Police
The Rahami family owned a fried chicken restaurant in Elizabeth. An employee and a recent customer said Rahami worked there.
I come in here every week or two
column2: just to get something to eat
column3: local resident Ryan McCann told The Associated Press. ""He's always in there. He's a very friendly guy. That's what's so scary. It's hard when it's home.""

column1: Members of the Rahami family apparently did not get along well with the local police and sued several officers in 2011 for allegedly harassing them over purported violations related the restaurant's operation. The case was dismissed in 2012
column2: pending the resolution of a related legal matter
column3: according to documents.

column1: Investigators are poring over Rahami's past travel
column2: including what may have been a recent nearly year-long trip in which he flew to Quetta
column3: Pakistan in April 2013 and returned to the U.S. through the United Arab Emirates in March 2014
column4: according to the U.S. official. Rahami reported to authorities that he was visiting his wife and family
column5: who he said were Afghan refugees living in Quetta
column6: and that he had traveled by car between Pakistan and Afghanistan.

column1: New Jersey State Police
In August 2014 Rahami was arrested after allegedly stabbing someone in the leg
column2: according to court documents. A complaint filed by a police officer said the officer ""has reason to believe that the person is a danger to himself
column3: others or property
column4: but Rahami was not indicted.

column1: Today Rahami was shot at least once by police during an exchange of gunfire before he was captured and then taken to a local hospital
column2: authorities said. He is not cooperating with investigators
column3: even so far as refusing to give his name
column4: according to a source briefed on the case. Officials said they have not determined a motive for the attacks.

column1: Late Monday officials announced charges against Rahami related to the shootout with police: five counts of attempted murder
column2: second-degree unlawful possession of a weapon and second-degree possession of a weapon for an unlawful purpose. Bail has been set at $5.2 million. It is unclear if Rahami has an attorney.

column1: A senior Afghan official told ABC News the Afghan government is ready to assist the U.S. in any way it can and is searching for any information it may have on Rahami.
New Jersey State Police
ABC News' Cindy Galli
column2: Megan Christie
column3: Randy Kreider
column4: Alex Hosenball and Cho Park contributed to this report.

column3: however

column1: 367	"Obama weighs in on the debate
President Barack Obama hasn't changed his assessment of Donald Trump after Monday night's debate: The GOP nominee
column2: he said on Tuesday
column3: lacks the preparation and temperament for the presidency and can't be trusted to address serious threats like nuclear weapons and climate change.

column1: The president unloaded on Trump during an interview with Ryan Seacrest in the wake of Trump's showdown with Hillary Clinton
column2: which he watched from the Treaty Room of the White House.

column1: Story Continued Below
Obama touted Clinton’s performance and her qualifications for the presidency
column2: saying “she’s serious and does her homework.”

column1: And he blasted Trump for not having the “preparations and the temperament or the core values of inclusion and making everybody
column2: you know
column3: have opportunities that would take our country forward.”

column1: The president said his two biggest concerns for his daughters’ generation are the spread of nuclear weapons and the onset of climate change — adding that Trump falls short on both.
I get worried when I hear somebody like Donald Trump start saying
column2: 'Well
column3: I don't necessarily know whether Japan or Korea should be protected by us. Maybe they should get their own nuclear weapons.' That shows somebody who doesn't pay attention to these issues
column4: and you don't necessarily want close to the nuclear button
column5: ” Obama said. (Trump objected to a similar characterization of his views on East Asia during Monday's debate
column6: saying it was ""wrong."")

column1: Obama also took a shot at Trump for suggesting
column2: in a November 2012 tweet
column3: that climate change is a hoax created by China.

column1: The concept of global warming was created by and for the Chinese in order to make U.S. manufacturing non-competitive. — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) November 6
When you hear somebody like Trump say he thinks this is a plot by the Chinese
column2: that this is a fraud and a hoax
column3: when 99 percent of scientists are saying you've got to do something about it
column4: Obama said
column5: ""that worries me.""

column1: Kellyanne Conway
column2: Trump's campaign manager
column3: said in a TV interview on Tuesday that he believes climate change is ""naturally occurring.""

column2: there are a ton of polls that were conducted online that say Trump won in a landslide. How can that be?

column1: Here’s The Huffington Post to answer that question:
Are polls like this an accurate measure of how the electorate responded to Monday’s debate? — Huffington Post (@HuffingtonPost) September 27

Why is this obvious joke of a poll so damning for all the online polls claiming Trump destroyed Hillary? Because this shows how online polls are meaningless. CNN actually contacted people. Anybody and everybody can answer an online poll. The results generally skew heavily to one side or the other
column2: depending on the outlet’s usual audience and which organizations/social media channels post poll links.

369	"7.5k SHARES Facebook Twitter
A public high school has been accused of indoctrinated Islam into their students. Allegedly
column2: the school has been mandating children profess the Islamic statement of faith
column3: memorize the five pillars of Islam
column4: as well as teaching students that the Muslims faith is stronger than a Christian or Jews. This is all according to lawsuit filed in federal court this past Wednesday.

column1: The lawsuit was filed on behalf of John and Melissa Wood with the Thomas More Law Center and the action is being taken against La Plata High School in Maryland. According to John Wood the school banished him from their property when he complained about the Islamic teachings.
Richard Thompson
column2: President of Thomas More
column3: said

column1: “Defendants forced Wood’s daughter to disparage her Christian faith by reciting the Shahada
column2: and acknowledging Mohammed as her spiritual leader.”

column1: The Law Center commented that for non Muslims such as Christians and Jews that reciting the Shahada Islamic creed which is their statement of faith is the equivalent of converting.
Spokespeople for the Charles County Public Schools have refused to comment other than to say they have not received any such lawsuit yet. However
column2: the Principal Evelyn Arnold
column3: Vice Principal Shannon Morris
column4: and Charles County Board of Education were all named in the lawsuit.

column1: The lawsuit says
“During its brief instruction on Christianity
column2: Defendants failed to cover any portion of the Bible or other non-Islamic religious texts
column3: such as the Ten Commandments. Instead
column4: the class included disparaging remarks about Christianity and the Pope. Such discriminatory treatment of Christianity is an unconstitutional promotion of one religion over another. United States Supreme Court precedent does not create a double standard that allows for the promotion of Islam in our public schools while disallowing and silencing teachings of Christianity and Judaism.”

column1: Classroom assignment copies indicate the teachers were instructing students that most Muslim people’s faith are stronger than that of the average Christian. As well
column2: the copies show they taught students that Islam is a peaceful religion that treated their conquered nations with kindness and respect too.

370	"CHAOS! NC Protest MOB Ambushes Female Truck Driver
column2: Loots Truck
column3: Sets Cargo On Fire – No One Helps!? [VIDEO]

column1: There’s nothing wrong with protesting a perceived injustice. One of our most cherished American rights is the right to peacefully assemble — to protest. However
column2: that’s often not what happens when Black Lives Matter activists set out to make a statement. Too often
column3: they don’t understand what the words “peaceful protest” mean. That was proved true once again in North Carolina last night
column4: when a Black Lives Matter mob descended upon a highway and began attacking people.

column1: The rioters began by throwing rocks at cars and trucks
column2: protesting the shooting of a black man on that same highway.

column1: VIDEO: this is what we saw overnight; protestors throwing rocks
column2: blocking a major interstate
column3: face-to-face w/@cmpd @TWCNewsCLT #KeithScott pic.twitter.com/BvhuBKj4X9 — Christina Watkins (@CWatkinsTV) September 21

column1: But it quickly became dangerous
column2: when the mob ambushed a female truck driver. She was trapped in the truck as the rioters looted her truck
column3: stealing the goods and lighting them on fire
column4: all while she was inside. She called police
column5: but they never came. Instead
column6: a media chopper got footage of the violence.

column1: 🤕Try & picture Collapsing Hillary Clinton getting out of bed to deal with Chaos & Violence in N.C #KeithLamontScott pic.twitter.com/KAVPlHmWPb × 101 Things All Young Adults Should Know by Sir John Hawkins John Hawkins's book 101 Things All Young Adults Should Know is filled with lessons that newly minted adults need in order to get the most out of life. column1: It didn’t stop there
column2: though; by the end of the night
column3: 16 police officers were injured and the freeway had been shut down.

column1: Message to these Black Lives Matter protesters: this doesn’t help your cause. Protesting the killing of a black man at the hands of police is a valid thing to do. Shutting down a freeway
column2: throwing rocks at cars
column3: attacking an innocent truck driver and injuring 16 police officers is not. That’s not a protest; it’s a riot. And it doesn’t endear anyone to the Black Lives Matter cause. It makes racial division worse and inflames racial tension. That doesn’t fix anything.

column1: Martin Luther King
column2: Jr. encouraged people to use love
column3: hope and integrity to make a difference when he was fighting for civil rights. It’s shameful to see the Black Lives Matter movement literally doing the exact opposite. Instead of love
column4: they spread anger and hatred and intolerance. They encourage black people to see themselves as perpetual victims and white people as racist oppressors. column1: 371	"Hillary Clinton’s campaign is making one plea ahead of Monday night’s big debate: Don’t let Donald Trump get away with it.
And Trump’s campaign is firing right back
column2: arguing that the press is biased against the Republican nominee and
column3: in any case
column4: Clinton’s team is just trying to “game the refs.”

column1: Story Continued Below
The debate is playing out against a backdrop of polls that indicate a tightening White House race
column2: with Trump drawing even or ahead in national and battleground-state surveys. Polling averages now show that Clinton’s post-convention lead has evaporated
column3: and no less a guru than Nate Silver declared on Monday morning that the race is a “dead heat.”

column1: “The latest polling is consistent with a Clinton lead of only ~1% nationally. State firewall breaking up. Trend lines awful
column2: ” Silver tweeted.

column1: During the critical hours of expectation-setting ahead of the 9 p.m. showdown at Hofstra University
column2: both camps claimed their candidate would be held to an unfair standard
column3: with Clinton’s aides explicitly requesting that moderator Lester Holt fact-check Trump in real time.

column1: “We are concerned that Donald Trump may lie
column2: he may throw misinformation out there
column3: and that Hillary will have to spend all of her time trying to correct the record rather than talking about the things she wants to accomplish
column4: ” Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook told “CBS This Morning
column5: ” adding that all the campaign is asking of Holt is that if Trump lies
column6: “that that simply be checked.”

column1: “The thing that concerns us is not the moderator themselves
column2: who have been selected by the commission
column3: because they will be seen as fair and even-handed. What bothers us
column4: Mark
column5: is the very public and very coordinated attempt to game the refs
column6: Trump campaign manager Kellyanne Conway shot back in an interview on MSNBC.

column1: But Conway was soon put in the awkward position of defending Trump’s claim that Holt may be unfair to him because he’s a Democrat and the system is “very unfair.” The “NBC Nightly News” anchor has been a registered Republican in New York since 2003.
“I don’t know that he knew what Lester Holt’s voter registration was
column2: ” said Conway
column3: who went on to dodge multiple queries of why Trump lied. “He didn’t lie
column4: ” Conway said at one point
column5: explaining that “a lie would mean that he knew the man’s party registration.”

column1: In a presidential cycle that’s seen endless debates about debates
column2: Monday’s theme was conflicting interpretations of what it means to be a moderator. After suggesting a debate with no moderator
column3: Trump has already signaled to Holt that he shouldn’t try to be Candy Crowley
column4: who famously injected herself into the 2012 presidential debate between President Barack Obama and Mitt Romney with a fact-check of the GOP nominee.

column1: But Clinton’s campaign has beat up on Holt’s NBC colleague Matt Lauer
column2: who was widely panned in the media for allowing Trump’s false assertion that he didn’t support the Iraq war go unchecked during a national security forum earlier this month.

column1: View One week of Hillary Clinton fact-checks (September 24
column2: 2016) One week of Hillary Clinton fact-checks (September 24

column1: The nonpartisan Commission on Presidential Debates
column2: which selected the debate sites and moderators
column3: weighed in Sunday. “In our history
column4: the moderators have found it appropriate to let the candidates be the ones that talk about the accuracy or the fairness of what the other candidate or candidates might have said
column5: ” Janet Brown
column6: the commission’s executive director
column7: told CNN’s “Reliable Sources.”

column1: When it comes to fact-checking
column2: Brown warned
column3: “I don’t think it’s a good idea to get the moderator into essentially serving as the Encyclopedia Britannica.”

column1: For her part
column2: Clinton won’t let Trump’s lies “go by the wayside
column3: ” press secretary Brian Fallon told CNN on Monday
column4: insisting that Holt shouldn’t
column5: either.

column1: “There is enough lies that Donald Trump tells consistently that everyone
column2: by now
column3: should be able to call them out
column4: ” he said. “Lester Holt
column5: Hillary Clinton will
column6: too
column7: but I think that even the observers and reporters tonight watching that are grading the two candidates’ performances should take it into account. By now
column8: we all know he likes to lie about his record when it comes to the Iraq war
column9: he lies about his support for the intervention in Libya
column10: he lies about who started birtherism
column11: he lies on any different number of issues and he tells them so frequently that we all know them now. If he says them again
column12: that should be disqualifying. He can’t possibly be given a passing grade if he repeats those lies.”

column1: Former Trump campaign manager Corey Lewandowski
column2: a paid CNN contributor who is still receiving severance from the Trump campaign
column3: dismissed the idea that a fact-checking moderator is of any concern.

column1: “I think what the concern is from both of the campaigns — and what it should be — is that the moderator is not the person who’s running for president of the United States. So I think you let the candidates debate
column2: you let the candidates answer
column3: ” he said. “You can hold people accountable
column4: there’s no question
column5: but I don’t think it’s the role of the moderator to inject themselves in so they’re making themselves part of the debate structure and people are talking about the moderator after the debate.”

column1: Trump’s campaign
column2: including his former aide Lewandowski
column3: also pushed the narrative that Clinton is robotic. That charge was leveled in response to the Clinton camp’s preparation for two Trumps.

column1: “We don’t want Donald Trump’s lies and distortions to be a distraction. We’re hoping that can get checked so that Hillary can focus her time on what she wants to do
column2: ” Mook told NBC’s “Today.”

column1: Asked about Clinton’s rules of engagement versus Trump
column2: Mook added that “it just depends on what Donald Trump shows up to the debate
column3: and we just don’t know that.”

column1: View One week of Donald Trump fact-checks (September 24
column2: 2016) One week of Donald Trump fact-checks (September 24

column1: But Conway shot down the notion that there’s any other Trump
column2: while echoing the criticism that the former secretary of state lacks human compassion. Lewandowski cast Clinton as a policy wonk whose challenge is “to become human” during the debate
column3: senior communications adviser Jason Miller tweeted that “Overprogramming leads to short circuits
column4: ” and Conway joined the pile-on.

column1: “He’s not going to be robotic and scripted. Hillary Clinton is
column2: ” Conway said. “And that’s a problem in debates likes this because people want to see a future commander in chief and president of the United States who is nimble and resilient and can answer questions that haven’t been pre-programmed in their head through all this secretive debate prep and mock debates.”

column1: After Mook warned against “a double standard where Donald Trump can get the Most Improved award but Hillary Clinton
column2: you know
column3: is getting judged on the fine points of policy
column4: ” Conway added that the two campaign managers “are living in parallel universes.”

column1: “I mean
column2: Donald Trump has been criticized all weekend long. I think that the Clinton campaign has clearly been gaming the refs
column3: has been talking to the media for a week now saying it’s your job to make sure that Donald Trump is fact-checked in real-time
column4: ” she said. “I'm just surprised a campaign manager would try to lower expectations that dramatically for his own candidate. But look
column5: they know that campaign debates are not Hillary Clinton's sweet spot. Yes
column6: she's experienced at doing them
column7: but the experience hasn’t necessarily been beneficial.”

column1: Aside from how Holt will moderate
column2: Conway cited pre-written narratives and what she claimed was Clinton’s willingness to say anything to get elected as her top concerns.

column1: “I’m worried that some of the headlines are already written
column2: that they’re conclusions in search of evidence
column3: ” Conway said
column4: adding that newspapers and reporters have already begun trying to undercut Trump ahead of the debate.

column1: “What I would ask you all to do is start looking at the Twitter feeds of
column2: quote
column3: objective reporters
column4: particularly our embeds. These are not profiles in courage
column5: and this is not journalism. There are people who cover our campaign who actually just slander our candidate on Twitter
column6: ” Conway said. “Ninety-two percent of at least two of our embeds’ tweets are negative towards Donald Trump. Why are they on our campaign plane? Why are they covering our campaign? ... Excuse the Trump campaign if we feel like we can’t get a fair shake from certain people.”

column1: Conway also indicated that Clinton may play the woman card
column2: skewing headlines that take away from the real estate mogul’s performance.

column1: “So if she ends up saying to him
column2: ‘That’s just not true
column3: you’re distorting my record
column4: you’re being mean to a woman
column5: ’ and then people will say
column6: ‘He was mean to a woman
column7: ’ and the headlines will scream and Twitter will blow up — even if it’s not true
column8: ” she said. “So that would be my concern
column9: that he’s not able to get out all of his responses because
column10: as Joe [Scarborough] correctly points out
column11: people are so worried that she’s not a great debater
column12: that she’s not really ready for tonight the way he is
column13: that she’s going to try to interrupt him and confuse the people watching in such a way that he was somehow rude to a woman and he somehow lied on the stage.”

column1: Rudy Giuliani
column2: the former New York mayor and a prominent Trump surrogate
column3: said he had advised Trump to ""just let loose"" and be himself — and not try to compete with Clinton's detailed policy expertise.

column1: She's been in government since I was a child. I don't remember a time she hasn't been in government in one way or another
column2: Giuliani said on ""Fox and Friends."" ""So she's going to have obviously more specific knowledge than he has
column3: but I think he's going to comport himself very
column4: very well
column5: and he's going to be — he's just going to be like you see him on — when he comes here [on Fox News] and when you talk to him on the phone. He's going to be Donald Trump.""

column1: 374	"“I take great pride in the fact that I am actually offering an alternative
column2: Gary Johnson said. | Getty Johnson: 'I’m going to sleep well at the end of all this'

column1: Gary Johnson said a Hillary Clinton or Donald Trump presidency would be deeply flawed and shrugged off the notion that he could play spoiler in a tight presidential contest
column2: despite fears among Democrats
column3: in particular
column4: that he’s snatching votes from Clinton.

column1: “The people voting for me are voting for Gary Johnson
column2: ” the Libertarian presidential contender said Sunday on ABC’s “This Week
column3: ” with George Stephanopoulos. “I take great pride in the fact that I am actually offering an alternative. … Fifty percent of people that are registering to vote are registering as independents. How is it that we can only have two candidates?”

column1: Story Continued Below
“I’m going to sleep well at the end of all this
column2: giving people a first vote
column3: not a second vote
column4: not a lesser of two evils.”

column1: Clinton’s campaign manager
column2: Robby Mook
column3: who spoke earlier on the same program
column4: shrugged off Johnson’s impact on the race.

column1: “He’s taking votes from both candidates
column2: but your own poll showed that his numbers are — are dropping
column3: ” he said
column4: referring to a new Washington Post/ABC News poll that showed Johnson dipping to 5 percent support. “I don’t think that they’re — that either of the third-party candidates are really going to factor into the head-to-head in this race.”

Former Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan once said “Everyone is entitled to his own opinion
column2: but not his own facts.” To which the head of the Commission on Presidential Debates has officially responded: “Says who?”

column1: In a stunning interview with CNN’s Reliable Sources
column2: Janet Brown gave a baffling explanation for why she believes fact checking should be taken off the table at presidential debates.

column1: “I think personally if you start getting into fact checking
column2: I’m not sure. What is a big fact? What is a little fact? And if you and I have different sources of information does your source about the unemployment rate agree with my source? I don’t think it’s a good idea to get the moderator into essentially serving as the Encyclopedia Britannica.”

column1: Head of Commission on Presidential Debates doesn’t want moderators correcting lies because “what is a big fact
column2: what is a little fact?” #cnn pic.twitter.com/krm5FeV9aW — John Aravosis (@aravosis) September 25

column1: The statement was exactly what the Trump campaign had been demanding for weeks and was ecstatic to hear. Going into Monday’s crucial first presidential debate
column2: the Republican candidate understood that the most dangerous hurdle he had to get around was if the moderator called him on his lies. Trump
column3: who has dismissed preparing for the debate out of hand
column4: lies a lot. That’s his strength. He needs it to win.

column1: Politico recently analyzed Trump’s last five days on the campaign trail and found that Donald Trump lies at a rate of once every 3 minutes and 15 seconds.

Trump’s misrepresentations range from false pronouncements (he again wrongly said he opposed the war in Iraq before it began) to the petty (he insisted Clinton had copied him by holding rallies with her plane in the background and insinuated she was “sleeping” when she held no public events). He contradicted his own policy on providing health care to the poor
column2: overstated the ad-spending discrepancy between his campaign and Clinton’s and exaggerated the size of his primary victories and polling leads.

column1: (For what it’s worth
column2: they also fact-checked Clinton and found that while she
column3: like any politician
column4: does fudge the truth occasionally
column5: Trump’s lying “so greatly exceed[s] Clinton’s as to make the comparison almost ludicrous.” Ouch.)

column1: And while Debate Commissioner Brown used an intentionally vague example (“unemployment rate”)
column2: there is no indication that Trump will reserve lies to things so nuanced. One example that might come up: Donald Trump continues to insist that the crime rate in America is going through the roof. This is a blatant lie that is exposed by just quick glance at the FBI’s crime statistics. The debate moderator doesn’t need to serve as the “Encyclopedia Britannica
column3: ” he or she just needs to know the basic facts. Big and small. And not let Trump get away with misleading the American people who are tuning in.

column1: Journalists
column2: whose job it is to deal in facts
column3: are furious with this caving to Trump.

column1: If reporters aren't supposed to factcheck at debates
column2: why exactly are reporters moderators to begin with? Why not just have an actor do it? — Sopan Deb (@SopanDeb) September 25

column1: Debate Commission director seems to think there are no facts
column2: just different sources to support any claim. That helps elect President Trump. https://t.co/lPkCQi2KL4 — Mr Media Training (@MrMediaTraining) September 25

column1: What is the point of a debate moderator other than fact checking? Why is this even a discussion? — Dan Pfeiffer (@danpfeiffer) September 25
Meanwhile
column2: Trump’s supporters are actively celebrating. They
column3: just like their candidate
column4: understand that the only path to victory for Trump is if he can get Americans to believe his lies.

column1: @AJDelgado13 Here is a crazy idea…..let the voters at home fact check. Let social media fact check. Candy taught us this. — Judson McCulloch (@JudsonMcCulloch) September 25
Hint: If you find yourself in a political party that’s major talking point leading up to a debate is that your candidate should be allowed to lie on stage
column2: you might want to consider finding a new political party.

376	"Story highlights Hillary Clinton has a 6-point lead over Donald Trump in a four way race
column2: according to a new poll

column1: Clinton has the edge over Trump on a number of key issues in the poll ahead of the first presidential debate
(CNN) Hillary Clinton holds a solid 6-point lead over Donald Trump heading into the first presidential debate next Monday
column2: according to a new national poll released Friday.

column1: The McClatchy-Marist poll found Clinton leading Trump 45% to 39% among likely voters in a four-way race. Libertarian Gary Johnson garnered 10% support
column2: and Green Party candidate Jill Stein polled at 4%. A Wall Street Journal/NBC poll this week found Clinton leading by a similar margin

column1: Clinton maintains a massive lead among black voters in the new poll
column2: pacing Trump 93% to 3% despite high-profile efforts by the Trump campaign to improve its outreach to minority voters. Clinton also has a large advantage over Trump among Latinos
column4: but her support shrinks to 60% when third-party options are included.

column1: Both candidates continue to struggle with low favorability numbers -- 40% of likely voters say they have a favorable opinion of Clinton
column2: and 37% say the same about Trump.

column1: Trump has a slight edge on the question of who is ""honest and trustworthy
column2: as 44% of likely voters think he is
column3: while 36% think that Clinton is. The two run about even when voters pick who ""shares their values"" and who ""cares about people like them."" And Clinton beats Trump handily on ""know how to do the job"" and temperament.

377	"I was a Democrat all my life. I came to Washington to serve President John Kennedy and Attorney General Robert Kennedy. When the president was murdered and his brother struck off on his own
column2: I joined his Senate campaign and staff as his legislative assistant and speechwriter
column3: until his presidential campaign ended with his own assassination. I ran on a (losing) Democratic ticket in the New York state elections of 1970. When I was working to enact my own program of police reform in the 1980s and 1990s
column4: then-Governor Bill Clinton was chairman of my National Committee for the Police Corps.

column1: This year
column2: I will vote to elect Donald Trump as president of the United States.

column1: Story Continued Below
So profound a change
column2: and a decent respect for old friendships
column3: requires me to deliver a public accounting for this decision.

column1: Here it is. John and Robert Kennedy devoted their greatest commitments and energies to the prevention of war and the preservation of peace. To them that was not an abstract formula but the necessary foundation of human life. But today’s Democrats have become the Party of War: a home for arms merchants
column2: mercenaries
column3: academic war planners
column4: lobbyists for every foreign intervention
column5: promoters of color revolutions
column6: failed generals
column7: exploiters of the natural resources of corrupt governments. We have American military bases in 80 countries
column8: and there are now American military personnel on the ground in about 130 countries
column9: a remarkable achievement since there are only 192 recognized countries. Generals and admirals announce our national policies. Theater commanders are our principal ambassadors. Our first answer to trouble or opposition of any kind seems always to be a military movement or action.

column1: Nor has the Democratic Party candidate for president this year
column2: Hillary Clinton
column3: sought peace. Instead she has pushed America into successive invasions
column4: successive efforts at “regime change.” She has sought to prevent Americans from seeking friendship or cooperation with President Vladimir Putin of Russia by characterizing him as “another Hitler.” She proclaims herself ready to invade Syria immediately after taking the oath of office. Her shadow War Cabinet brims with the architects of war and disaster for the past decades
column5: the neocons who led us to our present pass
column6: in Iraq
column7: in Afghanistan
column8: Syria
column9: Libya
column10: Yemen
column11: in Ukraine
column12: unrepentant of all past errors
column13: ready to resume it all with fresh trillions and fresh blood. And the Democrats she leads seem intent on worsening relations with Russia
column14: for example by sending American warships into the Black Sea
column15: or by introducing nuclear weapons ever closer to Russia itself.

column1: In fact
column2: in all the years of the so-called War on Terror
column3: only one potential American president has had the intelligence
column4: the vision
column5: the sheer sanity to see that America cannot fight the entire world at once; who sees that America’s natural and necessary allies in this fight must include the advanced and civilized nations that are most exposed and experienced in their own terror wars
column6: and have the requisite military power and willingness to use it. Only one American candidate has pointed out how senseless it is to seek confrontation with Russia and China
column7: at the same time that we are trying to suppress the very jihadist movements that they also are attacking.

column1: That candidate is Donald Trump. Throughout this campaign
column2: he has said that as president
column3: he would quickly sit down with President Putin and seek relaxation of tensions between our nations
column4: and possible collaboration in the fight against terrorists. On this ground alone
column5: he marks himself as greatly superior to all his competitors
column6: earlier in the primaries and now in the general election.

column1: It must also be said: Mr. Trump is an imperfect candidate
column2: and he would surely be an imperfect president. He is crude
column3: often vulgar. He has areas of great ignorance. He insults people and inflicts unnecessary harm. He would be twice the candidate he is if he used half the words. He is often intemperate; though it is not Trump but his opponent who is so intemperate as to compare Putin’s moves in Ukraine to what Hitler did—an insult that throughout all the Cold War and to this day
column4: no American president has ever offered to any Soviet or Russian leader
column5: not even the enormous butcher Josef Stalin
column6: with whom in fact we joined to win the Second World War. And it is not Mr. Trump but Michael Morell
column7: a former CIA director now high in the councils of the Democratic candidate
column8: who has publicly suggested
column9: without rebuke from anyone
column10: that we should begin “killing Russians
column11: ” a doubly illegal act of war.

column1: Moreover Trump marks himself as a man of singular political courage
column2: willing to defy the hysteria of the Washington war hawks
column3: the establishment and the mainstream media who daily describe him as virtually anti-American for daring to voice ideas and opinions at variance with their one-note devotion to war.

column1: John Kennedy admired political courage. He began his first campaign for Congress at the height of the Cold War by saying
column2: “Above all
column3: day and night
column4: with every ounce of ingenuity and industry we possess
column5: we must work for peace. We must not have another war.” Years later
column6: in the Cuban Missile Crisis of 1962
column7: he and his brother had to overcome great opposition from their own military commanders
column8: government officials and other public leaders
column9: to prevent a war with the Soviet Union: there were 13 men in the ExComm room
column10: and Robert Kennedy said that had any 1 of 8 of them been president
column11: the crisis would have exploded in nuclear war.

column1: But within a year thereafter
column2: deeply affected by the barely-averted catastrophe
column3: President Kennedy had forged a close working relationship with Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev
column4: spoke all over the country to promote peace policies
column5: and delivered his historic American University speech of 1963. Our “strategy of peace
column6: ” he said
column7: was “not a Pax Americana enforced on the world by American weapons of war.” Rather it must be founded on negotiation
column8: cooperation in areas of mutual interest
column9: and recognition that “our most basic common link is that we all inhabit this small planet. We all breathe the same air. We all cherish our children’s future. And we are all mortal.” As to our great adversary the Soviet Union
column10: he said
column11: “we must reexamine our own attitude—as individuals and as a nation—for our attitude is as essential as theirs.”

column1: Six months later he was dead; and it was Robert Kennedy who must resume the effort. Robert Kennedy made ratification of the Nuclear Test Ban Treaty the early centerpiece of his Senate career. But as President Lyndon Johnson escalated the war in Vietnam
column2: it was that war which forced Robert Kennedy to make his doomed race for the presidency. Wherever he campaigned in 1968
column3: to virtually every audience
column4: he spoke of the loss
column5: the horror
column6: the infinite tragedy of that war
column7: in words that could be and must be repeated today
column8: after 15 consecutive years of wars all over the world.

column1: “Our brave young men
column2: ” he said
column3: “are dying in the swamps of Southeast Asia. Which of them might have written a poem? Which of them might have cured cancer? Which of them might have played in a World Series or given us the gift of laughter from the stage or helped build a bridge or a university? Which of them would have taught a child to read? It is our responsibility to let these men live ... It is indecent if they die because of the empty vanity of their country.”

column1: He also urged that we consider the Vietnamese mother
column2: desperately trying to shield her baby from the fire from the sky
column3: sent by machines from a country she could barely understand. He demanded of his colleagues
column4: on the Senate floor
column5: to answer what gave us the right to destroy remote villages on the other side of the world
column6: to arrogate to ourselves the power of God
column7: the rule of life and death over others. “All this is our responsibility
column8: ” he said
column9: “not just a nation’s responsibility but yours and mine.”

column1: John and Robert Kennedy were no pacifists
column2: nor ignorant of the realities of power. But they required that great power be used with great precision and restraint
column3: and with humility. Both knew that their own lives were hostage to the possibility of assassination
column4: yet they kept trying to guide us toward peace up to the moments of their death.

column1: The legacy of JFK & RFK is “being abandoned by today’s Democratic Party.”
Theirs is the legacy that is being abandoned by today’s Democratic Party. We have broken one Middle Eastern nation after another. Hundreds of cities and villages lie in ruins
column2: hundreds of thousands are dead
column3: millions are refugees; and
column4: for all the press and political thundering against the menace of ISIS
column5: Al Qaeda
column6: or Islamic terrorism generally
column7: our military leaders offer no prospects of victory. They cannot tell us what victory would require or mean; though they are quick to assure us
column8: as in Libya today
column9: that this conflict will go on indefinitely. They cannot even explain how some of our current allies (example Turkey) are bombing and shelling others of our purported allies (example the Kurds). So a Democratic administration
column10: carrying on the work of the Bush presidency
column11: without thought and without question
column12: year after year
column13: has kept sending more young men and women into the grinder.

column1: Scores of Democratic elected officials once spoke and worked tirelessly to end our disastrous war in Vietnam. Today there is only the voice of the marvelous Democratic member of Congress Tulsi Gabbard
column2: a reservist who has twice deployed to Iraq and knows of what she speaks. And it is a Democratic president who sends an endless parade of drones to nations all over the world
column3: flaunting for all to see America’s unique military technology
column4: coupled with our seeming complete carelessness in how that technological prowess destroys people and nations.

column1: Most amazing of all
column2: however
column3: is that as we proclaim that the terrorists threaten Europe
column4: threaten the United States
column5: threaten Western civilization itself—as we face all this
column6: we do not concentrate our military might against this unique threat.

column1: Where are we sending our warriors
column2: our ships
column3: our planes? Why to Russia
column4: which the U.S. general who commands NATO has announced is the prime “existential” threat to America. As you read this
column5: ground
column6: air and naval forces of NATO
column7: led and largely paid for by the United States
column8: have been moving about the Western borders of Russia
column9: carrying out the largest military maneuvers since World War II. At the same time
column10: our most powerful carriers and naval air forces have been steaming about the South China Sea
column11: there perhaps to find encounters of unknowable potential with the rising forces of China
column12: our second said to be “existential” enemy.

column1: There are no Russian terrorists ravaging France or Italy or America. ISIS is not to be found on Russian soil. The only Russian terrorists who have attacked the West are the Islamists whom President Putin first asked us to join in the fight against in 1999. The only Chinese terrorists are Uighurs who are attacking not us but China itself. It would seem elementary common sense that America would have long since sought
column2: not to fight with Russia and China
column3: but to cooperate with both to suppress the terrorists and the terrorism that have plagued us for over a generation
column4: including the ISIS that is terrorizing Europe today.

column1: Former Defense Secretary William Perry
column2: a Democrat
column3: warns that we are now
column4: today
column5: “on the threshold of a new Cold War. ... a new nuclear arms race. ... the likelihood of a nuclear catastrophe is actually greater than it was during the Cold War.”

column1: Surely the wars and threats of war already on our horizon would be more than enough for any empire; and our empire
column2: as every thoughtful person knows
column3: is already staggering under the immeasurable loads of debt piled up by America
column4: by our governments
column5: our corporations
column6: our households
column7: our students
column8: and our promises of unlimited benefits in the future. The years of constant combat have exhausted our military. False hopes and vain promises of victory have burnt up the caches of idealism and patriotic commitment with which we began the wars a generation ago. Our forces are worn out
column9: especially the elite warrior units that have been constantly deployed for more than a decade.

column1: But
column2: ominously
column3: there is more to come
column4: more that already stares us in the face. The dire events of this summer have shown us the true danger that lurks here at home. This is not a danger imported from Syria or Iraq or Russia. Our greatest menace is the danger of our own history
column5: our inheritance to the latest day.

column1: For the fact is that while we chased a chimera of peace and justice in lands far from our own
column2: imposing ourselves and our concepts on strangers who rejected our teachings
column3: we were neglecting our own country and our own people
column4: our own neighbors
column5: our own children and our own friends. And now we can see the result. The violence we took to other countries bounces back to our own. The money we squandered on bombs in Iraq was not available for our own schools. The brilliant young men and women
column6: who gave up their bodies and their lives on distant battlefields
column7: were not here to teach and mentor and guide the young people of the ghetto. They were not here to police the mean streets
column8: to suppress and eliminate the crime that is the greatest cause of poverty. They were not here to bring the protection and the blessings of the American Constitution to the least among us. They were not here to protect American cities and enrich American lives.

column1: And they were not here to keep Americans and American children from murdering American police officers. This is our true present danger.
So my hope for America is this. First
column2: we must begin immediately to end our involvement in endless
column3: unnecessary and therefore murderous wars. We need our best young people to help us here at home. We need to stop the reckless military spending on more destructive armaments. We need to breathe free again.

column1: We must and will defend civilized order against its deadly enemies. ISIS and its brethren must be eliminated: no quarter
column2: no hesitation. But we will need to engage all civilized peoples in our mutual defense. We must abandon foolish skirmishes and petty jealousies. We must end our reflexive efforts to dominate other developed nations
column3: especially Russia and China.

column1: President Kennedy told us over and over that our own peace and security
column2: in this dangerous world
column3: would depend upon peaceful and cooperative relations with Russia and the Russian people; indeed
column4: at the end of his presidency
column5: Ronald Reagan said the same. Fools in Washington
column6: intent on world domination
column7: would have us ignore that wisdom now. But it is the wisdom that we need to preserve the world and our children’s future.

column1: Second
column2: we must at the same time begin to recover our domestic peace. There are many ills to be cured
column3: many shortcomings to be righted.

column1: But nothing can be accomplished in the midst of a war against police
column2: an insurrection against the Constitution itself. Our clear priority is reinforcement of our police and police departments. We need many more and better police. We need them to be better trained
column3: not as warriors but as shepherds
column4: as leaders and teachers of the young
column5: as peacemakers in communities that have not known real peace for many years. We need our very best young people
column6: not getting their legs blown off by IEDs in Afghanistan
column7: but saving all of our lives in St. Louis and Chicago and Detroit and Baton Rouge and all the other wasted places in our own land.

column1: Donald Trump has been mocked mercilessly for saying
column2: “America first.” But to demand that all the actions of government
column3: at home or abroad
column4: be first directed at the interests and well-being of our own country is not old-fashioned or outmoded. Rather it represents the deepest wisdom and tradition of American statesmen from the founders on. Only with a clear vision of what is truly in the interests of our nation and our fellow citizens
column5: and a full commitment to those interests
column6: can we act wisely at home and in the world beyond.

column1: Finally
column2: our president has told us we must lower our voices. Of course we do not hope for domestic discord. But the people of the United States have perhaps stood silent for too long. The elites of opinion and government have not hesitated to offer us instruction
column3: from the heights of their power and eminence. These are the people who have led us into useless foreign war and limitless domestic disaster. This president tells us that we must now spend another trillion dollars on new nuclear weapons systems
column4: and when we ask who will be the target for these world-destroying weapons
column5: says only
column6: “There can be no business as usual with Russia.”

column1: Surely he must have misspoken
column2: for anyone can see we are on a course of madness. We simply cannot fight the entire world
column3: Russia and China and all the nations of the Mideast
column4: and fight a war at home all at the same time.

column1: And therefore we citizens must not be silent
column2: we must speak as with one great overwhelming voice
column3: a voice as powerful as Washington
column4: as Jefferson
column5: as Lincoln
column6: as Martin Luther King:

column1: Return to the wisdom of the founders
column2: who fought necessary wars to defend the Union
column3: but sought no foreign conquests.

column1: Do not step over the threshold of a new Cold War
column2: a new nuclear arms race with Russia and China
column3: but seek to enlist them in common ventures to resist the forces of terror and chaos that threaten all civilization.

column1: Commit to our own domestic peace and security
column2: rather than persist in a vain effort to control the lives and affairs of 200 foreign nations.

column1: This
column2: as I understand it
column3: is the platform of Donald Trump. It was not the Republican Party platform
column4: and he had to overcome much opposition within his party to gain the nomination. But it is his platform. It is the platform he has restated again and again
column5: with determination
column6: and with the courage and persistence to outlast his critics. It is a platform that
column7: even in these troubled days
column8: could fulfill the hopes of the greatest Americans of all parties.

column1: Well may we seek reassurance whether Mr. Trump has the kind of cool judgment and self-possession that the presidency requires; the judgment that comes to the fore in crisis
column2: that saves a nation or perhaps a world. No one can ever truly know how a future president will react to such enormous pressures. But Trump has given some evidence. He set himself a unique course toward the office
column3: disdaining conventional wisdom
column4: speaking more truth about politics and about America than any conventional consultant or adviser thought prudent or wise. And yet it is his independence
column5: his willingness to name facts however unpleasant
column6: together with his great political courage
column7: that can give us hope and even some confidence that he may be up to the job. Perhaps most important
column8: he has proven that he is not intimidated by the generals and admirals who have up to this day had their unimpeded way with our wars and our budgets
column9: to the immense loss of both.

column1: Flawed as he may be
column2: Trump is telling more of the truth than politicians of our day. Most important
column3: he offers a path away from constant war
column4: a path of businesslike accommodation with all reasonable people and nations
column5: concentrating our forces and efforts against the true enemies of civilization. Thus

column1: 379	"Story highlights Obama has taken steps toward solidifying the alliance with Israel this month
His meeting with Netanyahu was likely to be their last face-to-face consultations
New York (CNN) President Barack Obama confronted one of his most strained foreign partnerships Wednesday during a final meeting with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu
column2: the pair making a last attempt at patching up their stormy bond before Obama leaves office.

column1: Speaking before their session
column2: Obama said he was aiming to ascertain the prospects for peace in the region as he prepares to end his presidency.

column1: Our hope will be that in these conversations we get the sense of how Israel sees the next few years
column2: what the opportunities are and what the challenges are in order to ensure we keep alive the possibility of a stable
column3: secure Israel at peace with its neighbors
column4: Obama said. ""These are challenging times. One thing that I would say about Prime Minister Netanyahu is that he is always very candid with us.""

column1: That candor has become a hallmark of the relationship between Obama and his Israeli counterpart
column2: whom the White House has accused of being less-than-diplomatic in expressing his opposition to US policies like the nuclear agreement with Iran. Obama's 30-minute meeting Wednesday with Netanyahu was likely to be their final opportunity for face-to-face consultations before a new president enters the Oval Office in January.

column1: Obama is intent on conferring solid ties with Israel upon his successor
column2: despite the personal animus that developed between him and Netanyahu
column3: as he looks to boost the relationship during the homestretch of a presidential campaign in which he hopes to see Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton prevail.

380	"President Obama today vetoed a bill that would allow survivors of the 9/11 attacks
column2: along with victims' families
column3: to sue the government of Saudi Arabia.

column1: “I am returning herewith without my approval S. 2040
column2: the ‘Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act’ (JASTA)
column3: which would
column4: among other things
column5: remove sovereign immunity in U.S. courts from foreign governments that are not designated state sponsors of terrorism
column6: ” Obama notes in the veto message.

column1: “I have deep sympathy for the families of the victims of the terrorist attacks of September 11
column3: who have suffered grievously. I also have a deep appreciation of these families' desire to pursue justice and am strongly committed to assisting them in their efforts.”

column1: The veto comes at the end of a 10-day constitutional window after Congress' overwhelming approval of the legislation
column2: setting up a fight that's likely to hand the outgoing president his first veto override.

column1: Suffering his first veto override so late in his second term would be significant
column2: especially considering the president's high approval ratings relative to the rest of his presidency. By comparison
column3: former President George W. Bush was overridden twice during his two terms in office and only in his final two years when his approval rating had plummeted.

column1: The last president to make it through a full presidency without a veto override is Lyndon B. Johnson.
If passed into law
column2: the legislation would allow victims of terrorism to sue foreign governments for damages.

column1: Obama and the White House have argued that language in the bill could potentially compromise the principle of “sovereign immunity
column2: ” and put the U.S. government and entities at risk of being sued by other countries.

column1: Overriding the president's veto means that this country will start pursuing a less forceful approach in dealing with state sponsors of terrorism and potentially opens up U.S. service members and diplomats and even companies to spurious lawsuits in kangaroo courts around the world
column2: White House press secretary Josh Earnest explained to reporters today.

column1: Our concern extends not just to the impact this would have on our relationship with Saudi Arabia
column2: but rather the impact that this could have on the United States' relationship with countries around the world.""

column1: But the showdown has also put the Obama administration at odds politically with the wishes of countless 9/11 families who argue they haven't had their day in court against all parties responsible for the terror attacks. Saudi Arabia has itself spoken critically of and personally lobbied against the effort
column2: maintaining it had no role in assisting the 9/11 terrorists.

column1: The House and Senate each passed the measure by unanimous consent. A veto override requires a two-thirds vote by each chamber
column2: and the White House says it has been working diligently behind the scenes to rally enough Democrats to block the override effort.

column1: 381	"Friday morning around 4:00
column2: three men – some of whom were armed – barged in through one of the doors of an Atlanta resident’s house. The resident’s co-worker was over for work-related reasons
column3: and when she heard the commotion
column4: she sprung into action
column5: wielding a handgun.

column1: The whole episode was caught on surveillance camera that was set up inside the house. The resident’s co-worker unloaded all the rounds from her gun into the intruders’ direction
column2: sending all three of them out the door. One of the intruders even jumped through a glass door. Two intruders are still on the loose
column3: and a third one died from his gunshot wounds in the driveway.

column1: After the gunfight
column2: the homeowner can be seen calming down his housemate and taking the gun away.

column1: In an interview with Channel 2
column2: Gwinnett County Cpl. Dean Washington reacted to the incident: “She exercised her right to defend her livelihood and property.” He added: “It’s not common that we receive this caliber of surveillance video showing the crime unfold
column3: an actual home invasion.”

column1: Washington hopes that the surveillance video will also lead to their being able to capture the two remaining suspects: “They’re not wearing anything on their faces so we’re highly anticipating someone watching the evening newscast will recognize these people.”
