382	"Lester Holt
column2: who anchors ""NBC Nightly News
column3: will be the moderatorfor the first debate. | Getty Everything you need to know about Trump and Clinton’s first 2016 presidential debate

column1: When is the first general election presidential debate?
The first general election presidential debate of 2016 will be held at Hofstra University in Hempstead
column2: New York on Sept. 26.

column1: Story Continued Below
What time is the debate and how long is it?
The debate will start at 9:00 p.m. Eastern Time and run for 90 minutes without commercial breaks.
How can I watch the debate?
It will be broadcast on all of the major television networks
column2: as well as the websites for major cable news channels and C-SPAN.

column1: Who will participate in the debate?
Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and celebrity real estate mogul Donald Trump. No other candidates qualified.
Who will moderate the debate?
Lester Holt
column2: who anchors ""NBC Nightly News
column3: will be the moderator. It’s his second time serving in that role in the 2016 presidential cycle. Holt was also a moderator for the Democratic primary debate on January 17. On February 15
column4: 2015 Holt became the substitute anchor of NBC Nightly News after Brian Williams was suspended. Four months later he became the permanent anchor.

column1: What is the format of the debate?
The debate will be divided into six segments of 15 minutes each. Each segment will start with a question from Holt
column2: after which each candidates will have two minutes for an initial response and then will be allowed to respond to each other. On Monday
column3: the Commission on Presidential Debates announced the tentative topics for the debate: “America's direction
column4: ” “achieving prosperity
column5: ” and “securing America.” The topics are subject to change based on news developments
column6: according to the commission.

column1: Why aren't Jill Stein or Gary Johnson participating in the debate?

Libertarian Party presidential nominee Gary Johnson and Green Party presidential nominee Jill Stein were not invited by the presidential debate commission. The commission said it would only invite candidates that averaged 15 percent in five national polls it selected. Neither Johnson nor Stein made that threshold.
What's at stake for Hillary Clinton?

The debate is Clinton’s chance to turn the page on a few weeks during which Trump has eaten much of the polling lead she built following her convention. Clinton’s camp has also been counting on her policy knowledge and debate experience to help her expose Trump’s weaknesses
column2: but the Democratic candidate also comes in facing higher expectations than Trump.

column1: What's at stake for Donald Trump?
Trump has been accused lacking policy gravitas and self-restraint
column2: and both of those perceived weaknesses could be exposed in a debate
column3: where candidates will be grilled on their familiarity with issues foreign and domestic and be expected to keep composed under rhetorical assault from their opponents. Trump has the advantage
column4: however
column5: of low expectations: At several turns in the presidential campaign
column6: even modest pivots away from his bombastic primary style were hailed as pivots to professionalism
column7: and a similar self-restraint — provided he still hits the high notes his supporters are expected — could help him clear the low bar again.

column1: What is the most watched debate in presidential history?
In 1980 the debate between President Jimmy Carter and Republican presidential nominee Ronald Reagan garnered a viewership of 80.6 million people
column2: the largest television audience for a debate since Nielsen Ratings began collecting viewership data in 1976. In 2012
column3: the first general election presidential debate between President Barack Obama and Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney attracted about 70 million viewers.

column1: What's the most-watched television moment of all time?
Super Bowl XLIX in 2015 on NBC is currently the most watched television program in U.S. history
column2: attracting 114 million viewers
column3: according to NBC News. The New England Patriots played against the Seattle Seahawks
column4: winning the game 28-24.

column1: Still
column2: that pales in comparison to the estimated 600 million people worldwide who watched Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin make the first moon landing on July 20
column4: or the estimated 750 million people worldwide that watched Prince Charles of Wales marry Lady Diana Spencer on July 29

383	"(CNN) Hillary Clinton's campaign manager said Wednesday that the Democratic nominee would implement a set of best practices to prevent police-involved shootings like the ones this week in Charlotte
column2: North Carolina and Tulsa
column3: Oklahoma.

column1: There are two prongs to her approach
column2: Robby Mook
column3: Hillary for America campaign manager told CNN's Alisyn Camerota on ""New Day."" ""The first is to have a set of national standards around how to manage the situations that doesn't exist right now and that could help through training to prevent situations like this.""

column1: There are no set of national best practices on how to manage situations
column2: he continued. ""These situations are handled by local policies currently. And what she is proposing is that we actually set up national standards so that localities have better policies to work with and train towards.""

column1: Clinton spoke out Tuesday against ""systematic racism"" following the recent shooting of Terence Crutcher in Tulsa
column2: Oklahoma. Crutcher was shot and killed last week after his car broke down. The 40-year-old black man raised his hands above his head just before Officer Betty Shelby fatally shot him. Crutcher was unarmed at the time.

column1: The Charlotte-Mecklenburg Police Department said Wednesday that ""approximately 12 officers"" were injured during protests after the fatal shooting of Keith Lamont Scott Tuesday by a police officer.
Mook said the other part of Clinton's plans involves working to improve the relationship between police and minorities.
The second piece is to restore bonds between communities and law enforcement
column2: so investing in community policing and making sure that local police have the resources to build the resources in the community to prevent something like this from happening
column3: he said.

column1: Clinton told radio host Steve Harvey on Tuesday's ""The Steve Harvey Morning Show"" that she plans to speak ""directly to white people"" about implicit bias. Mook said Wednesday Clinton meant she would explain that different ethnic groups are often treated differently in America.
What she's saying is our entire country needs to do some real soul-searching here. It is clear that the criminal justice system is not treating everybody the same way
column2: he said. ""If you are African-American or from a minority group
column3: you may not be being treated the same as a white person. And that's a problem.""

column1: Clinton said Tuesday that while there are ""good
column2: honorable
column3: cool-headed police officers"" working across the country
column4: ""we can do better.""

column1: We have got to tackle systemic racism
column2: Clinton said. ""This horrible shooting again. How many times do we have to see this in our country?""

column1: This is just unbearable
column2: Clinton said. ""And it needs to be intolerable.""

column1: Clinton later tweeted on the shooting
column2: writing
column3: ""Another unarmed Black man was shot in a police incident. This should be intolerable. We have so much work to do. #TerenceCrutcher -H.""

column2: both the Department of Justice and state authorities have launched investigations into the officer-involved shooting.

column1: 384	"2016 Obama’s team isn’t laughing at Trump anymore The president’s aides worry the Republican represents more of America than a fringe.
Obamaworld laughed as it watched Donald Trump’s hostile takeover of the GOP. After eight years of Republican opposition
column2: inconsistent policy demands and racialized hate against the first black president
column3: President Barack Obama’s aides
column4: past and present
column5: thought Republicans had gotten what they deserved--and more
column6: all but forfeiting the 2016 race to the woman they defeated eight years ago.

column1: They’re not laughing anymore.
Story Continued Below
Going into Monday night’s debate
column2: Obama’s team is feeling that same anxiety expressed by some top Hillary Clinton aides: maybe the country isn’t what they thought
column3: maybe the resistance to Obamacare and gay marriage and the progress they’re so proud of is broader than the vocal fringe they’ve always dismissed. Maybe
column4: the president’s aides – current and former – now concede
column5: they’re going to have to live with the fact that Trump could end up in the Oval Office in part due to a backlash against Obama.

column1: “I’m trying to think of a series to compare it to
column2: which was a series that started as a comedy and became a high stakes drama
column3: ” said Ben LaBolt
column4: a former White House aide and press secretary for Obama’s 2012 reelection campaign. “I feel like we’re maybe in the fifth season of ‘Breaking Bad’ here. We’re way beyond the laughs
column5: and just sitting on the edge of our seats in terror.”

column1: “There's not a lot of mirth in the circles I run in about him
column2: ” said another former senior Obama campaign staffer.

column1: Privately
column2: Obama has expressed mixed feelings
column3: according to people close to the president. He’s still nursing amusement at Republicans for being hapless enough to get railroaded by Trump
column4: but it’s mixed with frustration that there are so many Americans he failed to reach. People who've spoken to him say the president wonders what he might have done differently to break through in a way that would make people who’ve benefited from his policies—like those enjoying added health benefits courtesy of Obamacare—support Democrats.

column1: For Obamaworld staffers who had just been starting to settle into a new buoyancy about the president's climbing approval numbers
column2: Trump’s growing strength is an agonizing reminder of how far short they have fallen in delivering on ‘hope.' Even if Clinton wins
column3: the Republican has shown not only that America is divided between red and blue but that there’s an America that Obama never connected with at all
column4: and where all his data and rational arguments and appeals to sensibilities are as useless as Monopoly money.

column1: “We are still the country that elected Barack Obama in 2008
column2: and we are capable of that and more
column3: ” said Jim Papa
column4: a former special assistant for legislative affairs in the White House. “But we’re also capable of making bad choices and being seduced by someone who plays to fears and anxieties and racial differences.”

column1: Trump’s already done things they never thought he could
column2: like mainstreaming racist rhetoric and racking up so many small donors that they worry about the extent of his support. And that was even before he riled up Obama doubters again with his birther pirouette.

column1: And the result: Trump’s doing better in the polls at this late stage than Obama’s team imagined. With 43 days to go
column2: Trump and Clinton are essentially tied
column3: polls sitting within the margin of error
column4: even in battleground states.

column1: Though only a few weeks ago
column2: current and former Obama aides would joke about how the president’s great political legacy might be the Republican Party destroying itself in front of him. Now
column3: on the record
column4: they push back on the very suggestion that Obama’s legacy should be viewed in any frame that Trump also occupies.

column1: “I don’t think he thinks it’s his legacy
column2: I don’t think any of us think it’s his legacy
column3: ” said Dan Pfeiffer
column4: a former senior adviser to the president. “Trumpism is a lot of things in this country. President Obama is the face of that for some Republicans
column5: but the Republican Party got themselves into this mess.”

column1: But they worry about what even a Trump loss says about Obama’s America.
“I think he will lose badly in this election
column2: but I think the impact he’s had on our political process is incredibly damaging
column3: and will be lasting
column4: ” said Tommy Vietor
column5: a former national security spokesman who noted that his own amusement at Trump ended a year ago. “He’s made us look stupid. I think he is stupid.”

column1: For any efforts Obama made in urging people to disagree without being disagreeable
column2: as the president likes to say
column3: “Trump has shattered that
column4: ” Vietor said. “He has brought back a brand of politics that is you punch your opponent as hard as you can
column5: it doesn’t matter if it’s a low blow
column6: it doesn’t matter if it’s not of substance. That’s a bad lesson for people to learn.”

column1: According to Earnest
column2: Obama is serious about wanting a functional opposition and wishes that he’d had one to negotiate with on immigration reform
column3: trade
column4: infrastructure and other priorities. The sense of lost opportunity eats at them
column5: as does the sense that it’s not going away
column6: despite their confidence in Clinton’s chances.

column1: “I’m not saying we’d all be playing acoustic guitar in a circle on the National Mall
column2: but I am saying we would have progress to show for our efforts
column3: ” said White House press secretary Josh Earnest
column4: who's been with the president since the first campaign.

column1: Not everyone’s inside Obamaworld is down. Some schadenfreude remains.
“He's still exposed and ripped apart factions of the GOP
column2: enhanced their brand as hostile to a rising electorates
column3: and will leave them with no infrastructure
column4: ” said a more upbeat former Obama 2008 campaign spokesman Hari Sevugan.

column1: And Democrats’ sense of the vacuous GOP that Trump represents continues to resonate
column2: particularly as they see the Republican nominee attack an economy that’s gone wrong with the support of many of the same people who opposed the policies that the president credits for the economic rebound that includes the longest period of sustained growth and taxpayers repaid with interest from the bailouts that caused so much trouble.

column1: “The eight-year legacy of the recovery from the Great Recession is clear evidence that the Tea Party movement
column2: ” said Earnest
column3: “is intellectually bankrupt—or about something other than the economy.”

column1: But that doesn't take care of their grief about the state of American politics.
“I’d rather live in a world where the two parties really compete
column2: ” Papa said
column3: “than have a political edge on the Republican Party but have to live in a world where white supremacists have a channel and are legitimized.”

385	"United Nations (CNN) President Barack Obama made an impassioned plea Tuesday for countries to fulfill a moral obligation to alleviate a global refugee crisis ""of epic proportions
column2: despite a political backlash in the US against absorbing those fleeing Middle East violence.

column1: The President's interest in calling attention to the tens of millions of displaced people around the world
column2: and pushing back against the anti-refugee tenor
column3: was underscored by his decision to convene a Leaders' Summit on Refugees at the United Nations Tuesday.

column1: At the summit
column2: he also rejected another aspect of the American political debate swirling around accepting foreigners -- GOP presidential nominee Donald Trump's call to build a wall along the US-Mexico border.

column1: This crisis is a test of our common humanity. Whether we give into suspicion and fear and build walls
column2: or whether we see ourselves in another
column3: Obama said
column4: though he didn't mention Trump by name.

column1: Obama singled out the situation in Syria
column2: which has displaced 4.8 million people so far
column3: as particularly ""unacceptable.""

column1: JUST WATCHED President Obama at the UN: Then and now Replay More Videos ... MUST WATCH President Obama at the UN: Then and now 01:45
We are not as unified as we should be in pushing to make it stop
column2: he said
column3: describing the global refugee crisis as both a humanitarian and security challenge that tests countries' ability to take collective action.

column1: I called this summit because this crisis is one of the most urgent tests of our time
column2: he said. ""Just as failure to act in the past -- for example
column3: by turning away Jews fleeing Nazi Germany -- is a stain on our collective conscience
column4: I believe history will judge us harshly if we do not rise to this moment.""

column1: The refugee issue is one that's captured the world's attention more in the past two years than at perhaps any time since World War II
column2: seared into the public's consciousness by photos like that of a 3-year-old Syrian boy who drowned in the Mediterranean and the flood of migrants into Europe.

column1: A recent study by from the UN's refugee agency estimated 65.3 million people were displaced from their homes by conflict or persecution in 2015
column2: up by over five million from the prior year. Many are internally displaced within the borders of their own countries
column3: but about 21.3 million are classified as refugees.

column1: Obama's summit follows a similar UN-led meeting on the issue Monday
column2: which drew attention to the crisis but offered little in the way of binding commitments.

column1: Make no mistake
column2: US Secretary of State John Kerry said at the UN meeting
column3: ""additional efforts are urgently needed.""

column1: Leaders also called for a more orderly and equitable system to manage refugee flows -- acknowledging the burden is shouldered disproportionally by certain regions.
You have to know that today the European Union has a clear objective to restore order on its external borders
column2: European Council President Donald Tusk said in his remarks
column3: signaling a growing sense that patience in Europe with the migrant flow is wearing thin.

column1: There will be no repeat of the year 2015 with more than one and a half million irregular migrants
column2: he added.

column1: The Obama administration is hopeful the Leader's Summit on Tuesday afternoon can build momentum for more action.
National Security Advisor Susan Rice in June announced that the gathering -- co-hosted along with the US by Canada
column2: Ethiopia
column3: Germany
column4: Jordan
column5: Mexico
column6: Sweden and the UN Secretary General -- would seek an increase in funding of at least 30%
column7: a doubling of permanent resettlement
column8: and expanded access to education and work rights for refugees.

column1: Reaching these ambitious objectives will be challenging
column2: yet the level of need demands no less
column3: Rice said in a statement.

column1: But aid groups are skeptical the summit will prompt the kind of action they say is desperately needed.
We have to be optimistic that we'll see some real concrete commitments
column2: said Amnesty International's Interim Executive Director Margaret Huang. ""But the truth is
column3: even if those numbers are hit
column4: it's nowhere near what's actually needed.""

column1: The US is a major contributor of humanitarian aid for countries that host large numbers of refugees -- particularly Syria's neighbors -- and plans to increase the number of refugees it will take in to America from 85
column3: 000 next year.

column1: The President's chief spokesman last week conceded that even as the administration calls for greater global action
column2: it is limited in what it can do.

column1: The President's commitment to ensuring that the United States plays a leading role on this issue is not shared by a lot of people in Congress
column2: including by a lot of people in the Republican majority in Congress
column3: Press Secretary Josh Earnest told reporters. ""And that has an impact in terms of the resources that are dedicated to this effort.""

column1: Vetting efforts to screen refugees
column2: he noted
column3: ""are not cheap.""

column1: David Miliband
column2: president of the International Rescue Committee and a former British Foreign Secretary
column3: said he's hopeful but waiting to see whether any agreements are backed up with action.

column1: The scale of the global refugee problem demands an appropriate scale of response
column2: Miliband told CNN. ""Governments around the world haven't
column3: in the main
column4: been responding with the right degree of compassion or competence up to now.""

column1: But the co-hosts of the Leaders' Summit said in a statement they were pleased with ""new and significant humanitarian contributions"" from world leaders.
We sought a $3 billion increase in global humanitarian financing and commitments to maintain funding in future years
column2: they said. ""Through our mutual efforts
column3: over the course of 2016
column4: the 32 donors participating today have contributed this year roughly 4.5 billion additional dollars to UN appeals and international humanitarian organizations than in 2015.""

column1: As they await action from world leaders in New York
column2: a group of volunteers in London laid out a ""life jacket graveyard"" Monday to draw attention to the plight of thousands of migrants who've lost their lives attempting hazardous boat crossings in the Mediterranean.

column1: The conflict in Syria and resulting migrant crisis in the Middle East and Europe have dominated headlines over the past 18 months
column2: but refugees are a global problem.

column1: Perhaps nowhere are they more prevalent than in the so-called ""global south"" -- the developing countries of the southern hemisphere. Last week
column2: South Sudan joined the ranks of Syria
column3: Afghanistan
column4: and Somalia -- countries with over 1 million of their citizens living as refugees abroad.

column1: And protracted conflict in places like Somalia have led to a generation of lifelong refugees -- men and women in their twenties who've never known life outside of a camp.
These are not people who can envision what life would be like if they were returned to their home countries
column2: Huang said."	united nations cnn president barack obama made impassioned plea tuesday for countries fulfill moral obligation alleviate global refugee crisis epic proportions despite political column2: including Republicans

391	"Kellyanne Conway praised Donald Trump for showing restraint at the debate. | AP Photo Trump camp: ‘Donald Trump is guilty of answering the question asked’

Donald Trump’s campaign manager Kellyanne Conway praised her candidate for showing restraint at the tail end of Monday night’s debate when Hillary Clinton attacked his history of disrespectful and derogatory remarks about women.
“I have to say
column2: certainly as a woman
column3: I appreciated the restraint at the end. I am not sure I would have been able to exercise it myself
column4: but restraint is a virtue and it’s a presidential virtue
column5: ” Conway told MSNBC’s Morning Joe Tuesday. “To tell Hillary Clinton after she accused him of being terrible with women
column6: to tell Hillary Clinton ‘I was prepared to go rough tonight and I am not going to do it because your husband and daughter are here.’ That is going to grow in importance in the next couple of days in a moment of great temperance and restraint.”

column1: Story Continued Below
With just minutes left in Monday night’s debate
column2: Clinton managed to work in a line of attack against Trump that she has also used most-recently in a new campaign ad
column3: hitting the Manhattan billionaire as “a man who has called women pigs
column4: slobs and dogs.” After the debate
column5: Trump told CNN that ““I was going to say something extremely rough to Hillary
column6: to her family
column7: and I said to myself
column8: I can't do it
column9: ” indicating that he was uncomfortable leveling such an attack with Clinton’s husband and daughter in the audience.

column1: Tuesday morning
column2: Conway was happy to fill in the blanks for viewers wondering what exactly Trump’s attack might have been.

column1: “I think he could have said what was on millions of Americans’ minds
column2: no doubt
column3: that are we going to relitigate who’s been good to women and who hasn't?” Conway said. “They’re taking a couple comments he made over any number of years as a private citizen
column4: versus where he could have gone
column5: and I think we all can finish the sentence. People did last night
column6: they finished the sentence
column7: they said
column8: you know
column9: maybe he was going to talk about Bill Clinton's record with women
column10: but he decided not to.”

column1: Overall
column2: Conway said Clinton failed to deliver a “knockout punch” that would have forced Trump into a major error. Instead
column3: Trump’s campaign manager said the former secretary of state came off as rehearsed and determined to squeeze her talking points into the conversation
column4: regardless of how pertinent they were to the questions of moderator Lester Holt.

column1: “Donald Trump is guilty of answering the question asked
column2: and I thought Hillary Clinton last night wanted to make sure that no matter what was asked and what was answered
column3: she was going to repeat back to us everything that she had learned in the last week or two weeks
column4: and that’s fine
column5: ” Conway said.

column1: “I don't think Hillary Clinton did a thing last night. If somebody can correct me
column2: what was the big takeaway moment where she offers this huge vision for economic growth and an end to wage stagnation
column3: ” she added. “So I didn't hear any big moment for her where she convinced the 70 percent of Americans who want change
column4: who want a different direction
column5: that she's their gal.”

392	"Donald Trump has a reputation in the media for being open and accessible to interview requests. He is known for a willingness to spout off to whoever sticks a microphone in front of his face
column2: and it has helped him get this far as a political candidate.

column1: But lately
column2: as Trump has hired new handlers and other assorted campaign personnel
column3: he has also been in something of a retreat. That is
column4: Trump is only talking to Fox News right now.

column1: Trump is saying “yes” to Fox News almost every day but saying “no” to most other major networks and news organizations — a highly unusual strategy for a presidential nominee. He called into “Fox & Friends” on Monday morning
column2: he is booked on “The O’Reilly Factor” Monday night
column3: and he has another town hall with Sean Hannity coming up on Wednesday. Rousing the base instead of reaching out to undecided voters may ultimately pay off for Trump. If nothing else
column4: it limits the candidate’s exposure to hard-hitting questions — while fueling frustration among journalists.

column1: At Fox News
column2: Trump can avoid pesky follow-up questions about his support for the racist birther conspiracy
column3: long after he claims to have dropped it. Fox News hosts won’t ask him why he reacts to possible terrorism by screaming about how he was right
column4: rather than express condolences for the victims and support for law enforcement. At Fox News
column5: Trump isn’t challenged – and that’s the way he wants it.

column1: The problem is
column2: wrapping up in the Fox News cocoon may feel good for the time being
column3: but the way to win an election is to appeal to audiences outside of your base of comfort. Trump isn’t reaching out.

column1: It is a strategy that shows up elsewhere in his campaign
column2: where instead of following the model of successful politicians like George W. Bush and President Obama by holding campaign rallies in “swing” districts hoping to persuade voters
column3: Trump has rallies with the converted.

column1: On election day in 2012
column2: Fox News viewers were shocked to find the Romney “landslide” the network had kept promoting was a harsh reality. They may be setting themselves up for a major failure.

column1: Posted by Frank Wilkenmeyer on 19 Sep 2016
Donald Trump Jr. Is quite possibly the dumbest person ever to take to social media. In the very least
column2: it’s a tossup between him and little brother Eric
column3: who just yesterday made a fool of himself with his childish self-admiration for being the answer to a crossword puzzle question
column4: along with free wifi
column5: pushup bras and Bozo the Clown.

column1: Together
column2: the dimwitted duo provide enough social media fodder to make fun of them well into the next generation with posts to spare. When this election is finally over
column3: it will be almost sad to see them fade back into oblivion. Maybe we’ll keep track of their Twitter accounts just for a giggle every now and then.

column1: Today’s silliness begins with Oompa Loompa Jr. pinning a tweet that is certainly relevant to a particularly volatile national discussion happening right now: Colin Kaepernick and the National Anthem. As more and more athletes decide to take a knee in protest to support Black Lives Matter
column2: more and more conservatives trash them for it
column3: calling them unpatriotic and demanding they stop getting media coverage. Lord Cheeto II has been one of the most vocal
column4: accusing Kaepernick of disrespecting our troops and those who died for his freedom.

column1: For the left
column2: it’s a simple matter of the 1st Amendment. Regardless of how you feel about the issue
column3: these athletes have the right to express themselves. Yes
column4: that means from government oppression and prosecution and not public criticism
column5: but let’s not forget that it’s people like Little Comb-Over who are calling for police to stop providing protection for these athletes
column6: for their employers to terminate their contracts and some have even gone so far as to suggest they be jailed for treason.

column1: For years
column2: we’ve known that the only constitutional amendment conservatives care about is the second
column3: so when this tweet appeared pinned to Mini Douche’s Twitter account this morning
column4: I couldn’t help but bust out in hysterical laughter:

column1: Clearly when you’re the son of pure evil you have a hard time understanding the words you use. When “liberals” — otherwise known as “sane people” — try to explain why people like Kaepernick and those who have followed his lead are expressing that very right
column2: we’re attacked in a frenzy of hate by people who think placing your hand over your heart and singing a song is mandatory patriotism. It’s not. The first amendment is exactly today what it was when the founders added it to the framework of a growing nation in 1789; the right to be you.

column1: The Supreme Court has sided with those “liberals” every time the issue of free speech is tied to something conservatives think should be compulsory
column2: like the pledge of allegiance and school prayer. I’ve said it already once in this article and thousands of times in my everyday life and I’ll say it again: The 2nd Amendment is the only one they see as absolute. All others are open to the interpretation of some holier than thou asshole like Donald Trump Jr.

column2: Clinton 42% and Gary Johnson 8%

column1: Mitt Romney won the state by 8 points in 2012
Washington (CNN) Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton are in a tight race in in Georgia
column2: a traditionally deep red state
column3: according to a new poll.

column1: The Republican candidate has 45% to Clinton's 42% in the Monmouth University poll
column2: within the poll's margin of error. Libertarian Gary Johnson had the support of 8% of likely voters.

column1: Trump is underperforming previous GOP candidates. Mitt Romney won the state by 8 points in 2012 over President Barack Obama.
The incumbent Republican senator is also out-polling Trump. Sen. Johnny Isakson has a 16-point lead over challenger Jim Barksdale
Clinton's strength comes from the Atlanta area
column2: where she leads Trump 55% to 35%. But Trump leads her 51% to 33% elsewhere in the Peach State. She leads 88% to 4% among the state's black voters
column3: but trails 20% to 66% among white voters.

column1: 396	"Getty Images Wealth Of Nations Trump vs. Clinton: A Fundamental Clash over How the Economy Works He sees it as zero-sum. She believes all boats rise together. Hillary is right
column2: but a lot of people are buying into Trump’s vision.

column1: As he made clear once again in Monday night’s debate
column2: Donald Trump sees the world in zero-sum terms—when one person or one country wins
column3: another always loses. Asked by NBC’s Lester Holt how to help American workers
column4: Trump responded in his usual way
column5: saying America was getting beaten by everyone else around the world
column6: and the NAFTA free-trade deal was “one of the worst things that ever happened to the manufacturing industry. ... We have to stop these countries from stealing our companies and our jobs.”

column1: Hillary Clinton
column2: by contrast
column3: sees the world as a place where all boats can rise at once—as she also made plain Monday by harking back to Bill Clinton’s pro-globalization presidency
column4: which included NAFTA. ‘I think my husband did a pretty good job in the 1990s. I think a lot about what worked and how we can make it work again
column5: ” she said. “Incomes went up for everybody.”

column1: Story Continued Below
That is the election of 2016 distilled down to its essence. “My whole life is about winning. … I always win
column2: ” Trump says in explaining why he’s running. The economic plan on his website begins with the rubric “Winning the Global Competition.” You don’t get more zero-sum than that.

column1: Despite the view of most economists that the economy overall is not a zero-sum game—but rather a complex mechanism that
column2: if run right
column3: can raise everyone’s welfare at once–Trump’s message has resonated in an era when it’s become common to speak of winners and losers in the global economy. The zero-sum message fits neatly with the widespread reality that many millions have been severely harmed by the transitions in our economy over the past decades. As Danny Vinik recently noted in Politico
column4: the gap between those who are thriving in the new economies of today and those who are not continues to grow.

column1: The recent Census Report that showed a 5.2 percent increase in real median income between 2014 and 2015 was taken by many as proof that the narrative of an America in decline and losing is fundamentally flawed. Statistically
column2: if the United States is one unit
column3: that is true. But 320 million people have a huge variety of experiences ill-suited to one size fit all numbers
column4: and while the averages and medians may go up or down
column5: that says nothing about the lived experience of tens of millions who diverge from that one number. And the experience of a goodly portion of what was the industrial heartland and what was the epicenter of the mid-2000s housing bubble is unequivocally negative
column6: insecure and economically grim.

column1: Hence
column2: you have the sense that those who perceive themselves as winners in the global economy are trending towards the Democrats
column3: while those who think they’ve lost are going toward Trump. There is some truth there
column4: but that isn’t a sufficient explanation for why
column5: for instance
column6: massive percentages of African-Americans and Latinos
column7: who have certainly struggled economically and socially
column8: support Clinton.

column1: No
column2: what is most striking about this election is the degree to which the electorate is polarized not between winners and losers per se but between those who view the world in such zero-sum terms
column3: like Trump
column4: and those who sense that it is possible to multiply the numbers of “winners” without creating a commensurate number of losers. That has been the mantra of Clinton and her predecessors in the Democratic Party
column5: and it was also the foundation of Ronald Reagan’s appeal. The belief that the economic pie can expand year after year and embrace ever more people has also backed up by a generation of economists who argue that open trade and globalization makes the whole world wealthier.

column1: Hillary Clinton has continued to deliver that message. At the Democratic Convention in July she spoke of an America thriving with economic opportunity
column2: with millions working hard and succeeding. President Obama has also been at pains to highlight the innovations of Silicon Valley
column3: the revival of many cities in the past decade
column4: and the substantial gains on the other side of 2008-2009 financial crisis. Judging from polls and surveys
column5: those who fit that description – clustered and concentrated in large metro areas
column6: and on the coasts especially – support Clinton and the Democrats by wide margins.

column1: Is either side right? Most economists see the liberal internationalist order backed by the law establishing the rules of engagement in free markets as a key element to the emergence of a several billion-strong global middle class. In general
column2: that view is correct. But it still tends to gloss over just how wrenching it is to be among the tens of millions in the United States caught in the vortex of rapid change. It does these global laggards no good to say that they have bigger homes and longer lives and more possessions than their grandparents. They legitimately fear that they will lose those homes
column3: be unable to afford healthcare
column4: that they will see their communities crumble and their children’s hopes extinguished. And they see a world of others who appear to be doing better
column5: who seem to be winning
column6: and a political establishment that has promised everything and delivered what feels like nothing.

column1: The voice of the so-called losers in this global competition is as loud
column2: politically speaking
column3: as it’s been in a long time. Hence Trump (not to mention Bernie Sanders’ powerful insurgency in the Democratic primaries). The last time so many in the United States were so sour about the inequities between those winning (the few) and those losing was at the dawn of the Progressive Movement in the 1890s. Many early Progressives rebelled against an elite vision of Social Darwinism then prevalent which said that the strong and the best thrive while the rest manage to eke out what they can. In 1896
column4: the scion of that view was William Jennings Bryan
column5: who painted a picture of the United States every bit as bleak and dark as Trump with his thundering about elites on the coasts crucifying hard worker labor and farmers on a “cross of gold.” Bryan lost two elections
column6: and his zero-sum view never came to dominate American politics. Much of his message about inequality and the need to reform the system
column7: however
column8: was taken up by Theodore Roosevelt and generations of both Republicans and Democrats. Some of it harsh and redistributive
column9: focused on trust busting and exerting American influence and prestige abroad
column10: and much of it was about expanding opportunities for all.

column1: Trump also enjoys a good deal of sub-rosa support among business leaders and Wall Street
column2: who certainly haven’t lack for economic benefits in today’s world. They aren’t supporting him with their money
column3: but many of them detest Clinton and see Trump as expressing their world view. For Wall Street
column4: that makes some sense
column5: in that in the wake of the financial crisis
column6: key aspects of finance are becoming less popular and less profitable. In that sense
column7: finance
column8: which was the winning sector of the economy from the mid-1980s through the mid-2000s
column9: has been losing ground. The idea of gain and loss
column10: and that every trade represents a winner and a loser
column11: is deeply embedded in aspects of Wall Street.

column1: We have
column2: of course
column3: no idea which candidate and which worldview will prevail in six weeks. But if Trump wins
column4: he should remember: it is impossible to find any society and any point in American history where a zero-sum formula has led to increased affluence for the many and increased security. Zero-sum most often begets zero-sum
column5: whether in the form of trade wars or actual wars. By contrast
column6: the profound strength of the United States has been a vision of an open economy that thrives on education and innovation and an open world where the strength invariably overcomes the zero-sum countries and alliances that pepper the planet and always have. A vision of winners and losers invariably begets more winners and losers
column7: and little else.

column1: Zachary Karabell is head of global strategy at Envestnet and author of The Leading Indicators: A Short History of the Numbers That Rule Our World. column1: (CNN) Kevin Johnson -- the NBA star-turned-Sacramento mayor -- was pied in the face by a man at a charity dinner Wednesday night at the high school he once attended.
But the pie-thrower appeared to get the worst of it.
Sean Thompson
column3: approached the mayor
column4: pulled a pie out of the bag and shoving it in his face -- setting off a short scuffle
column5: in which Johnson punched Thompson in the face several times
column6: according to witnesses descriptions of the scuffle in local media reports

column1: There was an altercation that occurred after he got the pie in the face
column2: Sgt. Bryce Heinlein
column3: a Sacramento police spokesman
column4: told CNN.

column1: There were some punches thrown
column2: and then the subject was quickly taken to the ground by one of the officers that is on the mayor's security detail"" and some event attendees
column3: Heinlein said.

398	"""He didn't ask her about a lot of things she should have been asked about
column2: Donald Trump said about Lester Holt. | Getty Post-debate
column3: Trump team hits moderator Holt for 'some hostile questions'

column1: Donald Trump and his campaign complained Tuesday morning that debate moderator Lester Holt targeted him for unfair questioning while neglecting to ask Hillary Clinton about any of her various scandals.
“They were leaving all of her little goodies out. They didn't ask her about
column2: you know
column3: much
column4: ” Trump said on Fox News’s “Fox and Friends.” “But I was asked about my tax returns
column5: which I've told about 500 times. But
column6: you know
column7: I think I did — I think I really did well when we were asked normal questions. I think I did really well in answering those questions
column8: but those questions are not answerable in a positive light.”

column1: Story Continued Below
Still
column2: Trump was upbeat overall about the debate
column3: which he said “went really well” despite “some hostile questions.” The Manhattan billionaire gave Holt a C+ for his performance as moderator
column4: praising him for his issue-based questions in the first 45 minutes of the debate but attacking him as biased for a series of more direct questions about a housing discrimination lawsuit filed against Trump’s real estate company in the 1970s
column5: even though it was Clinton who brought up the Justice Department lawsuit.

column1: “I didn’t think he did a bad job. You know
column2: when you look at it
column3: you watch the last four questions
column4: he hit me on birther
column5: he hit he on a housing deal from many years ago that I settled with no recourse and no guilt. He asked me about that
column6: ” Trump said. “That's a beauty to be asked
column7: you know
column8: 40-year-old lawsuit
column9: or older. I just hate to say it’s older because then you’ll know
column10: then [Fox News anchor Ainsley Earhardt] will say “’Wow I didn’t know Trump was that old.’ Hey
column11: she’ll be unimpressed.”

column1: “Well
column2: he didn't ask her about the emails at all. He didn't ask her about her scandals. He didn't ask her about the Benghazi deal that she destroyed
column3: ” he said. “He didn't ask her about a lot of things she should have been asked about. I mean
column4: you know
column5: there's no question about it. He didn't ask about her foundation.”

column1: Attacking Holt became a running theme from Trump's campaign Tuesday morning
column2: as both his running mate and campaign manager took to the morning shows to criticize the moderator.

column1: I was disappointed that Lester did not get into some of the issues that had been in so much of the forefront of Hillary Clinton’s candidacy – the FBI investigation
column2: pay to play
column3: the whole disastrous events that took place in Benghazi and Libya – that never came up
column4: GOP vice presidential candidate Mike Pence said on Good Morning America.

column1: Trump's campaign manager Kellyanne Conway took a similar line
column2: saying on CNN Tuesday that there were topics she wished Holt would have raised.

column1: “I just would have liked to have heard more about Benghazi or e-mails or the Clinton foundation since these are very clearly in the news
column2: she said. ""You know
column3: one of our guests last night was Mark Geist
column4: not Mark Cuban
column5: Mark Geist
column6: who's a Benghazi hero and survivor. And You know
column7: he was within several feet or yards of them and I think it's a good reminder to be Americans of what her record is on that particular issue.""

column1: While the Republican nominee insisted that he had outperformed Clinton at the debate
column2: he said that he struggled throughout the night with a defective microphone that made him difficult to hear for the audience in the debate hall. Trump suggested that perhaps his microphone
column3: which he said worked perfectly earlier in the day
column4: had been tampered with.

column1: “I had a problem with a microphone that didn't work. I don’t know if you saw that in the room
column2: but my microphone was terrible. I wonder
column3: was it set up that way on purpose
column4: ” he said. “My microphone
column5: in the room they couldn't hear me
column6: you know
column7: it was going on and off. Which isn't exactly great. I wonder if it was set up that way
column8: but it was terrible.”

column1: Asked if Clinton had successfully managed to get under his skin during their 90-minute back-and-forth
column2: Trump said she had not until the end of the debate
column3: when the former secretary of state brought up Miss Universe winner Alicia Machado
column4: who Trump called “Miss Piggy” and “Miss Housekeeping” because of her Latin heritage. Addressing Trump directly about the name-calling
column5: Clinton said
column6: “Donald
column7: she has a name. Her name is Alicia Machado. And she has become a US citizen and you can bet she is going to vote this November.""

column1: “I know that person
column2: that person was a Miss Universe person
column3: and she was the worst we ever had. The worst
column4: the absolute worst. She was impossible
column5: and she was a Miss Universe contestant and ultimately a winner who they had a tremendously difficult time with as Miss Universe
column6: ” he said. “She was the winner
column7: and
column8: you know
column9: she gained a massive amount of weight
column10: and it was a real problem. We had a real problem. Not only that
column11: her attitude
column12: and we had a real problem with her
column13: so Hillary went back into the years and she found this girl. This was many years ago
column14: and found the girl and talked about her like she was mother Teresa and it wasn't quite that way
column15: but that's okay. Hillary has to do what she has to do.”

column1: 399	"Story highlights Bush will deliver his first lecture on Thursday
He is a staunch advocate for charter schools
column2: voucher programs and higher education standards

column1: (CNN) Jeb Bush will be a guest lecturer at Harvard University this fall
column2: focusing on education in ""a number of multi-day visits"" this semester
column3: the John F. Kennedy School of Government announced Tuesday.

column1: The former Florida governor and Republican presidential candidate -- who was known for his wonkish love of policy on the campaign trail -- will deliver his first lecture on Thursday.
He'll also co-lecture in a course titled
column2: ""The Political Economy of the School
column3: and participate in faculty-led student study groups.

column1: After dropping out of the presidential race in February
column2: Bush returned to his position as chairman and president of the board of directors at an organization he started called the Foundation for Excellence in Education.

column1: Bush -- a staunch advocate for charter schools
column2: voucher programs and higher education standards -- attempted to make education a defining hallmark of his presidential campaign.

400	"Hillary Clinton said this year's election will impact the next 50 years of America. | AP Photo Clinton: ‘The next 50 days will determine the next 50 years’
Hillary Clinton on Tuesday warned that the nearly 50-day sprint to Election Day will impact far more than just the next four or eight years.
Making an appeal to black voters during an interview on the “Steve Harvey Morning Show
column2: ” Clinton stressed that voters can’t sit this one out.

column1: Story Continued Below
“Every issue they care about is at stake in this election
column2: ” Clinton said. “This is not: ‘Oh
column3: you know
column4: a little here
column5: a little there. We can — you know
column6: we can take it
column7: no matter who wins.’ No. The next 50 days will determine the next 50 years
column8: and I say that absolutely seriously.”

column1: The former secretary of state said she hopes everyone is registered to vote and directed listeners to a website to find out whether they’re registered “because I need you.”
“We gotta stand up and be counted in this election
column2: ” she added.

column1: Clinton’s comments come after President Barack Obama made an appeal on Clinton's and his own behalf in an address to the Congressional Black Caucus Foundation on Saturday.
“My name may not be on the ballot
column2: but our progress is on the ballot
column3: ” Obama said. “Tolerance is on the ballot. Democracy is on the ballot. Justice is on the ballot. Good schools are on the ballot. Ending mass incarceration
column4: that’s on the ballot right now.”

column1: But up next on the docket is the first presidential debate between Clinton and Trump on Monday in New York
column2: where the former senator expects to absorb a bunch of body blows from an aggressive foe.

column1: “I am going to do my very best to communicate as clearly and fearlessly as I can in the face of the insults and the attacks and the bullying and bigotry that we’ve seen coming from my opponent
column2: ” she said. “You know
column3: I can take it
column4: Steve. I can take that kind of stuff. I’ve been at this and
column5: you know
column6: I understand it’s a contact sport.”

column1: What Clinton won’t take
column2: though
column3: is any insults toward anyone else. “You know
column4: his attacks on African-Americans and immigrants and Muslims and women and people with disabilities
column5: it’s just — it’s just something we cannot tolerate
column6: ” she said.

column1: As Clinton wrapped up her interview
column2: Trump taunted her on Twitter: “Hillary Clinton is taking the day off again
column3: she needs the rest. Sleep well Hillary — see you at the debate!”

401	"Story highlights A final lab test of ISIS weapon fired on US troops tested negative for mustard agent
US forces were fired on last week by ISIS
column2: initial tests showed a chemical weapon was used

column1: Washington (CNN) The American-led military coalition against ISIS said Tuesday that a final laboratory test of the weapon ISIS fired at a US-Iraqi base in northern Iraq last week did not contain a mustard agent as earlier believed.
Col. John Dorrian
column2: a spokesperson for the anti-ISIS coalition
column3: tweeted that ""definitive"" lab results show the munitions that hit Qayyara air base on September 20 was not a chemical weapon.

column1: Definitive lab tests conclude: No mustard agent present in munitions fired at Qayyarah West AB Sept 20. #Daesh #ISIL — OIR Spokesman (@OIRSpox) September 27
Initial field tests of what has been described as either a rocket or artillery shell did indeed test positive for the chemical weapon and US personnel were required to undergo decontamination.
Last week
column2: the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff
column3: Gen. Joseph Dunford
column4: told the Senate Armed Services Committee that ""we assess it to be a sulfur mustard blister agent"" when asked about the attack.

column1: Military officials had told CNN that a second test of the weapon had produced negative results while a third lab test was inconclusive. The most recent test announced by Dorrian represents the final test of the weapon.

402	"The pressure is on Hillary Clinton.
Insiders in both parties agree: Clinton
column2: having lost most of her lead over the past few weeks and bringing more experience to the stage
column3: faces higher expectations than Donald Trump when the two square off for the first debate on Long Island.

column1: Story Continued Below
That’s according to The POLITICO Caucus — a panel of activists
column2: strategists and operatives in 11 key battleground states. Roughly equal percentages of Democrats (69 percent) and Republicans (74 percent) said Clinton is under more pressure to perform than Trump. But Democrats mostly lamented the low expectations for Trump
column3: a relative political neophyte who has exhibited little command of the issues.

column1: “She shouldn't be [under more pressure]
column2: but so long as he avoids standing on stage and vomiting on himself
column3: the press will give Trump a glowing review
column4: ” said a Nevada Democrat — who
column5: like all respondents
column6: completed the survey anonymously. “Hillary will need a strong performance to demonstrate that she passes and Trump fails the commander-in-chief test.”

column1: “The media and Trump himself have set the bar too low for Trump
column2: ” a New Hampshire Democrat added. “Presidents don't get graded on a curve
column3: and candidates in debates shouldn't be either.”

column1: One Ohio Democrat detected a double standard for the first female major-party nominee.
“Hillary Clinton has spent a public lifetime of being held to a strikingly different standard
column2: and this debate will be no exception
column3: ” said the Ohio Democrat. “She will have to answer every single question flawlessly
column4: exude gravitas
column5: look presidential
column6: channel Bill's and Barack's oratorical mastery
column7: not raise her voice
column8: not cough
column9: wear an acceptable pantsuit
column10: smile enough
column11: be likable
column12: not laugh and have a good hair day. Donald Trump will just have to show up.”

column1: Republicans also said Clinton was under greater scrutiny on Monday night
column2: but for different reasons: tightening polls that show Trump eclipsing Clinton in some battleground states.

column1: “Somehow she needs to reverse the trend
column2: ” said an Ohio Republican. “Never seen anyone do it before. This will be her chance — and maybe her last chance.”

column1: “She has to stop [Trump’s] momentum with a strong debate performance
column2: and she has to be able to stand on the stage for 90 minutes and look healthy for 90 minutes or the whole issue of her health comes back with a vengeance
column3: ” added a Virginia Republican. “All [Trump] has to do is not say anything racist or sexist and look like he could be president.”

column1: Among those insiders who said Trump was under more pressure — 31 percent of Democrats and 26 percent of Republicans — most pointed to the GOP nominee’s volatile personality.
“Hillary Clinton is expected to do well. She is a policy wonk
column2: ” said a Michigan Republican. “The pressure is on Donald Trump not to lose his cool. He has been doing very well in his public appearances
column3: but that is with the assistance of a TelePrompTer. He will have no such help at the debate
column4: and if I were coaching Hillary Clinton
column5: I would be encouraging her to get him as riled up as possible. To win the debate
column6: all Trump really needs to do is meet expectations
column7: keep his cool
column8: and look presidential.”

column1: “The question we are all waiting to have answered is: Can he be serious?” added a Michigan Democrat. “Can he answer questions directly? How will he react (or overreact) when he is directly challenged? Can he control his temper?”
Two other takeaways from the pre-debate survey:
Most insiders expect Clinton to “win” the debate.
Majorities in both parties peg Clinton as most likely to be the victor on Monday night: 76 percent of Democrats and 59 percent of Republicans.
“Media look at who best answered questions
column2: and that will likely be Hillary
column3: ” said an Iowa Republican.

column1: “[Clinton’s] mastery of issues and policies and no-nonsense delivery will prevail over bluster
column2: name-calling and promises that can never be kept
column3: ” added a New Hampshire Democrat.

column1: But not all Democrats were so optimistic about Clinton — or the media through which voters will interpret the debate.
“The press wants Trump to win
column2: ” said a Florida Democrat. “Their disdain for her
column3: plus desire to keep the race alive
column4: means unless he really screws up
column5: they'll give him the win on the most absurd grade curve ever.”

column1: Some Republicans also claimed media bias — in the other direction.
“The media has never been more in the tank for a candidate in modern history: CNN
column2: NBC
column3: ABC and POLITICO will all say she won
column4: ” a Virginia Republican said. “But then again everyone also 'knew' that Carter beat Reagan in their debate as well.”

column1: Insiders think the debate will matter.
Asked whether they expect the debate to have a significant impact on the race
column2: most insiders in both parties think it will generate momentum for one of the candidates.

column1: Among Democratic insiders
column2: 66 percent believe Clinton will benefit from the debate
column3: 11 percent think Trump will get a bounce and 23 percent don’t expect the debate to move the needle.

column1: “Trump will flounder
column2: ramble and lie (because he always does)
column3: ” a Michigan Democrat predicted. “The moderators will challenge him
column4: and he'll get mad. He'll complain afterwards that they picked on him and favored Hillary. First impressions are hard to shake off
column5: and this won't go well for him.”

column1: The numbers were flipped for Republicans
column2: with slightly less enthusiasm for the GOP standard-bearer: 52 percent think the debate will help Trump
column3: 26 percent think it will help Clinton and 22 percent said it wouldn’t have a significant impact.

column1: “Trump has the most to gain by appearing presidential and even-tempered
column2: ” said a New Hampshire Republican. “He does that successfully
column3: and he cuts into Hillary's greatest strength.”

column1: But some Republicans said Clinton could stunt Trump’s momentum with a strong performance Monday night.
“If she pins his ears back
column2: [it helps her]
column3: ” said an Iowa Republican. “If it's a draw
column4: it's a net negative for her. She has to have something to stop his momentum. She's got to hit him with a brick.”

column1: Other insiders
column2: however
column3: doubted whether the debate would have a significant
column4: permanent effect on the race.

column1: “We're past the era of the big debate swings: the bloodless Dukakis death penalty answer
column2: the Reagan age quip
column3: the Bentsen 'you're no John Kennedy' moments
column4: ” an Iowa Republican said. “Swing voters are like the California Condor
column5: a critically endangered species disappearing at an alarming rate. Opinion media
column6: partisan polarization
column7: and two highly unpopular candidates make this a battle over a very small group of voters in about a dozen states
column8: and whatever bounce comes out of this debate will dissipate as quickly as it appears.”

column1: Added a Florida Democrat: “Does a damn thing matter this year? I think not.”
These are the members of The POLITICO Caucus
column2: not all of whom participated in this special survey:

403	"CLEVELAND — Donald Trump campaigned Wednesday morning in a church in a historically African-American community and sold himself as the candidate who could fix the problems of urban America. Within hours
column2: Trump was proposing a vast expansion of “stop-and-frisk” policing policies that have proved explosively controversial in black communities for encouraging racial profiling.

column1: It was just another day in Trump’s up-and-down black outreach campaign undertaken to wash away the stain of racism charges lobbed at him by Hillary Clinton and the Democrats.
Story Continued Below
The effort has taken Trump from a black church in inner-city Detroit earlier this month to addressing largely white audiences in rural North Carolina where
column2: on Tuesday evening
column3: he proclaimed in a small town named after a slaveholder that black communities ""are absolutely in the worst shape that they’ve ever been in before
column4: ever
column5: ever
column6: ever.""

column1: On Wednesday
column2: Trump hit the campaign trail with former boxing promoter Don King — who dropped the N-word before a group of pastors at a Cleveland church while extolling Trump as a “gladiator.” King hailed Trump as the rare candidate who would overthrow the existing political system under which minorities have suffered.

column1: “The system is the problem
column2: and he’s the only gladiator that will take on the system
column3: ” King said.

column1: After the church event
column2: Trump sat for a “town hall” with Fox News host and unabashed supporter Sean Hannity. Asked by an audience member what he would do to address “violence in the black community
column3: ” Trump embraced stop-and-frisk.

column1: “We did it in New York
column2: it worked incredibly well
column3: ” Trump said.

column1: Fierce opposition to that policy in minority communities was among the issues that Bill de Blasio rode to prominence and
column2: ultimately
column3: the mayor’s office.

column1: But even before Trump’s stop-and-frisk comments
column2: he was taking heat for his “ever
column3: ever
column4: ever” remark Tuesday night.

column1: “I don't know what Mr. Trump is talking about to say that the situation for African-Americans is worse than it's ever been
column2: ” Rep. John Lewis
column3: the Democratic civil rights icon
column4: said Wednesday on MSNBC. “Is he talking about worse than slavery? Worse than the system of segregation and racial discrimination — when we couldn't take a seat at the lunch counter and be served? Worse than being denied the right to register to vote
column5: to participate in the democratic process and live in certain neighborhoods and communities?”

column1: Trump’s polling numbers among African-American voters have been dismal — in the low single digits — and some believe his outreach to black voters is as much about convincing moderate white voters
column2: particularly women and those in the suburbs
column3: that he is not racist. Trump regularly brings up his outreach to blacks — “What do you have to lose?” he says — to largely white audiences.

column1: At the New Spirit Revival Center in Cleveland
column2: Trump assembled an eclectic kitchen cabinet of some of his closest advisers to attest to his beliefs before a diverse crowd.

column1: Seated to Trump’s right was Mike Pence
column2: his soft-spoken running mate. To his left
column3: outspoken longtime attorney Michael Cohen. Behind him: King (“there’s only one
column4: ” Trump said)
column5: former presidential rival Ben Carson (“tough”)
column6: retired Lt. Gen. Michael Flynn (“a tough general”) and former ""Apprentice"" star Omarosa Manigault (“a wonderful woman”)
column7: who has helped with Trump’s black outreach.

column1: “I’m different from a lot of Republicans
column2: frankly
column3: ” Trump said from the pulpit.

column1: Trump
column2: who has called himself the “law and order” candidate
column3: criticized the police officer who shot an unarmed black man in Oklahoma last week. Trump said he had watched the video and that the officer may have been “choking” in the fatal shooting. Trump has mostly defended the police in such incidents.

column1: Now
column2: did she get scared? Was she choking? What happened? But maybe people like that
column3: people that choke
column4: people that do that
column5: maybe they can't be doing what they're doing
column6: OK?”

column1: King
column2: whom top GOP officials had pushed not to speak at the Republican National Convention due to a past manslaughter conviction
column3: was given the prime slot of introducing Trump at a forum billed as a pastors leadership conference.

column1: King
column2: clothed in a sparkling jacket and clutching the flags of Israel and the United States
column3: argued repeatedly that “the system” had oppressed minorities and women and only Trump can upend it entirely.

column1: “Every white woman should cast a vote for Donald Trump
column2: ” said King
column3: who also went on an extended riff about the struggles of African-Americans.

column1: “I told Michael Jackson
column2: I said if you're poor
column3: you're a poor Negro — I would use the N-word — but if you rich
column4: you are a rich Negro; if you are intelligent
column5: intellectual
column6: you're an intellectual Negro; if you're a dancing and sliding and gliding n-----
column7: I mean
column8: Negro
column9: ” King said.

column1: When Trump took his turn at the pulpit minutes later
column2: he grinned
column3: “Ah
column4: there’s only one Don King.”

column1: Before King
column2: Cohen
column3: Trump’s attorney
column4: used his time at the church to slash at the “disgusting
column5: liberal
column6: mainstream media” and its casting of Trump as a “racist.”

column1: “The word of the 2016 election has somehow become ‘racist
column2: ’” Cohen complained. “I’ve lost count as to how many times the disgusting
column3: liberal
column4: mainstream media have attempted to label Mr. Donald Trump as racist
column5: a xenophobe and a bigot. And let’s not forget
column6: sexist
column7: misogynist
column8: narcissist
column9: Islamophobe
column10: anti-Hispanic
column11: anti-Semite demagogue. And countless others. It’s disgraceful.”

column1: Cohen said
column2: “Not only is Donald Trump not a racist
column3: he believes that all people are part of one race: the human race.”

column1: Trump insisted that Democrats had abandoned black voters
column2: and that he wouldn’t.

column1: “They come and they take your vote
column2: ” Trump said
column3: “and they say they’ll see you in four years.”

column1: Ahmad Khan Rahami is taken into custody after a shootout with police Monday in Linden
column2: N.J. | Nicolaus Czarnecki/Boston Herald via AP U.S. attorney sees no rush to arraign Rahami in federal court

column1: Federal prosecutors are pushing back against a demand by defense lawyers that New York and New Jersey bombing suspect Ahmad Rahami be arraigned immediately on federal charges he is facing.
Late Tuesday
column2: defense attorneys wrote to federal magistrate judge Gabriel Gorenstein asking that Rahami be promptly informed of the charges against him at a court proceeding that would also formally advise him of his right to counsel and his right to remain silent.

column1: However
column2: prosecutors from the office of U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York Preet Bharara said in a letter to the magistrate Wednesday that Rahami isn't in federal custody so there is no legal obligation for the federal courts to get involved.

column1: The defendant in this case
column2: Ahmad Khan Rahami
column3: a/k/a 'Ahmad Rahimi
column4: ' has not been arrested on any federal charge. He is not in federal custody. He is in the custody of the State of New Jersey
column5: on state charges
column6: and is subject to a bail package issued by the New Jersey state court
column7: federal prosecutors wrote. ""While a writ of habeas corpus ad prosequendum has been lodged with the United States Marshals Service
column8: it has not been executed
column9: and there has been no such federal arrest.""

column1: The writ referred to in the federal prosecutors' letter would require state or local officials to hand over Rahami to federal authorities for prosecution. Rahami is facing five attempted murder charges in a New Jersey court in connection with a shootout Monday morning in which the suspect and two police officers were wounded. Rahami is currently in a Newark hospital. A judge has set $5.2 million bail and an initial county court appearance for Sept. 28.
Defense lawyers contend that Rahami has been ""without the benefit of counsel"" since his arrest
column2: but it's unclear whether he's been advised of his Miranda rights or whether he's made some decision not to meet with an attorney. Lawmakers briefed on the investigation say he has not been cooperating.

column1: While Attorney General Loretta Lynch said Wednesday that Rahami would be taken to Manhattan in the ""near future
column2: the letter from prosecutors evinces no urgency to such a move. Prosecutors say Rahami has no rights in the federal system at the moment
column3: including a right to counsel.

column1: The letter indicates that lawyers from the Federal Defenders office in New York have sought appointment in Rahami's case
column2: but prosecutors say that's ""plainly premature"" until he is brought to court. Prosecutors cited a series of terrorism cases where judges ruled defendants were not entitled to court-appointed counsel until they appear in court.

column1: Court records show no immediate action from Gorenstein on the request for Rahami's arraignment or the defense lawyers' request to be appointed as his counsel in the case.
Josh Gerstein is a senior reporter for POLITICO.

405	"Conway: Trump will explain his Islamic State plan if asked
Donald Trump will detail his plan to destroy the Islamic State during Monday night’s debate against Hillary Clinton — if asked
column2: according to his campaign manager.

column1: Asked by Willie Geist during MSNBC’s “Morning Joe” whether Trump will offer specifics beyond his broad statement that he will “knock the hell out of ISIS
column2: ” Trump campaign manager Kellyanne Conway replied in the affirmative.

column1: Story Continued Below
“He certainly has a plan. I’ve heard it
column2: ” Conway said. “This is his debate tonight
column3: Willie
column4: he’ll tell you if that question is asked. But there’s also — you know
column5: people are just amazed that Hillary Clinton would put on her campaign website what her plan to defeat ISIS is. Is it that ISIS can’t read that plan?”

column1: Trump has vowed to “knock the hell out of ISIS” but has been mum on how he would do so
column2: suggesting that he doesn’t want to tip his hand to the terrorist network.

column1: Pressed by Geist and Mika Brzezinski on whether voters deserve to know details about his plan before they cast their votes
column2: or at least a sense that he has any “knowledge of the landscape
column3: ” Conway said
column4: “Yes
column5: and he’ll be happy to offer those specifics without telling the enemy exactly what we’re going to do.”

column1: “So just to put a button on it
column2: we’ll get the ISIS plan tonight in the debate?” Geist asked.

column1: “You will get his view of how best to defeat the enemy without telling ISIS particularly
column2: specifically what it’s going to be
column3: ” she said.

406	"U.S. women's soccer star Megan Rapinoe could face disciplinary action if she continues to kneel during the national anthem before games.
Despite an official statement from U.S. Soccer stating that both coaches and players are expected to stand at attention during the national anthem
column2: Rapinoe continued to kneel at the Sept. 18 game against the Netherlands
column3: protesting what she believes to be injustice and oppression in the United States.

column1: Rapinoe first began her protest in solidarity with San Francisco 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick
column2: who announced that he will not stand for the anthem as long as there is continued police brutality and racial prejudice in this country. His statements and actions have created a national movement
column3: with athletes like Rapinoe following in his footsteps.

column1: Popular Video This young teenage singer was shocked when Keith Urban invited her on stage at his concert. A few moments later
column2: he made her wildest dreams come true.

column1: Her actions in particular have angered U.S. Soccer
column2: which released a statement saying that her protest goes against everything the organization stands for.

column1: As part of the privilege to represent your country
column2: we have an expectation that our players and coaches will stand and honor our flag while the national anthem is played
column3: the statement reads in part
column4: according to ESPN.

column1: While she wasn't immediately punished for her protest
column2: ESPN reports that the situation will be re-evaluated if Rapinoe continues to kneel throughout the rest of the season.

column3: with one fan yelling
column4: ""Stand up!""

column1: 408	"Donna Brazile said Trump’s hectoring of America’s first black president about his birth certificate recalled for her and many others the nation’s painful past. | AP Photo Donna Brazile slams Trump for not apologizing for birther claims

Democratic National Committee interim chairwoman Donna Brazile said Donald Trump’s refusal to apologize for spearheading the so-called “birther” movement that questioned the citizenship of Barack Obama is a “wound that won't heal.”
Recalling her visit over the weekend the newly-opened National Museum of African-American History and Culture as well as her own family’s history
column2: Brazile said Trump’s hectoring of America’s first black president about his birth certificate recalled for her and many others the nation’s painful past.

column1: Story Continued Below
“Donald Trump should take just a walk through that museum and see what it means to have to produce papers. I mean
column2: my ancestors could not get papers simply because they were brought here as slaves. And it took centuries before we could finally get papers
column3: ” she told CNN’s “New Day” Tuesday morning. “To bring this up over and over again
column4: and to smear the first black president of the United States
column5: Donald Trump should be ashamed of himself
column6: and he should apologize. I get emotional. I got a birth certificate. My parents had a birth certificate. My grandparents did not. My great grandparents did not.”

column1: The issue of Trump’s support for the birther movement was raised late in Monday night’s presidential debate by moderator Lester Holt
column2: who asked Trump what he would say to Americans hurt by his championing of the issue. As he did at a press conference two weeks ago
column3: Trump blamed Hillary Clinton and her associates for first raising the issue and took credit for bringing the matter to rest. To those who might have been offended
column4: the Manhattan billionaire said “Well
column5: I say nothing
column6: because I was able to get him to produce [his birth certificate].”

column1: Brazile admitted that the apology she wants from Trump is “not forthcoming
column2: so I know I'm speaking into the wild darkness of Donald Trump
column3: but I think he should be ashamed of himself to bring that up and to say -- and this is what he said
column4: ‘I'm the one who got him to produce the birth certificate.’ It's amazing.”

column1: “I think it's a shame we put the president of the United States through this. It's just awful. And every time we talk about it
column2: it's the wound. It’s the wound that won't heal
column3: ” she said. “And this is what Donald Trump should understand
column4: it's the wound that will never heal as long as people go out there and exploit what I call real racial pain and animus in this country.”
