409	"In March
column2: in a bold “Oh yeah?” moment during an interview with the Washington Post’s editorial board
column3: Donald Trump took the paper’s dare and revealed
column4: then and there
column5: his very short list of foreign policy advisers. There were just five
column6: though he said
column7: “I have quite a few more.” The list was a head-scratcher
column8: a random assortment of obscure and questionable pundits. One of the names
column9: offered without elaboration
column10: was
column11: “Carter Page
column12: PhD.”

column1: Who?
Story Continued Below
Reporters quickly Googling found that Page is the founder and managing partner of an investment fund called Global Energy Capital
column2: and that he claims to have years of experience investing in Russia and the energy sector. As for his connection to Trump
column3: when Page was reached for comment by the New York Times the day after Trump’s big reveal
column4: he said he had been sending policy memos to the campaign and the paper said he “will be advising Mr. Trump on energy policy and Russia.”

column1: This piqued my interest: I have been a Russia wonk for most of my adult life
column2: I spent years living and reporting from Moscow
column3: still go there regularly for reporting trips
column4: and am in touch with lots of friends there. And yet
column5: despite the tightly knit nature of the expat business community in Russia
column6: no one I spoke to had ever heard of Carter Page.

column1: “What’s this guy’s name?” says one former Western energy CEO who spent years in Russia
column2: and would have overlapped there with Page.

column1: “I had not heard of Carter Page before it came out in the media
column2: ” says another prominent Western businessman who has worked in the former Soviet Union for over two decades. “But I am getting a lot of emails from friends asking
column3: ‘Have you heard of this guy?’”

column1: “Strangely
column2: I've never heard of Carter Page until this Trump connection
column3: ” Bill Browder responded to me in an email. He was one of the biggest Western players in the Russian market until President Vladimir Putin turned on him and Browder became his fierce critic. “It's odd
column4: because I've heard of every other financier who was a player on Moscow at the time.”

column1: Someone
column2: apparently
column3: has heard of him: On Friday
column4: Yahoo News reported that Page was being probed by U.S. intelligence for purported back-channel ties to Russian leaders. The story resurfaced the name of a character who’d all but vanished from the campaign
column5: and reawakened questions about who
column6: exactly
column7: Trump was surrounding himself with.

column1: This has been a concern swirling around the outsider candidate since he began
column2: a real-estate developer with almost no serious Washington connections to tap for advice. “I’m going to surround myself only with the best and most serious people
column3: Trump famously told a Post reporter last summer about how he would staff his campaign. ""We want top-of-the-line professionals.” As the primaries unfolded
column4: it became increasingly obvious that Trump would need all the top-of-the-line help he could get when it came to foreign policy. In an interview with conservative radio host Hugh Hewitt
column5: Trump confused the Kurds with the Iranian Al-Quds Force
column6: couldn’t tell the difference between Hezbollah and Hamas
column7: and couldn’t recognize the name of the leader of ISIS. (In his defense
column8: Trump said that “Hugh was giving me name after name
column9: Arab name
column10: Arab name
column11: and there are few people anywhere
column12: anywhere
column13: that would have known those names.”) The Republican foreign policy specialists who would normally be a brain trust began slamming him in the press or publicly signing on to anti-Trump manifestos. And since they increasingly were fleeing the candidate
column14: who were the people who would line up to advise him instead? What would they be like?

column1: Enter Carter Page
column2: a 44-year-old Ph.D.
column3: and business school graduate who claims an expertise in Russia and energy
column4: yet who
column5: I quickly discovered
column6: was known by neither Russia experts nor energy experts nor Russian energy experts. (“I can poll any number of people involved in energy in Russia about Carter Page and they’ll say
column7: ‘Carter who? You mean Jimmy Carter?’” says one veteran Western investor in Russian energy.) Page also
column8: as I would be surprised to discover
column9: appears largely unknown to Trump’s own campaign.

column1: What I did find
column2: however
column3: is that while Page might not be helping Trump
column4: Trump has been a significant help to Page. Since being named by Trump as an adviser
column5: Page
column6: who has spent his career trying to put together energy deals in Russia and the former Soviet Union
column7: has finally begun to be noticed in the region. He is being treated in Russia as a person with potentially important ties in America. “He’s an extremely well-informed
column8: authoritative expert on Russia
column9: ” says Mikhail Leontiev
column10: a pro-Kremlin talking head and spokesman for Rosneft
column11: Russia’s state oil giant. “People really respect him in this industry. He’s a very serious guy
column12: and he has a good reputation.” According to the Yahoo report
column13: U.S. intelligence believes Page had an audience with top Russian officials—including Rosneft head Igor Sechin—during a summer trip to Moscow. From what I could find about him
column14: it’s hard to imagine he could have secured those meetings without that mention by Trump.

column1: Page has also been the subject of some breathless coverage in the American press. A March Bloomberg profile touted his “deep ties” with “executives at Gazprom
column2: ” the state-owned Russian gas giant
column3: whom he says he advised on some of its biggest deals of the past decade. Last month
column4: the Post ran a piece that was breathless in a different way
column5: casting him as a shadowy broker with potentially important ties in Russia
column6: some of them unsavory. The Yahoo story also portrays Page as a well-connected
column7: high-rolling businessman with “extensive business interests in Russia” and an office “around the corner from Trump Tower.”

column1: Page has fueled all this by making some remarkable statements
column2: including saying Putin is a better leader than President Barack Obama to a June closed-door meeting of foreign policy Brahmins in Washington. In July
column3: in Moscow
column4: he spoke at the New Economic School’s commencement ceremony
column5: a university that had hosted Obama just seven years ago. Page used the speech to slam the “hypocrisy” of American foreign policy in front of a Russian audience
column6: saying
column7: “Washington and other Western powers have impeded potential progress through their often hypocritical focus on ideas such as democratization
column8: inequality
column9: corruption and regime change.” He is now frequently quoted on Russian television
column10: which hails him as a “famous American economist” and “adviser to Donald Trump on questions of foreign policy.”

column1: All of which reveals something deeply strange about Trump: when he shoots from the hip
column2: his remarks do more than just whip up Twitter controversies. They also occasionally and unintentionally mint a new species of “insiders
column3: ” people who seem to be in Trump’s orbit but who may not have—and may never have had—any access to the gilded inner sanctum at all.

column1: But someone is paying attention. As I started looking into Page
column2: I began getting calls from two separate “corporate investigators” digging into what they claim are all kinds of shady connections Page has to all kinds of shady Russians. One is working on behalf of various unnamed Democratic donors; the other won’t say who turned him on to Page’s scent. Both claimed to me that the FBI was investigating Page for allegedly meeting with Igor Sechin and Sergei Ivanov
column3: who was until recently Putin’s chief of staff—both of whom are on the sanctions list—when Page was in Moscow in July for that speech.

column1: So the question continued to linger: Who is Carter Page?
I should tell you before we get any further that Page wouldn’t talk to me for this story. I called his fund and left messages
column2: both on the general line and his personal voice mail. I emailed him repeatedly. I asked the Trump campaign to put me in touch. I emailed the Bloomberg journalist who interviewed him
column3: who passed the request on. I even called Carter Page’s father in Poughkeepsie
column4: New York
column5: who told me he would ask his son to talk to me. But alas
column6: no dice.

column1: This was disappointing: No one who worked in Moscow when Page was there seemed to know who he was
column2: and I just wanted to talk to someone who did. At a certain point
column3: I just needed confirmation that he even existed.

column1: OK
column2: I thought. Try a different route. Maybe all these prominent Western businessmen who worked in Russia for decades didn’t know Page
column3: but maybe it was because some of them worked in different spheres of the Russian economy. He did
column4: after all
column5: have such an impressive résumé.

column1: Page’s biography on the website of his energy fund
column2: Global Energy Capital
column3: hits all the right notes. It was
column4: at first glance
column5: the résumé of an up-and-coming player in the opaque but lucrative Russian energy market. “He spent 7 years as an investment banker at Merrill Lynch in London
column6: Moscow and New York where he most recently served as Chief Operating Officer of the Energy and Power Group
column7: ” his bio reads. “He was involved in over $25 billion of transactions in the energy and power sector. He spent 3 years in Moscow where he was responsible for the opening of the Merrill office and was an advisor on key transactions for Gazprom
column8: RAO UES and others.”

column1: Those were some of the biggest energy deals of the 2000s
column2: and Page’s tenure in Merrill Lynch’s Moscow office
column3: from 2004 to 2007
column4: would have put him in the right place at the right time. He says he was part of the carving up of RAO UES
column5: a massive Russian electric power holding company. He told Bloomberg that he advised Gazprom when it bought a stake in the Sakhalin II oil and gas project. Those were huge
column6: huge things. If he were deeply involved
column7: he would definitely count as a player. And surely he left at least a trace in the records of those deals.

column1: So I called Ian Craig
column2: the CEO of Sakhalin Energy from 2004 to 2009
column3: who was doing the negotiations with Gazprom and stayed on as CEO after the deal went through. (It wasn’t really a deal
column4: to be clear: Sakhalin II was a large project in the Far East
column5: and Gazprom essentially elbowed its way into the project when the government forced the consortium to sell the gas giant a controlling stake.) But Craig said he didn’t know anyone named Carter Page. He was also surprised to hear about Merrill Lynch’s purported involvement in the deal. “I don’t think Merrill Lynch or anyone else was front-lining the negotiations
column6: because it was all done at the highest level
column7: because it was very political
column8: ” says Craig . “It closed at CEO level
column9: and eventually Putin himself signed off on it.”

column1: When I asked a prominent Western businessman
column2: who has worked in the former Soviet Union for over two decades and who is said to socialize with Sechin and other members of the Russian elite
column3: about Page’s claim to Bloomberg that he advised Gazprom on Sakhalin II
column4: he said
column5: “I rolled my eyes at that one.” (He
column6: too
column7: said he hadn’t heard of Page until Trump’s announcement.)

column1: Fine. OK. Maybe Page exaggerated a bit on that one. But what about the reorganization and privatization of RAO UES
column2: the Russian electricity giant? Maybe some of the Russians he worked with remembered a Carter Page?

column1: Turns out
column2: they did.

column1: “His nickname was stranichkin
column2: ” from the Russian word stranichka
column3: or “little page
column4: ” says Artem Torchinsky
column5: who met Page during the breakup of RAO UES. Torchinsky
column6: who was part of the company’s financial department
column7: worked alongside Page
column8: who
column9: at the time worked in Merrill Lynch’s Moscow office. It was 2007
column10: and Merrill Lynch was underwriting the sale of one part of RAO UES
column11: and Torchinsky was resentful of Page and the other Merrill Lynchers: Torchinsky and the in-house team did all the work
column12: and Page and his team would swoop in to give the presentation. They were the fancy Western window dressing. “It really irritated our team
column13: ” Torchinsky told me over Skype. “We worked around the clock
column14: and then they would come in and say something incomprehensible and we’d have to correct them. These guys didn’t know what they were talking about.” As for Page
column15: “He made no impression whatsoever. Whether he was there or not
column17: ” Torchinsky says. “When you’re dealing with a pro

column1: OK
column2: harsh. But then I talked to Page’s former boss
column3: former Russian Central Bank Chairman Sergei Aleksashenko
column4: who ran the Moscow office of Merrill Lynch for part of the time Page worked there. “He wasn’t great and he wasn’t terrible
column5: ” Aleksashenko says
column6: exasperated and confused by the interest of all these journalists pestering him for information about someone “without any special talents or accomplishments
column7: ” someone who was “a gray spot.” “What can you say about a person who in no way [is] exceptional?” he asked me.

column1: Page was a vice president at Merrill Lynch in Moscow
column2: which sounds senior but is a common title in the finance world; a big firm like Merrill Lynch might have thousands of VPs. In the Moscow office
column3: there were five ranks
column4: and VP was right in the middle. In effect
column5: it was “just the oldest of the youngest
column6: three from the bottom
column7: ” says Aleksashenko.

column1: When it came to finance
column2: Aleksashenko says
column3: Page “was not a specialist in any branches of finance or in any instruments.” When it came to energy
column4: Page and his team were
column5: according to Torchinsky
column6: “mildly speaking
column7: not competent in the field of energy.” And
column8: says Aleksashenko
column9: “judging by the drivel he spews on Russia
column10: you can tell he doesn’t really understand the topic.”

column1: Trump’s putative adviser on Russia and energy and foreign policy
column2: in other words
column3: “did not create the impression of someone who was intellectual or well-educated
column4: or someone who was in any way interested or knowledgeable in foreign policy
column5: ” says Aleksashenko.

column1: For the past few years
column2: Page has styled himself a foreign policy expert. He has written columns in Global Policy Journal
column3: a new peer-reviewed journal run out of Durham University. They are confoundingly written and make logically curious leaps. “In recent months
column4: renewed calls for equal justice have brought social tension across the United States after the killing of Michael Brown and Eric Garner by police officers in Missouri and New York respectively
column5: ” he wrote. “Although commonly overlooked
column6: the impact of other fatal mistakes by government officials in the foreign policy arena might vastly outweigh these tragic deaths in potentially catastrophic proportions.” He is the kind of thinker who writes that Kanye West’s “New Slaves” and the “artist’s creative work offers valuable ideas that could fundamentally improve the direction of U.S. foreign policy and world affairs” but does it by opening with a citation from the Oxford English Dictionary (“Slave; Pronunciation: /slāv/…”)
column7: roping in Adam Sandler
column8: William F. Buckley and Dick Cheney.

column1: His speech in Moscow’s New Economic School was a similar construction of empty spaces held together with repetition
column2: tautologies
column3: and abuses of the word “ironically.” “For the last 15 years
column4: I’ve been researching
column5: teaching
column6: and writing about fundamental trends in the world economy
column7: which have really continued to evolve in this period and in the years immediately preceding it
column8: ” he began. The video of the speech also suggests that after three years living there and a lifetime studying the place
column9: he couldn’t really speak Russian—he had to have his questions translated for him into English. Except to quote
column10: haltingly
column11: brokenly
column12: Vladimir Putin: “We never meddle in the internal political affairs of other countries. Unlike the USA.” Which is troubling for two reasons: that the adviser of a presidential candidate of a major party is criticizing America abroad by citing Putin
column13: and that the comment implied that he seemed to not know anything about anything going on in
column15: Syria or Ukraine.

column1: Page also managed to find his way into a fellowship at the Council on Foreign Relations
column2: where he cut a strange figure. Like other Westerners doing business in Russia
column3: Page took the view that Putin was not the blood-stained and corrupt tyrant some in the West imagine him to be
column4: defending him as a strong leader who brought order and prosperity to Russia. But unlike other entrepreneurial defenders of Putin
column5: people at the Council recall that Page was not particularly good at it. “He had a guilty-seeming style in making these arguments
column6: making it seem like he didn’t really want to engage
column7: ” one person from the Council says. His columns made the rounds and raised eyebrows. “That blog post about the slaves. That’s just … strange
column8: ” says the Council member.

column1: “He’s a nice guy
column2: but of the people that I know that have Russian foreign policy experience or access and contacts
column3: he wouldn’t be in the last decile
column4: but he’d be in the second-to-last decile
column5: ” says one American executive with experience in Russia and its energy sector. “You’d have to dip really far and wide to find a guy like Carter Page. I mean
column6: wow.”

column1: I should’ve just dropped the Carter Page story
column2: but in the months since Trump named him an adviser
column3: the campaign’s Russia connections have become a bigger and bigger issue. Fancy Bear
column4: who was probably a Russian hacker
column5: broke into the Democratic National Committee emails
column6: seemingly handed them over to Julian Assange
column7: who continues to leak the information in a way that is clearly designed to help one campaign and hurt the other. Trump’s second campaign manager
column8: Paul Manafort
column9: flamed out in August because of his shady business dealings with the pro-Kremlin side of Ukraine
column10: and Trump himself continues to say absurd things about Russia and Putin
column11: like publicly inviting the Russian government to continue hacking American servers. Washington was in full Hunt for Red October mode
column12: and it was all I could do to stay on Page’s trail
column13: which began to look more and more like an infinity sign.

column1: I was not the only one. Seemingly everyone I talked to had also talked to the Washington Post
column2: and then there were these corporate investigators who drew a dark and complex web of Page’s connections. Then there was Page
column3: praising Putin. I found myself juggling two mutually contradictory Page narratives: Was Page
column4: like Manafort
column5: followed by a long train of sordid dealings with dark and powerful players with deep pockets and deep resentments toward the West? This was the person described by the corporate investigators trying to whisper into my ear. Was Page a man wheeling and dealing in energy contracts with China and Turkmenistan
column6: who was a vehicle for the Kremlin to influence the American election? Was he a man who
column7: during a three-day trip to Moscow
column8: met with two of Russia’s most powerful men and was now being investigated for it?

column1: But it was hard to see that man when I actually talked to people who knew him. Page made his way into the financial sector as it ballooned in the early part of the past decade
column2: securing a spot at Merrill Lynch’s London and Moscow offices. Today
column3: he claims he was cozy with Gazprom executives; his former colleagues laugh at the suggestion. “No one let him into Gazprom
column4: ” Aleksashenko says. “He didn’t go shake [Gazprom chief Alexey] Miller’s hand. He made sure there were cars
column5: hotels and meetings for investors in London.” Another of Page’s colleagues from Merrill Lynch confirmed that Page’s role was simply arranging meetings between Gazprom and Western investors
column6: something normally done by analysts
column7: the lowest rank on the totem pole. “People organize meetings with Gazprom all the time
column8: ” the former colleague said. “He hosted these guys in New York City but they would have done this 10 times a year… I used to do this; it doesn’t require all that much skill. You just send out an email to 20 people saying Gazprom agreed to dinner at this place at 8 p.m.
column9: do you want to come? The main thing is just getting those two [Gazprom] guys to agree. But because they agreed doesn’t mean they’re close to him.”

column1: But the meetings did provide him with something else. “Gazprom didn’t need money at the time
column2: ” says the former colleague. “They were the most profitable company at the time. Their net profit was something like $36 billion a year. Their problem was not getting investors
column3: but figuring out how to spend money in a non-efficient way if you read between the lines. He was probably aware of that. He would have known how inefficient and wasteful the company is.” Page became an investor in the company
column4: and has
column5: according to filings
column6: advised other companies he’s worked for to invest in them.

column1: After Merrill Lynch
column2: Page tried to set up his own fund to invest in energy projects and called it Global Energy Capital. But he tried to do this in 2008
column3: and we know what happened to the markets in 2008. The fund is registered to his father’s address in Poughkeepsie; Page listed himself as “founder and managing partner
column4: ” even though the only other partner seemed to be Sergei Yatsenko
column5: who was once a mid-level executive at Gazprom. He also maintained a website and handed out business cards that listed a fancy Madison Avenue address—that’s the one “around the corner from Trump Tower”— which was actually the address of a co-working space.

column1: “That’s Carter Page
column2: ” says an American businessman who has spent nearly a decade working in Russia. “That’s what he’s been doing
column3: without any actual funding
column4: without any actual experience
column5: without any actual connections or core capabilities
column6: he’s been trying to throw together these deals. He’s always been operating at a level far beneath that at which business in Russia is done. I admire that
column7: it takes a lot of gumption.”

column1: In the interest of due diligence
column2: I also tried to run down the rumors being handed me by the corporate investigators: that Russia’s Alfa Bank paid for the trip as a favor to the Kremlin; that Page met with Sechin and Ivanov in Moscow; that he is now being investigated by the FBI for those meetings because Sechin and Ivanov were both sanctioned for Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

column1: “I don’t know this person
column2: ” said Pyotr Aven
column3: one of the two founders of Alfa Bank
column4: which is considered the Western Russian bank. Aven and his partner
column5: Mikhail Fridman
column6: have transferred much of their assets out of Russia and have been quite critical of Putin. As for who paid for Page’s trip
column7: Aven was no less irritated by the question. “I give them money
column8: I don’t know how they spend it
column9: who they invite
column10: when they invite them
column11: I have no idea
column12: ” he said of the New Economic School
column13: which hosted Page and of which Aven is the main benefactor. Exasperated by my questions
column15: “Don’t bring these Russian-style conspiracy theories to me.”

column1: “You are engaged in onanism
column2: ” said Leontiev
column3: the spokesman for Rosneft and Sechin when I asked him if Page had met with Sechin. “It’s bullshit. Just bullshit. You need to understand who Sechin is to even ask this question. It’s hard to have a meeting with him at all. It’s absurd.”

column1: As for the FBI investigation
column2: well
column3: it’s unclear. A State Department official who works on Russia sanctions but was not authorized to speak on the record told me that
column4: for one thing
column5: there is “no prohibition meeting with a designated [sanctioned] individual. Moreover
column6: sanctions violations are not criminal in nature and not enforced by the FBI. OFAC runs them.” He added
column7: “the story doesn't add up.” What does seem to have happened is that various U.S. intelligence agencies were looking into Page’s time in Moscow
column8: then briefed Senate minority leader
column9: Democrat Harry Reid
column10: who wrote a letter to FBI Director James Comey asking him to investigate
column11: among other things
column12: “whether a Trump advisor who has been highly critical of U.S. and European economic sanctions on Russia
column13: and who has conflicts of interest due to investments in Russian energy conglomerate Gazprom
column14: met with high-ranking sanctioned individuals while in Moscow in July of 2016
column15: well after Trump became the presumptive Republican nominee.”

column1: I got my next surprise when I called Stephen Miller
column2: Trump’s senior adviser. I caught him just as the Trump plane was about to take off
column3: and asked him the tired
column4: old question: Who is Carter Page?

column1: “Who?” says Miller
column2: and then went off the record to expound on his lack of involvement in the campaign.

column1: “He has no formal role in the campaign
column2: ” Hope Hicks texted responding to my question.

column1: Now my interest was piqued. There were whispers all over Washington that
column2: despite Hicks’s denial
column3: Page was not only still part of the Trump campaign
column4: but its conduit for Russian influence. Was he?

column1: One way to answer the question was to figure out how he even got on that list to begin with.
One source suggested to me that Richard Burt
column2: former U.S. ambassador to Germany
column3: START treaty negotiator
column4: and longtime lobbyist for Alfa Bank
column5: was the nexus. It was Burt who helped draft Trump’s foreign policy speech in April
column6: and had been advising the Trump campaign
column7: via Senator Jeff Sessions
column8: on foreign policy. But when I met Burt at his office at the McLarty Associates lobbying shop
column9: he looked at me and said he had never even met him. “The only person I talked to about Carter Page is this guy at the Washington Post
column10: ” Burt told me. “And I told him I’d never met the guy. Let me put it this way: if I have met him
column11: I’ve forgotten. He’s the former Merrill Lynch guy
column12: right?”

column1: Someone else told me that the Page connection was Rick Dearborn
column2: Sessions’ chief of staff
column3: who hired Page because Dearborn knew nothing about foreign policy but needed to put together a foreign policy staff for Trump’s Alexandria
column4: Virginia
column5: policy shop and he happened to know Page. But Dearborn wouldn’t return my calls
column6: and someone who once worked for that policy shop told me it was neither Dearborn nor Burt
column7: but campaign co-chair Sam Clovis who recruited Page. “If he was part of that original group of people
column8: I can say with 70 percent confidence it was Sam Clovis
column9: ” this person told me.

column1: “I’m not answering your questions
column2: ” Clovis told me. He refused to tell me if he was the one who found Page
column3: but Jason Miller
column4: the campaign’s other spokesperson
column5: says
column6: “Carter Page isn’t someone I’ve interacted with.” Which confirmed what a policy staffer on the Trump campaign told me: “Carter is a red herring
column7: not a Rasputin. He’s never met Trump
column8: never briefed him. He has zero influence
column9: none.”

column1: Was Page the shadowy messenger between the Kremlin and Trump Tower
column2: or was he the nebbishy
column3: not-very-successful man trying to profit from the arbitrage between what Trump said—he’s my adviser—and what his associates said—“Who?” Maybe I wasn’t doing this right
column4: and maybe everyone was lying to me
column5: but it was hard not to come to the conclusion that
column6: regardless of whatever game the Russians were running
column7: Page was firmly in the latter camp.

column1: “I don’t know about his Russia fund
column2: other than it’s never really materialized
column3: ” says the prominent player in the energy space whom Page has pitched on various energy projects. “Every conversation I’ve had with Carter has not been terribly serious. They’ve all been pie-in-the-sky ideas. There are usually issues with traction and execution capabilities.” He went on. “I couldn’t name a project that I could connect Carter’s name to
column4: any project that actually happened.”

column1: “I don’t know how he’s earned a living off this
column2: ” the energy player says
column3: “but I think he’s been trying to be an intermediary. If you hang around Russia long enough
column4: it’s sort of like a pinball machine
column5: something will hit you.”

column1: Strangely
column2: it was not a Russian pinball that hit him; it was Trump. According to the Trump policy adviser
column3: this winter
column4: Clovis began to draw up a list of people who could serve as policy advisers to the campaign and give it some intellectual and policy heft. At a time when established Republican foreign policy specialists were tripping over each other to get away from Trump
column5: “a lot of people came to Sam Clovis in February
column6: March
column7: and said
column8: ‘I want to be part of the team
column9: ’” says the Trump adviser. And that’s how it happened. “He’s just a guy on a list. Trump looked at the list and said
column10: ‘He’s an adviser.’ And now he’s milking it for all it’s worth.”

column1: Now
column2: someone whom no one in the field had ever heard of was suddenly a Very Important Person in Washington—or at least could plausibly market himself as one. “I was not aware of him at all until he was named to the campaign
column3: and even after that
column4: I had never heard of him
column5: ” one Russia specialist in Washington told me. He saw Page at a Washington roundtable in June for Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi
column6: and what he saw was a strange kind of person: one who was very differential to everyone there “in a way that someone who is junior would use it to network
column7: ” but who was dropping hints full of meaning to anyone who would listen—and be impressed. “He was saying he was planning to go to Moscow
column8: ” the Russia specialist recalls. “He didn’t say what he was going to do there
column9: but he created the impression that there could be some meaning to the trip.”

column1: According to a congressional leadership staffer familiar with the intelligence briefings on Page’s trip to Russia
column2: “the meetings did happen and that’s been established as a fact. I think the investigation is more what happened in them.” But it remained unclear
column3: the staffer told me unprompted
column4: what this even meant. “It’s not just did he met with them or not
column5: but now looking into the bigger question of what the hell is going on?” said the staffer. “Is he acting as a conduit in ways that are against America’s national security interests? Wittingly or un-
column6: I should add. It’s what’s hard to parse about this. Is he doing this with nefarious intent or is this just about guys who are thrilled to be living in a John le Carré novel? Or are they being played by much smarter people in the Kremlin?”

column1: This seems to be vintage Carter Page
column2: a man whose story never quite adds up
column3: as much as he tries to make the numbers work. But he’s also mastered the art of manipulating the distance between his story as it is and his story as he wants it to be
column4: playing on the uncertainty in between to make himself seem more successful
column5: more connected
column6: even more evil than he really is—and to try to turn a profit off of that. “If Page using his status as ‘Trump advisor’ for personal gain
column7: that’s another matter: Time for Page to join Twitter!” Michael McFaul
column8: former U.S. ambassador to Russia
column9: tweeted after news of the investigation broke. The Russians may be feeling out the Trump campaign via Page
column10: but Page must be loving every minute of it. After all
column11: meeting Russia’s energy czar is an impossible dream for a would-be investor struggling to make it in the world of Russian energy—but the dream entered the realm of the possible when Trump said three words in March: “Carter Page
column12: Ph.D.” Now Carter Page
column13: Ph.D.
column14: has found a perfect candidate to latch on to
column15: like a pilot fish feeding off the carnage wrought by the oblivious Trump shark.

column1: For months now
column2: the American press has been twisting itself in knots trying to explain men like Page and Manafort
column3: and
column4: through them
column5: to answer the questions of whether Putin is trying to destroy America by their hands
column6: and is Trump a Kremlin stooge or a just a useful idiot
column7: and is there even a difference?

column1: There doesn’t seem to be one in the world of Trump
column2: which in some ways resembles Putin’s: the waters of truth are muddy and deeply suggestive. And that is all that matters. Is Putin actually meddling in our election and undermining the foundations of Western democracy in a massive way
column3: or doing just enough to make us think he is
column4: and thereby acquiring powers he holds only because we believe him to have them? “I want to hope that this is connected with the growing influence and significance of Russia
column5: ” Putin says of the rumors of Russian meddling in the American election—as we in the media continue to squeegee them around
column6: rarely really getting closer to the truth
column7: and watching it disintegrate in our hands when we think we’ve finally grasped it.

410	"Story highlights Democratic vice presidential candidate Tim Kaine says third-party Libertarian candidates will lose
He acknowledged that he and Clinton will make a case to voters who may be considering Johnson
(CNN) Democratic vice presidential nominee Tim Kaine has a message for voters considering a third-party candidate: They're going to lose.
The argument against the ticket is
column2: I think
column3: everybody knows that they're not going to win
column4: Kaine said of the Gary Johnson and Bill Weld Libertarian ticket in an interview with Yahoo News' Katie Couric this week.

column1: Hillary Clinton's running mate pointed to the 2000 election as evidence that a protest vote for a third-party candidate can affect the outcome of the race -- and history.

My argument against the (Johnson-Weld) ticket is the Al Gore-George W. Bush race in 2000. The third party candidacy of Ralph Nader cost Gore electoral votes in New Hampshire and Florida. And if Gore had been president
column2: we probably wouldn't had a war in Iraq
column3: he said. ""Casting a vote
column4: a protest vote
column5: for a third-party candidate that's going to lose may well affect the outcome. It may well lead to a consequence that is deeply
column6: deeply troubling. That's not a speculation
column7: we've seen it in our country's history.""

411	"Story highlights Obams reaffirms US commitment to fighting ISIS
Obama praised the response from citizens in New York and New Jersey
New York (CNN) President Barack Obama worked to calm Americans' jitters Monday after a series of attempts at mass violence
column2: suggesting that yielding to fear amounted to a win for terrorists.

column1: During two appearances in New York
column2: Obama praised the swift work of law enforcement authorities looking into duel bomb attacks in New York and New Jersey over the weekend. And he urged Americans to follow the lead of residents here by not submitting to fear.

column1: I think it is important to remember what terrorists and violent extremists are trying to do. They are trying to hurt innocent people
column2: but they also want to inspire fear in all of us
column3: and disrupt the way we live to undermine our values
column4: Obama said. ""We all have a role to play as citizens in making sure that we don't succumb to that fear. And there is no better example of that than the people of New York and New Jersey.""

column1: Folks around here
column2: you know
column3: they don't get scared. They are tough
column4: they are resilient
column5: they go about their business every single day. And that kind of toughness and resoluteness and a recognition that neither individuals nor organizations like ISIL can ultimately undermine our way of life
column6: Obama said. ""That's the kind of strength that makes me so proud to be an American.""

column1: The President was speaking Monday morning from a hotel in midtown Manhattan
column2: where he's attending his final United Nations General Assembly meeting. Two miles south
column3: in Chelsea

412	"The Department of Homeland Security's inspector general said that 858 people who were ordered to be deported or removed instead eventually received citizenship. | AP Photo U.S. mistakenly granted citizenship to hundreds of immigrants
At least 858 people who had previously been ordered to be deported or removed from the U.S. were instead granted citizenship
column2: the Department of Homeland Security’s inspector general announced Monday.

column1: The mistaken citizenships were granted
column2: the Department of Homeland Security explained in a press release
column3: because neither its digital fingerprint repository nor the FBI’s fingerprint repository contain exhaustive records of individuals who have previously been deported.

column1: Story Continued Below
The discovery was made by the Department of Homeland Security’s office of inspector general
column2: which released a report Monday on the incomplete fingerprint records and the mistakenly granted citizenships. The Department of Homeland Security’s records are incomplete
column3: the release said
column4: because paper fingerprint cards used before 2008 were not consistently digitized. The FBI’s records are incomplete because fingerprints collected during immigration enforcement activities were not always shared with the bureau.

column1: The inspector general's report specified that those granted citizenship were only ""potentially"" ineligible and were not necessarily granted citizenship incorrectly. A statement from the Department of Homeland Security said that the department is taking steps to correct the issues that led to the incomplete fingerprint records and that not all applicants whose records were incomplete wound up being granted citizenship.

It is important to note that the fact that fingerprint records in these cases may have been incomplete at the time of the naturalization interview does not necessarily mean that the applicant was in fact granted naturalization
column2: or that the applicant obtained naturalization fraudulently. Preliminary results from the file reviews show that in a significant number of these cases naturalization had been denied and that
column3: in some
column4: naturalization was not improperly granted
column5: department spokesman Neema Hakim said in the statement. ""Other cases are subject to ongoing criminal investigation or to denaturalization proceedings that are pending or completed.""

column1: In at least three cases
column2: the inspector general’s office discovered previously-deported individuals who were granted citizenship and then obtained clearance for “security-sensitive work at commercial airports or maritime facilities and vessels.” The release said all three have since had their security credentials revoked.

column1: “This situation created opportunities for individuals to gain the rights and privileges of U.S. citizenship through fraud
column2: ” Inspector General John Roth said. “To prevent fraud and ensure thorough review of naturalization applications
column3: [U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services] needs access to these fingerprint records.”

column1: Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump has made the vetting of immigrants as they enter the U.S. a major part of his presidential platform
column2: suggesting during the GOP primary that America temporarily ban all Muslims from entering the U.S. until a more stringent vetting process could be put in place. He has since backed away from that proposal
column3: which drew widespread criticism from both parties
column4: in favor of a ban on immigration from “any nation that has been compromised by terrorism.”

413	"Milwaukee Sheriff David A. Clarke Jr. has been a fixture on Fox News in recent months
column2: appearing on multiple programs on that network to attack the Black Lives Matter movement
column3: which he has compared several times to international terrorists.

column1: Clarke has also been an outspoken supporter of Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump
column2: and is often one of the first names Trump backers bring up when attempting to highlight support for the candidate among black voters. Clarke spoke in support of Trump at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland this past summer.

column1: But while he was busy on the cable network attacking the black community
column2: a man died in the jail under his command. He reportedly died of thirst
column3: of all things.

column1: Terrill Thomas
column3: was found dead in a Milwaukee County Jail cell on April 24
column4: nine days after being arrested in connection with a shooting. Other inmates heard Thomas beg for water in the days before he died
column5: the Journal Sentinel reported in July. […] Last week the Milwaukee County medical examiner announced that Thomas’ death was due to profound dehydration
column6: according to the Journal Sentinel. By labeling the death a homicide
column7: the medical examiner indicated that it was caused by the actions of another person
column8: although that judgment does not necessarily mean that anyone will be criminally prosecuted in the case.

column1: Inmates at the jail say the water in Thomas’ jail cell had been cut off for 6 days
column2: and that one inmate warned jailers about the danger to the man’s life. Attorney Erik J. Heipt told the site that he has received calls from other inmates to tell him that the water had been cut off to their cells
column3: and another inmate died in 2011 when his water was cut off as well.

column1: Clarke is reportedly part of a pro-Trump bus tour arranged by a super PAC that is supporting the candidate.
The Huffington Post also reports that Clarke took in over $150
column2: 000 in 2015 from “speaking fees
column3: travel reimbursements and gifts.”

414	"Donald Trump's reputation for being always available to reporters is way out of date.
Trump is saying ""yes"" to Fox News almost every day but saying ""no"" to most other major networks and news organizations -- a highly unusual strategy for a presidential nominee.
He called into ""Fox & Friends"" on Monday morning
column2: he is booked on ""The O'Reilly Factor"" Monday night
column3: and he has another town hall with Sean Hannity coming up on Wednesday.

column1: Rousing the base instead of reaching out to undecided voters may ultimately pay off for Trump. If nothing else
column2: it limits the candidate's exposure to hard-hitting questions -- while fueling frustration among journalists.

column1: Trump's surrogates continue to say that he is more accessible than Hillary Clinton
column2: but that is no longer true.

column1: Newt Gingrich knocked Clinton at a Trump rally on Monday afternoon by saying ""she doesn't do press conferences."" But Clinton has taken questions from reporters at half a dozen press conferences in the past two weeks
column2: including as recently as Monday morning.

column1: These sessions
column2: while relatively short
column3: have been plentiful
column4: while Trump has not held a press conference since July.

column1: Trump beat reporters are starting to make noise about the drought — especially since Trump made Clinton's eight-month period without press conferences into a major campaign talking point.
It's been more than 50 days since Donald Trump held a press conference
column2: David Martosko of The Daily Mail tweeted Monday.

column1: Trump's recent TV appearances
column2: on ""The Dr. Oz Show"" and ""The Tonight Show
column3: made news
column4: but not in journalistic settings.

column1: The Washington Post's Robert Costa had a newsmaking interview with Trump last week. But that's the exception to the rule. The New York Times last had an interview with Trump about a month ago.
Trump last appeared on CNN in late August. Because Anderson Cooper challenged Trump about the candidate's muddled stance on immigration
column2: The Post's Callum Borchers concluded that ""it didn't go very well"" for Trump.

column1: It went so not well
column2: in fact
column3: that you have to wonder whether his campaign will decide it's best to dodge the likes of Anderson Cooper and Chuck Todd — or
column4: for that matter
column5: Chris Wallace and Bret Baier — and stick to softball sessions with Sean Hannity and the 'Fox & Friends' crew
column6: Borchers wrote afterwards.

column1: Trump's last time on NBC was the ""Commander in Chief Forum"" on September 7. Moderator Matt Lauer was widely criticized for his light touch with Trump.
Related: Behind the scenes
column2: NBC execs concede Matt Lauer forum performance was ""disaster""

column1: The candidate's last time on ABC was a short interview with David Muir on September 6. His last time on CBS was a ""60 Minutes"" sit-down with Lesley Stahl on July 17.
Trump does have another CBS interview in the works
column2: a campaign spokeswoman said.

column1: TV networks are agitating for more interviews with both Trump and Clinton. The difference between the two is that Trump previously had a reputation for calling in to morning shows and sitting down with interviewers all the time.
This accessibility also once extended to his traveling press corps.
Trump used to be very
column2: very accessible to the press. At the beginning of his campaign
column3: he was extremely accessible
column4: CNN politics reporter Jeremy Diamond said on Sunday's ""Reliable Sources."" ""You could catch him for quick interviews on the way in and out of rallies. And that has really changed.""

column1: Diamond said ""he is less accessible I think
column2: in many regards
column3: than Hillary Clinton at this point.""

column1: Trump's campaign declined to comment Monday on its media strategy. Republican communications strategist Ron Bonjean said most candidates in Trump's position would be ""trying to reach a a broader general election audience.""
However
column2: most Americans already know Trump as a household name and he doesn't need to diversify his interviews for additional exposure
column3: Bonjean said. ""Trump is protecting himself from less friendly journalists while getting out his message at the same time even if it is to a more conservative audience.""

column1: This conservative-focused media strategy is also gaining attention among Trump's critics. ""He pretty much exclusively appears on Fox News now
column2: Judd Legum
column3: editor of the liberal news site ThinkProgress
column4: tweeted on Monday.

column1: Trump's relationship with Hannity is perhaps the best symbol of how the candidate gets out his message on his own terms. Trump has taped numerous town halls with the conservative commentator.
According to TVNewser
column2: Wednesday's town hall will focus on ""issues and concerns surrounding African-Americans this election cycle.""

column1: According to Nielsen data
column2: only 1.5% of Hannity's 2 million nightly viewers are African American. Overall
column3: at any given time of day
column4: about 2% of Fox News viewers are African American."	donald trump reputation for being always available reporters way out date trump saying yes fox news almost every day but saying most other column2: several US military officials told CNN.

column1: Officials said they now think the personnel bombed may have been Syrian military prisoners
column2: according to several US defense officials.

column1: That's a working theory of how US
column2: British
column3: Danish and Australian aircraft may have incorrectly assessed intelligence and targeted the site that killed more than 60 Syrian personnel near Deir Ezzor in eastern Syria. The UK Ministry of Defence is saying it used drones in the strike.

column1: Officials emphasized there are no final conclusions by the US about who was struck. Overhead imagery and interviews with those involved will have to be assessed.
But the US is not disputing that Syrian personnel were hit. The US is trying to determine what specifically led to the mistaken strike and how the personnel may have been misidentified.

416	"""Donald
column2: you’re a sniveling coward
column3: Ted Cruz said in March. | Getty 9 times Ted Cruz insulted Donald Trump before endorsing him

column1: Two months after he was booed off the stage at the Republican National Convention for snubbing his party’s presidential nominee
column2: Sen. Ted Cruz endorsed Donald Trump on Friday.

column1: That declaration to vote for him
column2: though
column3: comes after the Texas senator openly disparaged his primary opponent repeatedly — in part responding to Trump’s attacks on his wife and father.

column1: Story Continued Below
1. Early on
column2: Cruz speculated that Trump’s tax returns could show a mob connection

column1: In February
column2: Cruz offered his take on why Trump hadn’t released his tax returns in an interview on NBC’s “Meet the Press
column3: ” suggesting that they might show “Donald's business dealings with the mob
column4: with the mafia.”

column1: “The fact that Donald seems terrified to release his taxes suggests that there’s a bombshell there
column2: ” Cruz said. “It’s natural to wonder
column3: ‘Well
column4: what is it that he's hiding in his taxes?’”

column1: 2. In March
column2: Cruz called him a “sniveling coward”

column1: Speaking to a group of reporters in Dane
column2: Wisconsin
column3: after Trump made a comment promising to “spill the beans” on the senator’s wife
column4: Cruz pointed his finger and said
column5: “Donald
column6: you’re a sniveling coward. Leave Heidi the hell alone.”

column1: “It’s not easy to tick me off. I don’t get angry often
column2: but you mess with my wife
column3: you mess with my kids
column4: that’ll do it every time
column5: ” Cruz said.

column1: 3. He also called Trump a “big
column2: loud New York bully”

column1: “Let me be absolutely clear: Our spouses and our children are off bounds
column2: ” Cruz said . “It is not acceptable for a big
column3: loud New York bully to attack my wife.”

column1: 4. Also
column2: “a small and petty man who is intimidated by strong women”

column1: Trump’s attacks
column2: Cruz suggested
column3: were actions of “a small and petty man who is intimidated by strong women.”

column1: 5. Cruz called one of Trump’s theories “nuts” and “just kooky”
In May
column2: after Trump cited a National Enquirer report that alleged Cruz’s father may have had some involvement in the assassination of President John F. Kennedy
column3: Cruz addressed reporters in Evansville
column4: Indiana: “This morning
column5: Donald Trump went on national television and attacked my father. Donald Trump alleges that my dad was involved in assassinating JFK. Now
column6: let’s be clear
column7: this is nuts. This is not a reasonable position. This is just kooky.”

column1: 6. He also called him a “pathological liar” who “lies practically every word that comes out of his mouth”
Also in Indiana
column2: on the same day the state's voters would deliver a decisive victory to Trump
column3: Cruz added : “I’m gonna tell you what I really think of Donald Trump: This man is a pathological liar. He doesn’t know the difference between truth and lies. He lies practically every word that comes out of his mouth
column4: and in a pattern that I think is straight out of a psychology textbook
column5: his response is to accuse everybody else of lying.”

column1: 7. And Cruz was specific with the term “pathological”: Trump is “utterly amoral
column2: ” he said

column1: “I say pathological because I actually think Donald
column2: if you hooked him up to a lie detector test
column3: he could say one thing in the morning
column4: one thing at noon and one thing in the evening
column5: all contradictory and he’d pass the lie detector test each time. Whatever lie he’s telling
column6: at that minute he believes it
column7: but the man is utterly amoral
column8: ” Cruz said .

column1: 8. And
column2: while he was at it
column3: Cruz accused him of narcissism and being a “serial philanderer”

column1: Continuing to unload in Indiana
column2: Cruz offered : “He combines [dishonesty] with being a narcissist
column3: a narcissist at a level I don’t think this country’s ever seen. Donald Trump is such a narcissist that Barack Obama looks at him and says
column4: ‘Dude
column5: what’s your problem?’’’

column1: And: “Donald Trump is a serial philanderer
column2: and he boasts about it. This is not a secret. He’s proud of being a serial philanderer.”

column1: 9. In July
column2: Cruz still hadn’t forgiven Trump for the attacks on his family

column1: “I am not in the habit of supporting people who attack my wife and attack my father
column2: ” Cruz said
column3: answering questions at a Texas delegation breakfast at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland and facing backlash for not yet endorsing Trump.

column1: Referring to his pledge to support his party’s nominee
column2: Cruz said that statement “was not a blanket commitment that if you slander and attack Heidi I'm going to nonetheless go like a servile puppy dog"" and support him.

417	"Bobby Knight: Nobody can 'correct mistakes' like Trump
Over the course of his 75 years on and off the basketball court
column2: Bobby Knight said Wednesday that he has never met anyone who can fix mistakes quite like Donald Trump.

column1: There’s nobody that I’ve met in my lifetime that has a better grasp of how to correct mistakes and how to look at what’s wrong and how to correct what’s wrong and how to get it going right
column2: Knight told an audience in Toledo
column3: Ohio
column4: his home state. ""And I think that is the most important thing that can be brought to the next president of the United States. And there’s nobody who has a better background in correcting things that are going wrong and getting things going in the right direction and developing those things — the best person ever has been Donald Trump.""

column1: Story Continued Below
Back on the campaign trail with Trump after several months
column2: Knight extolled the Republican nominee as ""not just an American; he’s a world figure.""

column1: He’s known all over the world. Donald Trump put a lot of businesses together
column2: the coach continued. ""United States around the world. A lot of businesses. Created a lot of jobs
column3: thousands of jobs for people around the world.""

column1: And Trump
column2: Knight later indicated
column3: is the person for the White House.

column1: Believe me when I tell you
column2: I think you’re all gonna agree on this: Our next president is gonna inherit a hell of a lot of problems
column3: and it’s gonna take a problem solver to get us back where we want to be and where we should be
column4: and there is no one that even comes close to being smart
column5: tough and dedicated completely to the United States of America
column6: Knight said. He noted that the next president would have to deal with the national debt
column7: ""immigration problems and on and on.""

column1: Remarking on his study of history
column2: Knight said that he had come to the conclusion that ""when I need somebody on my side to help us with problems
column3: he's the first man I want to choose and the first man I want to see.""

column1: Knight
column2: clad in a red
column3: white and blue gingham shirt
column4: acknowledged to the crowd that he doesn't ""dress as well as politicians dress
column5: but I want you to know
column6: and it’s for all of you folks
column7: I wore my red
column8: white and blue shirt today.""

column1: And I think that when you leave
column2: I hope you all go out and buy a red
column3: white and blue shirt
column4: because it’s indicative of your love for the greatest country in the world
column5: the United States
column6: Knight said.

column1: The deaths of black civilians in confrontations with the police has taken center stage in the election

Orlando (CNN) Hillary Clinton kicked off a campaign event Wednesday by saying that the recent police killings of two African-American men that unleashed a national uproar this week are ""unbearable"" and ""intolerable.""
Clinton used those words the day before to describe last week's shooting death of Terence Crutcher in Oklahoma
column2: but revisited the issue Wednesday in light of the death of Keith Lamont Scott in North Carolina. Her comments -- which came at the beginning of a lengthy speech about improving economic opportunities for disabled Americans -- marked her first on-camera remarks on the shootings
column3: which have again sparked a debate about lethal police force.

column1: There is still much we don't know yet about what happened in both incidents. But we do know that we have two more names to add to a list of African Americans killed by police officers in these encounters
column2: Clinton said. ""It's unbearable. And it needs to become intolerable.""

column1: The Democratic nominee added: ""I know I don't have all the answers. I don't know anyone who does. This
column2: though
column3: is certain: too many people have lost their lives who shouldn't have.""

column1: Even as she referred to the deaths as ""two very upsetting incidents
column2: Clinton also urged the public against channeling their anger by targeting police officers as she pointed to the protests that unfolded Tuesday night.

420	"Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump ushered the 2016 presidential campaign into a new phase tonight
column2: and they did it with plenty of barbs.

column1: The two candidates faced off in their first general election debate at Hofstra University in Long Island
column2: New York
column3: in front of what was expected to be a historic number of television viewers.

column1: Here are 10 moments that mattered at the first general election presidential debate:
1. Nominees Started Off on a Friendly Note but No Escaping the Sarcasm
Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump have lobbed insults at each other from far away for months
column2: but tonight they tried to start their highly anticipated face off on a genteel note
column3: although the mutual contempt was just below the surface.

column1: When Clinton walked out in a red pantsuit and Trump in a blue tie -- the opponents’ trading traditional party colors -- the two shook hands and Clinton said
column2: “How are you
column3: Donald?” Perhaps trying to throw him off at the top with a warm greeting.

column1: Shortly after the debate began
column2: Trump talked about overseas trade deals
column3: saying
column4: “But in all fairness to Secretary Clinton
column5: ” before stopping himself and turning to his opponent and saying
column6: “Yes
column7: is that OK? Good. I want you to be very happy. It's very important to me.”

column1: He seemed to be referring to his addressing her as “Secretary Clinton
column2: ” although it wasn’t completely clear during the moment.

column1: 2. Personal Attacks Came Early
Clinton was first to go on the attack during tonight’s debate
column2: taking aim at Trump’s business roots by claiming he borrowed $14 million from his father to start his real estate business.

column1: “Donald was very fortunate in his life and that's all to his benefit. He started his business with $14 million
column2: borrowed from his father
column3: and he really believes that the more you help wealthy people
column4: the better off we'll be and that everything will work out from there. I don't buy that. I have a different experience
column5: ” Clinton said
column6: before expanding on her father’s work as a drapery maker.

column1: Trump responded to that personal claim rather than addressing her subsequent remarks that he believes in “trumped up
column2: trickle-down” economics.

column1: “For one thing
column2: and before we start on that
column3: my father gave me a very small loan in 1975 and I built it into a company that's worth many
column4: many billions of dollars
column5: ” Trump said.

column1: 3. Trading Barbs Over Trade
Voters saw the first fiery moment of the debate when the two candidates sparred over the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal.
Trump accused Clinton of supporting TPP
column2: the proposed trade agreement between the United States and 11 other countries along the Pacific Rim.

column1: “And now you want to approve Trans-Pacific Partnership. You were totally in favor of it
column2: ” Trump said.

column1: Clinton fired back
column2: “Well
column3: that is just not accurate. I was against it once it was finally negotiated and the terms were laid out.”

column1: Trump then pointed to Clinton’s once referring to TPP as the “gold standard of trade deals.”
“Well
column2: Donald
column3: I know you live in your own reality
column4: but that is not the facts
column5: ” Clinton said.

column1: Clinton promoted TPP as secretary of state under President Obama
column2: who is pushing the trade deal. While speaking in Australia in November 15
column4: Clinton said
column5: ""TPP sets the gold standard in trade agreements to open free
column6: transparent
column7: fair trade
column8: the kind of environment that has the rule of law and a level playing field.” Clinton came out against the trade deal October of last year
column9: saying that “what I know about it as of today I am not in favor of what I have learned about it.”

column1: 4. Trump Asks ‘Why Not’ Blame All the World’s Problems on Clinton
Less than 30 minutes into the debate
column2: Trump went after Clinton
column3: attacking her on trade
column4: ISIS
column5: taxes
column6: the economy and more. Clinton quipped: ""I have a feeling by the end of this evening I'm going to be blamed for everything that's ever happened.”

column1: Trump didn’t miss a beat
column2: saying to his opponent: “Why not?”

column1: Clinton responded: ""Why not? Yeah. Why not? Just join the debate by saying more crazy things. Now
column2: let me say this—“

column1: Trump interjected: ""There's nothing crazy about not letting our companies bring their money back into the country
column2: ” before the moderator reminded Trump
column3: ""This is secretary Clinton's two minutes
column4: please.""

column1: Drew Angerer/Getty Images
5. Trump Hit Over Not Releasing Tax Returns
Trump clashed with his Democratic rival over his decision not to release his tax returns.
“I don't mind releasing. I'm under a routine audit and it will be released
column2: ” he said. Trump went on to tout his disclosure of a different federally mandated form required by the U.S. Office of Government Ethics of everyone from presidential candidates to the postmaster general.

column1: Trump then pivoted to attack Clinton over her private email server. “I will release my tax returns against my lawyer's wishes when she releases her 33
column2: 000 e-mails that have been deleted
column3: ” he said.

column1: “I think you've just seen another example of bait and switch here. For 40 years
column2: everyone running for president has release their tax returns
column3: ” she said. “You got to ask yourself: Why won't he release his tax returns?

column1: “Maybe he doesn't want the American people
column2: all of you watching tonight
column3: to know that he's paid nothing in federal taxes
column4: ” she said.

column1: 6. The Birther Issue Gets on the Main Stage
Moderator Lester Holt asked Trump “what took you so long” to acknowledge that President Obama was born in the United States
column2: bringing the Republican nominee’s recent turnaround on an issue that was central to his public positions for years.

column1: At first
column2: Trump claimed that two Clinton aides were the ones who initially looked into Barack Obama’s birth certificate during the 2008 campaign -- a claim that he has made before -- and then said that he was “satisfied” with when Obama released his birth certificate.

column1: Holt noted that Obama released his longform birth certificate in 2011
column2: but Trump continued to raise questions about it’s authenticity until 2015.

column1: “Nobody was pressing it
column2: nobody was caring much about it
column3: ” Trump said
column4: referencing the years between the release and Trump’s decision this month to acknowledge Obama was born in America. “I figured you'd ask the question tonight
column5: of course. But nobody was caring much about it. But I was the one that got him to produce the birth certificate
column6: and I think I did a good job.”

column1: Paul J. Richards/AFP/Getty Images
7. Clinton Defends Being ‘Prepared’ When Trump Questions Her Time Off the Trail
Trump was talking about crime in the inner cities when he said
column2: “I’ve been all over the place. You decided to stay home and that's OK
column3: ” seeming to jab Clinton for leaving the campaign trail in recent days to prepare for tonight’s faceoff.

column1: I think Donald just criticized me for preparing for this debate
column2: ” Clinton said. ""And
column3: yes
column4: I did. And you know what else I prepared for? I prepared to be president. And I think that's a good thing.”

column1: Throughout the debate
column2: Clinton tried to portray Trump as unprepared and unwilling to do the hard work to prepare for the presidency. She also hit back against an attack he regularly makes on the campaign trail: That she doesn't stump as much as he does because she doesn't have his endurance.

column1: 8. Stop and Frisk Becomes a Big Point of Discussion
Trump’s support of stop and frisk
column2: a controversial tactic once heavily used by the New York Police Department
column3: was discussed at length during the debate.

column1: “Stop and frisk had a tremendous impact on the safety of New York City. Tremendous beyond belief. So when you say it has no impact
column2: it really did
column3: it had a very very big impact
column4: ” Trump said.

column1: Trump said that the tactic was not deemed unconstitutional -- which it was -- and added instead that “it went before a judge who was a very against-police judge.”
“They would have won an appeal
column2: ” he said
column3: noting that there was no appeal.

column1: Trump and Clinton went on to debate various crime rates in cities like Chicago and New York for nearly 10 minutes of the debate.
9. Trump and the Iraq War Under the Microscope
Toward the end of the debate
column2: Holt corrected Trump on whether he supported the war in Iraq before it started.

column1: “I did not support the war in Iraq
column2: ” Trump said. ""That is a mainstream media nonsense put out by her because she frankly I think the best person in her campaign is mainstream media.”

column1: Holt corrected him
column2: saying
column3: “The record shows otherwise.”

column1: The only time Trump seems to have spoken about the war publicly before it started was to Howard Stern in 2002 and seemed to support the invasion. Stern asked Trump
column2: “Are you for invading Iraq?""

column1: Trump appeared to hesitate
column2: responding
column3: “Yeah
column4: I guess so. I wish the first time it was done correctly.”

column1: Despite the attempt to correct him
column2: Trump continued to stress he was against the war
column3: saying
column4: “The record shows that I am right.”

column1: 10. Sparring Over Stamina
Holt asked Trump about when he once said that Clinton does not have a “presidential look
column2: ” asking Trump what he meant by that. Trump pivoted to attack her “stamina.”

column1: She doesn't have the look
column2: she doesn’t have the stamina
column3: ” Trump said. ""I said she doesn't have the stamina. And I don't believe she does have the stamina. To be president of this country
column4: you need tremendous stamina.”

column1: Trump has been hitting Clinton on her stamina and strength on the campaign trail for months
column2: but tonight Clinton tried to shut that line of attack down.

column1: Well

column3: a cease-fire
column4: a release of dissidents
column5: an opening of new opportunities and nations around the world
column6: or even spends 11 hours testifying in front of a congressional committee
column7: he can talk to me about stamina
column8: ” Clinton said.

column2: he tried to switch from looks to stamina
